content:
r 7, 2014
												Wasteland 2 is perfect definition for term "mixed feelings". At best, it's just mediocre post-apocalyptic cRPG. At worst - it's game full of bugs, inconsistencies and bad design decisions. But for some strange reason, I couldn't stop playing it. So pick it on sale with 75% discount.Pros:- Story you may like, especially if you're a fan of Terminator/Mad Max movies. There's enough bandits and robots to kill.- Most quests can be solve in more than one way. Or you can just shoot everyone.- Music.- Radio broadcasts are fun- Some strange magic - I couldn't stop playing, despite all flaws (and there are many flaws)- California - whole second part of the game is cool. Great factions, more interesting quests, etc. Unfortunately, more bugs too, and you first need to play 40h of boring Arizona. There's big chance you will never see Holywood.Cons (long list):- Bugs, bugs, bugs - broken quests, cutscenes not diplaying correctly, messed-up scripts (leading to broken quests) and more- Game looks bad. Really, really bad. Fallout 2 looks better. Probably any game released last 10 years looks better. It's first game I wanted to quit while making character. And yes, I completely understand that graphic is not important.- Massive FPS drops.- Unresponsive UI - sometimes you need to click several times on button or on the ground to execute action (go somewhere, change or reload weapon etc.)- Tactical, turn-based battles? Forget it. In most fights (many, many fights) you just need to shoot enemies while they come to you. You can't cover (because there are no covers), head shot is not valid option (because of massive penalties) and most enemies are just chargin on you. Shadowrun offers more tactical battles that Wasteland 2. So, Wasteland 2 is not Divinity: Original Sin, XCOM, Jagged Alliance 2. It's not even close.- Pathfinding - if you want to move from one end of map to another, your team most probably will not be able to.- Character development - there's nothing interesting in it. With each level you get some skill points, sometimes 1 attribue points. As you need all skills (or almost all), trying to create some unique builds is not an option. And there are no perks or anything that would allow you to create really unique ranger.

number of helpful: 55 of 78 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 23, 2014
												Tactical turn based combat, a cover system, optimal fire range's on all the weapons that you will have to consider, crouch and head shot options, overwatch mode, weapons that can jam and need to be reloaded mid battle, all of which will cost you action points to utilize in combat. You also have a skill system for outside of combat that include things such as toaster repair (think the wasteland version of treasure chests), perception (land mines, trap/alarms on objects), lock pick and safe crack, computer repair, mechanical engineering and much more. All of your skills you will be finding yourself using quite often in your travels to do many things such as get the core out of a plastic man to performing surgery (a skill) on a kid who had his leg blown off from a land mine or fixing various broke down machines you come across for the people of the wastes to make their lives easier. There are so many places for you to use your skills that they never feel like a useless point dump when your weapon skills are high enough. With a story set in a post apocalyptic wasteland where life is cruel and unfair and just a bit radioactive (maybe more if you're not careful) that's what kind of game this is. The variety of people you meet along the way and places you will journey is just amazing, there were a few times where I found myself laughing out loud at something stupid I came across from some junkie's camp or in wonder at the place I had just discovered filled with robotic junk and run down machinery. It really was a joy to explore in this game I have to say. Many of the characters have some real personality to them that you will remember long after you move on which really makes it feel more personal when the NPC's you meet aren't soulless bunches of code and pixels you know? Often there were times where I found it had a very elder scrolls quality to it where you just look around you and go wow I can explore ALL OF THIS which, if you ask me, is just a fantastic thing to feel in a game.

content:
7, 2015
												I backed it on Kickstarter, I'm a huge fan of the Baldur's gate series, Fallout 2 to New Vegas, Diablo, and many other RPGs, and think Wasteland 2 was absolutely terrible.With 40+ hours of game-time I feel like I have a pretty substantial view on Wasteland 2, and in the end, I  think the devs just don't understand what actually makes a game ***fun***:* Walking across an entire area cleared of all enemies to get back to the world map is not fun.* Holding back on my attributes because I might run into some challenge requiring more lockpicking is not fun.* Being interrupted on the world map for nearly always boring-as-♥♥♥♥ random encounters is not fun. (Seriously though, couldn't you make some unique random encounters that are more than nameless badies, or stop spamming me with encounters when I have a 100% chance of running?)* Save scumming is not fun. Holy ♥♥♥♥, 50% of my time is spent save scumming. Want to open a safe? Save scum. Want to take apart a weapon and need a certain piece? Save scum. Starting a hard battle and need to hit an enemy with a hard-to-hit headshot? Save scum."Oh but just don't save scum and accept the consequences" is the worst excuse I can think of. It is simply human nature to shoot for the best outcome; failing at a percentage based challenge we know we can avoid by save scumming just feels bad. It feels almost equally as ♥♥♥♥♥♥ to waste time trying to get the desired outcome, but still feels better than getting ♥♥♥♥-all for your effort by accepting your ♥♥♥♥ luck.New Vegas did this right: If you had the attributes to attempt a challenge it was pass fail. There was no reason to save scum,; save scumming wasn't even an option! Diablo did this right: If you exit the game, you save the game; you aren't even able to save scum! How did the devs mess up this crucial component in 2014?**Graphics and Camera**The graphics themselves are only OK. I don't expect them to be ground-breaking on an indie game. With that said, Fallout 1/2 and Baldur's gate still stand the test of time because every background is a literal work of art. Wasteland 2 simply looks, well, OK.The real issue is that the 3D camera mechanism SUCKS. The compass is constantly off in some unexpected orientation, things are often hidden from view, and the map system is painful at best. The landscape is so bland and monotonous that you can't tell where you are from simply looking around. Even after 40+ hours of game time I still get lost unless constantly looking at the map and re-orienting the compass. Even Baldur's gate, a game made in the late 90's, had user-placable map-markers, and BG 2 had pre-placed markers on top of that so you could tell where the ♥♥♥♥ you were.On top of the confusing camera and map, there is almost NO quick travel. Why do I have to walk across the entire prison map or Ranger Citadel to get in and out!? How does that enhance my experience? How is that enjoyable? It certainly doesn't make the game any harder, it just wastes more of our time.**Combat**Combat is OK; there is some element of strategy, and action point management is mildly interesting. That said . . it could really use more variety. Games like Diablo and the BG series had so much variety with spells and skills. Fallout 3 and New Vegas had the VATS system, stealth, and live combat. Wasteland 2 is just a throwback to Fallout 1/2, which is fine on it's own, but 15+ years later they couldn't think of anything new?On top of this, the lack of pause and coordination before a fight is maddening. In baldur's gate you could issue tasks to each member of your party to do unique and interesting actions . . you know . . LIKE A REAL AMBUSH!? In wasteland 2, all you can do is shoot the ♥♥♥♥ out of one person. Hell, even fallout 1 and 2 let you go into VATS mode!When I win a fight in Wasteland 2, I don't feel very GOOD about it. There simply isn't enough strategy to actually make much of a difference in a fight. The real decider of outcome seems to rely on your weapons, and the enemies decisions. If anything, I feel like I should go grind for experience to have a better chance, and that just makes me sad about wasting more time to progress in the game.**The Attribute System**Fargo talked all about making characters with specialties but absolutely failed. Getting by with a character who has under 8 intelligence is a pain in the ♥♥♥ because you miss so many skill-based opportunities. None of the other attributes influence your skills, so they are all a depressing mix of combat-stats. Charisma only needs to be high enough to pick up companions, and you're left ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off if you put it too low to include one. It all just feels like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ min-maxing formula: "At least 8 int, at least X charisma for these party members, and whatever mix gets the best AP for the rest of the stats while retaining a reasonable combat initiative. All this tailored to the weapon (higher CI for close-range weapons)".Because the stats do not influence skills, they all do practically the same thing. Nobody is actually specialized because making a character with too low of AP or combat initiative makes them near useless. Anyone used to a little bit of customization in RPGs will just make everyone a bland average that optimizes as much AP as possible.**The writing/acting**Good god, I don't know if it is the writing or the actors, but this ♥♥♥♥ is cringe-worthy the whole way through. From the insanely clean live-actors (really? No dirt on a DESERT ranger?) to the how-in-the-♥♥♥♥-am-I-supposed-to-suspend-my-disbelief voice acting, it is just painful. Did anyone actually enjoy the live-action video? Couldn't that money have been spent better elsewhere? Does Vargas talk like any real person you've ever heard?And finally . .**Side Quests**Rails nomad is the only place in all of Arizona that is full of quests you don't need to do to finish the game. All other standalone areas either have only a handful of trivial sidequests. The main areas themselves have many trivial side quests . . but none have any *substance*. The nuke silo is about the only substantial sidequest I can think of, and even that is pretty damn trivial in length. Compare to things like Fallouts 1 - New Vegas or BG, where there are side-quests spanning multiple areas, and MANY areas at least as intricate as Rails Nomad. All the side quests in Wasteland 2 just feel like shallow time-sinks.

												Kind of amazing that such games like Wasteland 2 still gets developed. It plays and looks like a CRPG from 15 years ago and it's just great. However the inspiration for the creation of Fallout was Wasteland. Now we have Wasteland 2, which greatly honors the CRGP genre unlike the modern iterations of Fallout. content:
ber 21, 2014
												This game is not Fallout or even Fallout tactics. It is horrible game that might be okay for 1980, but not for 2014.-Horrible skill systemYeah, it is. Artifically bloated skill list in order to put some artifical replayablility in the game. If character with sniper rifle skill 10 will take assault rifle (it's like sniper rifle, but without a scope) - he won't hit anything and vice versa. Stupid? Indeed. Social skills - pretty much the same. Instead of one skill responsible for speech, we have 3. And those skills aren't alternatives to each other in order to bring diversity in gameplay - different situations will require different skills. Why? Of course to enforce you to replay the game again and again. Let me remind you how it was in Fallouts: one skill that gave you different choices and those choices affected the result. When they wanted diversity - they were adding other skill/perk check in play. And don't even get me started on trade skills - it is all the same. We've got separate skill for cracking safes and we've got separate skill for picking locks. Why? Oh, see above. We also got WTF skills like 'brute force'. While it will be used once or twice in game - it is still separate skill. Why devs couldn't make strength check instead of it? Well, cause we need 'diversity'. Oh, and you can't recover mines you disarm and use them later. Cause, well, this isn't Fallout, it's much much worse game. And stealth skills in game about SpecOPs unit? Never heard of them. And this isn't even deep analysis of how horrible skill system is - I can go on and on about every skill. And perks/traits like in any proper RPG these days? Nope, they don't exist-Horrible level designYup. Your ranger team can't climb on the roofs or hide in the trenches, unless designers intended you to do so. They convinently put the boxes in the battleield so you could use them as intended. Awesome. Levels feel like they are copypasted. Night/Day cycle? Nay.-Horrible (N)PCsIn Fallout 2 a lot of named NPCs followed schedule. Shops opening and clothing, NPCs eating and drinking and so on. That was 1998. In 2014 Wasteland 2 we have static NPCs that stand or patrol all day and do nothing. Not acceptable for the game that position itself as RPG. Even more - your rangers in unit never talk to each other or in any other way express their personality. Even followers don't express themselves as personalities. You can't talk to them at all.-Horrible gameplayBut maybe all other problems is redeemed by awesome gameplay and plot? Nope. Plot is all the same - save the world, blah, blah, blah. But it gets worse. We've got long checklists instead of proper reputation system. For example. We got 2 tribes that are going to war. In normal RPG we help each of the tribes, build the reputation and then convince them to stop fighting and bring the peace.What we have in WL2? We have chief of the tribe with checklist: "You disarmed bomb - check, saved us from raiders - check, saved child from the lake - check, found drug dealer - check, but you gave my dog beef instead of chicken and therefore the war won't end". This gameplay design is crap. Oh, and don't forget the forced choice between settlements to save. You can't call reinforcements, you can't split your group, you have to make choice and then the game will make sure that you feel guilty about the choice you made, even if it was forced.Conclusion: don't buy it and don't believe those who compares it to Fallout 2. It's much much worse. If you don't believe me - watch letslpays on youtube - they will confirm everything I said. P.S. I didn't mention outdated game graphics, because I don't think that graphics is what determines how good or bad game is.

content:
3, 2016
Before you pass this review by the number of hours, please note that I have put 50+ hours from GOG. I simply couldn't pass reviewing one of the best role-playing experiences I've had, period. I jumped on board with the free-weekend experience to review Wasteland 2.Imagining a Rocket-Ship from a Cardboard BoxWhen I say that the role-playing is W2's greatest feature, some might translate it as the story or mechanics are very shallow. That is a gross misunderstanding, so I feel the need to explain this praise in-depth.The most remarkable aspect is not that there are so many options; it's that the developers trust you with all of them. The level of care put here can be seen when the game accounts for almost every action/consequence, and the team's flavor-text of cheeky, sardonic humor simply adds to the experience.If that's too confusing, then know only this: The developers role with your actions. What may seem like the game leaving too much to the player it feels more like a father adding the rocket sound-effects and shaking of the cardboard box for his child. (Or in a less emotional context, the Dungeon Master who believes in the "Never say no" rule.)The game provides as many solutions as possible. Whether it is handling factions with negotiations, violence or some other means. To making the best out of your team with their strengths and weaknesses. To wandering off from the main-quest at any point. (You can even end the game early.) To even how to bypass obstacles like doors, safes, or terminals. The result is that the game respects that you can handle it. And with the Director's Cut, this experience only has gotten better. Quirks, a deceptively simple feature, does so much to characterize your cast by making in-game benefits and downsides. (And unlike in Fallout 1/2, you have four main-characters, so you can roll with the negative effects.) The UI for using skills is now simplified to a right-mouse click if you have your whole team selected. Precision strikes offer more tactical options in battle, and make your character's growth feel better when you can utilize them in the end-game with better odds.All of these extra details will make creating squads just as much fun as playing the game itself. If you care only for min-maxing characters, however, then I think you're missing the point of the system.A C.L.A.S.S.I.C. ExperienceAlthough there is no wrong way to build a character, there are several missteps you can make to make a bad team if you don't read your character sheets for the details. So a few pointers might be helpful.If you have never played a CRPG, start on Rookie. You won't have to worry about the difficulty at the start.Never specialize in multiple weapons at the same distance; have a short-range and a long-range option. (Also, be wary of shared ammo pools at the beginning.) Stats for guns are realistic for once; you increase your handling, not the damage (outside of luck). Charisma for recruitment is cumulative (somewhere between 18 - 24 is good, which you don't need from the start). For leadership, which is one of the few essential skills, Charisma is a must.The way leveling up works is like this: You get a number of skill-points per level based on your intelligence—so long as you get two you should be fine—you get a perk which is based on meeting some skill-requirement every four levels, and for every tenth level you earn an attribute point. The max level is 50, so your attributes won't change much but it might fix some deficiencies. Combat Initiative helps you get to attack first, and before you get to L.A. you will want a minimum of 12 so you don't take too many first-hits.Skills' effects do not stack with multiple characters (but perks do like Radiant Personality which gives you 2x charisma for that character), so specialize characters' skill set. (Never have two leaders.)The only essential skills you will want someone to have are the following: Outdoorsman (higher rank, lower random encounters which is not required), Perception, Explosives (to disarm traps), and Leadership.If you cannot get every essential skill, don't worry as the NPC Angela Deth is a beginner's tool. (She leaves at Titan's pass, so don't rely on her—the only one who will leave by the plot.)Although almost every skill is viable Animal Whisper and Toaster Repair are more fluff than real skills. They do yield unique stuff.If you know this info before going in, then I think the stats' screen will be less intimidating for newcomers and a friendly welcome mat in time.  While the story may not warrant replay value for more context, the content itself is worth replaying, even if you've seen the Wasteland once before--but in another time and space. You're Entering A World of Similar Sounds, Sights & Time...While many people too often criticize W2 for not being more like Fallout, there is a unique problem with the similarities between the Fallout universe and Wasteland timeline. Addressing the problem of "Who's on first" doesn't matter but what W2 doesn't take it into consideration is its identity problem.W2 acts like the original in the 1990s wasn't scrapped and that Fallout never happened. Except it did, and it results in a feeling that you've seen everything already if you have played Fallout 1/2 (or New Vegas).For example, many names come off as the Mad-Libs for Fallout staples:-The DESERT RANGERS are a militaristic, militia-based army in Arizona that has territorial expansion in mind as they claim the Wastelands as a unified force. -The Rangers took over the Citadel base of the GUARDIANS OF THE OLD WORLD, a xenophobic group that claims ownership over pre-war tech like power-armor.-The MAD MONKS revere Titans (nuclear warheads) as religious beings/forces of power.-Synths, Roboscorpions, Super Mutants, Mutant animals, a "not-New-Vegas" L.A and other not-Fallout staples appear in this game.It's weird to call this issue out, but the first half of the game relies on these similar faces that I think many people might not stick around for L.A. where groups like the God's Militia, the Mannerites, Hollywood, and the Children's Citadel come in. This is one of the only few writing problems I have with W2.As for the main-questline, it suffers from reusing the same objectives (attach repeater units, get kitty litter, get super kitty litter and two more repeaters). The means to fulfill these objectives, however, are different.Lastly, when it comes to the writing the only bad aspect is its sexual content. Sometimes it is really, really cringe worthy (more so than Borderlands and New Vegas), and sometimes it can be really ill-timed. (Ex. Sleeping with show-girls in a brothel with murdered women in the other room.) I don't have a problem with the content as it's optional--I simply wished they hired a show-girl or porn-star to better handle it. Sex should be sexy. All of these complaints, however, pale in comparison to the worst offender some might find: The combat.Don't Die On Me Just YetFor all its complexities, I rather enjoy the system for what it offers, and it kept me engaged for the first 35 hours (before Hollywood). However, by that time I was either expecting the game to end and/or add more. Unfortunately, it doesn't and I had to lull in the final ten hours to my ending.To offset its tediousness, enemy variety keeps it fresh just to the end without RNG encounters. What I think needed more effort are the weapon mods, an ability to distracts enemies' attacks to one player,  and control over NPCs in battle. These aspects feel very unrefined to the rest of the game, and they are the only other faults to be found. If you can accept a little bloated content and dull edges, then you can enjoy an IBM computer classic made in modern times.

content:
ber 22, 2014
												Sigh, what a complete letdown, they completely half-arsed the game.  I was a $100 backer on kickerstarter and the short of it, this game sucks.  Bugs are one thing, and there are plenty of those here which is quite disappointing.  But the real problem is that the game itself does not even look remotely close to a $3,000,000+ game.  What the did they spend that on, because it sure was not the cheapo Unity3d engine (looks just as bad as Shadowrun did with Unity3d, which just makes me mad).  The miserably bad live action intro (really?  I mean really???) maybe?  I'm guessing they pocketed it.I am looking at this game from the perspective of having played every single major isometric in the history of gaming, period.If you were letdown by Shadowrun (which I was in a BIG way), be prepared to be let down again, just as hard.The Bad:- Really bad, very primitive interface, does not seem to avail itself of any modern interface concepts.  Want a chat log?  forget about it, best write stuff down *manually* or just have photographic memory.  Quest tracker?  Forget about it, it is kind of there but is missing critical quest details, especially if you save and come back the next day you are left wondering what the heck is going on.  Moving items between people is painful.  In game help system is terrible, it is arbritrary not reviewable, fire once and then disappear forever which seems to be the basis for the entire game design.  Want to rotate your camera?  Be prepared to be fustrated by the terrible pausing mechanism (camera "hitches" on the cardinal directions) which prevents smooth rotation.  Limited options all around, the interface options you want are probably not going to be there.  Awkward, clunky, primitive, not a $3,000,000 interface!- 3d characters looks cartoony, again the same problem with Shadowrun and I will just straight up blame Unity3d and the laziness of not just doing it yourself.  In a game like this, a "serious" game, a $3,000,000 game, the last thing I think you would want is any kind of cartoon look and they blew that.- Very limited skill selection and character customization.  You load it up and you are like, huh, looks like quite a few skills there, especially in character creation (if the rest of the game had that level of customization, the game may have been worth a damn).  Then you realize it's mostly gun skills with a few tacked on skills like lockpicking and then the lol "hacking" skill that all work EXACTLY THE SAME WAY.  Click, watch an icon change color a few seconds, soon you will be bored.  And then a few hours later in the game you will be depressed by the limited amount of customization available once you start the game and next thing you know you are leveling up "submachine guns" to get 5% better chance to hit.  Joy, so fun.- Inventory / loot - terrible.  Just terrible.  You walk around mostly picking up Junk, literally called Junk.  Oh sure they spent some time putting description on the Junk, which you can one-click sell to vendors.  Whoop De Frickin Do.- The world map.  SIgh.  Why, why not just take some time to make it *cool*.  But no, it is half arsed like the rest of this game, you get to watch a spinning sheriffs star icon move across a static map.  Sometimes you find an "oasis" where absolutely nothing happens except to fill your water bottle, fabulous.  Some random encounters, with no plot attachment, no story, just random meaningless garbage.- The bugs.  I love watching NPC's run around with empty text bubbles over their head.  Right in the beginning of the game.  Right where even the most primitive QA process would have caught it.  QA.  That's an interesting word, one they obviously did not bother googling even, certainly did not spend any money on it.- I'm depressed, not because the game was super awesome, dark, apocalyptic and really drew you into the setting of the game and left you with the post apocaplytic feeling you have been craving for years after dumping money into this kickstarter project.  No just the opposite, it was so bad it draws you *out* of the game as you are appalled by the low quality that $3,000,000 can produce.  Well done there Inxile, a good notch on your belt.  Which is probably a Gucci belt that holds up your Versace pants as you get into your Mercedes AMG and laugh at the kickstarter chumps all the way to your McMasion.The Good:- Excellent job with the ambient music.  I would like to say that this extends to all the in game sounds, but not so much.  The bugs appear to make some of the sound not work to begin with, for example missing voiceovers, you will have one character with a voice over and the other character just has text and no voice, really poor form (I can't even write anything good without hitting the bad - BAD SIGN)- Good story.  Which would have been great, like really great, if it was paired with a game that was worth anything.- It is a post apocalyptic setting and you are fanboi and don't care about any of this...go for it.---Finally a special thanks to Kickstarter for making this steaming pile of garbage possible and stealing all of our money.  Thank you, really, no, thank you.

content:
ber 22, 2014
												War. War never changes. Wasteland 2 is such a spiritual successor to old Fallout games that I almost expected Ron Perlman to deliver those iconic lines during the opening video. Now, let’s not forget that the original Fallout was inspired by the first Wasteland game. And now, in turn, a Wasteland game is inspired by the first 2 Fallout games – and as such, should be a treat for all those Nuke Cola loving, bottlecap collecting vault-dwellers out there.It’s been more than 2 years since Wasteland 2 campaign on Kickstarter was successfully funded – and after more than a few delays, a full version is finally available – but is it polished? Well, yes and no. While the reports of bugs are everywhere on the interwebs, in my 10+ hours of playing I encountered only one game-restarting bug when my party just refused to move from the spot. A quick restart solved the problem, but such bugs should not happen in a game that was delayed for so long and live tested with the huge community of early access players.I won’t spoil the story so far, but the main premise is this – after the politicians “pushed the button”, the survivors of the nuclear wasteland are living in small interconnected communities, looked after by “Desert Rangers”, a self-made police of the apocalypse. You are one of them.The choices you make in the game will affect the story, just like in any good RPG. For instance, near the beginning of the game, while you are patrolling the desert you get 2 distress calls at the same time – one from a farm where mutated plants and animals started wreaking havok, and one from a town being attacked by raiders. You can’t save both – I helped the town attacked by raiders, and when I managed to got to the other town, it was completely destroyed and overrun with mutant zombie plant people. Yup, enemies in Wasteland 2 are awesome.Anyway, my choosing to ignore the first one while helping the other had a consequence – mutated plants were now spreading across the wasteland, so now you encountered zombie plant hordes on the map, solving additional quests that included ridding the affected villages of them and treating the water supply with the serum to stop them from spreading further.This is definitely a game that just has to be played more than once – and I love that.One more thing I loved about Wasteland 2 is the sense of “yikes, I’m getting the hell out of here and coming back later with better weapons” feeling – the dangers in Wasteland are real – and some of them will require you to run with your tail between your legs.That’s all I’m willing to write without spoiling details of the game further. Except for this one little spoiler: there’s a skill in the skill tree called “Toaster Repair”. Yes, there’s an entire skill dedicated to repairing toasters. Of course I invested points in it! :) In short, if you loved Fallout 1 and 2, you will LOVE Wasteland 2. If that was not your cup of radioactive tea, look elsewhere, because turn-based combat and slow but steady exploring is not for everyone.More game reviews at www.bundlehq.com

content:
20, 2016
												There have been a lot of high profile Kickstarter projects as of late, and few have been larger than Wasteland 2, the project that first showed up on the crowd funding platform back in 2012. RPG fans have been keeping an eye on the title for a long time and, after a lengthy period in early access and a few delays, it finally arrived in September 2014. It’s very faithful to its roots and it provides a lot of the complexity that fans of this genre have been hungering for. This challenging and addictive epic should hit the spot for old-school gamers looking for a party-based RPG fix.The game is a slow starter and it takes at least several hours to sink its addictive hooks into you, but it is an overall success, despite its ugliness and some blunders with the interface.As a sequel to the 1988 classic Wasteland, Wasteland 2 stays very faithful to its roots and picks up about a generation after the events of the first game. It takes place in what used to be Arizona, which has been cut off from the rest of the world by deadly radiation. Your party of four is part of the Desert Rangers, a group of enforcers sworn to protect the innocent in this futuristic wild west.As a post-apocalyptic game, Wasteland 2 contains just about all of the staples of the genre. It has mutant plants, mutant beasts, an assortment of guns, lawlessness, raiders, small settlements separated by vast empty space, survivalism, and radiation. It even has a de facto currency (“scrap” in this case), and just about every other feature that you may have already experienced if you have consumed the glut of post-apocalyptic fiction that is available today in games, TV, and movies. And, herein lies arguably the biggest problem with the game – its setting is stale and it does nothing to provide it with a breath of fresh air.The somewhat overused setting shouldn’t be taken as an indictment of the game’s writing, though, which is very good.  The game has a ton of dialog, lengthy dialog trees, many memorable characters, and a lot of well written lines. You can skip through them if you want, but if you do you would be missing a critical part of the Wasteland 2 experience. The game sprinkles in a healthy dose of dark humor, and there are multiple laugh-out-loud moments. Much of this humor stems from the game’s basis as “1980s retro-future”. Wasteland 2 immediately drops you into the thick of a mystery and asks your green recruits to head out and solve the murder of a fellow Ranger who was trying to set up radio transceivers in the area. Controlling them will be immediately familiar to anyone who has played any nineties CRPG, and helpful tips will guide you through the initial orientation. Moving your party around an area is as simple as selecting them and clicking the desired destination, but zipping around towns is not recommended as you will miss out on a huge amount of information. Pop culture references are littered throughout the game, both relevant and obscure, and range from smirkworthy to hilarious. The breadth of coverage is extraordinary, running the gamut from Blade Runner to Mrs. Frisby and the Rats of NIMH, via The A-Team. Ever want to see junkie barflies sing the theme tune to Cheers? You've come to the right place. The writers have obviously had fun building Wasteland's world and exploration is thoroughly rewarded, not just with enjoyable throwaway lines but often with useful items for the inquisitive.The story is broken up by the excellent turn-based combat system which will be familiar to Fallout fans. Combatants are queued up and assigned a number of Action Points (AP) to utilise. These are consumed by movement, attacking, reloading, and other actions such as crouching or preparing to ambush assailants which stray into range. When your AP are used up, the turn moves to the next attacker in the queue. You can store a small number of AP to use on your next turn and may benefit from Luck which can grant you extra AP or critical hits. Battles usually take place in areas which are strewn with objects to take cover behind or destructible items such as fuel cans to aim at, which adds more strategy to proceedings. Similarly, planning for encounters is essential to success - charging in gung-ho will get you mown down, especially if your gun jams. Instead, remembering to reload after battles, taking higher ground where possible and utilising the best weapons for the job are key. Sniper rifles are as useless up close as handguns are from a distance, so giving your team a combination of arms alongside hand-thrown munitions will generally give you the best chance of survival.Combat is genuinely fraught, and your team can become afflicted with unconsciousness, bleeding or more serious negative status modifiers which tick down to imminent death. You’re able to inflict these on the enemy of course, but if your medic is out of reach of the party, or worse, momentarily taken out, the tension can be unbearable. Even the new recruits to your team - amongst them a washed-up hobo and a diehard mercenary - have their own ideas during battle, and can often take fights into their own hands and throw your carefully managed plans into disarray.The inventory system is laid out well, although the distinction between useful goods and junk which can be immediately sold is not as clear as it could be. The balance between available goods and the amount of scrap you have for sale is reflective of the overall setting; ammunition is scarce and you’ll need to make each bullet count. Caches of goods can be found in safes, crates and on the bodies of your assailants, but you’ll want to ensure that any traps are dealt with beforehand.If the game falls down somewhat, it’s in its aesthetic. It’s far from the prettiest adventure you’ll play through and the browns, yellows and greys of the post-nuclear landscape are not particularly easy on the eye. That said, the areas you’ll visit are clearly distinguishable. Whether a lush, overgrown agricultural centre or the dingy tunnels of a water treatment plant, the variety of locations is impressive and the game gets by more on the personality of the characters within the world than the actual dwellings they inhabit.The situations you’re thrown into and the decisions which Wasteland 2 forces you to make are what elevates the game beyond standard CRPG fare. The humour is as black as it comes and the gory dismemberment of your foes by shotgun and plasma rifle is easily matched by the disturbing encounters you’ll have with some of the world’s inhabitants. Early on, you’re given the choice of saving one of two key facilities. Choosing isn’t easy and the game will make it abundantly clear to you that your actions have damned the population of the location you neglected, in quite disturbing tones. Similarly, for many of the quests you’ll be handed, the “right” decision isn’t always the correct one and the repercussions of your actions will be felt further on in the game when you least expect it. The most enjoyable aspect of it all is that there is no set path.Wasteland 2, for the most part, provides everything that its Kickstarter backers and fans of the genre were looking for. It has genuine role-playing, a lot of exploration, solid tactical combat, and a long and satisfying campaign. The game’s ugly graphics are the result of budget-related tradeoffs that RPG fans will probably find perfectly acceptable. Its unimaginative fiction and interface issues may be harder to swallow. These issues do keep the game from achieving true greatness as an RPG, but Wasteland 2 is still a very strong entry into the genre.

content:
, 2016
												Wasteland 2: Director's Cut is a diamond with rough shapes, imperfect, not the most attractive, unpolished...but still a diamond!A very fun and enjoyable experience, especially for older RPG fans (Fallout 2 and earlier era), with decent story, interesting choices, freedom in creating your team with lots of skills and perks.You can solve many missions in different manner, lot of homage and easter eggs can be found(or digged) in this game, funny characters and followers and good ol' turn-based fighting system.Overall, it's been a while since I've enjoyed in a new game that wanted to pay respect to older classics.Two thumbs up!p.s - time spent in game was almost 80 hours....

content:
er 27, 2016
												For the first half of the game, it feels great, the world design is on point, the world feels alive, and the characters are vibrant and insteresting. HOWEVER, for the second half of the game the world space becomes becomes one flat piece of land, and the intricate quests are boiled down into one tedious and annoying fetch quest. Also it is worth mentioning that the combat falls short, enemies move way to far on their (and so do you) some weapons are downright useless, some are overpowered, and the AI is horrible.The party system starts out great, like a lot of things in this game, you create 4 rangers specify their skills and backstories to make each character unique. After creating these characters they become mere interchangable cardboard cutouts, they atribute nothing to the story. The companions you can find throughout the wasteland help combat this, most of these NPC companions are useless though, most become useless halfway through the game.The attribute system is a joke, if you try to create 4 diversed characters with each a unique set of skills, you will have a bad time. The only useful attribute is Intelligence, as it determines the amount of skill points you get with each level. All of the others are effectively useless and only determine if you can see something, swing something a bit heavy, get your turn first (sometimes), or shoot your gun twice instead of once.Wasteland 2: Directors Cut added a system in which you target a specific part of an opponets body, each part would have different effects on the enemy if you hit them in that spot, however each part makes your chance to hit significantly lower, to the point where it is useless, it becomes either, you MIGHT be able to shoot this guy's gun out of his hand, or you can just straight up kill him. The sysytem is interesting on paper but is just garbage in practice.Here's hoping Wasteland 3 doesn't fail in the same way.

content:
r 26, 2015
												I have played both Wasteland 2 and Wasteland 2: Director's Cut. I *really* wanted to like this game, and there are things I do like about this game, but unfortunately they are overshadowed by several design decisiosn that I feel are completely game breaking, decisions that ultimately left me feeling nothing but disappointment.To get this out of the way first, yes, there were a *lot* of bugs, from graphics not lining up properly, to strange problems with the names of clothing, to crashes to desktop on load, to a horrific problem in Ranger Citadel where attempts to load the game in Ranger Citadel would leave me with a completely crippled interface and the feeling that I had somehow broken the game so much that it would never recover. To be clear, while these were annoyances (yes, even the Ranger Citadel bug for which I eventually found a work-around), none of them were bad enough to actually make me dislike the game.Also, to get THIS out of the way, I agree that the visual style could have used some work, and the audio definitely left something to be desired, especially the background noises which, in the Ag Center, nearly had me tearing my hair out at one point. But, again, none of this actually made me dislike the game.Instead, up to a point I liked the game *in spite* of these problems. I liked the combat system. Sure it was relatively light on tactics if I wanted to just plough through encounters, but if I was smart, I could end encounters in one or two rounds. I liked the weapon and armor system well enough. They were definitely servicable, and modding weapons was kind of fun. I liked character customization well enough. The perks and quirks were a nice addition. I also liked some of the rebalancing, and felt like my characters in the DC were better able to handle themselves in a variety of situations than my original Wasteland 2 characters. I liked the plot for a while. I saved Highpool on my original Wasteland 2 playthrough, I saved Ag Center on my DC playthrough, and I liked them both. I liked the Rail Nomads, and the little hidden surprises scattered around the wasteland, including the random encounters. I especially felt good about the number of options I seemed to have for resolving a number of the situations I ran across. It felt good. It felt right. I was pretty happy.Then I went to prison, and everything went to hell. Suddenly all my options went away. Without spoiling anything, the prison area presents you with little in terms of choices, and it is frustrating. Especially in the DC, I got to the prison with characters that had a lot of options available to them, and yet at the prison they were largely unusable. Further, the logic that the game presented behind *why* I had no options just did not follow. What's worse, the outcome at the prison seems to be the same no matter what you do there. I've searched for an explanation online, only to discover various apologists saying that the development team was trying to hammer home the idea that the wasteland is really terrible. The problem with this argument, of course, is that you do not have to take away player agency to get this point across, and yet this is what we are left with. Confusingly, in earlier versions of this game those choices did exist at the prison, and there seems to be no good explanation as to why they were taken out.And, unfortunately this is where I had to stop playing both versions of this game. This is when it stopped feeling like a role playing game, and started feeling like a visual novel with some cosmetic combat, and not a particularly interesting or engagine one at that. Is it unfair to judge the entire game based on my experience? Maybe. But I have tried to get back the feeling I had of playing a role playing game, the one that the game still managed to engender early on in my playthroughs, but the immersion has apparently been broken irreparably.Maybe if I hadn't seen the setting half a dozen times in other games, or if the plot were more unique and engaging, or the gameplay more interesting, or the game less frustratingly buggy, or the graphics more beautiful or the audio less . . . horrific . . . Maybe if these things had been the case it would have carried me through this immersion-breaking area and onward towards the end of the game. And maybe I will still be inspired to play through the rest of the game, experiencing it in its entirety and I will change my tune. But every time I try to play again, I am presented with the fact that my choices in the Prison area will have no impact on the game, not even any HOPE of impact, and then despair sets in and I cannot continue. Not despair over the setting or the plot. Not despair over the fates of the individuals in the Prison area who are doomed because the wasteland is a horrible place. No, my despair is over the poor design decision. I *know* that it could have been a better game, that they could have confronted us with an unforgiving area that showed us how brutal the wasteland can be without taking away our options/choices/agency. But they did not, and so I cannot recommend this game.

0, 2016
												A better Fallout game than Fallout 4. If you want a good CRPG with: story, choices, characters, gameplay, and plenty to explore. This is the game for you. The only 'downside' to the game that I can think of is, if you haven't played other games of this type such as: Baldur's Gate or Icewind Dale you might be a bit lost to begin with. If you've only played RPGs that hold your hand and tell you what you can and can't do then this might be a shock to the system. The game is about exploring and finding your own way of doing things, even if the game doesn't state you can do, it doesn't mean you can't.

content:
14
												I was a kickstarter backer for this game and originally played it back when it launched. The game at launch was very buggy. I remember about three separate times when I had a problem with a quest but finished it anyway only to get a patch the next day that fixed the problem I had. I don't remember much of my original playthrough other than I stopped playing at the canyon of titan and decided it would be best to let the game incubate and then restart it some time later when it's been all patched up.That was almost three years ago. Since then, they've released the Director's Cut edition complete with better textures and a new perk system. They've even moved on to promoting Wasteland 3. Surely Wasteland 2 must be in its finest form by now, right? Guess not. Instead of having a bunch of minor bugs with unimportant sidequests, I have run into a game breaking one that prevents me from progressing the main story. My current campaign that I have invested 26 hours in has been a waste of time. I couldn't even get further than my original playthrough. This alone makes me unable to recommend this game to anyone for any reason. To be more specific: I was trying to get to Damonta. I talked to Red at the junkyard and asked him about the Rad suits and he told me to talk to a prisoner at the citadel. For some reason, this conversation never registered. Vargas nor the prison guard will awknowledge it. After aimlessly walking around, I went back to Red only to find that goat mountain had reset and so had all of Red's dialogue. Asking the same questions a second time still did not result in being able to speak with the prisoner in the Citadel. But what if there were no bugs? Even then, I think the game would be OK at best. You start the game by creating four rangers. Its impossible to make characters that look good unless you really like the punk-ish, mad max "junkyard tribal" look. In fact, the game in general is kind of ugly and low poly in a bad way. Even for 2014 standards. Should I have different standards for kickstarter game graphics? I'm not sure. A quick search for mods to remedy this revealed only additional character portraits. You can control seven characters total and the small bit of praise I will give this game is that the characters you can enlist along the way are all better looking and way more interesting than your four main rangers. The enlisted characters also allow unique interactions with some quests. Seeing how they fit into the world was always neat.  When characters lose all health, they go into a downed state. If they're attacked in this state, they're dead forever. Theoretically, you could kill off some of your four main rangers and have mostly enlisted characters, but the enlisted characters can leave your squad for story reasons so that's not the best idea. The core component of the game is combat. It's fine. Combat is turn-based and takes place on a grid. Each individual unit takes a turn with the order of turns determined by the unit's stats. Its very similar to the pre-bethesda fallout games. You can put your troops behind cover to get aim and evasion bonuses, but what counts as cover seem inconsistent. There were also a few times when the combat grid did not properly fit inside a room resulting in the east wall counting as cover and the west wall being half a square off grid and impossible to take cover behind.I think my biggest gripe with ideal bug-free Wasteland 2 is the skill system. Skills are things like being able to shoot shotguns well or pick locks. Each skill has 10 tiers. There are way too many skills for you to construct a team that can handle everything. That would be fine if it wasn't for the fact that some skills are way less useful than others and you won't know this until you are well into your first playthrough. I'm convinced that Wasteland 2's skills could be organized into a tier chart much like people do with characters in a fighting game. I found toaster repair and animal whispering to just not be worth it at all. I've never tried safecracking and I'm afraid safes are the same as toasters, just random high-value loot stores. It's also hard to know what spreading a character's skillset too thin looks like at first. From my limited experience, I would not recommend giving someone more than five skills but I can't be sure what that will look like by the time you reach the end of the game (*IF* you reach the end of the game). If five seems limited, it gets worse when you consider one or two of those skills should be a weapon skill. Maybe you can get away with having a pacifist utility character, I haven't tried it. I don't like the idea of missing out on the end of a side quest because I wanted to shoot a gun more accurately when I should have invested in computer science and wish they had separated the progression of combat skills and utility skills. It's important to be able to shoot the bad guys but finding alternate routes through quests using utility skills is fun! What if you could do important AND fun things?!But I guess Wasteland 2 isn't about doing fun AND important things. Its about wasting your time with bugs. Waste... 2 much time... land. Yeah.Don't buy this game. Have doubts about the upcoming sequel.A final story-related nitpick:I also remember not assuming that giving the leader of the topekens the brake shoe would result in war and instead, I would be given a chance to reason with the topekan leader. I made that assumption again in my most recent playthrough and was very disappointed to fail that quest a second time. Is that on me or is the Rail Nomad stuff poorly designed?

content:
ber 22, 2014
												I really wish instead of a yes or a no we could choose "Eeeeehhh" when it comes to whether to recommend a game, because that's basically how I feel about Wasteland 2. While the story is interesting and the character creation is deep, the combat is basically broken. Your party members will miss most of their attacks regardless of what their to-hit-chance is, and I literally just spent two and a half rounds watching every single character I had miss every single attack over and over, and each of them had a percentage chance to hit their enemy higher than seventy. This isn't unusual, and the frustrating thing is your enemies typically have no such issues, and always have greater AP than you do, so when you're frequently facing off against multiple enemies, you're basically just watching your party take piles of damage. It got so bad that at a certain quest location, I had to leave the area to purchase more supplies because my party had no way of healing itself, and the NPC who was with us called us cowards and left the group, and now I have no way to complete the current questline without going and grinding up levels so I can sink points into the required skills she had to pass obstacles. It's not about challenge, it's about a lack of balance in the to-hit numbers generator. When my characters can succeed every single time cracking a safe or defusing a bomb with less than a 30% chance to do so, but they can't hit something standing right in front of them three times in a row with a 76% chance to land a blow, there's something broken. Similarly, though this is more an issue in the player's favour, early Raider loot is sort of ridiculous. If you wander around outside the Ranger HQ and grind levels there, after one level you should have no difficulty slaughtering the raiders that pop up as random encounters with ease. Not only do they give a solid chunk of EXP each time you win, but they drop PILES of expensive healing items and ammunition, sometimes multiple stacks of them, and everything else they drop can be sold for a ton of cash. The machetes, for instance, go for $42, and while not every Raider will have one, they still drop frequently enough that you can simply farm them for cash and equipment until you have stacks and stacks of healing items and armor and ammunition.The other complaint I'd offer is that the setting and world doesn't feel very apocalypse-y. Yeah, it's all sand-blasted, but water seems to be plentiful, people are growing food, and the atmosphere fails to give a sense of tension and danger. This is largely due to the fact that travel simply happens on a map, and the random encounters take place in the exact same little mini areas each time (down to the placement of objects), so the world seems very small and empty rather than giving you an idea of scope and the consequences of the end of the world. It feels less like an RPG and more like a linear turn-based strategy game... there's no real reason to explore the world map, and there's nothing to do unless you continue the main quest, which you don't really get any input in. In all honesty, I likely would have been a lot less harsh on this game as a whole if the accuracy issue hadn't soured me towards it, and if that were patched I'd recommend it a lot more. It has the potential to be a rock-solid, challenging, deep strategy game, but as it stands, it feels like it needs more tweaking under the hood.

content:
ber 22, 2014
												They should never have summoned the name of Fallout 2. A game that can never hope to find its match.There are about 5 skills that are basically a different form of unlocking chests. And 3 skills that are persuasion. It's redunant and feels arbitrary. The choices in the game, at least at the beginning, are basically moot. IE: Choose food or water. Whatever you choose, prepare to hear what an idiot you are from everyone in the game constantly.Also, after playing the first mission twice and experiencing both sides of the quest, I found that one side is monumentally more developed than the other. With more voice acting, more characters, more missions, and a much better story. It's so incredibly weighted in one direction is its kind of gross. You end up with far more loot and levels after completing one side of the quests than the other. Very strange.What got me to write a negative review was getting to a town where a NPC is drowning and there is only one way to save him. The player must have one particular skill leveled up to save him or he will drown and you will hear from 50 different people what a screw up you are. That's not clever. That's not good game design. That's just lazy.PSDon't play this game on anything higher than the lowest difficulty. The combat is interesting at times but grows tedious. And you'll want to skip having to replay a fight just because all five of your team members had their weapons jam in one round of combat.

content:
er 21, 2013
Early Access Review
								First of all, this is my 3rd review or so?  Anyway, over the course of the development my opinion on Wasteland 2 has changed considerably.  Like a few others, initially I wasn't too happy with the progress and the money, but over time and updates ive grown to accept it.  It is a promising game, that I hope will resurface the Brian Fargo legacy, as it is an interesting setting for a video game.  Being a fan of fallout, I jumped to this game shortly after the early access was announced.  However recently there have been a number of large updates, most of which render saves useless, which is understandable.  I won't be playing it though until the stream of updates and patches come to a halt, as I am eager to see the finished product.  If you are considering this game, I'd say go for it.  You will have to be patient, as Rome wasn't built in a day, and post-apocalyptic Arizona wasn't nuked in a....well you get the idea.  It will take time, but i'm sure the hardworking developers are putting a great deal of effort into it.  Combining the X-Com and Fallout genres, this might be the game for your summer.  As far as recommendations on what to do with it, i'd like to see an improvement on all aspects of combat, like guns jamming, limbs being torn after you do an overkill.  One thing I would love to see is a more basic version of the Sniper Elite killcam, with bullet time.  Im not sure if that would work, but definatly might be a nice reward to snipers in game. Anyway, rant over, buy the game, enjoy the summer, aaaaaaannnnddd im done :D.

content:
ber 23, 2014
												Tough, painful, and worthy of ragequitting. And no, I'm not talking about the game being difficult.I'm talking about:A skill system which is brokenAttributes which mean nothingclunky game mechanicsthe AI taking multiple turns in a row with unlimited SP and near 100% hit ratestatistics shattering weapon jams and missesutterly no roleplaying experiencea tactical game where you only need one tacticand the list goes on.In fact here's one example, you have an assault rifle, there's no one around you, your enemy is in the "sweet spot" as in not too close, not too far. Your gauge shows that you have a 70% chance to hit. and you miss. not just once, but 5 times in a row. or more. As I posted on another person's review in a comment: "I really think the devs need to go back to hs and take some statistics, cause the odds of missing so many shots in a row when it's 70% or more "to hit"... is beyond stupid. Think about it, a 3 in 7 chance to miss five times in a row is 3 in 16,807 (or a 0.01% chance of happening). But it happens so frequently it's more like the reverse 70% chance to miss. But then again, even the odds of missing 5 times in a row would still be 7 in 243 (or a 2.88% chance of happening).. which is still absurd. And yet the game does this for most people I've heard talking about it."This is a common experience. and it just keeps going. enemies almost always hit, have twice the range of your snipers (from even the beginning missions), your guns jam at least once a battle (when each gun's jam rate is 5% or less), and so on.I just about rage quit the other night because the immersion in the story is so awful it just breaks you out of the game by destroying the suspension of disbelief. You get "badass" rangers telling you that they are the team that goes in and kills other rangers, and get told stories of other rangers making tough choices and coming out on top. Then you try and do anything contrary to the story and you're done. You do one thing wrong and an entire town aggros against you. And no there's no charisma stat that calms people down, no speechcraft skill which says "slow down compadre," no kill the leader and stop the aggro, it's just one bugged out exchange where you might as well reboot to your last save (if you're lucky enough to not trust the game to make backup saves from time to time) or you kill the entire town/area and (as some have said) you cannot complete the game. I personally don't have any experience with that, as I'm only 20 something hours in, but come-on, this is ridiculous.It's not about a complex storyline or making a game that's tough, it's sloppy game design mixed with poor story writing. And it's bad programming, on numerous occasions I've experienced a plethora of bugs including one where the camera won't pan, but for some reason I can move the sun in the sky (yeah, no joke). And the stuff that is programmed "right" is just poor. There is no choice in the game other than linear save town A and you have problems with town B for the game, or save town B and have problems with town A down the line. Then there's the AI and battles, at first it's new and fun and interesting. Then it's just a poorly designed squad tactics game where the enemies do the same thing every time and so do you. I really only employed one strategy in 20+ hours of gameplay. set up 2 short range fighters, set up 2 assault rifle fighters and 1 sniper and the rest of the game is a cake walk. It's not fun, it's repetitive.Another problem is the "fans" who jump on any topic you make or post and immediately say it's your fault the game is bad, or that you're not reading all the text, or that you are doing combat wrong, or... blah blah blah, but the game is as I've stated above, one-dimensional, clunky, broken and worthy of ragequitting. This last bit about the fans can't be the dev's fault, but the hype about this being the game everyone wanted Fallout 3 to be, is like gasoline on a fire, it just burns hotter and less controlled. If you take an objective look at the game, you'll see the same stuff that I and many others have pointed out. At least with the story stuff I'm willing to agree to disagree, as I can see how if you don't think about the story or complete failure on the roleplaying aspect of the game then you've got yourself a repetitive one-tactic game where you make choices like a train choosing which railroad track to take, sure you can take the long way around, but the end result is the same, you're still stuck on the tracks.I really really really wanted to like this and I just can't. Maybe I'll give it another try down the road, but I've got a sour taste in my mouth right now.

number of helpful: 65 of 102 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
y 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								I want to start this off with this comment; the game is currently in beta.  That said, I am sure you have read that multiple times now through the various posts.  So, where to start?  Straight up, this game will not be for everyone.  No, that does not mean it is a bad game.  Far from it, honestly.   I bought the deluxe edition on a whim.  Wanted to try something new.  I saw it was beta, so I started playing with that mindset.  That, so far, is the biggest thing.  It is not a complete game, so some things do not work, or work as expected.  Now, keeping that in mind, if you get this game, the end product in my opinion, will be phenomenal!  I am playing on max settings, looks and runs smooth, no issues.  I DO NOT have a top of the line machine.  Voices thus far are good, dialogue is great.  Combat mechanics are good.  Story so far seems great as well.  To make this easier, if you take the time to read this, I will break it down.  Again, keep in mind this is a BETA.  Not a beta you may be used to, more like end of the line alpha.  Point being, a WORK IN PROGRESS.  PROS:--Character customization and looks in game.  --Story is great thus far.--Combat will be great once game is complete.--Graphics / audio / and interface thus far are all great.--Gameplay is sweet.  I said it may not be for everyone because combat is tactical / turn.  So, think back old school with X-Com.  I love that part of it, personal opinion.  --Combat animations / effects are sweet.  --Choice and consequence are a part of this game.  You save someone from drowning, his parents offer him to you as an added party member if you want.  Plenty of characters to change up the party.--Different skills are used for different things.  Obviously, ha ha.  Those chances to use the skills on a frequent basis are not persistent in other games.  There are a lot of opportunity to use each skill you have in your party.  I like that.  --A TON of interactions within the world.  Be it digging stuff up, repairing gadgets, even down to repairing toasters, ha ha!  (definitely have someone in your party that can repair them, because you never know what's stored in one!)--Completed game will hands down be great.CONS:--Loading a save will often change the portrait of your character(s) if they are created from scratch.  A minor annoyance, unless you get into combat, then you have to go by name.  Or, if you made a guy and your portrait is now a gal.--Combat, sometimes, can be a bit.. Interesting.  You have a sniper, that has 0.0% chance of hitting a target.  That same target now moves behind cover, and you now have an 80.00% chance to hit.  --Combat again, some enemies have ridiculous move / attacks.  They will move across the screen, attack you twice, then move again... BETA, remember.  It will frustrate / annoy you though, ha ha.  --Make sure you get a dedicated surgeon / healer.  I roamed around for a bit trying to find someone that could heal my wounds, to no avail.  --There are times when walking around on the world map you are accosted by bandits, raiders, whatever, only to enter combat (if you choose) and find everything dead.  Good for the free loot, bad because you never know what will really happen!--The game crashes from time to time AFTER combat is completed.  --Some game choices have to be made on the spot, you do not have a lot of time to fart around and trying to figure the puzzle out.  You take your time, (drowning boy for example,) he will die.  Some people may not like that part.  --With no tutorial yet, character creation can be.. difficult.  --Finally;  some characters you may spec for conversation bonus dialogues, sale prices, et-cetera.  Once you enter dialogue, there is no way to change who is talking, so in cities, towns, you want to lead the party with the talker if that is your thing.Again, it is a beta.  So far, overall, great.  Most of the cons I have listed will be fixed (I assume / hope) with end product.  If you can look over those things for now, you will not be disappointed.  ESPECIALLY if you like RPG, tactical combat, decision making, and crafting.  I do not typically write reviews, but I wanted to get one out there since there are a lot of negative reviews.  A hidden jewel for a game, even in beta.  I give my nod of approval.

content:
r 26, 2014
												I really enjoyed this classic-style turn-based CRPG. Imagine something similar to the original Fallout games, but with an interface more akin to the new X-Com. You can rotate the camera and zoom-in and out. Plus, you create four characters rather than control a single hero. The skill system, quest structure, and NPC selection add greatly to the replay value.There's also some fun writing and scenarios you'll find yourself in. It's definitely a bit gritty, but not without some humor of the dark, grossout, and lewd varieties.It's not without faults, but in my opinion it's a great tribute to the original Wasteland and a great game on its own.

content:
er 12, 2014
												This game is not Fallout by any means, but true sequel to the original Wasteland. Familiar places and characters, tons of references to the original game and even plot continues W1 storyline almost directly. Graphics is functional and personally I like the style and design. Combat is pretty fun and satisfying, death animations are gorgeous, but most of the time it is very straightforward and tactical depth is lacking. I think it is not a huge problem because it is  not a pack of "clear the map"  missions unlike Fallout Tactics (don't get any ideas, I love it) but true big CRPG with choices and consequences and you don't need to fight anything on your way. And there is so much things to do here! So many non-obvious ways to deal with problems, that you hardly see 65% of the game content in one playthrough. Beating this game once took me about 80 hours. Pretty lengthy for the nowadays non-sandbox RPG's, I should say.Absolutely recommend this. Truly immersive, packed with amazing dark humour, tons of skills and stats and exceptional replayability potential. Post-apocalyptic RPG's fan heaven.

content:
ber 27, 2014
												This game isn't so much 'wasteland' as 'wasted opportunity'. Where Fallout/F2/FTactics were self-explanatory in regards to mechanics and tactics, this game mistakes 'complexity' for 'depth'. I play tactical turn-based (TTB) for the pleasure of planning and setting up effective ambushes and assaults and despatching enemies efficiently. It is this element that is at the heart of all turn-based tactical games, from Silent Storm and Jagged Alliance through to the original Fallouts. Wasteland 2 throws this aspect of the genre out altogether. What is not clear is whether this was intentional, or just the result of really incredibly poor game design and a lack of knowledge of what the genre is all about. Remember, Wasteland was an RPG, not a TTB, and Wasteland 2 has not made the transition well. It's not RPG enough to be an RPG and not TTB enough to satisfy the TTB grognards. The combat system is borked. There is no tactical complexity to the combat at all. In all real combat, the side with the initiative tends to win. In this game, initiative automatically goes to the enemy. No setting up mutually supporting arcs of fire then luring the baddies in. No, you set up your mutually supporting arcs of fire, fire a single shot, then the baddies swarm you.  You only get to try to gun them down when they're next to you. They are able to run across the map to get you. My 'leader' toon has an assault rifle. When he fires a single shot to initiate combat, enemies (even those outside his range of fire) have the opportunity to run fifty or sixty yards and initiate hand to hand combat before he can fire a second shot. It's ludicrous to include a semi-automatic rifle in the game that fires the equivalent of once every fifteen seconds. A hundred years ago, soldiers with bolt-action rifles were firing aimed shots every two seconds. Does InXile understand how firearms work?The probability engine is also borked. It's not uncommon to miss 5-6 60% shots in a row. This also extends to other skills such as lockpicking or safecracking. Many other people giving negative reviews have also commented on this. The presence of indestructible objects (ie, the vines in the Ag Centre) that block progress until other goals are achieved is inexcusable, especially considering the confusing and unclear mission objective system. You literally cannot approach a mission in any way other than that deemed appropriate by the developer. The character development process is bizarre. Your Strength stat has nothing to do with your strength-related skills. Your Charisma stat has nothing to do with your social interaction skills. You may as well put all your points into Intelligence to maximise stat points on level up and enough into Agility to maximise your action points in combat. To reiterate: no matter how rubbish your stats are, as long as your skills are high enough, most of the stats really don't matter.I completed Fallouts 1 and 2, and got as far as I could in Tactics until the bugs killed the game, and never felt as frustrated as I have with this game. The fact that I have 20 hours invested without even completing a single module says a lot about the game. The graphics are, to my mind, no better than we saw in Fallout nearly twenty years ago.  But I could forgive that if the core gameplay was there, but it's just not. The tactical aspects are ruined by an idiotic system that ALWAYS gives the enemy the initiative. The mission log system is unclear and confusing. There are booby traps on at least a third of the items, doors and chests EVEN IF THERE IS NO REASON FOR IT. I applaud the attempt to bring Fallout-style gameplay into the present day, but this game is just a wasted opportunity. I wanted to believe, and instead I just wasted $40.What a tragic waste of time and money.EDIT:You know what?The only thing funnier than how bad this game is, is the number of people who keep comparing it favourably to Fallout 1/2/Tac (bearing in mind those games are 10-15 yers old).The only thing more tragic than a wheelbarrow full of cute puppies on fire is the number of fanboys who cruise the negative feedback section giving 'not helpfuls' to people trying to steer unsuspecting buyers away from this piece of crap.It's just sad.
