content:
ber 29, 2014
												One of the first rpg's I ever played was Wasteland 1 as a youngster (Either first or second). I have great memories from it, at the time it was something very new and different. Years past by and when I was a bit old Fallout 1 came out, while not the same it was great to play a game with the same "heart" as my beloved Wasteland 1. Then came Fallout 2 which was even better and Fallout Tactics which was alot of fun to. Years later Bethesda does a new "next gen" fallout game with fallout 3, which while good for the mainstream and new players to the series, to vets it just wasn't the game we had hoped it would be. It didn't have that fallout (or wasteland) feel to it, the story was crap, most the characters extremely dull and overall a game that just realy felt like Oblivion with guns (as annoying as that saying was to me before fallout 3 came out, it did ring true for me after fallout 3 came out and I beat it). Thankfully Obsidian came to save the day and released the wonderful Fallout New Vegas. I was excited by this, Obsidian has alot of old Black Isle devs (guys who made fallout 2) and sure enough the showed Bethesda how to do a proper fallout game with there engine. A bunch of factions helped, Obsidians wonderful writing for the story helped, the dialogue was well done, interesting characters, great voice work (John Goodman? Hell yes), it felt ALOT more like the early fallout games (it just had that fallout feeling, something fallout 3 just couldn't nail)..After all that we have Brian Fargo bringing his talents to Kickstarter and getting Wasteland 2 kickstarted. What we have here is a wonderfully crafted game, jam packed with content, Wonderful writing (characters, story and dialogue), tough choices that matter (best since Alpha Protocol and New Vegas decisions imo), great atmosphere, fun gameplay, Controls are good and a great job of balance (especially in the skills and character builds you can do). For new comers asking "What is this game like? I never played wasteland or Fallout1/2!". Well it has a bit of Wasteland 1, a bit of fallout 1/2 and a bit of xcom all mixed together. The turn based combat is a joy to play and doesn't get boring as each battle can be different then the last.You're choices actually matter in this game, you might make a decision and not think about it, only to have it come down on you later as it shows the consequences of you're choice. The game does a wonderful job in the writing department as I said above, having Chris Avellone from Obsidian helped in this aspect and it shows. Characters you meet are interesting, the dialogue is very well done and the story keeps you very interested. The game world is harsh and unforgiving, you better make you're decisions wisely, always make sure you have ammo and medical gear and be on you're toes. You will thank me later :)This game is deep, complex and I friggin love it. The game has come a veyr long way since it was in alpha, at first the UI they had was terrible and I was worried this was really going to take away from my enjoment of the game. Thankfully though the developers tried some new versions, listened to fans and in the end made the UI a ton better. Alot of missions have multiple ways of doing them, you will find yourself either playing the game 2-3 times or saving the game and seeing how different decisions or actions effect the game and the world around you later on. Sometimes I find I have made the right decision at first and then hours later you might hear of bad things that happend because of what you picked. The game is not perfect, there is a few bugs, I wish there was more visual customization for characters and the graphics are not the best, but the good far outweighs the bad in this  new modern crpg. If you are looking for a new rpg that has hundreds of hours of gameplay, great replay value, wonderful writing, nice atmosphere and great gameplay give this game a go ASAP. You can really tell that this game was crafted with love, no publisher telling them to get it out early or telling them what to add to make it more popular. This Brian Fargo and his team at there best and this is a testament to old school rpgs and doing kickstarter/early access the right way. After spending 100+ hours on this game (and plants to play atleast another 100-200 ours), I can say it was well worth the wait, it is one of the years best games and that I am very excited to see what InXile comes with next for there new Torment game. If it is as good as Wasteland 2 we are in for another treat and another resurection of a charished old school rpg. 26 years after I first fell in love with Wastelands charm we get Wasteland 2 and Inxile sure did deliver, this game rocks boys and girls. There are a few things I wish where in the game and a few negatives but 95% of this game is a masterpeice I must say. As someone who has been playing rpgs for 25+ years, this is just what I wanted from a Wasteland sequel, good writing, fun gameplay, interesting characters, tough choices and tons of content. In a day and age where old game series get new reboots and games totally different from the original games, it is a breath of fresh air to have a sequel to an old game be JUST what the fans of the original want.

number of helpful: 64 of 102 people (63%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
ber 1, 2016
												I backed this game on Kickstarter and would do so again, if only to feed the hope that classic Western CRPG's might live again someday. After all, it inspired some other Kickstarter RPG's I've enjoyed, like Shadowrun: Dragonfall... But Wasteland 2 is not the messiah we were waiting for. It's a passable game that ticks all the right "old-school RPG" boxes, but it doesn't feel inspired. It doesn't feel like the game that a team of devs had been dying to make for years, as the story went. It feels by the numbers, cheap, and boring.Wasteland 2 simply disappoints in almost every respect. The graphics are passable, and have improved significantly since the beta, but they have no art direction or style - they're just, well, ugly. The gameplay is cool at first, because it's nice to have turn-based combat and actual RPG skills back, but as you progress through the game you start to realize how unbalanced it all is. Combat is either far too easy or impossibly hard, with enemies one-shotting your fully leveled and heavily armored Rangers. Most skills are only ever used for opening different types of boxes filled with random loot that usually sucks, and since you can easily max out all skills across your party fairly early, the "hard" skillchecks just become annoying random dice-rolls with a high chance of failure, even with full skill.And worst of all, the characters and story are amazingly bland and forgettable. There are plenty of "choices and consequences", but few of them are affected by how you built your character (only 3 skills are ever checked in dialogue - the dialogue ones), they seldom intertwine or branch out, and they're just not interesting. Most of the situations in the game are actually comical (or at least try to be). Why should we even care? It's hard to believe how many skilled and experienced writers were supposedly on board for this project, when the results are this utterly forgettable.I enjoyed parts of Wasteland 2, just because I enjoy any oldschool RPG where you can create your own party. But in the end I felt compelled to finish it only because "Well, I've come this far..." I would not recommend the game to anyone, not even a hardcore RPG fan. Just play one of the classics again, and don't bother with Waste-of-time 2. I sure hope inXile's future RPG attempts are better.

Early Access Review
								Woe to any game that comes out between September and early 2015 - Wasteland 2 is the old school CRPG we've all been waiting for.  The beta still has some beta wonkiness, but the game that is emerging is everything I hoped it would be.  The systems strike the nifty balance of being both deep and intuitive, and I can't say enough good things about the writing.  Long and the rest of the writing team might just have crafted one of the best written RPGs in history.  The tone is super specific and unique, and there is just an embarrassment of writing riches.Wasteland 2 doesn't feel like a throwback.  It feels like a modern game that evolved naturally in some alternate universe where cRPGs never went out of style.  This is an easy Desert Island Game for me.  And it isn't even done yet!

ber 19, 2014
												I've preordered this game, via steam, as an early backer. I can only speak for the beta, which I would give 8.5/10.This game is a tactical RPG (Think Final Fantasy Tactics, Fallout, Might & Magic) with a setting in a post-nuclear wasteland (Think Fallout, but different). The REAL spiritual "Fallout 3", the story is a successor to Wasteland 1, but NOT a requirement to play the game, it's completely standalone.The biggest strength of this game is: The feels. Early on (15 mins) you get a choice which will immediately change the storyline in a minor way.Over and over you will feel the sting of the game as your actions bite back in an emotional way.Ask yourself these two questions, and then you're ready to play this game:"Do the needs of the many really outweigh the needs of the few?" and "If I save this man from death, how will I know he will not harm others?"Game on, brothers and sisters.

												I wanted to like this, but it's just no fun. Your characters have no personality, at all. The conversations are just a boring series of "Tell me more about X". There's no need to choose your characters' skills because you can cover everything between your team. Stats are woefully unbalanced, there are clear and simple *best* stats and *dump* stats.Worst of all, the gameplay is so, so slow. Everything is about slowing you down, wasting your time. I played for 4 hours across 3 sessions, and every time I stopped it was because I just couldn't handle the tedium any more.I backed the kickstarter, everything sounded good, but the final product is mostly mediocre with a few really awful bits spread around. I wouldn't recommend it for free, because it's such a boring waste of time with no redeeming features.

content:
r 22, 2015
												I first played Wasteland 2 back when it was finished. Its was a damn good game but with a couple of issues here and there but overall a really fun game that was essentially the closest thing to Fallout 2 since Fallout 2. (I love the original Fallouts almost as much as I love the new ones.) Im happy to say the Director's Cut version is a massive improvement over the original. With a multitude of fixes and additional content/mechanics to make the game feel fresh. Its overall the superior experience. It does still have a few bugs, a few confusing quests and overall slow pace early on in the game but despite this the game is great fun. For those of you that dont know Wasteland 2 is the sequel to the original game from the 80's and a spiritual  sequel to Fallout 2. Its an isometric turn based post apocolyptic RPG, one of the few of its kind. You have some really in depth character customization/rpg elements and some really damn good combat. Seriosuly its great, its even better than X-COM's combat. Overall if you love Fallout, RPG's, post apocolyptic games and have some patience then Wasteland 2 Director's Cut is the game for you!(Note I have deleted my original review and updated it with this one)

er 6, 2015
												This is a bit of a spoiler, but I met a weird guy out in the wastelands who professed his love of vintage video games. Dude's place was stacked, every wall covered with game posters, every shelf packed full of memorabilia--dude even had a collection of vintage arcade cabinets. We had a fun little conversation and after I left that town I didn't think of it again. A few weeks later I'm out dicking off in some obscure corner of the in-game map, wandering around looking for an oasis to refill my canteens when I stumble upon a little easter egg: the buried literal truckloads of unsold 1980s ET atari cartidges. There were a ♥♥♥♥-load of them, way more than we could carry in our packs. Then it ocurred to me: you know who I bet would be into all of these cartridges? Video game collector guy.So we load up with as many cartridges we can carry and backtrack all the way to that town. Now, we exhausted all the quests in that town, met with all the dudes and solved all their weird problems; we had no real reason to return. The game gave me no indication that this dude would be interested in these ET cartridges. No quest compasses, no journal entries, nothing. But lo and behold collector dude loses his ♥♥♥♥ with excitement over the ET cartridges. It was like we brought him the holy grail. We got experience and rewards for doing it. And this was something that we easily could have missed, something I easily wouldn't have even thought of doing. But the game knew. And the game rewarded it.♥♥♥♥ like that will never happen in a Bioware or Bethesda game. Even in an Obsidian game, I reckon. Next level RPG. A+

content:
r 11, 2014
												This game is HUGE and AWESOME! If you explore thoroughly and do everything you can, the game will take at least 70 hours. And if you enjoyed Fallout 1 and 2 then you will almost assuredly enjoy this.But the real reason to play this, and something I don't see discussed much for some reason, are the choices you get to make throughout the game. I've played a lot of games where you are given quests and different ways to resolve them, but this game blows all of them out of the water. Almost all main quests and most side quests have 2, sometimes even 3, different ways to resolve them. And it isn't just a simple resolution with a different reward, characters and sometimes places change based on your decisions. Almost right at the beginning of the game you are given the choice to save one of two towns (or neither) and both places have their own unique recruitable NPC and quests. Not to mention the ever present option of "kill everyone you meet".In fact, there are unique dialogues put into the game if you choose to kill indiscriminately. For fun I decided to save my game then kill everyone in the mayor's office of the town I saved. Afterwards some anonymous citizen radios Ranger Citadel and snitched on me, so Vargas radios me asking if it's true and I'm given a choice of admitting it or playing dumb. If you play dumb he tells you to go check it out, if you admit it he asks you why and then gives you a free pass this time. I'm pretty sure if I had continued my murdering ways Vargas would send after me the elite squad I met at RC who handle "problem rangers". I reloaded though.It's not uncommon to go to a town and there be some kind of conflict going on. You pretty much always have the option of siding with one side or the other (or neither), but more than that there are usually different ways to solve it for either side. If you have high enough speech skills you can usually make it easier and/or more diplomatic, or do what the leader wants you to do (like eliminate the opposition instead of finding peace). Although, since this is the wasteland, few people are entirely "good". Almost everyone is bad in their own way, though not always entirely malicious. Sometimes the bad stuff they do is to try to help others, so is bringing them down truly the best choice for that town in the long term?What really impresses me is not just the incredible amount of quests and their multiple ways to solve them, but all the little touches made based on your choice. In one town there was a guy about to be executed and I had noticed a pre-dug grave for him. After I managed to free him I decided to go back and re-examine the grave, and there was new text saying someone had taken a dump on the gravestone. I love it.Yes there are some bugs, including quest-breaking ones. But when you understand the mind-boggling amount of connectivity everything has based on quests and the many different ways to do them, then I think you can forgive the relatively few bugs there are currently in the game. And don't worry, the devs are working on fixing them!In closing, there is an extraordinary amount of replayability in this game. If you love the ability to make choices and see those choices have a real impact on the world around you, then you simply cannot pass this game up. Buy now, no need to wait for a sale!

er 4, 2016
												This game is so close to being awesome. The characters are fun, the world is immersive. The weapons upgrade system is alright. Exploring is fun.The combat is what is really difficult to handle. The grid system is horrible. During regular movement, characters can move and stand in what seems independent of a grid system. But when combat starts the characters are forced into a very clunky grid formation. This makes diagonal shots somewhat of a cheat when hiding behind "cover".  Also, there is no way to move your party in a formation, which means that when walking into an obvious ambush, there's no way to keep your party in good order. They just move into a lump. It's hard to have a good time with the combat system with these limitations.

content:
ber 5, 2016
												Wastelands 2. What to say. First off, if you like turn based games wich offer immersion, depth and an enjoyable long story then this game is for you. Wastelands has quite some really good things going for it but some flaws as well as I see it. I'll try to list them below.Good:- The setting. Really well done. Heck, the intro made me misty eyed and I felt my emotions responding to things happening in the game more then once. I was quite touched when a companion died for one and really came to loathe the bad guys even if they weren't bad for the sake of being bad. All the factions made sense to me and their struggles were a delight. - Your choices and actions matter. Maybe you don't see it at once but very often you do see the results of choices later in the game, sometimes quite subtle. Well done! Actions have consequences. Quests almost always have more then one way to solve it.- The combat system is well done even if it isn't entirely balanced and I feel some stats (speed) and weapons (assault/ sniper/ late game heavy) are better then others (luck/ charisma and melee, shotguns and hand weapons.)- The game looks quite nice. The locations are quite varied and ussually carefully made. Some minor locations and battle scenes were slapped together or recycled though. It takes a while to fully explore a town and that's good.- Lots of easter eggs and hidden secrets - you are rewarded for taking a good look as opposed to rushing through. - The voice acting is really well done, adding to the immersion. Not so good:- Quests tend to need a string of actions to be done in exactly the same the correct order to get the optimal solution. Who cares if I order first and then put coins on the counter or vice versa in the shop? This is a source of frusteration. You also likely will look untill you are eighty or crack and shoot everyone for the solution of some quests without using the internet. Ye gods. This would have ruined the game for me more then once if the story wasn't so compelling.- The difficulty spike half way the game is beyond silly. For a few encounters you have to fight vastly superiour enemies with hugely sub par weapons. I don't enjoy duelling a fully armored knight with a wooden sword thank you. After you find some new weapons the difficulty goes back to a much more acceptable level. This really needs a fix.- I didn't like the first major choice and how it would doom people no matter what I did.If you can live with three two above points I think you should grab the game, pin on your desert ranger star and start patrolling Arizona.

content:
, 2015
												I can't recommend this game. I guess I can't complain too much. I am a huge fan of Fallout and Fallout 2 and it is truly a blessing someone wanted to create a game in that vein. However, there is too much that cannot be overlooked. The game looks hastily prepared. Interactions feel generic. There are countless in game glitches. Pathfinding is very difficult and that makes it hard to complete the missions without having to read clues from forums. Even when you know exactly what you are supposed to do, it is sometimes very difficult to make the NPC's progress to the next quest item or find the resolution without hunting down some obscure almost unrelated item to trigger the resolution after doing all the rudimentary work to complete the quest. I tried to find enjoyment, but after a while, the game became tedious as I had to level up a specific skill in order to complete a mission. That meant I had to wander around the wasteland searching for enemies to kill just so I could level up skills that would open my dialog choices or help me "see" things in order to trigger events. So if you are playing, make sure you level up perception, kiss ♥♥♥, smart ♥♥♥, and tough ♥♥♥ skills. If you level up combat skills and the usual lock picking, medical, hacking skills, you will not beat the game. That leaves you with very little freedom in choosing your skills, and to add insult to injury, you are only allowed to level up to level 50, therefore you cannot waste your skill allocation on something you might need in the beginning of the game like melee weapons. Energy weapons are almost useless towards the end of the game. Only level up in Assault rifles, sniper, and maybe Heavy guns. Lastly the back stories were dull and uninspiring. FInding things and reading things was a treat in the predecessors. The history books and back ground journals are dull and tedious adding to an already tedious game. When the game hinted of a Wasteland 3 game, I thought oh no.

content:
ber 23, 2016
												If you played the original Fallout or Fallout 2, and liked them, then definitely check this out.  It feels like what Fallout 3 would have been like if Bethesda hadn't taken it FPS.  This game is really fun and has a lot of depth to it.  The story is ok, nothing amazing but solid and keeps you wanting to find out more.  Keep in mind that "fun" doesn't equal "exciting".  It's a slow paced, tactical rpg.  You'll get 50+ hours of exploration in a single playthrough, gradual character development, etc.  It's also got replay value, considering there are a few choices that you have to make that alter the game quite a bit.  There are some mechanics that I could see frustrating some players, like friendly fire chance if there's a teammate near the person who you're shooting at, weapon jam percentage, etc.  But I think it adds to the fun when you start upgrading your weapons to NOT jam so damn much.  Skill checks are a bit annoying, since you have to wait a bit for an animation with each one, and there are a LOT of them.  But it feels like they shortened the wait time in the Director's Cut (along with other improvements that were made to UI and graphics).  The graphics are solid.  Nothing special, but really feels like a polished, higher texture version of a late 90's top-down rpg. The best part about this game, to me, is how the story just kind of develops around you.  For example, my first playthrough:  I'm trying to get my sniper out of this jail.  I'd offered to have him locked up in this settlement (fairly far into the game) while I complete a quest for the leader.  But after I complete, he refuses to let him go!  It's my sniper, so I try to take a hardline against the guy.  This sets off agro for the ENTIRE TOWN (dozens of people and soldiers to suddenly fight).  So my team's backs are agains the wall, fighting endless waves of guards.  As we're fighting, I accidentally target the town's merchant as he's fleeing (the target was red, I thought he was an enemy!) and kill him.  Sorry bro.  Keep fighting, and after 30 minutes or so I finally have murdered the entire town, but my sniper is free!  While I'm looting the corpses for ammo and such, I come across the merchant.  His ENTIRE inventory is on his body, and lootable!  I bank upgrades for all of my characters, plus armor, plus a sizeable amount of money.  Did I feel sad about murdering the town?  Hell no, they'd double crossed me.  Felt more like I'd hit the lotto!  Would do it again.So if you need constant excitement and stimulation to enjoy a game, this won't be for you.  But if you can appreciate a well designed game that unfolds slowly but gives you a great story with random humor mixed in (the screaming goats, lol), then check this out.  I highly recommend it.

content:
r 25, 2014
												I waited for the finished version of this game with great anticipation. The hype and the promise of a return to old school, turn-based, squad based adventure gaming in the mould of Fallout 1 and 2 was enough to have me keen to play.Ultimately, having just finished the game, i have to say it was a disappointment that fell way short of my expectations and my desires. The gameplay is a regression to 20 years ago (with updated graphics). The environments look good, but they are mostly eye-candy and are not interactive at all (except for doors,chests,safes and holes in the ground).It is as if the last 25 years of turn-based games never happened, and none of the detail and gameplay innovations from games like JABIA have been considered for this game. Worse still, the game is not even as good as Fallout 1! The combat is so old-school it's ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥...one of the worst turn-based combat engines I have played in years. Like I said...as if nobody in the development team had even played any modern turn-based games in the last 20 years, or if they had, they had chosen not to apply any of the principles to their game.It is barely a sandbox - with two small maps and about 6 major locations on each map. The game felt very scripted and linnear and freedom of gaming choice felt very limited. This game is not worthy of admission into the post-apocalyptic hall of fame. It is as if Fallout 1 and X-Com Enemy Unknown had an unwanted, stupid, ugly child.All in all- NOT woth the $40 u.s.d. that I paid for it and it has left me feeling very disappointed because I wanted so very much for this one to knock it out of the park and to redeem the genre for a new generation. It looks as if I am still waiting for a game that completely updates my favorite style of gameplay, with an intricacy of detail that modern computers make possible, and a depth of interactivity with characters that I create within a massive story that I control through the choices I make.

ber 20, 2014
												Wasteland 2 is Fallout and it isn't. Imagine meeting a long lost relative from a gruffer more harsh time period when men were men and there wasn't any horseplay. That's how Wasteland feels compared to a younger Fallout series that doesn't take itself as seriously. I see a lot of replay value as the game forces you to make hard choices right away you know will impact the rest of the world. It's a very mature game for hardcore RPG veterans with rock solid graphics for a period game revolving around atmosphere, and if you were a fan of the old series you'll feel right at home.Here's an update as of 7/11/16:My take on Wasteland 2 vs the Director's Cut: You can't go wrong with either, and my only regret is when I played Wasteland 2 at launch the achievements werre bugged so I need to go back and get those at some point but....I have yet to go back to Wasteland 2: DC because the original left me so satisfied. It took roughly 135hrs to power my way through Wasteland 2 (I'd say about 45 of those hours were spent backtracking/loading due to bugs/glitches/ai RNG cheese) thoroughly and it was worth every penny. Very well written and detailed. Acceptable graphics and combat. Feels like a great Fallout game if you don't mind it's a tad linear.

												Wasteland 2 is the best written game I've played in a very long time. Every time I find a new piece of junk I rush to read its item description. The world isn't black and white but also not grimdark, you get the sense of a place where most people just try to scrape on by. content:
16, 2016
												** Quick note: I spent around 60 hours playing, and Steam tracks those hours under the 'Directors Cut' sub, but makes us review the game under the vanilla sub, which is kinda odd. **Wasteland 2 is an isometric RPG with turn-based combat set in a post-apocalyptic world. The story is simple enough; you as a group of new Desert Ranger recruits must set out to investigate the murder of another Desert Ranger, and continue on with the work he was trying to do. In your travels you will meet plenty of folks out in the wastes all needing help of some form, and you are free to carve out your story as you see fit. This game excels at throwing moral dilemmas at you, often making you make some pretty tough decisions. Most of the situations you face or often many shades of grey, and you often find yourself trying to decide on what the lesser of two evils may be. I love that sort of gameplay element. There is no ‘good guy’ or ‘bad guy’, and the Wasteland world is a harsh and complicated place.The decisions you make in your travels do have a big impact on the world around you and I love that. You will see a montage upon finishing the game reminding you of the people you met and how your decisions changed their lives or situations.  It also means this game has high re-playability, with multiple story branches to follow on further playthroughs.Apart from that there is plenty of loot to find with all the usual weaponry at your disposal, and your Rangers have fairly diverse skill tree’s to play around with. This game can be quite tough though so unless you’re a veteran to these sorts of things I would suggest playing on normal difficulty and remember to save often. Highly recommend to all CRPG fans.

content:
er 23, 2014
												Man is this game good. Wasteland 2 should be the benchmark for franchise reboots and how to do them right. So often, when a beloved franchise of yesteryear gets a new game, one of two things is the result:1) The game is pretty cool, and has the same theme as the original, but is wholly different in most other ways, and has completely replaced all your classic gameplay with something else. (See: Fallout)2) The game is faithful to the original to a fault, the big fault being that the original was sort of clunky and it's now many years later so they should have made this ♥♥♥♥ a lot less cumbersome, but chose direct adaptation over quality.Wasteland 2 manages to thread the needle and avoid both of these traps. All that good classic Fallout-type gameplay is there, but they've gotten rid of all the agonizingly slow annoying clunkiness. This is just pure old-school fun. The skill-use system is great. Assigning skill points is great. Making decisions that matter and effect the world is great. This game is an exemplar of the form, and while not everyone enjoys tactical combat and meaningful choices in a harsh world, anyone who does should play this game.

												I should note, that this game takes time. First 4-6 hours i wondered what's so good about it, but later it was impossible for me to stop playing, so if you're having problems with the game just try to force yourself through couple of first quests. I promise you, it gets better. Pros:+ nice and versatile story. There are several different outcomes of the main quest and each is interesting in it's own way+ gameplay is good. It's turn-based and mostly depends on your positioning, gear and your character's skills+ visuals are fine. Sure they're not stunning, it's not Crysis, but it'll do+ tons of cool side-quests and ways of completing them. You can go in guns blazing or take a more subtle approach(es). Each choise has it's own advantages and good sides, but it's up to you to decide what to do.+ interesting characters. Not all of them, of course, but mostly characters (aswell as the story) are written very good with a nice slice of humor. + exploration is really rewarding. Game encourages you to go where you're not supposed to (like radiation clouds and other places, where you might find shrines or cache)+ lots of weapons, clothes, equipment and other stuff+ tons of fun easter eggs and references+ is generally fun to play once you get a hang of it Cons:- sometime it feels like the game overstays it's welcome - some quests and their alternative ways are really not so obvious. Some people might like it that way though- it's really easy to screw up your character (try to pick 3-5 skills for each character and only level up those. Otherwise your char will be a mess) - it's slow. Because of turn-based gameplay and lots of walking-there-doing-that some basic quests take lots of time.What i expected: bigger-better-cooler FalloutWhat i got: basically what i expected

r 23, 2015
												I really wanted to love this game - I've played through, completed, and thoroughly enjoyed the original release: sure, it was always buggy, and almost ever gaming session ended in a crash, acheivements never worked for me on OS X, and there were numerous glitches - but it had character.So, with the chance to finally make this the great game it always had the potential to be, I'm sad to say that the Director's Cut is a distinct step backwards which appears to have needed more refinement and playtesting before release.There are numerous bugs which seems to have been reintroduced (Mac and Linux acheievements are again MIA) or created (when you expel a character from your party, they disappear forever - you're supposed to be able to recruit them again) and then there are the technology problems: there's apparently a significant memory-leak in the Dynamic Shadows implementation which progressively kills long-running sessions, and there are serious issues with non-nVidia graphics cards.Running the game on OS X on a Mac Pro, the frame-rate is awful and the game crashes 100% of the time when trying to leave the first area, both with custom and stock parties: the game is unplayable.Although it pains me to say this, as I really do wish the game well, in its current state I'd wait for further patches and confirm via the forums[forums.inxile-entertainment.com] that the major issues have been resolved... but I remain concerned that the game made it to release in its current state.I'll update this review if and when the problems are patched.

The original version of this game I have only idled for 15 hours or so get the cards drop (which seemed to take forever by the way). Maybe the first 20 hours or so I spent playing with my first crew which I then discarded, having learned enough of the mistakes I had made creating it. The rest of the time, 190 hours were divided between two complete playthroughs maybe by a ratio 100:90 respectively.It's not a flawless game and it may be easy to disagree on various amounts of it's design decisions. Nevertheless it certainly is a worthy effort in it's genre, and as a whole it captivated me like only a few percent of all games have done. If the post-apocalyptic theme appeals to you and/or you miss the classic isometric RPGs, I think you would be potentially denying yourself one heck of a ride by not giving this one at least a shot.

content:
y 9, 2015
												This is my first review ever here on steam, and never has a game compelled me so much to review it as WL2, so here goes.Short Review:  This is an unfinished game.  If we, as players, accept this very low bar of completion as OK, then we will reap the "rewards".In-Depth Review: I think it's important to understand where this game is coming from before criticizing it.  Tons of Fallout fans were less-than-impressed when Fallout 3 came out and, despite being promised something other than a re-skinned Oblivion (now Skyrim) got just that.As such, the hype was huge for a game from the original makers crowdfunded a true sequel with tried-and-tested Firaxis on board.  The target of 1 million was met and grew to 3 million dollars. The game won a GOTY award and has been well-received.That was all I needed, so jumped in and was ready for just such an experience.I did some reading and carefully crafted characters for the long journey ahead, nevermind thst there's very little in a tutorial to prep you.  I'm seasoned gamer, so go!So I end up roaming the wastes and get random encounters.  Some I try, some I try to flee.  You get "caught", and then you're loaded into an instance.  The mobs are now romaing about in the instance, not chasing you, and you get to do these a lot unless you have one skill.  Same scenarios and maps.  Hmmm...is this GOTY material?Then you get into your first quest to go to X place and do Y things.  Along the way, my noob party visited a much higher level area than they were fit for.  Hmmm...no warning?Luckily, we left and didn'tengage our certain death.  We went on to the Ag Center.  I was woefully unprepared, but managed to survive most of it...until I found myself at an impass:  I had tried to crack a safe that has a critical keycard to enter one of the next areas, but I critically failed which essentially bricked the safe, which was the only place where I could get the keycard.I went on having learned the critical rule of this game: you save about every 2 seconds and keep vast repositories of save lists.  Unfortunately, I learned this after i borked the safe with the keycard.  Not one to give up, I went on to other areas and did a boss fight where only 2 of my people had ammo left.  After about 20 tries, we got the guy without running out of meds for people he wasted.Now, that's what happened in the game.  The combo of ridiculous bosses, minimal resources, and the CRUSHING fact that I might not get the keycard I needed nearly caused me to uninstall.My reaction to this is now what you might expect, but it's what gets repeated ad nauseum on forums related to this game.  I took this as old school. You just have to deal with your decisions.  YEAH, and this makes everything more realistic, right?  So I left and had my NPC surgeon Rose desert us and picked up Angela Deth, who is great and all but nobody told me i'd need her, and we progressed...But at the same time, the clunky camera and its limited zoom functions created this "very atmospheric" sense that I was lost.  I was...and just wanting one more level of zoomout as compared to the satellite view in my inventory.And then you go into a scenario and place your characters just like you want them as you've done a thousand times by this point: in the right position but facing walls.And this was the point of no return.  I just realized that, for all the "difficulty" you face,  the execution is just sucky.  I knew that, if enough people complained, patches would fix things,but, I thought to myself for the first time ever, "THIS is GOTY?"I stopped blaming myself and started thinking "these are the problems that justify the existence of play-testers."  Did anyone playtest this game before release?  Not based on my experience, and forums suggest I'm not the only one who's had the same problems I've encountered.AND AND, if you want to see this done right, X-COM does it to near perfection.   Bottom line: the game required a million dollar budget.  It got 3 million.  In turn, we got something that is still in beta. finished.I don't blame players who are enjying this, but I'll never trust entities again which have chosen it as GOTY when it's not

content:
ber 25, 2014
												Having had a long, wonderful history with the old Black Isle games (Fallout 1, 2; Torment; Icewind Dale; Baldur's Gate; etc.) I jumped at Wasteland as soon as I read who was developing it. With 20+ hours of gameplay so far, I'm enjoying Wasteland 2 more than I have any other RPG in years -- more than I have any other game I've gotten from Steam in a long time with the exception of Civilization releases.Wasteland 2 is engaging, thought-provoking, well-written, intellectually stimulating, and even educational. Every battle is a new puzzle. No amount of playing can make the player impervious to what may come next. The writing is superb (surprise, surprise) the music is great, the graphics are beautiful -- although not a selling point -- and all in all this game is easily a 9/10 in my book, and it's not even selling at a triple-A title price (just 40 USD on release day).Negatives: people say there are bugs everywhere. I have encountered one. It was not a game killer and I expected to see more bugs than one within 48 hours of release.People say it is too hard. If you were born after 1990, you'll probably hate even the normal difficulty and very likely the game altogether. There's plenty of reading to do and very little hand-holding. I don't mean to be guilty of ageism, it's just that games have gotten far, far, far more user-friendly since the days of Atari and Infocom. The truth is, Wasteland 2 has 1/10th the difficulty of Wasteland, and W2 is catering to the same crowd. In short: this is a *compromise,* and InExile Ent. isn't apologizing.Conclusion: if you loved the Black Isle games and are on the fence about W2, don't be. I'm hardly through my first sizeable misson and I haven't relaxed so deeply into a game in years. It's like all those comfy afternoons playing Baldur's Gate, except new and improved and back in the Wasteland I spent my 20s in. Quality game development in my book, through and through.

												First, let me say that I LOVED the original Fallout games (fallout 1 and 2), and enjoy the occasional turn-based strategy game (X-com, for instance). However, this game just fell a little short. I'm not saying it's a bad game, but I probably wouldn't recommend it, especially at its current price.Pros:- The graphics are good enough for this genre.- The sound is okay- The setting is great, and the overall storyline seems kind of interesting.Cons:- THE CAMERA. Ugh. Unfortunately, the camera does not seem to expand far enough in any one direction, and the overall size and spacing of the terrain means you will constantly be heading into dead ends because the camera didn't let you see far enough ahead. It's not a game breaker, but is consistantly annoying.- Too many skill options. I understand that maybe this eventually improves replayability, but it's frustrating to make it through a couple of quests, level up a couple of times, and still be level 1 in most of the skills you've chosen for your character.- Controls and gameplay are annoying. I don't know of a better way to describe it then that. They are not bad, they are not game breaking, but it is constistantly a nusance to come up on an enemy unexpectedly, and all 4 of your squad members are clustered together and are immediately getting shot at.In summary, it's not a bad game, but so much of it is frustrating and cumbersome that it becomes kind of annoying to play. If it's available on sale, maybe try it out, otherwise pass.

content:
er 28, 2014
												Wasteland 2 hearkens back to the day when a 7% chance to fail meant failing 3 out of 4 times, and a game would beat your ♥♥♥ into the ground for the first hour or two, and then dramatically ease up after you get to sink a few skill points into your characters.I'm not sure whether it's more appropriate to say that this game is Wasteland 2 or Fallout 3D, given it owes so much to the original Fallout, which in turn owes a lot to the original Wasteland. In any case, if you've played any of the original isometric Fallout games, then you will be right at home playing Wasteland 2 as the locations, world map, sound track, random encounters, combat, sense of humour, and missions all hold strong comparisons. Also, interestingly, there are positive aspects of the combat that are borrowed from XCOM: Enemy Unknown as well. But that's not to say that this is just knock off - Wasteland 2 is deeply linked to the original Wasteland in its lore and the developers have learnt from the long gap between releases and taken the best of the old and the new and combined them to create a well-designed and deeply entertaining product.Speaking of well-designed, as much as I generally dislike what Early Access has done to Steam, this is one of the games that has clearly benefitted from the system as you can spot numerous little features that have been implimented to improve the game's basic playability and fun-factor. Things like a button to sell all your junk at once, comparisons between the weapon you want to buy and the weapon you have, a solid log book that displays your missions, a button that reveals all objects that you can interact with, and the choice to automatically distribute your loot intelligently to the people who would use it best. All these things and more save the player time, eliminate clunky inventory management or frustrating moments when you don't know where to go or what to click - issues that were all too common in the heyday of isometric games. Wasteland 2 is a loving heir to the original, and exists as a well-designed gem in a genre that typically suffers from over-complexity, suffering little of the clunkiness that one might expect from what one could call a 'throwback'. Its world is real and believable, the combat is fun (even if, at times, the hit chance feels skewed) and its characters are numerous, colourful and well-acted. I highly recommend this to anyone who loved the original Wasteland, any of the Fallout games, or indeed anyone who likes a well-optimised RPG.

content:
ber 27, 2014
												This is not a very good game. The NPCs and their dialogue are boring and lack character, they're little more than placeholders to guide you to the next quest, which is unfortunate because Fallout 1 and 2 had such interesting NPCs and conversations.There is no perk system. Attributes other than strength and intelligence are pretty pointless. Levelling isn't exciting since there's no reason to diversify your skillset, so you wind up dumping all of your skill points into one or two different skills.There is WAY too much combat. In fact, this game is almost exclusively combat focused, in my time playing it is very rare to move the story forward without a lengthy combat sequence. While this isn't ideal, it'd be fine if the combat were at all interesting. There's a cover system, but it's hardly used and most combat takes place without being around any cover. There's no bonus to pincering an enemy, so there's not much point to moving around during combat. Gone is the Fallout system of targetting different body parts to cripple them, or make them drop their weapon, the only option you have now is to take a headshot for two extra AP at -50% chance to hit for 200% weapon damage (which is never worth doing since your chance to hit will never be above 95%). The jamming system has replaced the critical failure system. Now you can have a weapon that has a 1 in 10 chance to randomly jam up, wasting your turn.Using skills is tedious. After combat you will want to heal your rangers, which requires using first aid. Each use of first aid requires watching a cross fill-up over 5 seconds, and most rangers require two first-aid packs to fully heal. With a party of 6, healing after battle requires about a minute of not being able to move around or do anything else in the game. Almost every loot container is locked or booby-trapped, oftentimes both, which requires watching some other animation that lasts 5 seconds to fill up. Waiting for animations to complete gets very tiring.One of the strangest design choices was to have a rotating camera. The camera is VERY annoying, you'll frequently miss important items, people, and entrances and exits because your camera wasn't pointed the right way. Designing the levels from the ground up to have a fixed camera perspective would have made a lot more sense.Lastly, the game just doesn't have much character. So far it's a lackluster wasteland without the zaniness, wonder, and humor of the classic Fallout games.I hope they do a lot better with Torment...

												'there was too many text to read''the game play is retro , the play map is confining , claustrophobic , the combat is mediocre'Sorry kids that the game is following back to it's roots, but not everything can be a Fallout 3-4 clone.The game is great for what it is and meant to be: a roleplaying crpg post-apocalyptic adventure. Going back to when you had to READ text to understand a story or plot, Wasteland 2 allows you to become immersed in your story with even allowing you to create your own backstories for your characters and customize them. The game has tons and tons of backstory that you can read through if your aren't as lazy as many of these negative steam reviews are. Of course this might not be the type of thing people aren't into but there's no reason to give a negative a review just because you thought the 'gameplay is retro - dislike' like really? What did you expect a game to be when it's trying to mimic the same techniques from a game made in 1988?? This game brings back it's cRPG roots from a 26 year long hiatus, and if you don't like it: it's alright, but don't go placing a dislike due to it being a 'waste of HD space' because it obvious that you can't come up with any constructive criticism that follows up with your argument of it being a 'waste of time'.I'd give it a 9/10 - for what it's trying to be, it does it flawlessly. However, it does suffer from the occasional crashes and camera problems.

content:
y 7, 2015
												First and foremost - THIS IS NOT FALLOUT (first nor second)! Drill this to your head. Do not buy this game thinking it's Fallout. Do not PLAY this game thinking it's Fallout. Wasteland is one thing, Fallout is something completely different. Now lets begin.Do you like post-apocalyptic lite CRPGs? If you do then this is something you should definately check out. Now when I say "lite" I do really mean it. This game feels, at times, extremely shallow and simplistic in everything from interactions with the environment, quests, combat and items. Everything is simplified. Yet this still is a good and enjoyable game and worth every penny you spend to buy it.The closest comparison that I can make to this game is Fallout Tactics, which in my opinion was vastly underrated and received way too much flak than it deserved, and I still rate Fallout Tactics higher than this.Character creation is based on the CLASSIC system (whereas Fallout uses SPECIAL) with just attributes and skills. No special perks or traits. You can customize your Rangers appearance, bio and so on but none of that affects your game in anyway.Combat is single squad, turn-based and squared grid layout playing field. Nothing too fancy, straightforward and to the point. You have different guns, bombs and heavy weapons with some different fire modes and ability to try a headshot. The cover system is similiar to the new XCOM Enemy Unknown game with the icon showing cover positions.Quests are typical (somewhat gliche'd) CRPG quests of fetch things, solve problems and make binary choices between factions.Environment is a bit stoic. Things you can interact with can be highlighted with a press of a key and that's about it.Game is full of easter eggs, dark humour and references. This was actually something that really started to annoy me. It feels like in every scene and place you visit is just riddled with them. I mean come on! Candy is nom noms but too much candy makes your stomach hurt.As a whole Wasteland 2 is a good game. It's not fantastic or rebirth of CRPGs. It's just a good game. Just do not try to compare it to Fallout games. The only things these have in common are Fargo and the post-apocalyptic theme.

content:
, 2016
												I have 45 hours in Wasteland 2: Director's Cut. Steam doesn't allow reviews from that version of the game for some reason so that is why my time in this is so low. Anyway, onto the review.Wasteland 2 is a solid game. There is no denying that fact. It scratches the itch of old CRPG's within the tactical genre and it does a lot well. It just does not manage to grab me in the same way other games within the genre do.Good:+ Solid storyline+ Great individual character skill, perk and attribute customisation+ Great combat+ Interesting charactersBad:- Poor visual character customisation- Very little actual "role playing" elements- Massive variation in character build qualityThe game is strongest in developing and enhancing the abilities and equipment of your squad and putting your efforts into practise during combat. The problem with this is that they're weapon types in the game that are almost not worth using. The reason for this is simply becuase they are outmatched by the stronger weapon types in the game. The same is true for the character skills in the game and this is my biggest problem with the game. You will realise around 10 hours in that some skills are worth more than others and a broad range of skills within a party is more effective than a highly specialised party. This is fine, it just takes some of the role playing out of the game when compared to Fallout 1 and 2 or other games in the genre where they're often alternative methods for completing objectives in a desired fashion. Whereas here they're instances whereby you need certain skills to simply progress forward. The same is true when you compare the damage and overall functionality of an energy weapon, heavy weapon or a handgun to an assault or sniper rifle. The game therefore artifically begins to pigeon-hole you into creating certain builds in order to make a character or the party in general to be effective. It is almost important to note that if you haven't played a CRPG like this before then you can get truly lost and/or stuck. You may need to use a guide in order to find your way around but this is relatively minor. What I will point out though is that the game can simply gimp you for picking certain followers as I found out in the final battle. Without spoiling anything some followers of mine were rendered useless during that fight with very little foreshadowing or warning of it occuring beforehand. There also seems to be very little choice in how your characters directly handle storyline events or in side quests. You will invariably be forced into a fight at some point to complete a quest and the game rarely deviates from that formula.Is it a bad purchase or is it worth the time to play it? I think that is more of a personal decision depending on what you have personally played. If you haven't played the classics like Fallout 1 and 2, Baldur's Gate, Planescape Torment or more recent examples like Pillars of Eternity or the Shadowrun franchise then I would suggest playing them first since I would consider them better games. If you have played CRPG's before and you want something familiar but don't mind using the "optimal" weapons and skills then this is a good game for those players. Otherwise I would look elsewhere for your CRPG itch.

content:
ber 23, 2014
												If you loved "Fallout 1" and "Fallout 2" as well as "The Fall - Last Days of Gaya" you will absolutely love Wasteland 2.  Party based RPGs have been missing for a LONG time, those in a post-apocalytic setting for even longer. Wasteland 2 brings this forgotten genre back to live with thrilling tactical combat, great story telling and that sense of humor that made the orignal Fallouts so great in the first place.I am not sure how far in the story I am now but after doing the first set of major places (4 of them visited) I can also say that they really stuck through with their promises that choices in this game would matter. Both local and immidiatly as well as on the grand scheme of things to come. And I love the game for it.I am not really sure what some people's gripe with the combat system is because as far as I can see there is not much difference from X-Com's and Shadowrun's systems other than some rules about iniative that lead to enemies doing their turns before some of your squadmates do as well as squadmates having two action phases per round. And hey for the most part the AI acts a lot smarter than in those games, which makes overcoming forces that outnumber your squad quite the challenge. You gotta use the terrain and cover otherwise you are quickly out of means to heal your squad or even worse out of ammo.A Modding Toolkit is announced for some time after release and when it arrives I am looking forward to playing some really great mods.

content:
r 30, 2014
												Ian McEwan once said that very few really long novels earn their length. I feel the same way about computer roleplaying games - especially the kind calling itself Final Fantasy.Wasteland 2 is a game that requires a ♥♥♥♥ing huge commitment - beating it took me 100 hours (more or less, I tend to be a slowbie). And that was just one playthrough where I played the game as a stereotypical do-gooder hero, exploring everything and being a helpful do-gooder with a ♥♥♥♥ed up set of character skills and a tendency to reload and find the best outcome to satisfy my sad, sad do-gooder neediness.But god damn it, this game is worth it if you're into these kinds of timesinks. It's a mix between the old gameplay styles of Wasteland and more recently released computer roleplaying games - a lot of the mechanics of the original Wasteland are at play here, re-tooled for an experience more suited for modern gaming. What I liked the most about it was the ability to solve problems through different means without hinting too deeply at what a solution could be, letting me get creative whenever I could. Locked safe? Hit it with a grenade. Locked door? Get that sledgehammer and ♥♥♥♥ it apart. Terrified settler due to gigantic robot scorpion? Hack the mini-scorpions that it produces to distract the big scorpion while drilling .50 caliber rounds into its face. A guy begging for a CD-i? Shoot him in the face and take his video game rocket launcher to sell for Snake Squeezins. This is such a refreshing breath of fresh air in a roleplaying game, this ability to solve problems!And yes, it looks like something from 2003. Yes, you shouldn't need to read a little text box to figure out what's going on in the game, but what are you, scared of reading? Are you yeller about words? If I had any complaints beyond those two, I'd say the combat gets a wee bit much at times, the atmosphere and story are good but a bit flat in some places, and the thought of playing it AGAIN over another fifty hours or so is not something I'm interested at all in doing right now (but then again, I don't typically re-play video games I beat, mainly because I'm out chasing after a new experience or doing something equally wasteful with my time, like moving my eyes to read a page of things in a collection of pages bound by a spine that also is host to two covers HAVE YOU FIGURED IT OUT YET, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥S?)So yes. I wholeheartedly recommend Wasteland 2. It's a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ joy to play, experience, and mess with.

number of helpful: 15 of 22 people (68%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
4, 2015
												Wasteland 2 is a tactical RPG sequel to a very old text-based game.  While I had never heard of it before, it was the inspiration behind the well-known Fallout games.  To have a sequel come along after 27 years is unheard of, and thankfully they did a very good job with it.While the game was released in a pretty buggy state, inXile diligently released patches to fix everything.  When I played it, I didn't run into any significant problems and there is a director's cut special edition coming in the near future to improve the game even further.  While I feel bad for those who bought the game at release, I'm very glad that inXile stuck with it rather than leaving it a buggy mess like many companies would.  Hopefully their future projects will be released in better condition.As for the game itself, it is a top-down squad RPG with tactical turn-based combat.  There is a metric ton of text dialogue, with the main story being voiced.  The writing and voice acting is ok, nothing special, though there is a lot of humor and references to many other games and old technology which I found enjoyable.  I would prefer more voice acting since I get tired of reading text pretty quickly but I understand that inXile wanted to stick to a similar style to the original game and at the same time having the whole game being voiced would likely be too expensive.  The pathfinding is some of the best I've ever seen in a game with your squad able to easily navigate all the way across large maps with a single click.  Unfortunately, traversing these large maps can take a long time and you will be doing a lot of this, especially if you want clear out your inventory which I will go into later.Wasteland 2 has its own unique RPG systems, with a standard stat system providing bonuses to various skills.  Each character will only get enough skill points to be competent in a couple skills so specializing is required.  There are even special skills that can only be acquired by finding specific skill books throughout the game.  Several of the skills deal with unlocking containers and doors and this is where one of my sticking points comes in.  Even with maxed out skills, your characters have a very low chance of succeeding (and an accompanying high chance of critical failure) and these objects can only be repaired once.  Following a second critical failure they can never be accessed again.  I believe it's meant to convey a sense of permanence to decisions but I feel like it just encourages save scumming.The combat could be a sticking point for many people, though it's not an issue for me.  Everything functions as you'd expect but later in the game, tactics becomes less and less useful.  Arranging party members behind cover can get tedious and isn't necessary later in the game since as you level up, enemies are less dangerous.  At the very end of the game however, it becomes necessary again.  My only real complaint about the combat is that at the very beginning of the game, it is extremely difficult.The game's biggest problem though is inventory clutter.  The game is filled with the greatest variety of junk items I've seen in a game.  Most of these are just sold to shops but some have a shining effect indicating that they are useful in some way but you don't know how.  Unfortunately the "sell all junk" button includes these shiny items so you have to manually remove them from the shop each time.  In addition to the junk there are tons of miscellaneous items, each of which can be given to a specific NPC for a reward.  There are tons of these items and tons of NPCs with no hints about who wants them other than remembering what NPCs may have told you when talking to them.  It's a royal pain trying to deal with it all but can be ignored if you aren't a completionist.The game makes good use of the Unity engine with DX11 support and pretty good graphics, though unfortunately due to using Unity it does not support fullscreen mode.  This led to significant performance problems for me.  I'm really hoping that the update to Unity 5 for the director's cut version will fix this particular problem.  Regardless, the game does seem to require much more power to run than it should for the type of game it is.  It seems to be a common problem with Unity games that aim for high graphical fidelity in my experience.Despite a few problems, Wasteland 2 is a fine game.  It has all the RPG depth you'd expect and plenty of content to play through.  Having skipped most of the dialogue due to not wanting to read so much, it still took me more than 50 hours to beat the game.  Wasteland 2 is a game I can highly recommend to RPG fans.

0, 2016
												While I can't NOT recommend it, I can't exactly recommend it with flying colors.It's not a bad game, unless you get stuck encountering bugs that show up due to your hardware configuration (and there are a lot of hardware configurations this game doesn't like, both AMD and Intel, both Radeon (AMD) and Nvidia (Intel) graphics cards), you will probably find this game endearing and a bit nostalgic at first.Then you'll realize that's just icing, and there is no cake underneath. It's a very thin layer of icing too.Fallout 1 and 2 are available on Steam.Get them if you've never played them.You'll understand why this game has so many negative reviews.If you want to drop 40 bucks on a game that doesn't hold a candle to games you can currently get for $5-$10, that hails form a modern era but lacks so much of the depth both in combat and questing systems and dialogue that Fallout has... then buy Wasteland 2.In Fallout 1, you're pretty much released from the intro mission, and given the ENTIRE game map to roam. You can follow the quests or wander off, and time isn't completely irrelevant either, but it doesn't punish you for exploring and side-questing.There is very little of either, exploring or side questing, in Wasteland, due to the constrained play areas at each step of the plot. The plot is fairly linear, and often the plot's goals and requirements are not only unintuitive, but completely nonsensical, and not even brought up or highlighted or alluded too in any dialogue with any characters. (One quest you have to stop a small war from breaking out, the only way to do it is to murder a drug dealer who I'm not sure how he's even related to the damn quest at all... But you HAVE to murder him. Only way to stop it. Both unintuitive and very narrow).In short. Buy the game on sale. 20 bucks or less.You'll get LONG play time out of the game, but its really up in the air whether that play time is quality enjoyment, or tedious simplistic combat with a constant feel of nostalgia reminding you... There's more to the Wasteland than what you're doing.Cheers and good gaming, peeps.

number of helpful: 25 of 41 people (61%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
r 5, 2014
												Let me preface this review with the following: Do not buy this game unless it is $15 dollars or less. In this game Armor actually kills you and you have to strip down to actually beat some encounters or you will die!Spoilers will be in here.So after 70+ Hours I think I have played enough of this and gotten the mechanics down to write a review. Now I get this is supposed to be a classic styled game. I loved Wasteland and the Fallout series which is why I had to play this. I went in expecting some pretty decent gameplay ala Fallout 1 & 2 style. While the base game has some decent overtones and it looks extremely polished. The feel and amibiance are fantastic game looks and feels great and just oozes style. However the mechanics are what destroys this title or should I say lack thereof. Unpopular Mechanics: How the Waste was made.So lets get this started you have Attributes which give you various bonuses to derived stats and a lot of skills. Every skill or stat goes from 1 to 10 including the  equipped armor stat, but more on that later. Now most of your stats are straight forward extra skill points on level up or higher crit chance on in particular is interesting "Combat Intiative". Seems pretty standard it makes you act sooner in combat right? Well partially right, it allows you to act faster in combat. Meaning you can go two or even three times more then a character with a low score. Making it a godly stat if you get enough of it. Also the average of 13-15 is considered low by the game. Enemies have average 17-19 meaning they go first and sometimes twice before you do. That leads us into the mess which is Wasteland 2's combat system. Lets start with weapons and see what does what.Assault rifles: High damage, wonky stats between rifles as some higher tier ones do horribly low damage and most have a solid three round burst mode. This is the go to weapon for most situations the only draw back is they have accuracy penalty at point blank range and if a enemy moves next to you a further aim on all shots is inccured. Also the enemies WILL do this every chance they get to cripple your snipers even if they don't attack them. Pistols: high crit low base damage. Early ones fire for a pittance of 3 action points a shot allowing you to do some damage. Later higher but not assault rifle damage ones are typically 4 AP a shot. A decent side arm for using 4 ap you can't shoot with a rifle as you switch between guns, not particularly effective though, As you can rarely get a third shot off late game.Heavy Weapons: These are joke level, they waste huge amounts of bullets to fire large bursts of VERY low damage shots that combine up to equal a couple good assault rifle shots. Bonus joke is you start with a broken M2 .50 caliber machingun rechambered in 5.56 if you select this skill at start. Even though you get .50 BMG ammo later on there is apprantly no real M2 that uses it. To put it in perspective a assault rifle using the same round does 44-70 damage for the 20-30 damage of a heavy weapon. Both of which will be reduced by enemy armor making even a minigun barrages damage miniscule. No mods can be used so they will jam or not have great chance to hit/Hit your own dudes.Submachine guns: These are to pistols what heavy weapons are to assault rifles. Low damage bullet wasters.Energy Weapons: Now we are talk here is the games central gimmick and one of things that breaks the game utterly. The more armor the target has the more damage it takes from energy weapons. Late game enemies use energy weapons and melee weapons that go right through your armor. There is a ambush later in the game where synthetics attack you from all directions, I died after 2-3 turns and retried this encounter many times and went back and leveled up and did stuff I might have missed. I was level 34 at my highest character and still died. Solution? I took off my armor before entering the location and the 120 damage hits I was taking turned into 15-20 damage hits. I completed the whole fight with no one under 80% health and having done NO healing during the fight.Totally disgusting as all my power armor and cool gear I worked for actually slowed me down and made me take MORE damage. Also Explosives do straight damage ignoring armor so a pipe bomb always does 50 damage and a frag grenade does 100. To reiterate I had to take off all my armor in order to progress through the game or I would die if they I wore armor. Shotguns: Laughable for a good eighty percent of the game. Enemies will often kill each other with the low damage cone effect. Later ones gain burst fire but insane accuracy penalties where they will either do maybe a shot of assault rifle damage or triple shot remove late game enemies.Sniper rifles: High damage and long range, Keep enemies back or lure them in for close combat. The best gun in the game is likely the .50 caliber sniper rifle you pull out of the dump as it can and will crit for 250+ oh and like pistols these have a high base crit and rarely miss when in range. Oh and uh melee weapons: they do more damage based on levels you put into them even though it apprantly doesn't say that. Anything with AP 2-3 is extremly viable especially against rifle using enemies who will run away from you. If you max these out early they are absurd like no other. Especially as later ones have very high armor pen and status effects. Do not trust the listed damage, once you are 6-8 skill points in they pulp whatever you hit, and you can swing multiple times.Skills or how I learned to extend play time through save scumming. Every skill besides first aid (unless surgery on npc's) has a critical failure. Even a easy 92% check has a chance of going HORRIBLY wrong and maiming your character or breaking whatever you were interacting with. This can straight up break entire quests as you break a lock and are unable to progress in that chain. Frequent saving and loading on critical areas is advised. The game loves to throw critical failures even when its only a 5% chance to hit them.Weaponsmithing is a mess as it provides a chance to get weapon mods by destroying guns. The random list has older mods which are no longer useful. Though breaking weapons can lead to weapon parts which can be sold at the ranger citadel in arizona for huge profit once you get the basic tier of mods done. Even maxxed out the chances of good mods is not that good unless you have stacks of high tier energy guns and assault rifles. which can instead be sold for bullets and health items better guns.Theres also a bunch of crazy trinkets that you can swap out for stat bonuses though you will have to save scum when you realize you didn't have your ranger badge on when you needed that extra point of hardass in a conversations as the conversation skill prompts are removed if you quit the conversation or talk about something else no backsies!Speaking of no backsies, if you pass up a safe or locked item only to come back when you have higher skill. Several times the safes are now "looted by scavengers". Tough break.The quests, dialog, writng, amibiance, voice acting, art style, animation, story and basically every thing else are top notch. However this game most reminds me of Arcanum with its horrible skill and combat system. So in summery: Armor kills you and also slows you down, Assault rifles blow basically everything out of the water, even more so when weaponsmithed (save scum those laser sights!), Combat intiative is the best stat next to action points, You can go two to three times for their one and get all your action points each time. Heavy weapons are a funny joke by the devs and are ineffectual unless enemies spam them and even then kinda meh. Finally, you can't polish a turd but you can sure ruin something trying to polish it with a turd.

number of helpful: 17 of 26 people (65%) found this review helpful
content:
r 26, 2014
												Wasteland 2 is a great take on post-apocalypse. It's very similar to Fallout 1 & 2 and should appeal to anyone who loved those.Game's a mix of RPG (both character development in terms of skills and attributes, and choices in story and consequences). The story is again similar to Fallout series, with a dose of humor and typical post-apocalypse madness. It was definetly entertaining and motivating to find out, but could have been slightly better written to enhance the immersion. The world in Wasteland 2 is huge and allows a lot of exploration, but is not entirely open: you have to progress the story to gain access to certain areas. The world itself is highly detailed in content, and is therefore fun to explore. My favorite part of exploration is that you can find interesting and weird stuff where you least expect it. Here I rather mean finding weird characters and in most cases items, and not unique new quests or adventures like you do in the newer Fallout games.I was somewhat disappointed by the graphics. The details of certain objects and buildings were non-existent. I wish the game simply was sharper and more detailed, which would farther help increase the atmosphere. The voice acting was in most cases pretty good, but not always convincing, and to compare to Fallout 1 & 2 lacked some of the uniqueness in the characters you meet (i.e. like Marcus), but only to a lesser extent: there are lots of weird people out there.In general the game is absolutely worth your time. Strongly suggested to Fallout fans (especially 1&2) and those who are into post-apocalypse in general, or just someone looking for a game that can draw you in for at least 50 hours. I spent 80 in the end, and still hadn't explored every corner in the wasteland and finished all side quests.

content:
r 1, 2016
												EDIT: Thought I'd rewrite this now I've played it fully through. I still recommend it, but some earlier gripes have gone.The Good+ Great Ranger/Squad character creation+ Solid turn based combat, which rewards strategy+ Good roster of companions who have unique commentary on people and places+ More than one solution to each problem (if you can't pick a door, fire an RPG at it..)+ Some great locations and characters+ First half is excellent overall+ Morally gray writing; less "goodies" and "baddies" more "devil you know"The Bad- More than a few locations feel unfinished, lack-lustre or just plain empty- The later acts feel a bit rushed and dry, with no real building up- Easy to miss entire sections of story if you miss an NPC or pick the wrong choice- None of your big choices have an impact on how the larger story plays out- Difficulty spikes, even with maxed out skills you'll face locks in the last half that you only have a 20% chance of passing.. - Too many obtuse solutions to quests; for example there's a hidden text option in one quest that is the only way to settle things peacefully. The game teaches you that typing anything other than the available options won't work, /but/ this one time it does but it doesn't tell you. That's not cool.Overally, I'd still recommend Wasteland 2. It's a great game, genuinely interesting and a lot of fun.

content:
ber 20, 2014
												Please stop comparing this game to Fallout 1 & 2.  Please stop saying things like it's "the true Fallout 3."It's not.  It's not even close.  It lacks any and all of Fallout's whimsical charm, it forces you to create a squad at the beginning instead of striking out on a lonely, eerie struggle.Moreover, the game feels like it's high on its own supply.  Overhyped, oversold, generally just not ideal for someone who wants an original Fallout experience.  There's a big difference between this super serious, staid setting and the wacky retro-future of Fallout.Honestly, this is like a better verison of Fallout: Tactics at the end of the day.  I'm not saying this is a bad game, it's just extremely misleading to compare it to the original Fallout titles.  It is NOT like them.  No traits, no perks, no color or humor.  Not enough attribute and skill points at the beginning for an individual character, since you're supposed to make four.  There's no room for character development or finding your own identity.  The very first conversation, I'm pushed into saying "sir" constantly and being a military recruit.  Maybe I don't WANT to join the rangers.  Maybe I want to just run out into the wilderness or find a city hub and just make my own path - like I did in Fallout.I realize everyone is different.  But part of the reason I loved Fallout was that my companions had their own minds and I didn't have to micromanage them constantly.  It ended up creating hilarious (and sometimes awful) situations in which my companions surprised me in combat.  Overall, it was more immersive (to me) because I was focused entirely on my own character, instead of mysteriously mind-controlling a group.Overall, it's hard to say whether or not I recommend the game.  I know some people will love it.  But I can't get over the vast disappointment after I was lead to believe, from literally everyone, that this is like Fallout.  It's not.  Fallout, in my opinion, is way more fun.  Mechanically, aesthetically, and otherwise.Just one woman's point of view.  Take it or leave it.
