content:
r 20, 2014
												I really wanted to like this game. But i can't. I love isometric RPGs and i played them all. I even replay both the original Fallouts once every three years or so. Sadly, the Wasteland 2 fails on so many levels that the few that are actually good won't save it. And the fact that Divinity: Original Sin and Shadowrun: Dragonfall came out recently and are superior on almost every level makes this game look even worse.Combat:Total letdown. Almost no tactial options. While in Divinity i would use my rogue to sneak behind enemy lines and start with an ability that costs a lot of AP and is therefore only useful as an opening getting bonuses from backstab as well as from attack from stealth. After that i will use the artifact and teleport my tank to the rogue and make him knock down the most dangerous foe while my mage will teleport oil barrel near the enemies and ignite it. While my tank has fire resist over 100% so the flames actually heal him.And in Wasteland? I open with a shot. After that all my other characters shoot. Some use the weapon ability to shoot multiple rounds as it has the best dmg/Ap. Then all the enemies shoot, now all my characters shoot. When you are skilled you can try for a headshots (And that just causes more dmg, no penalties to the enemy or anything and you can't aim for any other bodypart) Sometimes you can use verticality or cover (that has been clearly added to the game as an afterthought as it is not possible in most of the fighths) And THAT IS ALL! No abilities, no gadgets, no skills, no perks. NOTHING!!!Character progression:There is none! You have attributes and skills. Attributes can be minmaxed as some are clearly better than the others. Skills are just your percentual chance to do stuff. You will NEVER gain new ability or perk or anything. Nothing that will change the gameplay. You will just know how to open a box better. Mainly because boxes near the end of the game are harder to open than the boxes at the beginning of the game. Yes, the same boxes...Quickloading:As the game desing is bad you will load very often. In fact you will memorize the loading screen very well. You see, everything is percentual and dependant on your skill. Luck based. You see a locked box with a trap and an alarm. You have 50% to disarm the alarm, 40% to disarm the bomb and 70% to pick the lock. So disarm - fail - disarm - fail - disarm success - alarm - fail - alarm - fail - alarm - success - pick - fail - pick - critical fail - LOAD and repeat.Graphics:Amazingly bad. I mean really bad. Much worse than Fallout 1 or 2. It is technically bad (low res textures, low poly models) and aesthetically bad (repeating of assets, assests with different textures next to each other, the same mood everywhere, the same models everywhere). You don't even have much of an avatar picture choice when creating your characters. And some of that pictures are later used in the game on other characters! The graphics are much worse than in The Fall: Last days of Gaia which is old, low budget german post-apo game from noname developer.StoryHere it isn't bad. The story is quite good. Sadly it is told via big chunks of texts. I like to read in games. Planescape Torment is one of my most beloved games and it has much more text. But the text in that game is exciting and relevant. Here most of the things that people will tell you are things that you have already heard milion times from others. But you have to read it all because sometimes in this ocean of text there is useful information.ChoicesThe choices are a mixed bag. You are often presented with multiple choices and you actually feel the consequences. That is very good. But sometimes the choices themselves seem illogical. At the beginning of the game you have to choose to save one of two settlements. Either the superimportant one that feeds all the surrounding settlements (including your ranger base), or the other superimportant one that provides water to everyone. You as a new recruit. One ranger of many. And after you do that you suddenly hear the other rangers chat on radio. How they helped to save some merchants or how they saved some cows. Yea, but they couldn't save the superimportant settlement...Conclusion:This review might seem too harsh but if someone asked me what game to play - Wasteland 2 or Fallout 1, the game that came out 17 years ago, i would recomment F1 without hesitation. And that tells you something about this game...If you want to play good modern isometric RPG, play Shadowrun: Dragonfall or Divinity: Original Sin.

content:
ry 28, 2015
												I've never played the original Wasteland so I had no particular expectations about this game.I hold Fallout 1 and 2 in high regard and I can say that Wasteland 2 is what I would have wanted a different Fallout 3 to have been. A PC-centric isometric turn-based cRPG through and through; detailed stat sheets, lots of options, lots of skill and much room for exploration. This game has a learning curve, it doesn't hold your hand in the way many modern AAA RPGs do. It's also long. Very long. Depending on how thoughrough you are with side quests and exploration it may take between 40-60 hours to complete. The many choices you have in the game does offer replayability, but the gameplay is quite combat-oriented.But it also has some problems though:1) Pacing. This game requires a lot of patience. It takes a while before the story gets off the ground. The skill checks eat up time as well. I needed to take a break from the game about half-way through (I found some of the areas midways somewhat uinteresting and the combat was becoming repetitive) and then come back to it again after a couple of months. However the second half of the game feels better. I almost think it would have been better if the developers had cut some of the content to make the game more focused. 2) Armor system. This is just badly designed. Armor comes with a armor threshold. Weapons come with armor penetration. If weapon penetration exceeds armor threshold then armor does nothing. And it so happens that most enemies you encounter use weapons with armor penetration that just about match the best armor you can get in that part of the game. And later in the game more enemies use energy weapons which deal increased damage to high armor ratings. Thus you find yourself in situations late game were your armor is either detrimental or useless. This really calls for a major balance rehaul patch.3) Graphics and animation. This game would have looked good ten years ago. The animations are fairly rough and stiff at times. Many backgrounds are nice, but the overall impression is very mediocre. But these issues should not deter you if you're into long and involved turn-based cRPGs.

content:
ber 21, 2014
												Absolutely great!  As someone who recently went back and picked up Fallout 2 only to realise it was a LOT better in my memory, than in my 2014 spec PC reality - Wasteland 2 is exactly what I needed. OK so sure, I hear what some reviewers are saying - as far as tactical combat goes, this is not XCOM. Nothing is. But the game has all the elements I used to love in the original Fallout series; gritty humour, no imposed moral code, diverse skill system, crafting and more. Definitely gets my crystal clear recommendation to anyone who loved the Fallout originals. If you've only ever played modern RPGs (and therefore is not struck by nostalgia like myself), try it anyway - and maybe catch a glimpse of what all the rave was about.

content:
9, 2015
												Wasteland 2 is a good game. If you want an old school RPG, you will probably enjoy this. Unfortunately it has some flaws. The graphics aren't pretty (I think it's getting an overhaul though), the combat could be more polished, the AI was frustrating at some points regarding followers you can't control, and I didn't like the way certain skills worked, for example you could have a lot of points invested in lockpicking and still have a high chance to fail at it, encouraging you to save and reload.Despite all this, the reason why I recommend this game is because it's a true RPG. Choices matter, many things change depending on how you act, I found many quests and places in the world to be interesting and made me think if what I was doing was the right thing to do, and what consecuences those actions would bring. The story is decent for a video game, the writing is good and many NPC's were very unique. Now that it's been some time since I've finished it, I can say that it was a very memorable experience.

content:
ry 2, 2016
												I was looking forward to this game since its announcement. Sadly, Wasteland 2 dissapointed me a lot. There is no strategy, challenge nor variety involved in the combat, which wouldn't kill the game so much if the role-playing elements were superb (Mass Effect 1 for example). They aren't however. Quests are filled with numerous bugs (especially in LA) that make them uncompletable. Almost none of the loot matters. The choices you'll make throughout the game are mostly black and white. Characters feel like clichés instead of actual people. You don't build any loyalty towards the game's protagonists Desert Rangers because your communication with them basically amounts to them levelling you up. And so on...But! For some reason it did still compel me to complete the game. So it's definetely not as bad as I'm making it out to be. However, I'd still like to warn those interested in this game to look deeper into it, buy it on sale, or when an even more definitive "Director's Cut 2" is out. That or play Fallout 2 for the billionth time.

content:
ber 22, 2014
												I can't recommend this game, the promises that it makes and the potential of this game are amazing, but it quickly becomes obvious that it's built around a good idea with really poor implementation. The fact you move your characters around in real time before a combat start oftens leaves you're characters all huddled together before you can start the combat, as at least 2 or 3 members of your party are out of cover. The combat soon turns into a waiting to see if you're lucky enough to hit as the AI just charges forward or stays still shooting at you. The options in combat for crouching, headshots and ambushing just aren't enough or actually useful, the combat is really stale it really could have done with copying xcom wholesale.The game hides the fact of which skill to use on particular objects, which left me to go to the internet to figure out that the demolitions skill allowed you to disable traps. The uses for the various skills are fairly pointless, you need perception, demolition, lockpicking, first aid, surgeon and safecracking, then you need to invest heavily in combat skills to stand a chance of hitting anything.The conversation system could have been wonderful and added much needed depth to the game, it is generally well written, but it turns into a case of just clicking every single option to find out all of the information the uses for social skills tend to be few and far between. There are apparently hidden key words in the conversations, I tried asking about lots of different options and none of them came up.The camera also is pretty limited and hides things, you'll end up pressing z almost constantly whilst exploring to see stuff to interact with.

content:
8, 2016
												You can't actually write a review for the Directors Cut because... Steam. I have 94 hours logged on that game and finished it so, here's my review then!In many ways a throwback to classic isometric PC RPGs. Can be brutally difficult at times but I enjoyed the challenge. There is some degree of learning curve to deal with as well. Basically if there is a stat you can level up, it's probably useful. Do not sleep on Kiss ♥♥♥, Smart ♥♥♥, Hard ♥♥♥, and Perception. Even Toaster repair is pretty useful. Other than that, explosives are your best friend. Unless the explosive in question is one of the many land mines you will step on... hence why perception is important.I wouldn't say it's an incredibly ambitious game but it gets the job done. The game seems to run fast and largely bug free. The graphics get reused a lot and really aren't anything amazing. You'll see the same character portrait several dozen times. They actually seemed to have crowdsourced a lot of the assets. So you funded the game... and you kind of made it too... It may be spartan, but it may finally push you to get off your ♥♥♥ and make your own game in Unity.When it comes to cons, the worst part of the game would have to be the VO. I played the majority of the game without headphones on. Some of the voice actors sound very amateurish and seem to want to drag out their lines for an eternity. I can only guess this was a backer reward or maybe one of the developers owed someone a favor. Other than that, the music is decent enough. In some ways Wasteland 2 was more enjoyable than Fallout 4. There are many times your decisions actually have impact on the outcome of the story (F you Preston Garvey!). The sense of humor, while juvenile, gives the game a nice vibe that contrasts with the dark subject matter. It has much more personality and challenge than Fallout 4 but it is also more ballsy and "adult" in subject matter.If you love classic isometric RPGs then give Wasteland 2 a shot.

content:
er 5, 2016
												I really wanted to like Wasteland 2, but in the end I feel it failed me on most counts, the first and foremost being the writing, to the point where I couldn't muster the will to finish the last mission after 81 hours in (Director's Cut).The good?* Squad management with all the skills and weapon types is actually fun.* Combat is enjoyable enough.* The setting has some gloriously bizarre moments and characters.But all of it is undermined by shoddy execution, overall simplistic writing, lazy and uninspired artwork (honestly, Fallout Tactics looks better and put more effort into customizing character portraits) - all the things that kill immersion and suck the fun out of the game.As far as execution goes, there're plenty things in the game that feel unfinished or unpolished. Pieces of dangling quests here and there or failure to react to you doing things in wrong order, small things like rearranging squad formation or viewing completed quests sorted in order, reused locations - all contribute to the death of a thousand cuts. Squad management fun is obliterated by the fact that your companions don't level if you leave them at the base, which effectively means that you'll be stuck with almost the same party throughout the game. So much for recruit diversity.But what really killed the game for me was the writing. I'm honestly struggling to see the lauded brilliance here. It's a pulpy shlock, by design, sometimes funny and eccentric, but so over the top that it kills all tension and willingness to care. It doesn't know what tone it wants to set. On one hand it attempts to be grim and portray a ruthless wasteland, but most such moments go hand in hand with cartoonish grotesque hilarity. First third-to-a-half of the game is a tedious linear slog. The Prison -> Canyon -> Damonta stretch is a dreary and dull timesink with no redeeming qualities or payoff. But when it suddenly becomes somewhat more open, you are still offered only cartoon characters, clear cut black and white choices and moustache twirling villains. The choices are obvious, the outcomes are formulaic, quest chains predictable, no subtlety, no suspense, no stakes. The one moment of doing something different literally happens during the 2nd assignment, and that's that, the only trick up Wasteland's sleeve.It probably sounds a bit too harsh and bitter. If I had an option, I would've given WL2 a mixed review. Ultimately it's a game that can be fun but is undone by its flaws, and in the end looking back all I feel is frustration and disappointment, so I can't honestly recommend it. ...The first Shadowrun Returns also left a sour taste of disappointment in my mouth. But it was followed by Dragonfall and Hong Kong - two games I love to death. Here's hoping that inXile could only go up from WL2.

												8.5/10 (-1.5 mostly mechanical reasons, bugs, cannot edit the appearence of non-ranger allies and the CAMERA Control is annoying in some areas. I have 2 native american people who look 'out of place' with what they're wearing. Who wants some twigs held together by threads protecting you in a gun-fight?)This is one of those games where you're playing it for the 1st time, you're about 30+ hours into the game and you cannot wait until you complete it, simply so you can start a whole new game. A lot of games these days boast about how your decisions effect the story and the path you'll take but in reality they're usually weak and have very little consequences to your actions but here, you'll be enqountering many branches, each as strong as the last in terms of how your team will grow and what plots you'll follow. A shout out to people who start bad reviews with "I'm a fan of the old fallout games" - If you played the old fallout games and don't like this game.... you must not be a big fan of them OR you don't realise you've become a fan boy.+ The characters are great, imaginative enough to make you want to learn more them, instead of doing it not to miss valuable info. I've also become very attached to my own custom characters who have intertwine backstories.+ Weapons etc keep you interested in, what's in the next box? If you play right you can have some explosive firefights. I once had 2 rangers use burst fire, 1 ranger use his SMG, one use his pistol, 1 use her sniper rigle all in the space of a second in an ambush attack. + It is TACTICAL. I have about 400+ hours on Arma3 and what you learn from that can be applied to this game.+ The mechanics in place like, weapon variety, abilties, perks etc have been crafted very well and the feel' of being a TEAM is strong. If I lost a member, I'd be lost for some time, morally and strategically.  + EPIC replayabilty... I really mean it.   TLDR : If you cannot enjoy this game, You must be out of touch with your inner geeky gamer or bought the game out of hype.

content:
1, 2016
Wasteland 2 is a post-apocalyptic CRPG created by InXile Entertainment. The long overdue sequel to the 1988 game Wasteland, it takes place in the western United States, in Arizona and later California, after that brutal 1998 nuclear war that totally happened. You create a squad of characters, all new recruits to the "Desert Rangers," a group trying to bring a semblance of lawfulness back into a desolate wasteland. Wasteland 2 can be seen as the spiritual successor to Fallout, as it's viewpoint, combat, and general feel is much closer to that than the original Wasteland. The combat is somewhat similar to the original Fallouts, although much more focused on in this game. Instead of controlling a single character with companions being completely AI, the game allows you to control each character on their turn. This adds more of a turn-based strategy feel in the combat; it's more about positioning and tactics than straight up firepower and ability to withstand said firepower. Fallout Tactics holds a similar, albeit clunkier, playstyle. The different skills are pretty good for the most part, although some weapon types do stand out as more useful.The freedom in this game seems scant at first, as you are immediately forced into the Desert Rangers and sent off on a mission, but diverges almost right away with multiple choices as to where to go first, who to help, etc. Only one time limit is imposed, and this time limit simply alters the game rather than ending it outright like in the first Fallout. Folks who prefer the darker side of life also have the option to go rogue in one of two ways, but I'll leave those up for you to discover. It's not completely open world, but more a sequence of maps linked by an overworld map.The graphics get the job done, but they're by no means stunning. Running in the Unity engine, the optimization is okay. The general aesthetic is certainly good, but it doesn't quite jump out at me like Fallout 1 and 2, or even Wasteland 1. The primary complaint would be the character models, they're not too distracting, but they aren't exactly the fluffiest sheep in the barn. To say it bluntly, the character models are bad, and at times don't even match the portrait of the character in question.ProsCombat system is complex and strategic, especially compared to it's predecessors.Freedom to approach situations, although combat is less avoidable.The world itself is goodVarietyConsCharacter models aren't very good.Some skills aren't as useful as others, although most are fun to use.Can be difficult for a first-time player.Final Thoughts:Fans of its forebears will find it pretty enjoyable, and certainly a worthy successor, and anyone who needs that CRPG itch scratched will be plenty happy with it. Those who like fast, action-packed games will have to look elsewhere. Rating: 9/10This review was written for and is published on the  Lit Reviews [LR] curator page.

content:
r 18, 2014
												Ultimately, Wasteland 2 is an average game that scratches a particular nostalgia itch for many gamers and is receiving praise beyond its merits.  Quite frankly, the Turn-based strategy genre has been in a drought for nearly a decade and fans are dying of thirst to the extent they'll lap up contaminated water riddled with disease and ask for seconds.  They're so enamored with a sub-standard product they don't recognize they're dying a most dishonorable death from dysentery.Combat - The combat is lackluster and is not tactical nor strategic in any sense of the fashion.  OK Corral gun duels might be more appropriate, except slow and with none of the skill involved.  If you want a game with good combat, just replay XCOM2012 or Xenonauts.Character building - No skill tree, no perks, nothing to be found except redundant skills to simply dump your stat points into every time you level up.  If you're looking for the complexity and fun of a D&D style character sheet, keep looking.  If you're looking for a Fallout perk system... keep looking.  Even Diablo 3, which the avid fans of W2 seem keen to mock, has a far more indepth character building system.Story -  Glaring plot hole at the beginning of the game that most people seem to overlook or simply not notice.  Even if you look past that, the only clever aspect of the entire game is the little Easter Eggs you'll occasionally find.  However, finding kitty litter, a condom, or big black didlo for the 15th time is just sad.  It's funny the first time, but like any good joke, you have to know when to quit effing telling it.  If you want a game with a good story, reboot Mass Effect, BG, Fallout... pretty much any other CRPG.Characters - Easily forgettable and none that will be remembered.  No Minsc & Boo, HK-47, Commander Shepards, Irenicus (best villain ever), Tomi Grin Undergallows etc.  No Delita or Ramza to be found here.  For the most part, they're as bland and lifeless as the Arizona wastes you'll wander around for the first half of the game.  Exploration - Some of the environments are interesting, but with the terrible combat and random loot, much of the fun is taken out of it.Graphics - The game wasn't trying to inspire us with graphical prowess or eye porn, but what it delivered is unpolished and ugly.  Some will argue it's stylistic or gritty, but to each their own.Sound - Ok, but no gripping musical scores to be found here.At the end of the day, everything W2 set out to do has been done before (obviously), but done far better.

content:
r 24, 2016
Product received for free
Wasteland 2 Director's Cut PC Review{shortened}  Prelude Wasteland 2 is a unique and incomparable game series that stands out from the competition being Fallout and XCOM. In Wasteland 2 you play as a squad of members, desert rangers to be more exact who are required to fulfill certain roles defined particularly through the attributes, skills, character and personality you choose in character creation. You can either hop right in by choosing the default squad option that creates the default characters that the developer has included in this game with specific attributes, personality traits and other characteristics in which they have selected or create your own. Wasteland 2's genre is not defined but rather it is a blend of many genres including turn-based strategy, open-word role-playing, action role-playing within its armor selection, equipping items found in the wasteland and finally the camera rotation and movement parallels the computer role-playing genre, which in recent years has disappeared but was re-imagined mainly in 2015 by Pillars of Eternity through Obsidian Entertainment and published by Paradox Interactive that redefined the whole computer role-playing ( CRPG) genre and it has done really well in its revival.  Wasteland 2 released on September 19th, 2014, published and developed by inXile Entertainment. Some of their other well known games are  Hunted: The Demon's Forge and The Bard's Tale. Genre: Adventure, Indie, RPG, Strategy.   Others say that Wasteland 2 is just another Fallout, but a more stripped down version that is full of poor combat mechanics, bugs and some other areas of concerns that don't seem to overshadow this game's success.  Let us take a look now and see how all of the elements fit in as well as any concerns I may have with this newer addition in the Wasteland series. Story     The story is incredible. You can tell that the publisher took their time with finding actually good voice actors that have personality, character and specific dialects that complement their attitude, behaviors, character, personality traits, skill attributes and action points that are assigned to strengthen specific skills that they have. The actual characters you play have no voice dialogue as far as I am aware of which would have been cool to see. We don't have the option to choose between different male and female voices in character customization which is a large disappointment I wish would have been included to make the story more immersive. It is ok though because Wasteland 2 makes it up through proper grammar that adapts to the dialogue of each separate non-playable character (NPC). Story Overall Score: 9/10 Character Customization, My Specific Squad, and Crew UsedMy Squad     My squad consist of four unique characters in which I incorporated two of those, being actual friends of mine with their respective alter egos. I will only briefly describe the biography of my characters and post them here as such.Friends Kai & Morgan, Alter Ego's1. Morgan-  Morgan is my right-handed girl. Her role is to keep Nathan and even Kai confident and upright when we lose sight of larger situations that may get out of hand. She is my right-winged woman that I go to when I need reassurance that what I am doing, is what needs to be done. She is calm, persistent, loving, caring, trustworthy, always in prayer and loves you for who you are. She has known Nathan, a team member since he was very young at the age of fifteen years old. She has grown him up into being who he is now. She is a bestie of Nathan's and necessary towards his survival because of his polarization. She is modest, cool and beautiful in her own right and unlike the others, she has no identifiable quirks.2. Kai - Kai, on the other hand, may be young at sixteen years of age within her adolescence as a ranger, but she has confidence, heart and is easy to earn your loyalty and trust. She connects through talking to others, although her quirk is ' delayed gratification'   She is confident, loving, mature, responsible, forgiving, honest and just wants to be understood all the time. We love you Kai and welcome to the team. I gave her the attributes of intelligence and charisma, her personality and desirability and she uses sniper rifles and sub machine guns because those are her favorites.3. Nathan- Nathan is a remarkable young man that is the leader and intelligent powerhouse for the whole group. He is the strongest physically and mentally being able to withstand much damage per second. He was raised in the most stable environment, a Christian household that was of middle-class socioeconomic status. Now, he holds skills in writing, understanding others and in showing the unseen, imperceptible within certain defined environments including those in which are more secluded.4. Lastly, we have Ashley. I will not talk to much about her since she is not modeled after some real-life encounters I have had in my life. She is fictional and is characterized by the quirk of manic depression in which her skills and attribute traits in the game, constantly change due to mood swings and alterations in her personality.Options     Now, we get to my first main disappointment with Wasteland 2. We have very little customization options when it comes to the way in which our characters look. Males have more facial traits that can be selected rather than females. All physical traits and even outfits are pre-made and cannot be edited or changed which allows very little room for personalization. Despite these nuances, I was still able to sacrifice some parts it lacked to make beautiful female characters in which I imported a couple of my friends into it, virtually with me which makes it more unique and interesting. I gave them real-life attributes through this first partial playthrough of Wasteland 2. Customization, Writing, Graphics, Presentation, Sound & Control Overall ScoresCustomization 5/10Writing 10/10 - Proper grammar, dialect, punctuation and supporting details with very elaborate points.Graphics 8/10 - Incredibly well done within the setting of Arizona.Difficulty 8/10 - Difficult compared to modern games.Sound 9/10 - Excellent intricacies.Controls 7/10 - Nice camera controls, takes time getting used to. The mouse is preferred for the most authentic and realistic experience.Presentation 10/10 - Presentation is far more appealing than the wasteland included in Mad Max & the Fallout series.Elements - 7/10 - I can't give it an 8/10 because the combat is very challenging as far as positioning right, not being able to dodge attacks too often and some flaws that can sometimes be seen in the cover system.Overall/ Verdict (combined average) 8/10 -  Astounding, the perfect alternative to Pillars of Eternity and the Fallout series Age/Content Rating     According to Common Sense Media, Wasteland 2 is recommended at the age of eighteen years and above because of sexual themes, violence, and very strong language. Similar to Fallout, there is a brothel you can visit, and you can actually catch sexually transmitted diseases (STD’s) if you choose to engage with ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. Also, some audio clues and in-game sequences are set in brothels. However, no actual sexual scenes are depicted. This is dialect and strong language you would normally find in western based movies of the past and in present times. Lastly, there is some sexual moaning at the brothel and also some parts of a mission where drugs are involved.  Disclaimer  Wasteland 2 was provided by game journalist Warwick Janetzki of Gamephasis as a review copy. If you want to help out, visit their site at www.gamephasis.com

content:
ber 23, 2014
												I remember playing the original Wasteland on my dads computer 13 years ago and I was clueless as to how the game operated and I spent no more than 2 minutes with it and never went back to it until last year.I played through Wasteland and found myself pleasantly suprised by the depth the game had and how enjoyable and how much I got attached to my custom made rangers.So now we have finally come to Wasteland 2 a game which has been patiently waited for by fans of the series for over 25 years (You give Half Life fans a run for their money) and it's return is glorious.The story of Wasteland 2 is as follows, You and your group of rangers(All of which you can personally customize) are tasked with regulating the hostile wastes of Arizona and later Los Angeles from raiders, mutants, robots, cyborgs and more.One aspect of Wasteland 2 is choice, like most games that have cropped up recently Wasteland 2 is no acception to choice based gameplay.One of the first choices you make is decieding whether to save the town of highpool from raiders or saving an agricultural facility from mutants.It was great to see that this choice had a lasting effect, as I choose the AG Center first, Highpool was destroyed and taken over by raiders as a result.The gameplay is similar to the original Wasteland but thanks to the advancement of technology we now have gameplay which will be more remeniscent of the games which Wasteland inspired allah Fallout with it's turn based gameplay and chance based combat, this means you have action points which are used in combat and anything from movement, attacking, healing and reviving all take up points.This means you have to be strategic and choose your actions carefully so 2AP for crouching, 3 for moving into position and 3 to take a shot.Weapons all have different AP usage rifles typically use 7AP and using pistols and fists takes up 3AP.Now onto the graphics.Wasteland 2 uses the unity engine and it does a pretty good job of capturing the look and feel of the post apocolaypse with run down buildings, sandy plains and nature taking back the enviroment with green plantlife and vine covered roads and buildings.It's been a long time coming and it does not disappoint in the slightest.If you are a fan of the original Wasteland, Fallout or stories set in the post apocolaypse Wasteland 2 is one that will kick you to the ground, stick your head into an irradiated toilet and keep you invested until the bitter end.

content:
ber 10, 2014
Remember Wasteland? 1988, a pivotal year towards the close of the last century. Arnold Schwarzenegger discovered that Danny Devito was his long lost twin.Tom Cruise encouraged Dustin Hoffman to play a little blackjack and George Bush senior had just been voted into office.A fact which I'm sure had no bearing on the emergence of a brand new gaming genre, the post apocalyptic RPG. Let's not Fall Out over it! The original Wasteland was a ground-breaking title back in the day with recruitable NPC's populating a persistent world. This is something we take for granted in RPG's today, but back in the pink and blue neon haze of the 80's this was unheard-of. Even if you haven't heard of the original Wasteland, I'm certain you'll be familiar with the Fall Out franchise. A franchise which would probably not exist had wasteland not come before. In the "meantime"It was nearly 10 years after Wastelands release before we got our hands on its spiritual successor Fallout. Sequels were planned for Wasteland but they never quite came to fruition, but now thanks to a little thing called kick starter and loyal fans with long memories ... Apocalypse Now ... We have the imminent and long overdue release of Wasteland 2. After 26 years lost in the wilderness, expectations are high, but are we in danger of placing Wasteland 2 on a pedestal, expecting too much and inevitably about to face disappointment when September 19th rolls around? Four Rangers and a FuneralAfter hitting the play button for the first time you'll find yourself at the character creation screen. Here you'll find more stats and options than you could shake an iguana on a stick at, with skills ranging from animal whisperer to toaster repair.Prepare to spend an unhealthy amount of time agonising over the attributes and skills sets for your posse of wannabe rangers. Not that this isn't fun, It's a good kind of agony trying to build your perfect team but if this kind of stat tweaking isn't for you, there is a roster of pre-built characters all lined up like puppies in a pound waiting for you to give them a new home in your squad. Once you've settled on what you hope is a complimentary skill set for your four rangers you'll be treated to a highly atmospheric cinematic which cleverly fills in a little of the back story for the desert rangers and leaves your group standing around the fresh grave of a fallen comrade. Ace in the Hole The writing on the makeshift coffin reads "Born a man, died a desert ranger" It's here that the game starts as "Ace" is laid to rest and you're team picks up his failed assignment. It's this assignment that will be your first thread of the main quest that you will follow through Wasteland 2. Triffid or not Triffid, That is the QuestionAfter some interesting conversations with the NPCS at the graveside you'll head off on your first mission and it's here that the first moral choice hits hard and fast. There's a distress signal from Highpool, a community under attack, they need your help, then almost immediately another from the nearby agricultural centre that's having some "plant problems", you'll only have time to try to save one, but which.... It's decisions like this which really make Wasteland 2 come alive, whatever you choose will have repercussions, you're a part of this dying world and your choices matter. We come in peace, Shoot to KillThe tough decisions don't all come in the form of moral choices either. The turn based combat present here will test your tactical decision making too. You'll be glad you spent all that time tweaking your stats and skills and matching your weapon load outs to your strengths when bad guys, gals, animals and plants come for you.When they do come, they'll look great. you'll find crisp detailed graphics and atmospheric audio in Wasteland 2 which makes every encounter a vivid experience. The end of the world never looked so good. It's The End of the World as we know it The experience InXile are creating here is shaping up to be one of the most interesting RPG's in a very, very long time.At the time of writing the game is still in Beta, although you wouldn't know it, the experience to be had in the first few hours of play is already highly entertaining and very polished.If you remember, earlier in this preview I expressed my concern that anticipation for this release is too high and that it can only lead to disappointment. So how do I feel about this now, after I've actually played the game? I Feel FineFrom my experience with the beta, the answer to this question is a resounding No. Wasteland 2 is everything I'm looking for in a crunchy RPG and I love it. This is going to be something special. I'm genuinely excited for the release of this title and I'm certain I'll be sinking an ungodly amount of time into the wastes over the coming weeks. It's time to rediscover the Wasteland To view the full review and others please take the time to visit  Review-Well.com [www.review-well.com]

content:
ber 28, 2014
												Edit: they've patched the game a lot since I wrote this and I don't know if its more fun now than it was on launchAs a Kickstarter backer I got this game for $15, but if I had paid $40 for it I probably wouldn't be happy at all.The whole way the game interacts with you is ripped out of 1987 in the worst ways. There's no fast travel, you watch your party walk for ages, because that's the only way out of the labaryth maps, walking back to the entrance, slowly. And there is plenty of mandatory back tracking. The combat is boring, and the RNG makes it an annoying chore, but most of the time you can't avoid it. Put points into outdoorsman and flee every random encounter.There's no cool stuff like reverse pick pocketing a land mine into someone's back pocket, or shooting their legs off so they can't flee. Just aim, and miss or get jam or whatever.The character creator is super unintuitive and weird and kind of horrible. INT doesn't help with "wisdom skills," charisma has nothing to do with your ability to influence people in dialog, and strength has no bearing on your ability to break down a chain link gate. Why not? Because!There is an over-world, but don't think that it's open, you need to follow the linear plot.There is lots to see, but the game moves ridiculously slowly, ie level 5 and done with the first dungeon in ~12 hours.The story is really decent and the game delivers a lot of it's "old school" promise, but honestly most of that is the bad things from the old days that should have been forgotten. For $40 I wouldn't buy it, and after my $15 I'm not sure if I will have the patience to finish it, even though I like the story.

content:
er 14, 2014
												Wasteland 2 is an amazing game and instant classic. It's very much like Fallout 1 and 2 (which were based off the first wasteland game), with lots of differences. First of all, you start by creating a party of up to 4 people (and can have a party up to 7 from npcs recruited in game), there a tons of different skill to choose from for each character, ranging from mechanical repair, to computer science to assault rifles, pistols, shotguns, outdoorsman, smart ♥♥♥/hard ♥♥♥/kiss ♥♥♥ (3 dialogue skills that vary on attitude), etc. There is also a decent attribute system, much like the SPECIAL from fallout, except this one is called CLASSIC (coordination, luck, Awareness, Strength, Speed, Intelligence and Charisma), and the attributes have a huge impact on characters and what they can do.The battle system is much like DnD or any D20 system, grid turn based combat, using initiative to choose when people act. If you've played X Com then it's much like that, except more in depth (then the newest x com) in terms of mechanics and what you can do. As opposed to the two move system from x com or D20, this one is based off action points (like the original fallout games), you have so many action points (depending on your speed, strength, awareness and many more) that you can do in a turn. Walking 1 square requires 1 action point, shooting different weapons require more as well as other various actions.Travelling the world map, again is very much like the original fallout games. You have the map, and your icon traverses across it as you may run into random encounters, there are oasises everywhere that give you water (as you gotta refill water to keep traversing the map), and you can run across various settlements this way. There are also radiation clouds that you must watch out for, you can go through them but you need radiation gear otherwise your party will get killed while walking through  it.On top of the game mechanics and battle systems, the quests themselves are very intriguing, lots of side content and missions to do, and A LOT of choices to do in those missions. You can do missions so many different ways, from sneaking into a fort and killing some dudes to negotiating with them and allying them with you, to poisoning their food and killing them off. The main big missions usually have various different outcomes in the missions, each giving you a drastically different faction running an area, or having you liked or hated by another faction, and even unlocking different potential companions depending on how you finished the mission.The game itself sort of gears you to be a "good guy", in that you are a team of rangers that are supposed to be a police force in a post apocalyptic wasteland - but you don't have to be. Though the game would be MUCH harder being a bad guy, there's nothing stopping you and you can kill anyone you feel like for any reason. Though your NPC characters (that arent created by the PC) usually dont like when you go around double dealing guys, killing innocents and just failing to protect people (though there are other NPCs that don't mind you doing so, just dont expect the philantropist doctor girl to stay with your team when you betray a settlement or start murdering people indiscriminately).Hell, you can even roleplay the morally gray ranger that is willing to sacrifice people and lives for the greater good if you so desired.So far, i'm about over 100 hours in game (right now steam says im at 88, but after an update when i was about 20 some hours in, it reset my hours played for some reason), and I'm only about half way done the main game (though ive been doing any side stuff that i come across). So far the game is amazing to me and im having a blast with it. Been waiting for a game like this for a long time, and definitely having a lot of fun with it and to me, this game will be a classic that i go back and play multiple times over the years, much like other classic RPGS such as Fallout 1 and 2, Knights of the old republic, Bauldur's gate, Neverwinter nights and Morrowind and so on.I would recommend this game to any RPG fan, specifically hard core RPG fans, and this game is definitely worth the 40 dollars for the base game. Such an awesome game!

content:
r 17, 2014
												Summary at bottom for those of you in a hurry. I approached this game as a newcomer to the series. I had never played the original. So, I have no fan boy bias at all. I will probably end up comparing it to Fallout at times, but I WAS NOT expecting it to be a clone of Fallout. I will repeat that to make sure everyone understands that. I WAS NOT expecting this game to be exactly like Fallout. That being said, nobody can deny the two are similar. They’re both apocalypse’ish games that are centered on RPG mechanics.The Good: I actually liked the looks of the game. They’re aren’t the most high definition graphics, but they do look right. The game mechanics work well when it comes to combat. I liked that you got to customize up to four characters to play as. That’s something you don’t get to see very often. The last time I remember getting to customize more than one character in a game like this is Jagged Alliance 2. The combat was pretty solid. It has some issues, but nothing that can’t be fixed with some tweaking. The sound effects were good and so was the music. Sadly that’s about where my praise for the game ends. The Bad: The characters. I didn’t really find any to get attached to. The only character I liked was one of the random NPC characters you can pick up. Any game like this has to have characters with personality. You have to either love or hate at least some of the characters for anything to matter. Fallout 2, which is the closest game to compare this to, had great NPC characters. I just would have liked more connection with the characters. I remember going around with Cassidy (and his daughter in New Vegas) and enjoying their company. Next, there are the bugs. This game has acres of them, but I’m willing to give that a pass right now since it’s new and this is an indie developer. They seem determined to fix them, so good on them.The Ugly: The story. I found it boring. There was no hook to it. The story starts off with you attending Ace’s funeral. Ace was a ranger and so is your party. You are tasked with the mission he was trying to complete of attaching devices to some nearby towers to track a transmission. This transmission has been transmitting some very worrisome messages. The problem with this whole plot is there’s no attachment to it. I didn’t know Ace before he was dead, so there’s no attachment to him. I don’t know the Rangers, so I can’t feel attached to them. This comes especially so when the General doesn’t let you in the main fort to get supplies. He even lampshades this saying something about it being a real dangerous mission when you ask to go inside to get supplies. You can very minimal supplies outside at a trader, but still. You don’t feel like you’re being treated like one of the group, so why should you care about them? Without spoiling anything, you get to a point in the story where some bandits are harassing the area, so you have to deal with them. Now, their camp is guarded by these huge invincible turrets. I was gratuitously over leveled at this point because I had explored every square inch of the game so far, but they slaughtered me. I was frustrated with this, but accepted it at the moment. But, on a whim, I decided to see if I could take on Ranger Citadel (the Ranger HQ). I wanted to do it just for fun, not to actually keep as part of my save. I slaughtered everyone with ease in there and the only one who posed a threat was the General. The four turrets in Ranger Citadel went down it 2-3 hits each. It made no sense that the highly militarized and organized group had worse equipment than some bandits. To be fair though, I did like the second half of the story a lot more. The second half of the game could have been the start and I would have liked it a lot more. There was more personalization with the characters and therefore the events happening in the story mattered. Long story short: I do not recommend this game. The story was lackluster. It lacked any sort of immediate trouble in the game. There weren’t any memorable characters for me. I had the same problem with Skyrim (I know they’re very different games). They both had good gameplay, but lacked anything that could remotely be called a good story or characters. Good story and characters is pretty much 75% of an RPG.

r 1, 2014
												If you're looking for a turn-based RPG, it doesn't get a whole lot better than this.  The game has many minor flaws - most of which are UI-related - but the world and writing oozes character and sucks you in.  There could also be some mild balance issues, but I'm not entirely convinced they're all in my head and I'm just rebelling against the CLASSIC system in Wasteland 2, compared to the SPECIAL system I'm used to from Fallout and Fallout 2.If I had any one desire, it'd be deeper, more interesting combat - especially given how common combat is! - but while it's not going to match XCOM: Enemy Unknown in that area, it's not *bad*, either.Wasteland 2 may not appeal to everyone, but if you're interested an old-school, turn-based CRPG, this'll scratch that itch for you.

												A huge disappointment.  How did this get 'Game of the Year' award?  Probably because those who gave it that award never tried to beat the game.  The further along the plotline you go, the buggier it gets.  There's intermittent crashing at the Damonta location, but by the time you get to Hollywood, the game is unplayable.  Characters randomly transporting all across the map, quests that get stuck or become impossible to complete, with most players getting past the location by killing everyone on the map as the only way to 'complete' the location.  Unlike Fallout 1 and 2, you can't "skip" a town's quests and move on.  If you can't complete the quest, the game is permanently stuck.  There are so many times I've gone across the whole game map, only to find out that I need to talk to some obscure, random NPC at some location just to "complete the quest" and open up a new location.  Frustration, frustration, frustration.  And the game's plot completely lacks all of the dark humor, the biting social satire, and the open-ended adventure of Fallout 1 and 2.  Disappointment.

content:
ber 22, 2014
												I have barely scratched the surface of Wasteland 2, but numerous people have been asking my opinion so I figured I would post a "first impressions" review.I came to Wasteland 2 as a Fallout 1/2 fan. The kickstarter was the first time I had heard of Wasteland so I didn't know what to expect. All I knew was that it was a combat heavy turn-based strategy game set in a nuclear wasteland. Based on the fact that "Toaster Repair" is a useful skill made me it assume it had a healthy dose of snark as well.When I started the game I found out it was both what I expected and entirely different. The interface was more or less exactly what I had expected. The descriptive text and conversations were a lot more detailed than anticipated, but still lived up to expectations. [WARNING: This game has swearing.]The fact that the interface was as expected made it seem easy to jump right in and start exploring. Wow, was I wrong. The content and difficulty were another beast.From what I've seen thus far the overall tone is best described as “Dark Attitude”. The rangers aren't lights in darkness, they are flawed individuals who find themselves in the roles of peacekeepers. Its not a game where you get thanked for helping, its one in which those you help will gripe about it taking too long to get there and generally be jerks. Fellow Fallout fans should be prepared for a very different tone. Contrary to what I expected it was not easy to jump in. I had chosen a party of pregenned characters, thinking they were relatively balanced, and was proven very wrong. This became very obvious in the Ag Center and led to me restarting. Chance to hit was low, ammo usage was high, and eventually I was running around punching everything with characters spec’ed for ranged combat. If you don’t explore everywhere and carefully manage your ammo, you are in for a hard time. Don’t forget your shovel, safe-cracker, and toaster repair expert!Despite, or perhaps because of, the difficulty, I find myself continually thinking about the game and wondering what is next. If you like turn based combat and don’t mind having to work for victory it is worth getting. Just don’t go in expecting a Fallout clone because its an entirely different game.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
8, 2016
												 Doing some reviews today and wanted to add my "positive" voice to this.      As has been said many times it's the spiritual successor to Fallout 1 and 2.   It retains the top down, tactical approach to gaming that old school fans of fallout remember. But let's be fair, this isn't fallout and so judge it accordingly.It's a modern version of the top down RPG.   Like the old D&D Goldbox games or Baulders Gate, you create a team to tackle an unknown threat to Arizona.      It does retain the open world quality and your choices on who you help do have consequences in "the end" (wink wink).  While I will recommend this game, I do acknowledge there's something of a feeling of it could or should be more.   That may have more to do with the kickstarter funds available and just how much game you can make for a given budget.   Still, as you can see by the hours spent on this game (roughly 200) there's plenty of stuff to do to get your money's worth.     One nice thing is that you do have options.    For example, hacking enemy robots to gain a numbers advantage for your team.   Or you can play your conversations Hard ♥♥♥, or Smart ♥♥♥.      Of course witha 4+ many team, you can have enough character builds to try out all these options while still having a unique characters compared to something like Fallout 4 where you level up so much that you basically create a person with "every" option and they cease to be unique at all. Personally I enjoy the idea of playing sides against each other and squeeking out those unique "perfect" resolutions if you're willing to try (and retry) all the options.   Based on that, I felt some pangs of dissapointment when it appeared the game design intentially forced me to choose one or the other even though "both" options were clearly visible and should have been an executible choice.       Visually it was passable.   It would definately been nice to have more unique artwork, or skipped that completely for more player face/body models.    Again it feels like going back to the 80's when the D&D games would reuse the same visual art work to represent mutliple people.      It's a minor criticism but one of those things that helps to pull you out of the experience.       All in all, if you like top down, tactical, RPG gaming with consequences for your actions, and you have 20 bucks (summer sale) give it a try.    Hopefully InXile will have pulled together enough money from this first forey to do a more expanded, enriched world with another Wasteland title.    Kind of how Fallout 2 expanded beyond Fallout 1.

												An RPG in the classic styling.  One of the more fun turn based RPG's i have ever played. The combat is decent but to me the game shines for it's story, and the way skills work are well done.  I'd put this game up there with any of the top RPG's i have ever played, especially if you are the sort of person that likes topdown, party based games.  Learning how to build a team is key, but there are guides around for that. Over all i'd give it a solid 8/10. My reasoning is there is always a bit of room for imporvemnt, like greater customization. It also could use a few more deeper choices or branching story lines, but it does have many already so it is more nit picking thatn a flaw. Id really love to see a wasteland 3 down the road, or another style game using a similar system.As far as polish goes, i have yet to have a single crash, or encounter a bug that stopped a quest in over 100 hours of play. It would seam like they have ironed out the early bugs quite nicely.

												As you may have noticed I played it only for like a 20 hours, which can make this "review" less legit. Or, maybe more legit.I backed this game on the Kickstarter, but after few updates I had this bothersome feeling that it won't end well. And it didn't, IMHO.After 20 hours, I didn't experience any memorable event or interesting quest. Not a single one.After 20 hours, I didn't visit any interesting location or fight any enjoyable battle. Not a single one.There is just nothing interesting or enjoyable in the game. There is no atmosphere. It's a post apocalyptic game, and there is no atmosphere. I mean come on, how is that even possible? Even Failout 3 had atmosphere FFS.The dialogues are more often than not boring or unnecessary. Characters are unmemorable, generic, boring. And the game is hideous. I don't care about the graphics, but I honestly can not think of uglier game I played in past decade. There is a lot of skills, that's nice. But most of them are completely redundant. There is 25 thousand skills for different kind of weapons. But no skill for throwing "weapons". So you have lvl 7 assault rifles skill and 80% chance to hit. And you have no skill with throwing grenades but you'll always hit the exact spot.When you want to open a safe, you need a demolition skill, disable alarm skill and safesomething skill (You don't always need all of them, but a combination of them more often than not). You need to switch between them and repeat until you are successful. I have to say that I enjoy the thought of having many different skills for different occasions. But not this huge number of unnecessary skills.I don't like the combat system either. When a melee enemy comes to you and you have a firearm, you immediately gain huge penalty and you have like a 15% chance to hit. So you have to run and shoot, which is just unbelievably stupid. And he will come to you in one turn without any problem.When you have 3% chance to jam your weapon, the weapon will jam every 5 turns. When you have 87% chance to hit the target, you will miss 2-3 out of 5. When you have 18% chance to hit the target, you will hit 2-3 out of 5.The game is throwing huge number of enemies at you most of the time, so the fights are long and boring. There is no excitement there. None what so ever.I honestly can't find a single nice thing about this game, so I won't waste my time.

												Wasteland 2 is not, perhaps, a great game. A thousand tiny things swirl around inside it, each bothering me a bit; like the aribitrarily obscure solutions to some puzzles.But whenever I play Wasteland 2, those problems melt away. I love it. It's one of my favorites, actually.It's very much like the early fallout games crossed with Fallout Tactics (which I thought had lots of promise but didn't play well.) It's descended from Fallout's grandpappy, too, which makes for nice continuity nods if you played the C64 original.Wasteland 2 is a squad based RPG largely set in the ruins of post-nuclear Arizona. Your squad of 4 Desert Rangers set out to find the meaning of mysterious radio signals, and uncover a sinister plot that could end the world a second time. In practice, the plot is a bit flimsy, but it provides a decent core for the weird people you'll meet in the wasteland-Pistol Packin' Priests being my personal favorite.Besides combat, which plays out nicely, you'll need a wide variety of skills to traverse the wasteland-Conversational skills to talk your way to the better solutions, brute force to smash walls, computer science, toaster repair and so on.I find myself having a hard time coming up with more to write. Please, if you're here take the time to watch the videos above. My time spent should tell you that I'm no casual when it comes to this game.As much as I love it, the price is pretty steep right now. Wait until it goes on sale. It's good, but I don't think you'll get your money's worth at full price.

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
20, 2016
												Wasteland 2 Director's Cut is an isometric CRPG where you lead a group of 4 player characters that you create (or you can take premade characters), level up, and control and up to 3 additional NPC followers that you level up and control. The story is the continuation of the original Wasteland story from the classic original game that won numerous game of the year awards when it was released back in late 1980s. Like the original Wasteland, Wasteland 2 has received numerous awards and accolades, especially in the RPG category.The Director's Cut version of Wasteland 2 improves graphics from the original Wasteland 2 game, but even with improvements the graphics are functional but not particularly exciting. I did notice a nice increase in the number of voiced comments by NPCs that bring out more of their personalities and morality. The view is isometric and combat is turn based. You will spend most of your time in this game doing one of these things. - Moving from place to place- Talking to NPCs to receive and solve quests- Fighting turn based combats, including random combats as your travel from place to place- Digging and opening stuff- Managing inventoryThese elements combine to create a game with lots of content that will take 60-80 hours to complete if you don't skip content. That said this game does become a grind at times as combat, movement, inventory management, and talking to NPCs can become tedious at times. I found that I stopped bothering to pick up inventory items to sell because dealing with the inventory management wasn't worth the money I would get from selling it. I also found things like digging up mounds of dirt with a shovel to be a very tedious mechanic and stopped doing it and stopped opening chests that didn't promise high end items to avoid the time it took to complete these tedious activities. That said, there's a good overall story and some good side stories, and some interesting and tough combats (how tough depends on the game difficulty you select - if you play on Rookie, you probably won't be challenged by the combat). There are also lots of different ways that problems can be resolved that impact the final outcome and the ending you receive. This also provides some replayability because you can take different paths through different parts of the game. Overall I enjoyed Wasteland 2 DC, and am recommending it. It was clearly a labor of love for the developers and I appreciate the fact that many of the original designers came back to create this sequel over 25 years later. My guess is that people who played the original Wasteland game (as I did) will enjoy this updated version of the game that continues the original story. If you never played the original game, and you're judging this game on its own merits, my guess is it will be a mixed bag that some will enjoy because it's a solid CRPG and some will not because they find parts of the game too tedious. If you generally like isometric, turn-based CRPGs, I would recommend you buy and play this game, but if you're not sure wait for it to go on sale. If you like fast paced games or more of an ARGP experience, this game may not appeal to you.

number of helpful: 37 of 68 people (54%) found this review helpful21 people found this review funny
content:
r 23, 2015
												Billed as the spiritual successor to the original isometric Fallout games, the Wasteland 2 that we have today is the result of 3 years and 3 million dollars' worth of work. And it shows:The new graphics are based on an innovative new rendering system that builds characters and environments using nothing but jaggies, bringing to life a rich and vibrant world of faded browns and greens. Despite the 3D graphics, the bold choice of camera angle in the game restricts your view to only a tiny rectangular area of the game world at a time, at times feeling like the top-down perspective of the 1988 release - something that should go quite well with inXile's nostalgia-based marketing. In essence, they've managed the herculean feat of combining unattractive low-budget 3D graphics with a visually uninformative, claustrophobic old-school style, and the results speak for themselves.Which brings me to the next point I wanted to discuss: the interface. Now, I love games like Darklands and Dwarf Fortress not because of the sheer breadth of possibilities and amount/variety of content that they offer, but because I'm a masochistic chump who enjoys the feeling of eyestrain, befuddlement and constant annoyance. In that sense, Wasteland 2 was perfect for me as a game in that regard - as it's managed to combine the obtuse, archaic interface design of those aforesaid games with the gameplay of a straightforward and mediocre RPG. I was worried that the Director's Cut might excise this feature from the re-release, so imagine my relief when I started the game and found it nearly impossible to buy or sell items! Folks, this wasn't even something that was a problem in the original release - you can tell that they really went the distance here.But, when you get down to it, all of that stuff is just window dressing when it comes to an RPG. The two things that really matter are the gameplay and the story. Where's Wasteland 2 stand on that? Well, the gameplay's your standard fare - you click on guys that you want your guys to shoot. There's also enemies that explode on death so that four guys with clubs isn't the most optimal party. That's the extent of the tactical gameplay.Roleplaying-wise, Wasteland 2 is very limited. Your party members are all interchangeable, and your communicative options are extremely limited as a consequence. For the most part, skills don't really factor into things beyond being used on objects to get extra loot. Your party does go around resolving conflicts and righting wrongs, and there's even a handful of world-affecting decisions you can make. It's got some interesting bits of world-building and story elements, and I feel that the story is genuinely interesting, if unexceptional - after all, as my friend Manco says, fight one megalomaniac with a messiah complex and you've fought 'em all. As an aside, you can tell how unimportant the characters are by the fact that there are only about four portraits per gender by default (and only two genders? inXile could stand to learn a thing or two about cis privilege I think) but I'm willing to excuse this because you can play as the Madoka Magica crew if you import your own portraits.All in all, Wasteland 2 is extremely disappointing. For all the hype it's gotten, it is ugly, limp and flaccid. Out of all the more recent RPG releases, Divinity: Original Sin has funner tactical combat and Shadowrun: Dragonfall has a much better story. That said, I kind of liked it - I don't really regret backing this game, despite my disappointment, and I enjoyed the time I spent playing it. However, I still wouldn't recommend it to another human being, unless they're also the kind of weirdo that feels the need to play every isometric cRPG in existence, in which case they probably wouldn't even listen to me if I told them not to play this game.Also, the music's pretty decent.Overall, I'd give this release an outrageously disgraceful 7/10

content:
5, 2015
												I pre-ordered this and I really really wanted to like it. Unfortunately there is not a lot to love. I know with the onset of roguelike RPG's there seems to be a consumer market for old-school difficult games but there is a fundamental difference between difficult and inconvenient. Wasteland 2 isn't that difficult it is just extremely inconvenient. Spammy and monotonous battles on the main map, no useful fast travel for getting from one area to another, and writing that, while definitely serviceable (sometimes funny), just doesn't stack up against other major RPGs. The combat is boring as hell, the upgrades system is weak and uninteresting, and there is little depth (though they can be interesting) to the few characters you can pick up that do have characterization (the main group you use is a blank slate with zero characterization). When you compare this to Kickstarter RPG's such as Pillars of Eternity there is just no comparison. Pillars of Eternity (which I am using as a comparison because it is also a kickstarter) is just a fundamentally better game.  Sure the graphics are crap (what do you expect from a kickstarter game?) but the plot, characters, upgrade system and combat is infinitely (haha pun) better. This is not a horrible way to kill time but there are just a lot better ways to kill it.

Early Access Review
								 I'm not a big fan pf paying for "early access", However, being a huge Fallout fan, and loving everything post apocalyptic, (well most everything, if its done well I should say), I went ahead and paid the 60$. content:
3, 2015
												I paid $10 for it and I feel ripped off.  Your 95% to hit is really about 40%, and the levelling system is ponderous at best. As others have said, the voice acting is atrocious.  The game plays better without it, but that doesn't help all that much because the text is boring to read.  The movement is slow and lanky.  It really ruins immersion when I'm bored and watching my guys move ponderously slow.  This game has too many serious flaws to be worth playing. The levelling system is seriously just painfully bad. You get 23 attribute points, and you get 2-5 skill points depending on how many of your attribute points you put into Intelligence.  You can't raise your attributes later on.  So if you put half your attributes into intelligence, then you cripple your combat skills so you can get enough survival skills end-game. First skill level takes 1 point, 2nd takes 2, 3rd takes 3, etc. You have 4 characters and you can get an npc.  You will need to level 10 non-combat skills to open doors, see traps, upgrade weapons, etc.  Another few skills if you want to get good use out of your medical supplies.  If you're a big fan of games like these, check out the Avernum line of games or X-COM: Enemy Unknown.     You can get Avernum on sale for $1-3  and it is far superior.

												EDIT for Enhanced Edition:Still buggy and unoptimized. Buy it if you are a patient person and the price drops to 10 EUR. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------According to devs, it is finished and they are just fixing bugs (the final patch will not invalidate saves, but it may damage them - release date is 19.9.2014). So, the time has come to make a judgment (preliminary since I did not finish the game, yet).Well, it is a difficult to decide, if I should recommend this or not.I will judge based on playing a lot of computer games, especially role-playing ones, but tactical, TBS, RTS and plenty more, too. First of all, I consider Fallout 2 with Restoration Project from Killap (I bow before this guy) as a kind of standard. I did play the original Wasteland, all Fallouts (F1, F2, Tactics, F3, Vegas).Right at this moment, this game is a disappointment for me (because I had very high expectations). The combat is comparable to Tactics (FT being better for me, but it is a matter of taste) and the role-playing part is worse than F2. It's a mixture, but it seems to me that the focus is on tactical combat with some RP decision making.It is not a bad game compared to what is produced these days. I just hoped that it would be so much better. There are some things – even in combat – that take away the immersion for me. So, if you liked Tactics, go for it – but not for the current ridiculous price. If you like more role-playing I would wait till the game is modded (fingers crossed) and there is a sale.Graphics is OK, nothing groundbreaking, but it does the job.Audio is OK, there no catchy tune in my mind, yet – but it corresponds to the setting.I would like to note that there may be something along the story that will change my mind. I will update after I finish the game (I will also go into more details about those little pesky things like the enemies with infinite ammo; they don’t drop stuff they were using in combat, etc.).

r 10, 2014
												After finishing the game (70 Hours) here is my verdict.Gameplay/Gameplay is one of the most aspects that drive my judjment towrd any game, the more solid the gameplay and polished the more i invest my self with it.The battle system doesn't offer much of creativity or presenting a new ideas, compering it to XCOM Enemy Unknown which has a simillar battle system, though the latter is better in that aspect.The AI in this game is highly underdeveloped, enemies with ranged weapons would charge towrd you despite that it will hinder thier accuracy and hit chances and they don't seem to use the environment In their favor that much, like cover for instance.The difficulty spikes seems to be absent most of the time regarding that you know what you're doing. I have't encounter any impossible situation that hinderd my progress. All of the hard encouters is doable with a will excuted strategy ofcurse.Nice and will implemented skills system that add a decent and rich experiance._____Graphics and Sounds/I don't usually mind graphics in games too much, but I do agree it gives a nice boost to the game experiance.Graphicly the game is not emprassive at all, varrying between a poor characters design and a moderate enviroment design.yet there is some nice areas that have some depth on them.The sounds generally is fairly good, but the game lack variety in the soundtrack department. _____Story and Writting/Likable strory with some nice twists and a bold and brilliant writting.The strongest features in this game is the writting and it's quist line.The game Intelligently combine decision making with your team's skills to progress through the game, making every playthrough a different experince.It sometimes present a deep and philosophical ideas but somehow faild to present it properly._____The technical sideUnfortunately the game doesn't excel technically, starting with massive frame drop and graphical glitches.In the first half of the game the frame rate average at ~90 FPS then drop dramatically in the second half at average of ~35 FPS (680 GTX OC).A lot of the time the game won't responds to mouse ckicks when initiating skills command.____

content:
r 22, 2015
												This is NOT a review of the Director's Cut. I'll get to the "why?" later on.Let's start by saying that I bought WL2 not long after release without looking into it too much... Everyone was praising this game, reviews were all positive...At the time it suffered some (*A LOT OF) bugs, some of them gamebreaking. So I had to put it aside for some time. When I took it back, the bugs had been fixed (at least the ones that plagued my playthrough), so I went on...The game wasn't as good as I expected it to be, but at the time I needed something to relax after more action-oriented games, and this one, for some time, suited my needs.It quickly bored me though. It was super repetitive and combat was so boring... but I wanted to see if, progressing through the game, things would have changed.I had to stop again when I read about the upcoming Director's Cut: better graphics (wow that was needed!), reworked gameplay, perks, quirks, body parts aiming à la fallout... oh and CONTROLLER SUPPORT!!! That's what I needed! A relaxing game that could be played on my big tv while lying on the couch!So I waited. And waited. And finally it came out.So going back to the opening of my review, why isn't this a review of the long awaited DC? That's quite simple... because I didn't had the chance to try it yet.CONTROLLER SUPPORT (my top feature): moving my guys is impossible.They do half a step at a time. Animation is broken and movement is slow and clunky as hell. I google for a few seconds and see that I'm not the only one experiencing this.They say that turning the graphics to minimum settings resolves the issue.IT'S TRUE! IT WORKS NOW!Just, the game, which already didn't look good, looks even worse now.Ok, nevermind, let's ignore graphics and let's enjoy all the amazing improvements this version introduces...CRASH TO DESKTOP.Ok, nevermind, let's reload and try again.10 minutes in, CRASH TO DESKTOP!AGAIN AND AGAIN!And googling around I see that I'm not the only one. And it's not the only bug. for example, a known issue concerns dismissed followers who, instead of going back to base waiting to be recruited again, just disappear...At the moment I don't even want to try any workaround as I personally think such release status is unacceptable even for an indie/small team game.I'll sure wait for some updates (they already had one out, but it did just address the zoom level of the camera as far as I understand...)TO ANYONE THINKING TO BUY THIS:The price is high. Too high in my opinion. If you really want to get this mess I advice you to wait for a 50% sale, at least.But keep in mind: in less than one week Divinity: Original Sin - Enhanced edition's gonna be out and I think it will be a much wiser purchase.Otherwise you can stick to this buggy-1998-looking-mindless-turn-based-combat-no-magic-no-combat-skill-no-real-options-besides-shooting-and-hoping-to-hit-even-if you're-on-95%-hit-chance game.EDIT: in 1998 games looked better than this one. Yes, Baldur's Gate, I'm thinking about you. I MISS YOU!
