r 11, 2014
Some of you know that our own indie After Reset[afterreset.com] was born in the moment when we simply got tired of waiting for a true old-school Fallout 3 (Van Buren), in the moment when we understood that no one other than us, the gamers would do that. For a long time we were left with a very skeptical mood toward Wasteland 2… And it lasted until last week, when we got its release version on Steam.Guys, it turned out to be very interesting! I.e., this game, of course doesn’t have anything in common with either Fallout 1&2&T, or with After Reset RPG… But it doesn’t even have to be like them, or even be a classic RPG. It has its own interesting style/setting/mechanics/gameplay… In general, I personally don’t understand what exactly its secret is, but it’s really cool and fun to play. I played all weekend without stopping (and there’s no end or border in this game), and I’ll be very happy to back Wasteland 3!One nuance: two times in the beginning I thought of deleting the game after creating a character (a sentiment I’ve heard from plenty of gamer friends). I really didn’t like the character portraits, and I don’t like to play as a big faceless group. But Brian Fargo has slyly provided for the ability to load your own portraits and delete the others besides your own character from the group. We’ve prepared a character portrait pack from After Reset especially for you: http://indiedb.com/games/after-reset/downloads/after-reset-rpgs-custom-avatars-for-wasteland-2.I’m sure that even if you’ve had doubts, with our pack, Wasteland 2 will sparkle with fresh colors for you! You have to play it; the game is really worth it!- Richard Nixon, Black Cloud Studios, http://afterreset.com

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 20, 2014
												Is Wasteland 2 up to spec?  No, sadly, it is not.As a squad-based RPG, it feels more like FO:Tactics than Wasteland.  There is a storyline, but the actual roleplay suffers from the lack of a central character.  You end up with less of a Fallout-style Jack of All Trades and more of a set of specialists that feels stale.The game also seems unfinished, with many bugs still present and most problems have one real solution and a bunch of approaches to it.  The conversation choices are just garnish and a lot of interactions will result in being attacked without a chance to explain or talk it out.  Prepare to be frustrated by a game that looks more modern, but lacks depth (plenty of breadth, though).It's been covered in other reviews, but here are the basic issues with this over-specialization:-You have to constantly switch between party members for each task (lockpicking, safecracking, defusing, disabling) and wait for each to have a small loading icon to complete the task.  The delay between selection, the poor controls, and having to swap between them makes it tedious.  All for an old teddy bear, a used polaroid, and some scrap metal (not a joke, this is the kind of loot you will be seeing a lot of).-Success at these skills yields XP, but only to the party-member who does it.  This means that your demo guy will be getting a lot more, as almost everyone in the wastes seems to have the knowledge, supplies, and desire to trap everything.-Some weapons types are so situationally specific as to be obnoxious (looking at you shotgun and heavy weapons).  Others have handicaps that don't make sense (an assault rifle suffers a penalty to hit when a target is adjacent, which the AI exploits by rushing a group of heavily armed people with an axe).-You have to micro-manage prior to combat to ensure that your weapons are optimally employed, but it is often a matter of getting interrupted by the enemy spotting you (no, there is no "sneak" option either) and having combat kick off prematurely while you awkwardly select and move your personnel.-NPCs (to include hire-ons) have a tendency to go rogue, ruining your carefully-crafted team composition and plan.  This usually means rushing out of cover and often shooting past teammates, hitting them in the process.  Tag-alongs (like animal friends or story characters) are always in this AI pattern, making you leave your positions to take the heat off of them.Now let's talk about design.-Levels are often open areas with little or nothing to do in them.  A few stashes (with locks, tumblers, alarms, and traps... whee!) or cliche'd NPCs and a lot of walking in-between.  You keep looking, using your perception skill, to try to find SOMETHING there, but the return is rarely worth the effort.-The AI.  It's horrible, devolving into people with guns rushing into range and often sharing cover with the enemy (in some cases, side-by-side).-Difficulty.  Harder levels just mean more HP and armor for the enemies and higher levels required for defusing, unlocking, etc.  Just a waste of time, as it makes the game tedious and not challenging.-Combat is disappointing.  While they did add "headshot" as a choice, the fights seem to be somewhat formulaic and the level design does not make for interesting cover-based shootouts or flanking.  It feels somewhat stale and would have benefitted from the location-based targeting of the Fallout series.  Also, the incidence of shooting friendlies is too high, making it a common occurence when AI starts rushing.  APs are too few to attempt to run around and you really don't have many options or any selectable skills to make it tactical.-The UI is clunky.  Rather than have selectable portraits at a fixed point, when you open the inventory/skill screen, it pops up a new set.  Baldur's Gate did not suffer from this issue, so why move in this direction?  When you open your skills screen to level up, the bars don't always load and you have to scroll to force it to do so.  There is also a delay when opening this screen, despite the relatively simple nature of its display.-The engine has issues with mouse-based selection, with items blocking your click with a transparent "hit box" (this happens with both terrain and mobs).  There are also times when the game does not register a click.  Not a deal-breaker, just makes the game feel less polished.-Movement honestly feels worse than in Wasteland.  I preferred the grid-based precision that the original had to the click and watch a throng of morons push past each other.  The ability to set up formations would be a welcomed solution (again, Baldur's Gate had this...).I'm disposed to complain, but here is the up-side:+The game seems pretty long and there are a lot of locations to visit (even if their maps are too bland).+There is a weapon mod system in which you can recover parts of a weapon (though it seems odd that it's random what you get).+The conversation system shows you what skills you would need to select what options, setting it up for future play-throughs in which you can make informed decisions regarding new NPC skills.+No crashes to date.  Despite some clunkiness, they seem to have made it very stable.+Some elements of the original remain and it is kinda neat to see how things have changed since.+The millieu is interesting, if limited.  There remain a lot of quests, both cliches and refreshing.If you liked Fallout Tactics, you will be right at home.  If you like Fallout 1&2, you might be a little underwhelmed.  If you're looking to recapture that Wasteland feeling...  Well, it's there in some storyline nods, but the gameplay has changed significantly.The sum is greater than its somewhat-flawed presentation.  You will get your money's worth if you stick with it, but there will be moments of aggravation.

content:
ber 24, 2014
												Let me get one thing out of the way first: I do recommend this game, I think it's great and it makes me feel like I'm playing the original Fallouts again... BUT. I had very high hopes for it initially, I wanted it to be a worthy successor to Fallout 2 and it just falls short in comparison for several reasons.The first thing I noticed is that the locations are graphically very busy but their size encourages to view them with the camera zoomed out all the way. This sometimes makes it hard to make out items of interest like NPC, chests and doors, I often find myself scanning the screen with my mouse, hoovering over everything trying to find something I could have missed. It's often also hard to see how high a given structure is or where are the characters allowed to walk, this is also due to the camera rotating freely and the levels not being designed to be viewed from a certain fixed perspective.My second gripe is the dialogue system, there are no dialogue trees and instead you always have a list of topics a given NPC can tell you more about, this makes talking feel much less impactful. I do love however that there is not one but three talking skills that might come handy at different times, hard-♥♥♥, smart-♥♥♥ and kiss-♥♥♥, each of which unlocks different replies that might change the outcome of a conversation.Another thing is the level design which often feels streamlined with one path leading you from start to end of a level. This is not always the case and there are some great non-linear locations, but I feel the Fallouts did a better job at this.Lastly, I don't really feel there are that many impactful choices in the game, NPC interactions often just lead you to the one expected outcome and 12 hours in I think there was only one meaningful choice I had to make.Still it's a very solid game. The combat is pretty deep, with positioning playing an important role. The skill selection is awesome, every one feels very important and comes in handy more often than not. There is an element of crafting, you can apply upgrades to weapons or strip them for parts. Trying to optimise your team build to cover the whole spectrum of skills and to be effective in combat is fun in itself, and you can always ignore some skills and concentrate on others (for example you don't need lockpicking and safecracking much if you know how to use explosives or brute force). I also like how non-initial party members always have a chance of going 'out of control' during combat and shooting an enemy of their choice instead of letting you issue orders, this effect can be mitigated with the leadership skill.All in all I don't regret backing it on Kickstarter and I haven't played such a good RPG in a very long time, but still it could have been much more.EDIT: After finishing the game I have to admit that there is indeed quite a lot of interesting choices in it, the longer you play, the more of them you see. I highly recommend this game if you enjoyed Fallout 1/2 and Torment.

												This isn't Fallout or even like the original Wasteland but still packs hours of solid RPG fun.I gravitate toward games with similar setting since while I enjoy RPGs, I'm not usually a fan of fantasy settings most RPGs are in. So I certainly have a built in bias for this sort of game. I still think people would generally find the game to be worth their time due to solid story, good mechanics, and generally good support.The game isn't flawless of course. It does have a bit of balance issue in regard to class and weapons, but you can say that about 99% of the games really. I personally found the combat system interesting, building on the Fallout style turn-based tactical combat and adding new elements like speed. Though I think thrown weapon aspect was bit too simplified. The character creation also is a bit on the simple side, lacking a bit of depth and true specialization.All that said, I don't think none of the negatives really prevented me from enjoying the game throughout the playthrough, but I can see it being a more glaing negative if you're a fan of hard-core RPGs.

												This was the year of the RPG and this was one I was really looking forward to. A strong pitch which felt like it laid out realistic goals, along with a spokesman who was hitting all the right notes. Yet what they delivered was so very bland. A combat heavy game with an incredibly shallow TBS component, one where it felt you did little more than maximise your damage each turn and terrain had little to no impact. Compared to Shadowrun Returns/Dragonfall, which had built their entire editor around creating good combat layouts, this was weaksauce.More than that though, the characters and story were dull. You have a team of nobodies, which would be fine if you had a strong combat system to back it up. The personalities you do collect are at a Baldur's Gate 1 level, and less memorable than those. Not one of the NPCs, party or otherwise, stands out.It just all came together to form a rather dull experience, and after a while I found I just sort of stopped playing. I couldn't find anything to motivate me to push on. That the primary mystery is spoiled during a joke death scene was just the icing on the cake.It leaves me worried for Torment.

content:
15, 2014
Early Access Review
								OK, this shows promise and as a fan of the first Wasteland I really like the walk down memory lane.The first few hours of game play were,however, a bit frustrating to say the least.***MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS***So you get this mission to check out a radio tower. The problem is if you don't go there straight away and roam a little you trigger this new quest line of either going to Highwater or some agricultural station. Your 'boss' tells you that these calls have priority over you initial mission, so off you go!Problem is, you automatically fail one of them. While you're exploring some hydro-plant which is about to fail you get this desperate radio calls from the other mission, how they're overrun but you can do nothing about it as the hydro-plant is about to explode. Moreover, prior to the power plant mission you get some side quests which ALL fail if you don't do them first. Basically, I saved the town's power plant from destruction but the grateful people of Highwater kicked me out of town because I did not kill the bandits first, found a dog and put out a fire for them. Consequently, the wrong person gets the votes to be the new mayor. He's all in with the bandits and tells me to get the hell out of town.Basically, after six hours of game play I'm a total failure. Is this a feature? I don't know. Maybe this game is about priorities but the jumps in the quest system seem contrived and lack immersion this way. Non-linear is OK but if you simply say 'If you don't do missions A,B and C before D then they must have failed!' is a bit sloppy in terms of story-telling to me.***END SPOILERS***Apart from that you pretty much get a product as advertised: An isometric sequel to Wasteland 1. It is all there! The setting, the desolate arid lands, the radiation zones, the bandits and mutants and all those old-school turn-based combat fights. The skill system is almost pen&paper-like but does the trick. The item system is working as intended. I really like how easy you could set up hot buttons and point and click your way to skill checks and interactions.I did have a hard time getting used to camera controls and setting up teams of party members but that might be my inexperience at work here.Bottom line: As a fan of the original Wasteland, you will not want to miss this, but the game does confront you with certain constraints you might not consider acceptable in a modern open world setting.But what do you get if you deduct the fandom? Not sure about that at this stage of development. I will restart the story with my utter and complete failure in mind and update my verdict.As for now I think you get a better chunk of post-apocalyptic America for your bucks from Fallout 3/New Vegas games.We'll see.......

ber 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								The good:++++ Incredible artwork (portraits, areas, ... )+++ Good writing: dialogue, storyline++ Impressive game Atmosphere: created by the music, the in game artwork/colours & mature environment.++ Game for adults: doesn't shy away from credible violence like seen in Mad max movies or a little bit of controversial violence and adult themes++ A lot of nice variation in environment locations (official ones)+++++ Originality (Tons of good original ideas: like the mad monks f.e.)++++++ The only old school RPG released at this date. It s not hard to be the best when you re the only one competing for the title, but despite the lack of competition for being the best Old school RPG the game is pretty damn good at becoming something as memorable as the Fallout 1 & 2 games where for me. (Not talking about Bethesda s version of Fallout as that is clearly a different game: more an adventure game like Oblivion). Fallout 1 & 2 fans will feel right at home, not having played wasteland 1 I can not speak for Wasteland 1 fans.The bad:---- Combat turn based isn't as good as in the latest Xcom game, could use a lot of improvement. But this isn't the focus of the game, so that s ok. ----- Random encounters not always as good. But I guess these can be improved later with patches to improve them.------ Learning Curve: Hard to figure out for new players how to build your characters: f.e. in the build screen it isn't obvious that low intellingence will cap the progress of your surgeon skill/ other skills or that strength lvl 4 is needed to wear certain types of armour. You will need several tries before you will figure out what is a good party and what isn't and which attributes go well together with each other and with which other skills. Maybe that s why this game has a manual: but to be honest, I never read the manual for playing a game (I try to figure it out on the go)It would be nice to see in a blink of an eye which attributes affect which skills and how. Or how f.e. group charisma has an effect to inviting new companions.

								(probably Spoilers)My hours may say I've had 66 hours but I'll be honest and say about 6 of those hours are from falling asleep due to playing this game non-stop. Are there bugs, yes, but from what what I noted they were minimal and most have been address if not noted on the many dev forums. Let me say this, Wasteland to me is a breath of fresh air to me in regards to gaming, I'm a fan of the original Fallout 1 and 2 and will admit to have never playing the original Wasteland. This game left me wondering something about myself, I've never really been able to get into Turned based combat RPG save for a few. For instance I can't get into any of the X-COM series...There's nothing wrong with the games, Maybe I just like post apocalypse more than aliens I guess. Every time in this game I had an idea about, I wonder if i can do this, the answer usually was yes, could I avoid contact with damn near all the wild life, due to animal wispers ability, damn near. Did it pay off to be skilled in toaster repair, sometimes. Finding out I could reprogram robots instead of fighting them everytime sure helped. On almost every instance I encountered someone the game has an option for the pasifits. Did I kill A LOT of people and things, oh god yes. But along the way the game has left you with so many options by the time I hit the "endgame" I had over 8 followers with me. I guess I can get 10 somehow, But from what I've seen I've gone over the entire map. But that's fine for me, I've seen everything however, not in EVERYWAY I can see it. Some of my crew were idiots who could take more than 4 steps in the game and were total meat heads, BUT could punch you in half and just walked around were the most perceptive of my crew. In the end I had a very Niave boy, a drunken hobo (who activily stole liquor from other crew members), a mutant horror that loved candy, a man who  Inever found out who is is other than I think a robot speaking in latin phrases and a goat that gave my animal lover a buff along with the people I actually created.Yes there is still room for much improvement which I can almost be assured is coming in the next couple weeks. Would I love to see body part by body part targeting. More story, more things to do, yes, but I must remember this is a ♥♥♥♥ing wasteland, so to want a heavily filled wasteland is kinda oximorinc. It's great for what it is now. and I can say for my money equalling now $1 for every hour I've played. I'd say yes totally worth it, also knowing that where I left off in the game it's whats known as the half way point. Holy ♥♥♥♥ I can't wait. Hell I'd pay a subscription to keep a steady flow of this, to find more of america or the world for that matter. GG guys thank you for making this!

content:
ber 19, 2014
												Full disclosure: I backed the Kickstarter and I've played during the beta.Wasteland 2 may look a bit iffy on the graphics end and there are some bugs that haven't been fixed yet (although I haven't seen anything gamebreaking yet) but quality can be found in just about everything else.This game is basically made for anyone who was a big fan of the old Fallout games (1 and 2) and possibly the first Wasteland game that came out in 1988. You take the role of four desert rangers who have been tasked with traveling to different areas in Arizona to help people in need in a world where nuclear war has taken place and is now... well, a Wasteland. The world is ridden with radioactivity, punks, fanatics, cyborgs, the list goes on.Wasteland 2 is a roleplaying turn-based strategy game. You have the ability to move about as either a group or split your team members up for tactical advantages. For example, mabye one of your team members is a sniper and you want that person to stay behind and pick off the enemies while your mid to close range characters take the front line. Be careful though since this game has friendly fire.As you start you get to create your four characters in a typical roleplaying game fashion. Place stats, choose skills, names, looks, etc. It can be very tricky to pick the right skills for each character because there are many skills to choose from and you won't be able to pick them all and still be able to use them all effectively since there won't be enough points for you to distribute for such a run. You will quickly notice that there are occasional obstacles that will require a quite high level in whatever skill is needed.One of my favourite aspects of Wasteland 2 is the text that is constantly being displayed in the lower right corner of the screen. Just like in the Fallout games, it details your surroundings, people you meet, objects, etc, just as if it was being told by a very witty game master in a pen-and-paper roleplaying game. Wasteland 2 has lots of black comedy, and I'm a sucker for comedy in games. I generally don't read most flavour text in video games, but in Wasteland 2 I'm willing to make an exception.All in all, I'm glad to see that Wasteland 2 turned out the way it did because it proves that Kickstarter can work as long as you crowdfund the right projects. Anyone who played the older Fallout games or Wasteland 1 will most likely be very happy to play this. I would go as far as to call this the real Fallout 3.GOTY 2014.

content:
ry 2, 2015
												This game has been marketed on a lot of hype that is by large not true at all.Blatant lies about what the game contains and its features start from the trailers you can all see.The promises about destructive environment and infinite diversity of enemies are just blatant laughable lies.What that comes down is one or two small boxes you can shoot per fight, and barely a dozen different kinds of enemies, most of which are really mindbogglingly unimaginative.The more you go into it the more of PR lies you will discover.Game mechanics:Any Party you create will have ALL of the skills available in the game. There is no diversity or difference to parties anyplayer will create.You will get so many xp and levels and skill points that you will be able to cover everything you might need.In addition to that several skills are just superficial skill bloat, where what can be called a unique skill was simply split into several "different" ones.Some of those you really dont need at all, some only need a few points invested over the whole game, some are just pointless filler. If your team of seven rangers takes all of them - you will be bale to pump them all to levels more then sufficient for the game.The setting:There is no actual Post Apocalypse at all, its just inane, incoherent circus painted over with superficial PA "graphikz" and backgrounds - none of which play any deeper role in anything you will experience. Save one or two locations that are flukes in the overall design. It is true that Wasteland setting is a zany kind of post apocalypse, but that does not have to mean it should be cheap, superficial, incoherent and frankly speaking - stupid.There is no scarcity of anything in the game. In fact the gameworld has more stuff in it then our current civilization has.What you cannot find - you can easily buy -and you can get as much money as you want due to random encounters and other content available.All the factions and groups you encounter in the game are just ordinary everyday types of groups that were just put inside that incoherent circus backgrounds presenting itself as post apocalypse. There is about two exception here too - but those are mistakes and flukes, rather then what should be the norm.Writing:There are two general streams of writing in this game.The first are verbose dialogues and descriptions you can read in the dialogues, text box in the Ui and so on, but they dont really influence the design of quests and stories and events, nor the choices and consequences of the game. That kind of writing is nothing but a background noise to whats actually going on. Unrelated.Then there is the writing as design of the quests, areas, locations, characters and all and any choices and consequences, which is best described as continuous insults to intelligence, common sense and good taste. It is all incredible cheap schlock that most of TV soap operas actually surpass in quality.The game does not have anything else to balance this bad content. It is in fact all there is in the game.The fabled Reactivity:Is a constant stream of horrible inane schlock scripted sequences and events you cannot affect in any way. Here are some of the examples:- Whatever you choose between Ag center and Highpool you will get the same gameworld consequences for it.- Angela gets angry at you for shooting or killing civilians all the time and even leaves the party if you do, but kills some poor innocent trader for a completely nonsense reason - and that doesnt affect anything. And you cannot do anything about it.- Ralphie the idiot is drowning two meters from the dry ground (and he is actually standing in shallow water but they darkened it after i laughed at it). Next to that "lake" is a witness who rats on you if you try to help but choose the wrong option, but he never goes to help "poor" Ralphie.His Juliet doesnt try to help him but runs away to a completely empty area of the map - because thats where your team will magically arrive. Angie tells you how you must go and save him but if you just leave and dont do anything she doesnt react at all. And if you shoot the idiot yourself neither she or Vargas the telepathic wizard comment on it - but if you try to help and pick the wrong option they both berate you for it. Vargas is apparently stalking you all the time through the radio - only not. (dont ask)But if you do "save" Ralphie he and Juliet immediately go to a explosive rigged bicycle for more stupid schlock moments. (designed by the boss himself i hear)- Scotchmo (a companion NPC) attacks you if you try to dig the only unmarked grave in the graveyard, which is where he buried his wife recently.... and thats the only grave without a name or any marks on it. Right? Just so you try to dig it, then kill Scotchmo - then reload because the situation is completely stupid.- The ranger that sells you cheap weapons in the Citadel has a sister who had been ♥♥♥♥♥ because of his debt and now she is in hiding from that ♥♥♥♥♥♥, a stupid single schmuck who is supposed to be scary because they called him Pit Bull.So now the brother who is a ranger in a citadel full of high level rangers (dont ask) - is selling cheap malfunctioning weapons to...get the money...so she can pay not to be kidnapped and ♥♥♥♥♥ again by a single stupid bandit.... while her brother is a ranger in a Ranger Citadel full of high level rangers...(dont ask it hurts the head).- There is a woman in the prison area who is sick and begs you to KILL HER. You cannot do anything about it with any of your skills. Your forced schlock choice is to kill her or to do nothing so she dies. And then nothing happens.- There is a woman in Titans Canyon area that gets her legs blown off in an explosion and she begs you to KILL HER or LEAVE HER ALONE!!! - because thats what people who just got their legs blown off tend to do, right? You cannot do anything about it, your medic and surgeon can just stand there, suffering through the blindingly stupid schlock as you do.The main plot:Is the same unoriginal garbage as it was in original Wasteland. The evil robots want to kill everyone.If you try and play for them - you will just get force killed after a few minutes. Because.When you get to California all that happens is that the game resets and you just go through same stuff you were doing in Arizona.It first forces you into some pointlessly huge and completely empty "base" location, where all the high level rangers were killed by some stupid small doggies, and then you cannot leave that location until you go around and kill all the stupid doggies and plug some stupid holes in small walls around by clicking on them - and until you go and visit one of the two remaining rangers DYIIINNGG AARGHH. Of course, you cannot do anything about it with your skills.Then you go around collecting bags of cat liter... fixing radio towers and shooting stupid robots and cyborgs naked, since wearing any armor makes you take much more damage then without - versus energy weapons.The combat:Is a fairly simplified turn based that is as actiony and quick as possible in its mechanics. A few weapons may feel useless but nothing too bad there.Its huge problems come from horrible encounter design that repeats itself through the whole game and relying on enemy HP bloat of gigantic proportions to create a false sense of difficulty. Compared to beta, nothing changed at all except enemies were given three to four times more of health points.  The additional smaller bugs and the laughable armor design only serve to degrade it al even more. Enemies have no Ai whatsoever and its all one looooong repetition of always the same stuff.All locations and maps for combat are drowning in incoherent false cover props. Too much bad stuff to write all of it... out.

content:
14, 2016
												Just as a warning, this game starts off extremely frustrating. Ammo management can screw you over in the opening hours and you can easily make some mistakes in skill allotment that further set you back early on if you don't know what you're doing. I probably have 8-10 skill points I've completely wasted just because I wasn't sure exactly sure what to expect, which is sort of a bummer, but it is nice to have some consequences to your decisions.Some boss encounters are also really annoying, and can waste big chunks of unsaved progress. No spoilers or anything, but more than once I've just randomly had someone who I thought was a friend turn on me in the middle of a conversation and lay waste to my unprepared guys. Some auto-saves before these points would really be appreciated.That being said, once you get past the first 3-5 hours ammo is much easier to acquire (buy/loot, safecracking skill is very useful here) and you get much better and more diversified weapons, and the combat really opens up. Additionally, the world is interesting to explore. Great setting, great characters, and a very diverse set of areas/locations to traverse. It isn't afraid to be dark/macabre, which is a nice change of pace from more recent post nuclear war RPGs... The game does feel a little low budget, which is understandable given how it was made, but it's been fine as far as stability. I can't recall any crashes.Overall, a very good game. Frustrating initially, but when you get your hooks in it's a ton of fun. I was not expecting at all to sink this much time into it.

content:
y 29, 2015
												Wasteland 2 - a game that completly flew under my radar til it was discounted on the last Steamsale. Having played all FallOuts up til New Vegas with the Exception of Tactics I was genuinly interested how this game would work out. That and I'm a huge nerd over CRPGs, still considering Baldur's Gate II the best RPG ever developed. GameplayThe game is played from an Isometric perspective, with a typewriter on the right side describing the locations and subtitles. This game has ALOT of reading, so when you are no fan of that you should take that into consideration. Only a few important characters are voiced and your PCs are  mute all the time (Sadly we can not make our own basic voicelines like in Baldur's Gate, but hey atleast we can use our own portraits). You traverse the locations in realtime while the Worldmap has a water limitation and combat is turnbased. It is pretty much reminscent of FallOut 1&2 before the series became what is today. You travel through Arizona visiting the different locations and working towards your way to uncover a sinister plot.Story Warning: Heavy Spoilers ahead, read at your own risk You create your own Rangersquad, consisting from up to 4 Rangerrookies, with different talents which you will more or less all need in the Wastes. Rangergeneral Vargas then sends you to investigate the murder of one of your fellow Rangers paired with the quest to investiagte strange radiotransmissions coming from behind the great radioation wall to the east. While the games plot starts superstrong, it will degrade over time and if you hit Los Angeles later it will drag on longer than it should (Felt for me like it). As soon as you know who Mathias is and what is behind his "war" with Dugal the plot becomes more or less predictable and the end feels a bit unsatisfying. The proverb "The journey is the reward" pretty much sums it all up. Also for a game that starts strong in meaningful choices and their consequences it als degrades in that regard. There is no evil playthrough possibility and if you try to side with Mathias he will blow you up with a nuke. (I refer to FallOut here where the Master was more than happy to add you to his army) So you are pretty much forced into a Good-Guy-Role.It was not a bad plot, but it started way stronger than it finishedGrafics, Sound& MusicThe game was made in the Unity-Engine and is certainly not the prettiest one, but it does the job and all locations are unique and memorable. The sounddesign is well done and paired with the games music it can feel downright creepy at times, the perfect feeling for a post-apocalyptic game.All in All if you liked the old Fallout-titles or you are intrested in CRPGs Wasteland 2 is definatly worth a look, even if it can feel downright clunky sometimes yet it was modernized in the right way and I will definatly see forward to a 3rd installment

content:
4, 2014
Early Access Review
								Let me put it this way: it took 62 hours of playing before I decided to take a break from it, and I haven't had it but a couple of months. If you like old school turn based rpg stategy, such as Falloout 1 & 2, old X-Com, Jagged Alliance series, Balders Gate, Planescape: Torment (and somebody needs to gtf on with rebooting Torment, that game was !@#$ing GREAT!), you're going to want this in your collection. The story thus far is pretty damn good, in my opinion, voice acting is well done too. I think it looks great graphically, and I run a mid range gaming comp. Buy it now and help them make it great, or buy it on release, but get it. Seriously. Just understand it's a beta build and treat it as such and you will enjoy it if you like this kind of game, the bugs are not that bad, except for a couple I'll note below. .The random encounter battles as you travel on the world map are a little small in area, which makes combat down and dirty and  fast, if you're playing anything but Rookie difficulty. That can be a pro or con, depending on what you like and your play style. Feels cramped to me on the majority random encounter maps. It takes away from the strategy aspect when you're pretty much at point blank range in most of your battles, which are pretty lethal to begin with. BUT, they are still fun and it's extremely satisfying when you win by the skin of your teeth. The big battles are hella fun!Not so much a con and probably a bug, but DO NOT dismiss characters on the world map. At least not Angela, if you have her. I did and unless she's supposed to be gone, she's still out in the Wasteland where I left her. Hope I left her some water, I tkink it was close to a water source, or her and Ace are gonna be meeting again real soon....she's not in the Ranger Citadel either. If you take that kid you save from drowning into your party, and go back to the Citadel, leave him at the entrance or don't let him be with you when you go in, a conversation fires off between him and another member of your party when you go near the museum and you'll be stuck there, in the conversation, with no choice for a response and no other choice but to reload, and that's the only game breaking bug I've found so far. The UI could use some tweeking, status effects are hard to determine visually on quick glance; I had already played many many hours before I noticed the tiny consussion icon above the character portrait for the first time. Other than those issues and some very minor stability issues that are probably more related to my rig than the game itself, any other bug I've come across, hasn't been anything major. I emphatically recommend this game, it has the potential to be one of the best titles of it's kind in a very, very long time.

												I've just finished this game after more than one hundred hours on it and it's one of the best RPG I've ever played for different reasons.The main reason is that, as a player, you have to make choices. Some of these choices are not easy and, more than that, they have consequences ! Another reason I liked this game is its humor : not for all audience, for sure, but I loved it...In short, a great game which considers the player as a mature person. It's so uncommon these days... That's why it's so refreshing.Vincent - Palaiseau - France.-------Je viens juste de terminer ce jeu après une centaine d'heure passées dessus et c'est l'un des meilleurs jeu de rôle auquel j'ai jamais joué. La principale raison est que, en tant que joueur, vous devez faire des choix. Certains de ces choix ne sont pas faciles à faire et en plus de cela, ils ont des conséquences ! Une autre raison pour laquelle j'aime ce jeu est son humour : ce n'est pas le genre d'humour que tout le monde apprécie, c'est certain, mais moi j'adore.En bref, un grand jeu qui considère le joueur comme un adulte. C'est tellement inhabituel par les temps qui courent... C'est pourquoi c'est si rafraichissant.Vincent - Palaiseau - France.

content:
23, 2014
Early Access Review
								 Ok so I really want this to be a winner in the long run. It is so damn buggy it's stopped me playing. I only hope my $60 will go towards cleaning up the end product and make it all worth while. I mean the story is great as I'd expect. The concept solid as ♥♥♥♥ but the combat is just ok. Skills are questionable. This is after just a few hours playing the game. I think the first 1 or 2 were spent wandering aimlessly in the waste as I had no concept of how to change camera angle let alone WTF the water gague was and how to refill it. So I finally find an oasis... I AM, FROM 1988, A FAN OF WASTELAND! ON THE APPLE II NO LESS AND I AM NOT HAPPY. Get it together guys, I know it's beta but $60? I can't even get it to full screen on windows 7. I love the story, the puzzels are great, the combat is ok but the skills and stats etc?? Did the first 3 missions which were kind of fun. The patchy loading is really annoying as is the lack of a full screen view. By highpool mission I'm a more than annoyed. I really hope the completed game is less patchy, has better graphics, more dynamic feeling turn based combat and is more imersive then just getting a portrate box with text and voice over. Maybe just some facial movement ie their lips move when they speak, expressions??  So yes I do recommend this game, if anything to give the developers more cash to polish the end product. If this is pretty close to the finished article there are going to be many dissapointed fans of the original. At least I can play the original if I have the time to indulge in nostaligia... for the price not really worth it. In the long haul if the game get's a serious overhaul and some much needed improvements then I will be a happy camper. If not, well that is $60 I wasted. If your a fan of the original, can overcome some serious glitches and bugs and annoying status effects that appear to have no cure (the plant infection WTF, even if it only last until the relevant section of the game is completed I think) confusion (expected from any beta) and a hefty price tag well this is for you. I look at it as a donation towards a fantastic end product. DO NOT DISAPPOINT ME PLEASE!!!

content:
y 1
												There's something about Wasteland 2 which just does not click with me. I grew up with Fallout and Fallout 2 so RPGs of this style aren't anything new to me. But, Wasteland 2's story, characters and world just seem incredibly mediocre. There was no pull for me. Combat was semi-interesting but otherwise not too involving beyond positioning properly and utilizing each of your Ranger's skills with the appropriate weapon at hand.The game is hideous. There's no other way of putting it. Fallout 1 & 2 look better than this muddy depressing mess. There's post-apocalpytic style but then there's just plain ugly. The conversation system was fairly well done however with your given list of topics as well as 3 different kinds of conversation skills to gather more information or influence an NPC beyond just the standard way. This just seems like more of a proof of concept rather than a proper finished RPG in the way of past RPGs. I didn't have a single feeling of "what's around the corner? what interesting quests am I going to run into in the next area? Who am I going to meet and what kind of conversations am I going to engage in?" throughout the handful of hours I put into it. A feeling which is prevalent in Fallout 1 & 2 which I still play to this day. I stopped because I simply was not having fun.

number of helpful: 15 of 27 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 27, 2014
												There should be a word that combines grind and slog so I can use it to describe Wasteland 2. In the before time, there was gaming, and whatever it was, we don't remember it now because in the intervening decade and some, we grew up and so did gaming. We learned that telling tales of "how hard game x was" to be far more entertaining than actually doing it. We learned how to design levels and create meaningful narratives and games that were fun to play, not just fun to have played. Oh, and we learned how to find voice actors. Wasteland 2 is probably faithful to its spiritual predecessor. I wouldn't know, because I wouldn't play that now either. The bones of a decent tactical rpg are there, but the level designs don't reward you for making use of them. Similarly, the bones of a good story rpg are there, but the disconcordant voices muddy the experience. Much like, "an arrow to the knee" cried out for a mod to stop, Wasteland 2 needs some serious fan love to be worth playing. Until the need to wander around the desert, grinding out raider encounters to level up is gone, I suggest you give this a pass and stick to New Vegas.

content:
r 18, 2014
												This game is not good. It's one of the worst modern RPGs I've played.  The graphics are bad and the art design is uninspired. Many of the environments are hideously repititious. The camera controls poorly. The RPG aspects consist of ensuring skill points are dumped into a couple of specialties in order to pass checks in conversation dialogue and opening locked boxes.In combat your options range from: Shooting, Crouching to Shoot, and Reloading. You can also hide behind arbitarily designated cover positions. If you've played XCom or Divinity: Original Sin you know this style of Turn-Based combat, and what you'll find here pales in comparison. The AI of the enemies is basically nonexistent. They will run at you and shoot you or they will run at you and stab/bludgeon you. Upping the difficulty seems to only increase the Bullet Sponginess of your foes.  Since you have extremely limited tactical options there's basically no point in playing on anything beyond normal unless you enjoy reloading quicksaves.Combat initiation is wonky. You can attempt to arrange your characters behind cover beforehand, but this process is extremely janky and you'll probably inadvertently trigger combat before you intended to.There are no real characters. There's a Native American companion who has a bow and is really good at sharpshooting. She talks a lot in ham-fisted stereotypical fashion. Oh and she also has a skill that allows her to Tame Wild Animals.  There's a gruff commander. He is gruff and old. There is a ranger who is sad that another ranger died. The entire thing feels completely perfunctory.  I got about four hours into the game and had yet to decipher what the game was supposed to be about beyond meandering from fetch quest to fetch quest.One storyline involves doing a bunch of quests for some townsfolk. One guy's house is on fire. One guy's dog is missing. The waterpumps aren't working.  If you help the people in these quests, the townsfolk will elect a good mayor. You know she's good because she's nice to you. If you don't do the quests the townsfolk elect a bad mayor. You know he's bad because he's mean to you. There are virtually no consequences in either result. If you enjoy this kind of compelling, interactive storytelling this game is for you.

number of helpful: 18 of 33 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
13
												Notice: My review states that I do not recommend this game because of inXile Entertainment's exceptionally scummy behavior during the "inXile vs The Alien Wasteland" incident (Google it for more details - basically, inXile used copyright laws in a frivolous way to bully a small indie developer). If you are in any way conscious about the future of game development, I implore you not to buy the game or any of the other Wasteland games. (If you are desperately looking for a post-apoc RPG, have a look at Underrail!)To other reviewers: due to a Steam glitch, you have to review Wasteland 2 DC by posting a review to regular Wasteland 2. That also means you have to install and play that for at least 5 minutes too if you haven't already. (This is why it seems like I've only played a couple minutes - my real playtime is ~50 hours right now.)For the sake of honesty, I am also going to write up a brief summary of the good and the bad points of the game itself. Wasteland 2: Director's Cut is a post-apocalyptic RPG about an American militia organization named the Desert Rangers who try to uphold law and order in Arizona after a global nuclear apocalypse, as well as the events of the first game (which, as explained very soon in the game as well, involved stopping a crazy scientist and a malevolent AI). You lead a party of four (or less) Rangers on a mission to find out about the circumstances of the death of another Ranger. This party can later gain up to three additional followers, up to a squad size of seven. These followers (of which there are plenty, so you'll have to make choices as to who you carry along) have the slight drawback that they can "go rogue", i.e. ignore your orders and do their own thing each turn (this can be mitigated), but are otherwise perfectly functional player characters.Sounds like a lot to manage? It's not as bad as it sounds. The character attribute/skill system is simple enough, though it can feel overwhelming on a first playthrough. However, W2 DC does provide a default squad - you can roll with it on the normal ("Seasoned") difficulty level on a first playthrough and do alright (at least I did). The tutorial system is adequate and explores the various elements of the game well enough that you probably won't feel lost after the first 15-30 minutes. Combat may seem a bit punishing at first, but if you explore enough, the game rewards you pretty soon with a "crutch" follower, who is quite a bit stronger than your characters at that point and will help you get through the first few areas. (Though I also have a minor quibble here: this very same follower will eventually leave you, so if you thought they were a solid fixture on your team and rely on them for a critical skill, you may suddenly be left with a gaping hole in your team after they leave. You are subtly warned that they might only stay while your team are still greenhorns, but the warning is too subtle in my opinion. Most other followers do stick around once they join you, though, unless you make a choice that pisses them off big time.)Speaking of choices, this game does have its fair share of "choices and consequences". Like most games that advertise this, this game does not deviate too much from its major storyline either, and the choices only have flavor effects or some minor gameplay effects at most. This does not mean the C&C system in the game is necessarily bad - I'm just telling you what to expect. Your choices do shape the world, even if not all of them have a significant effect on when and how you win the game. In keeping with the gritty theme, often you are forced to choose between two bad outcomes or may not be able to  stop a certain kind of evil at all no matter what you do, but at other times you can help the wasteland become a better place.The various factions in the game are interesting, many of them are well-developed and have engaging characters. Unfortunately, the main plot is a bit too railroaded for my taste - the game is designed with the assumption that you are going to be a Desert Ranger through and through, identifying with them without question and opposing the main boss. There are some interesting nuances to the ideology of the main antagonists, but the game does not explore them sufficiently. There are alternate endings where you do not do what the Rangers expect you to do, but they are unsatisfying to say the least. The side quests are actually more interesting than the main plot IMO.Regarding game balance, the game is balanced well enough that you can do a first playthrough on Seasoned (the default, normal difficulty level) with just the right amount of challenge, not too much frustration, but not too easy either. I think you might conceivably be able try a blind ironman first run as well, if you are so inclined - though I'd probably recommend  Rookie for that. The game is not a roguelike though, and it isn't designed for endless replayability - I think that there are about 2-3 playthroughs' worth of material in the game (provided you like it enough to replay it), and no more, so I'd advise against blind ironman play. One positive I'd like to note is that unlike quite a few CRPGs I've ever seen (the worst violator being Age of Decadence), this game - at least on normal difficulty - does not need extreme minmaxing to succeed, and you *can* start with suboptimal builds and still perform well enough. You can even branch out into a lot of non-combat skills and still be strong enough to be able to fight, and the game is forgiving enough that you can make drastic changes to your skill focuses over the course of 5-10 levels if you take your team in the wrong direction (my characters were around level 40 by the time they completed the game). For example, if you realize you desperately need the Lockpicking skill and forgot to take it on any of your characters, well, you'll be missing some containers for a while, but you aren't hopelessly behind and will probably still be able to max it out if you aren't too late into the game.The interface and user-friendly aspects are generally good - there aren't a lot of really inconvenient/frustrating functionalities I've found, carry weights are not a huge issue, useless junk items that have no use other than sell value can be sold with a single click all at once... not much bad I can say here.If you care about that sort of thing, the game is also LGBTQ-positive. Well, I haven't seen any T, but they might exist without you realizing it, y'know? There are quite a few openly gay characters though (mostly minor, but a particular married lesbian couple will help you out in the final battle if you help them out before). I've also found at least one crossdresser (in a town which is famous for its extreme sexual libertinism, to the point of being ruled over by a sex worker - and they are actually one of the nicer communities in the game, certainly compared to their main rivals) and hey, the game does technically allow you to have gay sex, though nothing is shown on screen - so if you're looking for smut, don't get your hopes up.As a minor bonus, you can dress up your character in one of many different outfits found throughout the game world - this'll affect the appearance of your toons in the game world and on the character screen (though it's only cosmetic), and since any worn armor doesn't actually appear on you, this functionality isn't made obsolete as soon as you want to put some armor on. You can put really indecent clothes on your females, or have your men walk around in a pair of hold-up stockings, or even dress them up in a way that's actually intimidating and/or practical (but why'd you want to do that?!). It's a fun little minigame you can entertain yourself with while you are shuffling your inventory around.Overall verdict: avoid, for reasons stated in the very beginning. If you do not care about punishing dodgy business practices, then I'll let you judge based on the rest of the review.

												Isometric RPG's are back and as good as ever! If you ever played and enjoyed the original Fallout games, or even the Baldurs Gate series, you absolutely owe it to yourself to try Wasteland 2. Successor to the original Wasteland, and spiritual Successor to Fallout 1&2, Wasteland 2 delivers a fantastic story, great voice acting, a compelling setting and the brilliant isometric RPG gameplay you'd expect from the old classics.My only real criticism is the poor graphics. They're not terrible, and I can understand that they didn't exactly have the AAA title budget, but they're just not up to the stellar standards set by the rest of the game.Overall I would highly recommend this game to any fan of the old school RPGs, as well as gamers looking to find out what all the fuss was about. Welcome back, Brian Fargo, Chris Avellone and everyone else involved in making this amazing game. You've been misssed!

content:
r 19, 2014
												Interesting, fun game, much in the spirit of the Baldur's Gate games and the original Wasteland. Old-school, pretty long and reasonably hard, with focus more on gameplay than on graphics. Plenty of choices, lots of possible ways to outfit your party, no "right choice". You can play as you like, and are actually encouraged to do so. You may very well be locked out from several parts of the game through your choices, but that tends to happen anyway, whichever choice you make. If you really want to see everything the game has to offer, you have to play multiple times, and fortunately the game makes that a viable option as different playthroughs will feel differently.So I recommend this game on its gameplay merits, but I have to warn new players for the fact that the game, at the moment of this writing, still seems to be in the beta phase. While it has officially been released a month ago, there are plenty of quests in the late game that may still get into an unresolvable state -- this is a consequence of the fact that the player may go anywhere he likes, and thus may get into areas that are quest-related without having got the quest in the first place. There are also quite a few bugs left which may cause a forced reload. So my recommendation is: if the style of game appeals to you, get it (preferably in some kind of sale), but wait with playing until the bugs are ironed out. It looks like the game will get a major update soon, considering that Steam has made it clear that achievements will be added.

content:
r 27, 2015
												[This review is NOT for Director's Cut, it is for Standard Edition - Director's cut only adds to this]If you like post-apoc games, this might be for you - especially the very patient, more old-skool users who have LOTS of time on their hands...No really, I mean lots of time, sometimes, a bit too much honestly.  In-case you don't get it PATIENCE MUST BE ONE OF YOUR VIRTUES, otherwise completing this game WONT be.Load times are quick [1-6 seconds on SSDs], gfx are okay (for this year, could be better...) sound is appropriate including periodic voiceovers that are well done and music that is quite fitting and will make FO 1&2 players feel right at home (Mark Morgan).  Good job getting the Fallout music man to come back.Went through and got the repeaters, and then had to go to the Ag center, to do the next mission, and the whole while I'm doing this, another outpost is claiming it's getting clobbered, and now I'm poisoned, and don't have a clue what to do.  You feel a bit helpless, and at fault, and not entirely in a good way, but that may have been just me.  There is entirely too much going on at once and I'm unable to concentrate on this mission enough to solve it, while still having to go to another place after this is done.   First hour or two went pretty smoothly, hours three and four I'm out of ammo, there's entirely too much ammo management for me to put any more effort into it so in most of the battles half my guys were without ammo and getting massacred by rabbits on easy (well almost).May want to invest in some unarmed skills at some point, just keep in mind to save enough skill points to get your gun skills up too or you won't hit ANYTHING.Will eagerly be waiting for Fallout 4 as this definitely is not Fallout... not 1 not 2 not any of them.  Too much inventory juggling - that was the icing on the cake and I'd have rather eaten the plate whilst I tried to figure out what to do!  A shared inventory screen would have been a wonderful invention with individual character inventories being limited to slots guns, armor, trinkets, etc.Pass this one up until you've exhausted the fallout series as of late.  It can be a good game, but you will struggle to afford enough ammo unless you loot everything and take every last bit of junk you can scrounge.  There is a barter perk but it brings at most 10% discount/10% bonus on bought/sold items.  It's not that this game is bad, it can be very unforgiving and hard to keep your guns loaded let alone hit the target until your gun skill is maxed.For those playing on a RADEON video card, I can attest that there isn't much gfx issue at all sans the water-building interior in Domonta - a little bit of flickering, but can still play fine.  You're only in there for the duration of one battle anyways so regardless, it won't be too much issue.  I have updated my review a bit, after playing 30+ hours (it is a long game, I'd say im half-way through it), and it feels like a touch of fallout tactics along with fallout 2.  I'd have to say that players who enjoyed the late-90s playthrough of Fallout 1 and 2 will feel at home here in the setting - all the way down to accidently nuking some religious cult - oops... heh.  Though I will say you can with assuredness tell that this is the first-go-round for some of the people creating the game, it is NOT shoddy work by any means.  There is much fun to be had here, and much humour to snicker at if you have the patience.   This isn't DooM, this isn't run-and-gun and blast through everything with reckless abandon...this is it's own game.  A 25-40$ USD price-tag seems appropriate here, and I think most people would be satisfied with the game for this.  That being said, it isn't nearly as crashey as Fallout 3 and New Vegas were out of the box (or possibly even now years after release), so don't let me sell it short.  Watch some videos, read the reviews and decide for yourself.  Try not to get discouraged before getting to level 15-20 or so with your characters, as it gets much more rewarding when you can actually afford ammo AND hit the target in battle.  I would also mention on this last note that the age-rating for this game applies to both the violence and the difficulty mentally that you may have if you lack extremely good problem solving skills (teenagers barring some ingeniously crafty ones may have trouble).  Good luck.Recommended to take a field medic-surgeon, weaponsmith, locksmith/safecracker, and someone with keen perception and good with knocking down obstacles with you on your first try, you'll get more characters in your party at a later date if you so choose.  You still won't be able to do everything your first time.  This game for most will be good for more than one play-through.Just buy up all the ammo & health-items you can afford, seriously.

While it has officially been released a month ago, there are plenty of quests in the late game that may still get into an unresolvable state -- this is a consequence of the fact that the player may go anywhere he likes, and thus may get into areas that are quest-related without having got the quest in the first place. There are also quite a few bugs left which may cause a forced reload. So my recommendation is: if the style of game appeals to you, get it (preferably in some kind of sale), but wait with playing until the bugs are ironed out. It looks like the game will get a major update soon, considering that Steam has made it clear that achievements will be added.

content:
4, 2016
Product received for free
												I recommend this game with some very strong reservations.I downloaded and played this game during the free play period.  The game is definitely dated - they don't make games like this anymore.  This is both a good thing and a bad thing.  The game had a good story (from what I could see) with consequences for taking action in one direction over another.  None of this modern “follow the yellow brick road and if you die you pick up where you left off,” and “don't forget to mash the buttons in the correct order” crap.  This game will punish you for making poor decisions.  Don't invest in certain talents?  You will fail missions.The game also chooses to use an isometric design for how you view the world.  This makes it awkward to control the camera, and often times puts you in positions where your character can see further than you can because of the angle of the camera changes as you zoom in or zoom out.  It made controlling the characters difficult at times.Like many others who wrote reviews, I played the game and sought to purchase the game while it was on sale, only to be notified that I already owned the game.  Now that the free play is over, so is the sale price.  I guess that means that it is time to wait until it is on sale again.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 5, 2015
												Freaking RIDICULOUSLY good...so far.  My biggest gauge of a game is how obvious it is that the devs gave it the love it needed.  W2 got enough love.  It's immersive, comprehensive, engaging, its world is deeply responsive, and it's as funny and cheezy as needed.  The expected micromanagement side of things took some getting used to, but it's not too much and it's solidly designed so you can get some good speed going with the interface once you get used to it.As far as criticism, the only things I've noticed so far after 100 hrs are minor.  For ex. when your level for a skill is below the minimum for a task, it'd be nice if it told you how many points you're under the minimum instead of just "this is impossible" (which makes me think it's actually impossible regardless of level).  I've only got a handful of other minor beefs (like dialog sometimes being stale vs a situation).  The biggest beef I've seen so far is that in some situations it's not obvious from what you're given what to do next.  In every case of that, peeking at hints online make me go "ohhh you dumbass".  It's still minor.  For a game this mechanically complex, that's a freaking huge success.Great work inXile, keep em' comin'.

content:
ber 27, 2014
												Isometric RPG's are back and as good as ever! If you ever played and enjoyed the original Fallout games, or even the Baldurs Gate series, you absolutely owe it to yourself to try Wasteland 2. Successor to the original Wasteland, and spiritual Successor to Fallout 1&2, Wasteland 2 delivers a fantastic story, great voice acting, a compelling setting and the brilliant isometric RPG gameplay you'd expect from the old classics.My only real criticism is the poor graphics. They're not terrible, and I can understand that they didn't exactly have the AAA title budget, but they're just not up to the stellar standards set by the rest of the game.Overall I would highly recommend this game to any fan of the old school RPGs, as well as gamers looking to find out what all the fuss was about. Welcome back, Brian Fargo, Chris Avellone and everyone else involved in making this amazing game. You've been misssed!

content:
ber 26, 2014
												A very compelling, classic, post-nuclear RPG with highly satisfying turn based combat in between. Wasteland 2 got a pretty cool flair to it, rough and sometimes weird characters. Lots of text, which you actually have to pay attention to - really nice to have something like that amidst the dozens of games requiring nothing of you but to look at the minimap and the HUD telling you to what to kill and how many of them. Pretty good integrated tutorial function, which holds your hand if you want to but you can also just go ahead and figure out most of the mechanics by yourself. Either way works. Skill system is deep enough but not overly complex and the story kept me hooked most of the time. The only thing that is not quite favorable are the graphics - and that is coming from someone who usually doesn't give a rat's ♥♥♥ about the looks of a game. And I'm not talking about polygons or explosion effects. It just seems a little bit too blurry in some scenes, the colouring is very desaturated and without a lot of contrast, sometimes making it hard to spot certain things like crates or objects related to quests.Other than that, if you like the style of games like XCOM, the Fallout series, maybe even S.T.A.L.K.E.R. (even though that's an FPS) you might just dig Wasteland 2.

												Ok, so to start off, this review is the very first I have ever written.  So if it's wack and unorganized, please forgive me. Also I couldn't log more than (I think 7 hrs). I got it during the free weekend offer, but didn't really play it until much later.Now on to the review/thoughts.I have never played any top down (Isometric(?)) Rpg's, EVER. This is also the only reason I've never played Fallout 1, 2, and tactics. The top down view wasn't really the thing I thought of when it came to an rpg, and I never really thought they would be enjoyable, that is until Wasteland 2. This game is so F****** awesome!!!I was pleasantly surprised at how much I enjoyed this game. The lore, the story, the characters, the setting, and how it was paced. The Mission in the beginning with the two towns was nerve wrecking. I kept trying to save the other as fast as possible but never succeeded. So when the game says your choices cause ripples that change everything, it wasn't joking.  Honestly, I don't know what else to say. I really enjoyed the game, and after this I'm going to buy it when I can. As well as, check out underrail, and the older Fallouts. If you like Post-apocalyptic settings but not too big on the top down perspective, I suggest trying out Wasteland 2. You may be suprised at how much you'll enjoy it. 10/10 would buy on sale - because I'm broke :D

content:
er 12, 2014
												To be honest with you, the moment the character creation screen pops up I thought I was in for a huge disappointment. The whole design is just ugly as hell. You try to customize a character to your liking but they all look like sewer vagabonds. The combat is simplistic for a turn based game and weapons are not consistent to their values. But I got over this problem quickly once I discovered the perfect party setup for every battle. NPC character portrait is an immersion killer because it feels like they're only using a dozen portraits to cover all the NPCs in the game! It would have been better if they just skipped with the portraits for minor characters. I mean how can the most important character in Hollywood have the same portrait as half of the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s in the game?In the end, my patience prevailed though as I found myself engaged to the story till the end. There are no easy routes for the big quests and finishing them feels like an achievement. The whole Wasteland itself is quite vast and there is plenty to do in every location.So I guess overall this game has a lot of technical and design flaws but if you can get past these problems, you'll find an engrossing story and gameplay.I give this game 7.5/10Director's Cut: Even with all the flaws, this game was still the most fun I've had playing RPG in a long time, and now with the update, almost every aspect of it has been improved. Most importantly is the visual presentation. This game now looks 3 times graphically better. There are new cinematic sequences too which added to the already rich environment. Wasteland 2 is now very near the total package. I say very near because the combat I feel is still a notch below other turn based games like X-Com. With that in mind, this game in its final form is a 9/10.

content:
7, 2014
Early Access Review
								If you like tactical games, post-apocalyptic worlds, guns, critical thinking, even if you enjoy dungeons and dragons; then I suggest you try Wasteland 2. If you like the world of Fallout, you'll love the world of Wasteland. Not to go into too much, but its from the same developers of the original Fallout games, joined by some of the creators of the newer versions of Fallout. As of now, the game is still in beta but is scheduled for release soon, and yes, I'll admit, the price is a bit steep for now, but I'd suggest it once it releases, and the price drops. You get a few added things if you buy the DDE, but that's for you to decide if its worth it. The game itself is interesting. There's a lot of reading, remembering key words, critical thinking (should I send my team in fighting? Or should I try a more diplomatic approach?) and storytelling. Quests and advancement is a little lackluster, but not bad, and every choice has a consequence. Graphics are decent, sound and music are stellar, and some of the game (easter eggs, dialogue, and random loot) are a little corny, but not bad. I would recommend this game to anyone that enjoys any kind of Role-Playing game.

content:
ber 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								I purchased Wasteland 2 many months ago. At that stage it was the seed of a brilliant game, but a seed that clearly implied the tree it would become. Wasteland 2 is for me the evolution from the original Fallout I had hoped for, even as the subsequent Fallout games were wonderful surprises. Having dipped my toe in again recently, far closer to the "finished" product (what really is "finished" these days?), it's staggering and heartening to see the attention this game has received from its developers... not just attention, but passion, polish, depth, style and love. When "final" release hits, I fully intend to drop everything I happen to be doing, even if it causes a kitchen fire or a traffic accident.

												I highly recommended this game to those that love tactical turn based RPGs in the same vein as the first two Fallout games (considering that those games are based on Wasteland 1). Wasteland 2 is a more contemporary universe, a less foreign world ravaged by nuclear war rather than the more comedic, 50's stylized alternate reality of Fallout. In my opinion it is also far more serious in its tone by forcing hard choices and painting a sad state of affairs for humanity. The humor present is often dark and subtle.This game easily beats out any triple A RPG title I've played in the past decade.

content:
ber 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								The fact that this game was made at all fills a corner of my heart with great joy -- Games like these (turn based rpgs) of good quality are often far-between, and I have no regrets playing this one. Very true to the wasteland of old, part of what I love is how you don't need to have played the ancient classic, but if you have it breathes life into many facets of the story. the gritty feel is spot on, and the skill system and character building is intriguing -- though perhaps not as fun as fallout series. It is interesting to note that Wasteland is THE game that inspired so much that came after it in the post-apoc rpg genre... so it is interesting that when it's sequel finally arrives, some of it's successors have already pushed the horizon beyond what it appears (thus far -- haven't finished yet) wasteland 2 will be able to take us. The "robots rising from the ashes of the past to take back the earth" premise has been done so many times since wasteland 1 -- at least twice in the fallout series alone, I'm kind of sad that wasteland 2's synthetics seem to be shaping up to be more of the usual as well... still, I can't write out the idea that this is a red herring as of the time of this review, but lets just say I'd be slightly sad if it's not. Wasteland 1 was revolutionary in almost every respect -- for Wasteland 2 to rise from the ashes, like the numerous armies of robots of whch I've spoke, only to not deliver something new would be unfortunate. Otherwise, great game -- solid RPG, great story, great mechanics, great atmosphere/world... nuff said.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 5, 2015
												Welcome to the glorious wastes of Arizona with nothing but old school RPG turn based combat and a plethora of cross roads to travel. This was a game I had been watching from the early beta days but decided against diving straight in and waiting for the "final" version of the game to come out. On that note before continuing, I use the term "final" very loosely.The first half of the game is fantastic. Hands down one of the most enjoyable games I've played in a while. Refreshing real choices with actual consequences. Multiple choices and decisions to be made at every corner ranging from simple attire, to devastating lesser of two evil choices that affect the rest of the game and years to come following. Great character creation allowing role-players to enjoy a world the can fully immerse themselves in. This and so much more awaits you.On the opposite side of the review this game is not without short comings and issues. The second half of the game is anything but complete. More than ever this is a game that you save often for and making 100+ individual save files. Major quest lines are riddled with bugs and plot holes the size of the grand canyon can be found more frequently than not. While I still enjoyed the vague idea of the second half of the game, it was a disappointment after how amazing the first half was. Another big issue was balancing. Take this bit of advice. Sniper rifles/ assault rifles/ shotguns and energy weapons are the only good guns in the game. The rest are terrible. If you enjoy turn based RPGs and an apocalyptic theme this game is for you, while I may have listed some off putting downsides especially for the second half it is still worth playing. The first half of the game does such a great job and the curiosity you will have to see how things turn out will help you through the issues of the second half. I finished this game 100% including a run on the higher difficulty in 158 hours. Well worth the money. 8.5/10
