content:
ber 13, 2015
												As I am not really experienced in writing reviews, but since I just completed the game, l would like to share my experience with others whom are still deciding to buy it or not. I am dividing it in several stages: Character Building, Storyline, Combat and Gear.==Character Building==I found it really challenging to build a team that would last me through the whole game, just because there are too many skills to choose from for only 4 characters of your team. I had to make a new game 3 times to find out that it's actually better to leave a couple of skills out, which you will find on other followers (even better progressed) later on in the game. - Rose for example has a really high computer skill and handgun skill.-  Apart from the skills I think there are limited but reasonably enough faces and clothing to choose from to make a pretty random team. EDIT: After I made new game on highest difficulty, it came to my surprise that I could use me old rangers again, still having all the skills and abilities from my previous end-game. Knowing this I can reccomend new players to start and complete an easier difficulty and then use the same experienced (veteran) rangers on higher difficulty to make it easier! Changed my rating from 7/10 to 8.5 after knowing this.Rating 8.5/10==Storyline==Depending on the choices you make, the storyline will change in many, many ways. Sometimes it doesn't turn out the way you want, and you can't do anything about it because of one of your previous choices. I quite liked this because it makes making choices more difficult and you will have to think ahead to make sure everything turns out ... o.k. Dialogues are sometimes crazy long, and very tiring to read it all. You will be clicking a lot. Mind you, read carefully. Sometimes you will need information in order to make the right choice. Having an advanced speech skill will also come in handy to unlock several special dialogues which will help you get things easier.The main story takes you and your team into the wasteland of Arizona to plant a couple of radio repeaters on several radio towers and re-establish broadcast range for your fellow rangers at the Citadel. During this mission you will stumble upon a lot of people whom need your help... or do they? You decide.After going through a lot of trouble to get the radio going again, you will fly to Los Angeles, where you will have to clear the name of the Rangers and bring good to the people of LA. You will soon notice that you're not the only one trying to gain power in LA and find yourself in conflict with several organizations that will stop for nothing until they have it. Make the right choices to make the right alliances and save the world from extinction.Rating 9/10==Combat==Combat is pretty much the same throughout the whole game.. this doesn't mean that it’s boring though. You will have a limited amount of action points per character, depending on your skills. Both moving and shooting will cost action points so use them wisely. Some combat phases can be really challenging because of the environment you're in. Gain advantage by seeking higher ground and make sure that you get a lot of cover, it will definitely save your life multiple times. A higher combat initiative allows your team to act more often in a battle and will surely come in handy when you fight 10 baddies at once.  Rating 6/10==Gear==You will be happy to know that you will be able to choose from a lot of weapon types to use. And you can even put modifications on them! A big variety of weapons and weaponmods allow you to create your own personal weapons of mass destruction. The only thing I found disappointing was that you will be using the same weapon for a long time until you proceed into a new area. They are also pretty expensive in the shop. Make sure that you make the right decision on bringing the guns you find with you, or turn them into scrap metal to sell.There is also a lot of clothing to be found in the wasteland. You will stumble across the weirdest hats, shirts and pants which together make an even weirder outfit. Make sure you try everything on!Rating 8/10-------------------------------So after having said all of this, I would very much like to recommend this game to people who like a game full of adventure, mystery and action with a lot of choices and plot twists. The overall rating of this game for me concludes:7,9/10A few extra tips:* Save a lot!!* Always reload before battle!!* Stock up on ammo!!* Take cover!!* ENJOY!!Mr. Grey*

content:
1, 2016
												   I downloaded the game over the free-to-play weekend, and I'm hooked.  It reminds me of why I used to love playing computer RPGs, particularly turn-based games like XCOM and Fallout 1 & 2.  The writing is funny and quirky, and there are just an incredible amount of easter eggs that reference the developers' obvious love for sci-fi, fantasy, pen and paper role playing games and late 20th century pop culture.  Just about every item, including the massive amount of different junk items, has a tongue-in-cheek description if you take a moment to click on them.   Some people seem to be complaining about the combat system, but it's pretty standard for any good turn based tactical game.  I like the fact that you can position your team around a skirmish utilizing high ground and obstacles for cover.  It's a nice, nostalgic change of pace from the real time combat that basically every game utilizes now.   I haven't gotten terribly far into the story, but it appears that every decision you make ripples outwards and affects how the rest of your play experience goes.  Feel like desecrating graves, shooting dogs and leaving a smoking trail of destruction behind your every move?  You're free to do so if that's what amuses you.  Your skill at picking locks not too great?  Blow open the door with some dynamite, kick it in, or just blast it open with a shotgun.  If you can't disable a trap, just have a tank open the crate and soak up the damage.  There are multiple ways to solve just about any problem you encounter.  I love that feature.  In most games, I feel like I'm missing out if I can't open every locked or secret door in the dungeon.   I probably wouldn't have stumbled across this game if it weren't for the free preview weekend, and I'm so glad it was featured.  It's not 100% perfect, but I'd give it a solid 8/10.

ber 25, 2014
												Best of the turn-based RPGs I've played this year.This tickled my turn-tactical bone in the same way X-Com Enemy Unknown did. Now that I've played it through I enjoyed the general story arc, it felt like you were bringing law and order to a land full of people clammoring for it. Gotta love the Star Trek-esque takes on alternative societies as humanity claws its way back from the grave.It isn't perfectly open ended, but you have a lot of freedom to accomplish goals. I ended up doing a lot of quest lines backwards by outright murdering individuals .. which inadvertently solved quests later. A lot of times you're forced to take 'sides' in conflicts between factions, but you can just obliterate both of them if you so choose. In certain cases that may even be desirable, we're talking about some odious people here.The gameplay is pretty solid. Investing in social skills heavily can pay off in several questlines later. There's plenty of skill objectives in every map, making it feel rewarding if you invested in something as seemingly irrelevant as Toaster repair. The various weapon types all feel useful in different ways, forcing you to seriously consider if items are up upgrades to your playstyle or not.Terrific RPG.

Early Access Review
								Wasteland 2 is to Wasteland what X-Com: Enemy Unknown is to X-Com: UFO Defense, and so much more. It is more than just a refurbished classic with updated graphics and interface; it truly is what happens next. I recognize people and places I knew when I first explored the Wasteland; old teammates are now grizzled veterans in positions of authority, landmarks are still there, just as I pictured them… and sometimes even better. I can see where my trials and tribulations helped the people of the Wasteland… and where my hard fought battles did not matter after all. It's nostalgic, new and exciting all at the same time. I highly recommend purchasing this game and enveloping yourself in post-apocalyptic Arizona again, or first time. You won't regret it!

content:
ber 28, 2014
												Let me begin by saying that Wasteland 2 is not like Fallout outside of the post-apocalyptic theme, and a few design choices. Wasteland 2 is a great game, but it is not as good as Fallout 2. The game is a good squad-based RPG that reminds me heavily of those old Fallout games, though. And indeed, I love this game much the same. There is a variety of ways you can solve most of your problems, and because of that, this game has consumed what has to have been over 10 hours of my life already. There are some problems I have with the game. And if this game were made by any other unknown indie developer, I would have rolled my eyes and moved on. But this game was made by Brian Fargo, with help from several other veterans of good old RPGs that we knew and love, so this makes me disappointed at a few design choices.1. A few skills are a bit too divided. Unnecessarily so. Why is Safecracking and Lockpicking two different skills? Why not just make Safes harder to lockpick? Why are Blunt Weapons and Bladed weapons separate? What was so wrong with a general "melee" skill? Why is there a skill just for modding weapons? Who in their right mind would put skill points into Toaster Repair? While some skill divisions made logical sense -- obviously, in a squad-based RPG, a generic "guns" skill would be broken, and speech is basically divided into what you want to accomplish with words (Reasoning, Seduction, or Intimidation). But I honestly think Weapon Modding should have been covered by Mechanical Repair, and Safes should fall under Lockpicking.1a. And while I am at it, what is the point of the Demolitions skill outside of trap disarming? All explosive weapons are disposable, one-use items (REAAAAALLY dislike, by the way), and none of them are affected by your skill at handling explosives. Instead, grenades and bombs are handled XCOM: Enemy Unknown style -- click where you want the bomb to go and the character tosses it, with little chance of error. Now, I loved XCOM, but what the hell? No grenade launchers with appropriate ammo? No rockets for your LAWs and RPGs? No mines? (well, the ENEMY can place mines, but you can't). No C-4? Why have Demolitions at all, outside of defusing the numerous (frankly obnoxious) traps inside every other box of loot?2. No Stealth mechanic or skill. This hit me pretty hard when I realized there was no stealth in the game, because I am all about conflict avoidance in RPGs. I am the kind of guy whose priority in Fallout New Vegas was getting my speech to 100 -- the fewer bullets I fire during a quest, the better. Not to mention there were several situations I ran into that practically BEGGED for the usage of stealth, and yet, it simply wasn't possible. Aside from that though, the game seems to be doing well in the "cause and effect" aspect that many RPGs sorely lack. There are tough decisions you will find yourself making as you journey across the wasteland. The best solutions that benefit everyone often require large amounts of skill in the required talents -- Unless you specialize your rangers, you aren't going to do many great things. It's a good RPG. And honestly, it has me hooked. But damnit, I DID expect better.I do recommend it though, despite its flaws. The game itself is good, it's just that I did not expect to find the flaws I did from veterans of the industry. If you liked Wasteland, and you liked Fallout 1 and 2, check it out. Of course, I must stress this -- it is NOT Fallout. Don't get the game expecting Fallout.

content:
, 2014
Early Access Review
								The fundemental flaw in the YES OR NO recomendations in steam reviewing platform really starts to ♥♥♥♥ me off when you review Early Access or alpha build games.  The problem is like many alpha and early games the changes that can and will come can drastically alter your entire experience.  In some cases an entirely new build may completely destroy what you got use to over the last 5-6 months of playing.Wasteland 2 I waited until it was on sale for, 60$ price tag was justified by not spitting in the faces of their kick starter backers, and I do respect that.  Was the $40 (on sale) I paid to play this game a few months before release worth it?  I would say yes.  While not an MMO and i won't get points for getting to x, y, z before anyone else, it still is a really solid return to classics.It shows that classic systems implemented correctly into newer engines can play really nice together.  Now I must admit i don't remember much if ANYTHING from the original wasteland, but I do remember Fallout and playing that.  This game feels more at home with an isometric Fallout (to me at least).  It plays really well, but for some it can be described as "too slow".Wasteland 2 doesn't hold back on a classic experience by giving you a bunch of tools at your disposal, and giving you the freedom to resolve conflicts your way.  Save a few game breaking bugs (again early build beta), the game is overall really solidly done.  Now while playing I felt like I have in most RPGs eventually your character becomes a hoarder and you are able to basically buy anything without it having it hinder you in any real significant way.For being survivors of a wasteland these guys sure as ♥♥♥♥ stockpiled the ammunition up.  It became overly easy to have an abundance of ammunition, also after recruiting 3 extra characters ontop of your 4, you become a small wrecking crew that is essentially an unstoppable killing force.  There are moments that will give you some pause and trouble, but for the most part i was able to breeze through the content without too much trouble, hell barely even used my medic skill yet continued to skill it up.Despite this, as you progress you start to want to ♥♥♥♥ with the wasteland's inhabitants more and more.  From the Rail Nomads and their rediculous fued, to the Red Skorpions in the prison, even the lowly little Wreckers.  All in all the game presents itself well, plays well, and has a story that is interesting enough to keep you wanting to play more.I do recommend when it releases, but I would not recommend the game for $60.  There is speculation if the game will be 25$ - 40$, and I'd recommend around those prices, but for just playing early on / few extras the $60 is up to your own budget.  A solid and promising title, with a good amount of polish and a hopeful final push before release date this could shape up to be an amazing title.Also the promise of the mod tools after release is a killer bonus as well.

												I have no experience with the classics of the cRPG genre, as I am a bit too young to have been good enough at video games to enjoy them during the glory days (25 now), but let me tell you something: This is the best genre of video games ever. No questions asked. I don't care if you have never played this style before, please pick up this game along with Pillars of Eternity. Honestly, these two games, which apparently aren't even as good as the true classics, destroy every modern game when it comes to storytelling, character development and lore. You really feel like you are a part of the world and that your actions are changing things. If you don't like to read, well ah, I guess Call of Duty is on here somewhere, but if you're even moderately intelligent, enjoy great storytelling and atmosphere, this game is for you. Don't be intimidated if you haven't played the classics. This is a fantastic game for rookies or vets.

content:
, 2014
Early Access Review
								Well as a fan of RPGs i couldn't walk away from this one. I mean this is a real hardcore, oldschool RPG at it's best! Early access brought on us many bugs, glitches and many times after another patch game would not run... but, now it's made a whole, there are some minor fixes left so what will Wasteland 2 can give you?Graphics: Decent. It's not masterpiece in graphical state, but it's not the polygons that make game looks, it's artstyle. And it's there! You think Wasteland 's a big sandbox? With some rubble piles here and there? Destroyed houses and cities? yes all that, but also plenty more! Gen labs, terrariums, farms, villages; there are enough places and variety to feel like home (if you're a fan of postapocalyptic).Gameplay: True oldschool. Do not touch this game if you're JRPG\console raised or school lad\lass. You probably feel lost, because game require brains to play. From Charecter creation to Wasteland jorney. You allowed to create up to 4 charecters, and will meet some more on ye joprneys, team can be 7 people max. And it is important what stats and skills charecter posses. Many times to find alternate root or to unlock secret, or simply to snoop around you will need some particular skill; One charecter will not be able to be master of everything, so think, do math... still you will probably will have to start game all over after first 3 hours. Stats btw are connected, so if you want fast or strong charcter you will have to sacrifice something in order to build that charecter. So it's important to understand what do you want, not blindly jumping into a game (stats btw can not be increased with level up, only skills can. Though you will find little trinkets here and there that will amplify particular stat). And the most awesome of all -- you can write your own biography for charecter! And use random avatars! As the game starts, well it's you standart RPG; World map, quests, exploration, fights... but with a certan twists here and there. For example, while wondering through the desert your charecters will need water and rad protection (or they will die) water can be refiled in Oasis or on base still you need to plan ahead. Combat can be very hard, or simple (depends on your charecter combatant skills and difficulty level), there are a variety of enemies and some of them can be really chalenging, or will require a certan tactic to defeat. Finaly a lot of secrets, alternate roots, quests that go against each other: Right from the begining you will have a choise to save X or Y and this WILL, I repeat WILL affect game, not like in JRPG or modern adventures. No, you WILL suffer the consiquences of ye choise... High replayability value. Music and Sound: Musik is... well it support atmosphere still you will probably won't even notice that it exist. Sound on the other hand is great.Final verdict? If you love Fallout 1 and 2, if you love oldschool RPG that require brain for play, if you hungry for challenge and want game that will give you freedom while restricting you gently. This is Wasteland 2 lady and gentleman: a game that every hardcore player and every oldschool gamer must own.

												Instead of telling you stories of what games that are similar to Wasteland or not, i'd simply tell you in short diary-form what you will encounter in your first 15 hours. Decide if that's your cup of tea or not.(This is from the point of view of a late-adopter that waited until release (except some 20hrs sneak peak) to dive into this. I have not read any forums/guides/walkthroughs or whatever. No spoilers!)- Read about all values/statistics and their interdependency. Think about what your group should be able to do- Best group ever! Will rule the wastelands!- First larger mission. Got stuck. Should have read the NPC-Dialogues. No pretty quest-pointer taking my hand. Ok, like in the old times now!- Walk into a fight feeling like a boss. This group can't loose! Got my ♥♥♥(es) handed over some seconds later. Bad lizards! Half the group is wasted, no ammo left, no medipacks to heal.- OK, Reload! No problem!- Lose one dude more this time- Start all over again. Thinking about lowering difficulty this time. Ego wins. If anyone would see that...- Walk into the next fight. Prepared you are! Fighting skills maxed, you have! Such clever, much thought, wow!- Survive the fight, come to the conclusion it was stupid to NOT have secondary skills too.- Restart. Lowering difficulty to match my...skills...noone will ever know!- Got a perfect group now! Everythings equalized. Should be efficient!- Met a new groupmember. Cool. Made 4 of my chosen secondary skills redundant. Still some others missing. DAMN IT!- Restart. FOR THE LAST TIME!- Clearing everything of <SPOILER WOULD BE HERE>. Except that one door. Need a skill i haven't covered. DAMN IT!- Should i restart? NO!- Screw that door. Oh there's another door i cannot open. DAMN IT!- Fights become controllable, i guess i start understanding. This is fun!- A Bossfight. Dead in some seconds. I suck at tactical combat. Time to admit it.- Finally did it. Piece of cake! Hard but doable with luck. I had luck.- Open next door, critical failure. DAMN IT! - Reload last savegame. DAMN IT! Before the boss. Forgot to save afterwards. DAMN IT!- Died again.- Time to write a devastating review! REVENGE!Do i recommend it? YES! Though it's really not everyone's cup of tea and quite anachronistic. Is it worth it's full price right now? Considering such epic failures like, e.g. Archeage, that are selling for like €144,-. Yes it's worth these 50,-Already put 15 hrs into it, and only scratched the surface i guess.

												Great RPG thats you can easily pour many hours into Pros+ Good story telling+ Unlike some RPGs nowadays your choices really matter in this game that can lead to great benefits and consequences+ You can play however you want build your team to your playstyle finish quests however you see fit+ Great dialogue system that has 3 different speech skills such as hard ♥♥♥ that lets you intimidat people kiss ♥♥♥ that lets you be nice to people so they may help you out and smart ♥♥♥ that lets you outsmart people + Fun turnbased combat that reminds me of the old Xcom games +Huge amount of skills to choose from everything from guns to blades to bombs hacking and speech+ Tons of replayability with all the ways you can play the game and the choices you can pickCons-The graphics in this game are not the best and the character models look quite dated even with this directors cut i dont really care about that but others might -Some skills in the game are kinda useless and others i feel are pretty much impossible to beat the game without- A lot of the combat and skill checks in the game as well as the loot system are heavly based on RNG so it can get annoying when you get a streak of bad luckOverrall i highly recommend this game to any fan of old school RPGs that dont hold your hand

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
y 6
												I recommend this game, but there's a few problems. basically, I had to open a walkthru to figure out a few quests, and I should never need to do that. and honestly, kinda tired of turn based combat, there's no way to crank the combat speed up to instant, so a lot of the petty overworld battles drag on. after the game removed one of my best party members in an unscripted story event, I actually downloaded a save editor out of frustration and gave myself a stack of free weapon mods and a ton of ammo. I feel like that is a flaw in the game design when I am suddenly and unavoidably crippled like that.that being said, this has a lot of charm and a good story. the final battle even rewards me for all the people and towns I saved, which is a great reason to take a lot of care when making decisions. I really loved being part of a well organized group of post apocalyptic vigilante lawmen right from the start, going on call and sniping monsters with my specialist team of tacticool operators.it's not a perfect result but at least they cared about the game. still, would have been better if I had the option to let scotchmo set off that nuke (oh, you mean I actually could have but didn't get any indication? that's not good).this is from someone who gave a positive review to fallout 1, 2, 3, nv, and 4. it's good to see someone putting in the work for a proper rpg.

r 20, 2014
												This game hates you.Loot aquisition is just horrible.  Make the best damn thief around, max out your skills and you'll still fail opening locks, safes, etc.  If you're so inclined you can save before and reload if you fail and try try and try a-frickin-gain.  I don't feel like cheating so I don't. At one point you get ambushed by a cyborg death squad that shoots you with energy weapons. It's crazy difficult.  The recommendations from the message boards: Before going into this situation strip off your armor.  Well grand. The game should have stopped in Arizona.  California is alright, storywise, but the game mechanics shatter.  Maybe it's a balance issue, who knows.  It feels like they wiped out your skills and reset them to zero due to the difficulty being so over the top. EVERYTHING in California is a Herculean skill difficulty.A lot of games really build up and reward you for the time spent, but no, not this game. THIS GAME HATES YOU.

content:
4, 2016
Wasteland 2: Director’s Cut is an isometric, turn-based strategy RPG set in post-apocalyptic Arizona. It follows the exploits of the Desert Rangers, a group of self-appointed peacekeepers who make it their business to settle disputes and protect the innocent from the horrors of the new world. Unfortunately, the Rangers have fallen on hard times of late, losing the trust of the common folk, and must work even harder to preserve their once glorious name.The game is an excellent update on a classic RPG experience, placing you squarely in the harshest of settings with a more benevolent role to play than most other “post-nuclear” game experiences with an excellent and open world exploration and battle system, as well as deep character customization and a dynamic, ever-changing story and world experience.Wasteland 2: Director’s Cut is very open in terms of story and flow, and will almost always provide a unique experience based on your party choices, in-game decisions, interactions with certain groups, and success in handling problems for the citizens of your jurisdiction. Each game is going to be a completely different experience based on the party you choose, simply due to the access or restrictions you’ll have from the skills your party possesses.THE GOOD- Immersive world packed with lore- Great world exploration- Excellent turn-based combat system- Deep character customizationTHE BAD- Bad camera control- Looks outdated in places- Crams a lot onto the screenDISASTER | BAD | MEDIOCRE | OKAY | GOOD | GREAT | AMAZING | MASTERPIECE

Welcome to the WastelandPROS+ NO BUGS/CRASHES almost after 5 patches changing the game itself for the better...+ VARIETY on quests (could be more but don't forget it was a kickstarter game not big a company)...+ REPLAYBLE starting over and over with different team and diferent choices which for me is the essence on this kind of game...+ DESTRUCTIVE enviroment & TACTICAL thinking on before positioning squad members, otherwise u are deadCONS- somewhat clunky UI but not that big deal- weak storyline and some bad writing on some quests- lacking in music & sound cover8.0/10Let me start by saying this game through the visuals & vivid setting reminds Mad Max universe, post apocalyptic, desert (for the most part), raiders etc etc my kind of favouriteAfter 100+ hours i concluded that you die a lot in the wasteland, which that can happen by a number of reasons poor character creations, bad judgement on the skill sets, choices that didn't come out and so on, thus making starting over trying to find the best squad to survive. This by all accounts is an excellent game...in overall i would strongly recommend it especially if you are a sucker of those old classic RPGs and with winter sales coming and going you can easily enjoy it more by getting it on discount. *MICHAEL BAY directed the last part of the game

content:
r 25, 2014
												I know this game is in no way linked to the fallout series, but obviously there are direct comparisons to the first two fallout games, and possibly tactics as well.  A lot of players have commented that it brings back the feeling of the old fallout games, but I can't agree with them.  The greeat thing about fallout 1 and 2 were the intellegence and humour of the games, and also the sense of progression.  The quests and puzzles were tricky, but not so much that you got fed up and gave up on them.Wasteland 2 seems to have taken all of the bad bits of the fallout series and left out the good bits.  There's lots of trudging around the wasteland with not much to do.  You encounter vastly overpowered enemies early on, you have to cycle through reams of pointless speach, progression through ranks is slow and painful with little reward at the end, the missions are nonsensical and give you little clue about what you are doing.  The last point is the worst part about the game.  I've trudged about for hours trying to fathom out what the hell I'm supposed to do to complete the first missions.  I ended up being attacked by most of the main characters and having to kill them!  I'm so gutted that I paid top whack for this game, as I really wanted to, and really tried to enjoy it.

number of helpful: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
r 24, 2014
												I would recommend playing fallout 1 or 2 instead of this game, it starts with your character talking to a ranger, no explanation about who you are or why you're here, he just tells you about the death of another ranger and assumes you're in on the loop, you're dropped straight into the story with no idea who your character is or how they got there. So you and your team of 3 (which you just met without introduction) leave the ranger camp to investigate a ranger's death for you're boss you just met, and for a moment I expected to embark on a grand adventure but dissapointingly the ranger died just a short walk away (along the way you'll have to fight the same 3 or 4 raiders over and over again) The team you lead doesn't say anything to eachother, apparently no one cares who they are or why they're here they never react verbally or non verbally to anything they're seeing or doing. In fact every NPC feels as lifeless as their voice acting, which frankly is dull and boring, understandable had they been reading perhaps the 400th line of dialog at 5pm on a Friday, but it seems they carry the same enthusiasm or lack there of throughout the entire game or at least the first few hours that I've played.After a few hours I began to grow impatient and decided I was going to do my own thing because I honestly don't care about the rangers, or their quests. I thought maybe I can start a fresh in another part of the wasteland, but you can't go walking too far into the desert, oh no, don't go exploring and trying to have fun because then you'll die of dehydration, you need to stay around the oasis' which are conveniently located along the routes to places you need to go, mother nature you sly dog. It's disapointing that there's nothing to do around these oasis' except fight the same raiders over and over which for some may be fun for a minute or two, but you'll soon run out of ammunition and you're party is very fragile often bleeding from a single gunshot until death. Not a problem if you have plently of supplies dropped by the raiders you've killed for no reason, but wait a minute, I can't use it because I didn't go through med school, I needed to spec my character in a particular way otherwise I'm not able to heal. That's alright I'll just go back to the ranger base and get them to heal me up, seeing as I am helping them out by investigating the death of their friend. Nope, they'll let me buy more of the supplies I've already got with the very little money I already have. But it seems they aren't prepared to give me treatment or anything else accept for the odd 'hurry up and do your job' radio message, If only I could somehow communicate to him that our group is very close to dead and would likely not survive another raider ambush. It's puzzling how these characters survived for the 20 odd years prior to the beginning of this game without any decent weapons or currency? Don't think about that you gotta keep focused on the story, about a ranger that was killed by a giant frog when he went for a walk? The only appeal a game like this has for me personally is story and I am trying really hard to find some story here, it's just not happening.

content:
14, 2015
												First, if I do not recommend a game, that does not mean it is bad. It is just not so good that amount of money/time one gonna spend is justified to what’s he gonna get.That being said, here is a list of things I found disappointing (list is incomplete and unordered): Repetitiveness of using skills to get random scanty stuff from chests, safes, etc. One cannot know beforehand if there will be random contents in a box or not. It gets boring, and save-loads before each box makes it even more miserable. Unrelated skills and attributes make some of latter inferior. Some of the weapon types are inferior to others by design. One cannot know beforehand (one third of the game it is becoming clear, and you lost about 25 hours already). Some of the skills are not needed to to be taken at all as some of recruits will have them. One cannot know which ones beforehand. So player is doomed to waste either time to restart the game, or read spoilers in guides, or waste skill points which actually needed to upgrade needed skills as difficulty of the game makes a sudden jump up in about half the game. There are not enough locations to roam, gameplay is a bit too linear. If the game has a squad-based combat tactics in it, why do characters walk a crowd and there is no way to choose a formation before the combat starts? Especially sudden scripted combats. No way to revive fallen surgeon. Even paid doctors who rarely happen to be nearby cannot help. Sorry, lad, load your game. How comes leaders of two different towns are both into other men’s wives?Overall it is actually a nice game, which should be recommended to a person who has spare 150 hours of time and desire to repeat one half of a game to learn what should and should not be done at character creation. Maybe GOTY edition will fix some of the issues, but I am not up to repeating this adventure.

content:
r 20, 2014
												I had had high hopes for this game, finally a promising RPG-style, turn-based, post-apocalyptic game. It has been since the fall-out series that I have been waiting for something comparable.So there it was: Wasteland2.I started playing and thought:"This looks nice, this is fun. Looks promising!"Several hours in I was still playing, but something was off. It took me a while before I realised:"I'm bored."That is the problem of the game. Looks nice (if somewhat unpolished), story line is okay-ish, but the game devolves into endless shooty encounters where the best tactic seems to be: focus fire on one target and then go onto the next one". You can outflank and stealth and whatnot, but in the end focus fire is the main thing.Bored with all the shooting? Travel to town, here you can only talk and there is no combat whatsoever.Skills and characters are bland. Just dump all points into two or three skills per teammember and over-specialise. NPC's are cardboard boring figures with no depth. Your actions do not have real consequences, it may seem like it, but nuh-uh.It's not a bad game, but it is just very, very boring to play. To sum it up:An okayish game, but bland and boring. Not worth more than five bucks on a rainy Sunday afternoon.I worry about Tides of Numenera, if this is what these guys can offer.

Sadly to me it is a big disappointment and I really tried to like it.I've caught myself trying to find reasons to keep playing the game and just couldn't find any better argument than "you've paid money for it, now you have to play it".Everything seems uninteresting, uninspired or plain weird. The characters are boring, the dialogue is lame, the quests feel like a chore. I didn't get any sense of adventure or exploration out of the game - whenever I found something on the map it didn't feel like I've discovered something special, it doesn't feel like it belongs in the game world, it feels like a set piece that's there because later in the game you'll have to do boring quests in it. This makes exploration even more tedious since I can't shake the feeling that I might break the game or quests if I start going where the story didn't tell me to go yet.

content:
r 24, 2014
												I found the game to have serious game design flaws that make me regret the purchase.  May this be a warning to others.First there is way to much useless clicking involved. Seemingly every action requires another useless click. For example: characters don't just level up, one needs to call in to HQ then pretend to read the useless exchange with the caption then click through a series of boring dialog options only then can one go to assking skill points. Seriously I was annoyed by this even the first time around. You have to do this each time a character levels up ...Here is another: assigning an item to a hotkey is not just dragging the item into the hotkey slot, you have to right click the item (even though the help says right-click to use, you have to disregard that) then click the assign hot key then click the hotkey. The interfaces are a little sluggish so you won't be clicking all that fast either.Maps: The maps are tiny, cramped and sluggish. One seemingly needs to always rotate the map back and forth not to miss a detail. There is always another zone to load there is no sense of exploration or adventure.  All the background are prerendered and non mostly non destructible. It is very difficult to figure out quest objectives - some objects are "indestructible" until some quest objective is finished but still show up as targetable - so you end up wasting ammo on them. Combat: The game interface is unforgiving in combat - it is hard to tell which character is in LOS of another thus in danger to get into a friendly fire incident. Combat alway seems to play out the same way, the enemy bum rushes you - and because the AI is dumb it has beefed up stats to make up for that. See that big rabbit that you shot four times already - it still has an insane range and attack power and still has the ability to quickly take down a trained well armed ranger. It is just bad game desing.Travel: The map travel is boring and uninspired, who wants to watch an icon moving on a map - there is this seeminly pointless difficulty setting of having toxic fumes appear out of nowhere thus killing your entire party. WTF game design is that?I really tried to like this game but unfortunately it lacks the simplicity and fun factor of old school tactical games such as XCOM or Jagged Alliance.

content:
r 24, 2014
 Great game full of  bugs  Overall a great game. You can spend hours just building your squad, making sure that they have the right mix of skills, knowledge and weapons to survive and conquer. Which really leads you to invest in the team member you build and train. I restarted the game so many times to make sure that I was covering all bases and leaving the right gaps for recruitable NPC's to fill. This has kept me in the first part of the game for a while now. However, having an exciting and deep background story I don't mind going over it again as it allows me to  pick up on things I've missed and uncover new dialogue that I would have otherwise missed. There are more bugs in the game than I would expect from a product no longer in beta. Though not catastrophic, they can take frustrate and take away some of the fun from and otherwise well designed and thought out game. Also the models could use some attention as the seem to lack any real depth or contrast and on that note im also finding the camera system too constrictive in the way im not able change the veiw in all of the directions I would like. Camera snapping to charecters during combat is also an issue, it completely resets veiws and im finding myself having to constantly readjust to get the veiw back the way it was after each charactors turn instead of the black screen it leaves me with. There is also a problem where the terrain and light source seperate not allowing panning of the camera during combat when trying to move a charactor which I was frustrated with a few times. Using ladders during combat can lead to some very interesting animation where you can expect to see the charactor ascend the ladder when it should be descending and just recently my whole world map reset after a raider battle. Although the forums say there wil be patches, by the time they're released I and im sure many others will be onto a whole new game.Although I do enjoy playing the game I also enjoy playing alphas and I think that a lot of the features this game lacks or has wrong feels very similar to an unpolished product that should otherwise be less than $20 and have Beta stamped across it. The only real saving grace at the moment is the depth of story as the game at $40 should look more like $20 in this condition, after all there are games at this price point that outstrip Wasteland 2 in a lot of ways. So would I recommend it? Not at this price. However I do enjoy playing it but would like to see it cheaper until fixed. $40 for a buggy, glitchy game or $40 for X-com? Perhaps more time in Beta and less rushing to push the game onto shelves could have seen an amazing game to rival RPG's its predecessor "inspired" but instead, all we really get is a great story full of bugs.I've noticed people hating on bad reviews so I would like to say that this is my opinion of the game if you don't like it then that's yours. Don't be lazy, write your own review.

Early Access Review
								(English / Japanese review, 日本語レビューは下のほう)Brian Fargo did it. I'm happy that I paid $115 on it(for physical CE).Team based RPG with up to 4 rangers in the team(don't know if you can separate the team that you could in WL1).Combat is AP based, but Initiative decides the action order(not Player team > Enemy team system like FO:T or Jagged Alliance).Graphic is rough(Especially character models) but I believe that's what Unity isn't really good at, and it's not very important thing for *DEEP* RPG like WL2.Bugs? Small UI? Imbalance? It's still beta, get on with them and you can help it making better!Forget Fallout 4 and get it, NOW.あのRPG界の巨匠Brian Fargoの新作。Kickstarterで$115(パッケージ限定版+送料)払った甲斐があった。4人パーティを構成してプレイするRPGだけど、前作みたいに別行動させられるかは不明。戦闘はAP(アクションポイント)制ではあるがFallout TacticsやJagged Allianceとは違い、行動順はイニシアチブで決めれる形で敵味方が入り乱れて動く。今の問題といえばグラフィック(特にキャラモデル)の出来はそこまでよくないが、Unityを使っていること(超グラフィックよりマルチプラットフォーム化と動作速度を優先してるのだろう)や、超ディープなRPGにグラフィックは重要ではないのであまり気にならないか。バグ、小さすぎるUI、ゲームバランスの問題は、まだβだから仕方ない。というか今すぐ遊んでその辺が改善されるよう手助けしよう。RPGゲーマーを自負するならFallout 4なんて忘れて、今すぐこっちを遊ぶべき。

content:
12, 2015
												Let all comparisons to Fallout 1 and/or 2 be retroactively rendered null and void with the same nullification applied to all comparisons henceforth. Simply put: if you are looking for an experience like the original Fallouts, keep looking. This isn't any fraction as good as either of them because it simply isn't good at all.I can forgive an ENORMOUS quantity of technical faults. Bugs, bland combat, and graphics that were obsolete 10 years ago simply don't phase me if the less tangible aspects of a game are exceptional. These aspects include, in order: writing, character interaction, and world interaction/immersion (coherence, reactivity and a sense of player agency). Fallout 1 and 2 had these in spades and although no game can touch Planescape: Torment's character interaction, I at least never felt like I was running around with faceless, generic AIs for companions.I should've known by the fact that you create an entire party (versus one player character who represents you) that the most meaningful and elusive elements of an RPG would be missing (the feeling that you're a participant in a world). The difference between Fallout and Wasteland 2 is like the difference between Baldur's Gate 2 and Icewind Dale...except Icewind Dale advertised itself correctly and successfully executed the thing it was trying to do/be.I don't know if it was laziness or simply a lack of skill that produced this heap of a plot, but it feels like it could be either and/or both. At around the 12 hour mark, I hear the radio transmission about becoming immortal, invulnerable, disease free and beautiful...Combined with the mysterious robotic/synthetic threat, the 'faction' known as Children of the Cathedral and the basic ability to put 2 and 2 together, I deduced that the plot was something to do with turning people into robots. Not unlike Fallout 1's Children of the Cathedral being a front for the Master seeking to turn people into mutants who are long-lived, disease free, stronger, faster, better, whatever. That's so much not unlike it, that it's EXACTLY like it. You can't even call that an homage...because homage doesn't mean 'blatant ripoff'.And the writing that everyone is showering in praise? Here's a stool - I mean writing - sample from Wasteland 2: "A lone road stretches on. A dry wind whips at your back with the sandy shards from decades of lost hopes and dreams." That's the line of text you get on entering The Prison...which is a former prison now occupied by raiders. So not only is there no visible/audible wind/swirls/eddies/gusts, the other half of the description is hard to connect to a place that housed criminals in the past and present. I'm not sure that I care about the hopes and dreams of murderers...and unwarranted melodrama aside, it's just too lengthy and hard to read...the second sentence should've been broken up into two. Compare this with a description from Fallout 2: "Before you stands Hakunin, the village shaman. He appraises you with his crazy eyes from somewhere in the world only he inhabits." Not only is that less cumbersome/awkward to read, when you actually see and speak to Hakunin, you realize that a more perfect description could not have been penned.All I have to say about the music is that I can't believe it was done by the same Mark Morgan who composed Fallout 1 and 2's music. It's as if he couldn't find any inspiration in the material for which he was to compose. No surprise there.The voice work is...serviceable at best and one step shy of laughably bad at worst...but mostly serviceable. I don't know if it was for a lack of space on CDs or for an abundance of sense, but games back in the day RIGHTLY kept voice acting to a minimum. This guaranteed that the voices that were present were of excellent quality. Compare this to the Elderscrolls approach of giving a million characters the same grating voice. Thank christ for the march of technology. There simply isn't a game budget (unless Warren Buffet was involved) to fund quality voice acting for all characters. Wasteland 2 seemed to understand that...but then couldn't cast decent actors for the few voiced characters it had. It also should've voiced fewer characters and hired better actors instead.That about covers all the non-mechanical stuff. And the mechanical stuff has already been covered by everyone else and yes, it's as awful as they say. 5 different skills for opening things. 3 different skills for talking to people. Did there really have to be separate skills for assault rifles and SMGs? Or for bladed and blunt weapons? The more obscure skills yielded disproportionately better results than the generally useful ones, artificially decreasing the effectiveness of reasonable characters. For instance: Hard safes contained the same crap as easy safes but hard toasters contain useful and unique weapons?!? 4% jam rates translate to 6 characters jamming in a row for two turns??? It costs more action points to clear a jam than to reload?!?!?! I can make headshots but I can't target other body parts for at least SOME tactical depth?!?! Enemies can't do more than charge or stay in place? Characters' faces can't have features in 2015???I could've forgiven all of that...if only Wasteland 2 gave me a world I could care about with characters that were more than quest dispensers and text that was better than college level. UGH! Even the first major choice you make, going to Ag Center or Highpool, is so poorly and heavy-handedly executed. HERE ARE TWO PLACES THAT NEED RESCUING BUT YOU ONLY HAVE TIME TO SAVE ONE. MAKE A HARD CHOICE AND THEN LISTEN TO THE DRAMA OF THE SCREAMING PEOPLE FROM THE PLACE YOU CHOSE NOT TO GO TO!!! IT'S BRILLIANT AND IMPORTANT AND NOT AT ALL FORCED! In Fallout, there would've been 5 ways to handle it. 2 with different, gruesome outcomes. 2 different neutral outcomes. And 1 where the outcome was unrelated but important and revealed later in the game (like in the Vault City vs Gecko quest arc).TL;DR Fallout is an experience. Wasteland 2 is just a game. Don't buy this thinking that your Fallout needs have finally been answered. They haven't. Lets just hope Beamdog somehow acquires the Fallout license and remakes Fallout 1 and 2 with added content or makes a Fallout 4...or something...I don't know...I have a Fallout deficiency.

content:
er 13, 2014
												In short, Wasteland 2 tells a story about what you cannot do - open doors, chests or safes, hit enemies or talk cunningly. Mostly at the beginning of the game to be fair, but even later on there are several objects to interact with that often cause you to fail critically when using a maxed out skill on them. You then either have to accept this and carry on or load a previous save game and try again.Given the fact that the loot often is not worth the trouble, option 1 should be the way to go (or ignore the possible loot in the fist place), but that's not what I expect of a game. Reloading (and again and again sometimes) is a slow and tedious process. May be I'm not getting the point and Wasteland 2 then is not the game for me, but on the other hand this is a personal review and all about how I like it.There's more boring stuff in it, like quests which have you to visit the same places a few times over without the possibility to quick travel. Given the size and layout of some areas and the way they are connected to other areas sometimes causes you to sit there for minutes and tell your team to go back and forth. That's a way of extending the play time. One I don't like at all. Especially if the quest giver sends you more often than needed to the same place when all that has to be done could have easily been accomplished on the first visit.Personally I didn't care much for the story. Cannot really identify the cause though. I found myself mostly rushing through the dialog options, only scanning for relevant key words to get through quickly - which is a shame because I think the writing itself seems to be fine. But I couldn't connect the the world like I did when playing Fallout 1 and 2 for example. In the end I tried to solve all open quests and finish the story so I could mark this game as completed.Technically I had severe performance issues in some (mostly indoor) areas on my Linux machine and encountered several bugs. The Linux version of Borderlands 2 for example runs much better here.I'm not saying Wasteland 2 is a bad game. Most people seem to like it. But you have to tolerate a couple of things which just annoy me to the point the fun gets significantly spoiled. All in all I'm too disappointed to recommend this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
3, 2016
Product received for free
												DISCLAIMER: I didn't get the memo. I only have the original WASTELAND 2.WASTELAND 2 is a post-apocalyptic game with gameplay elements inspired by the first Fallout games. It's centered around the Desert Rangers, pretty much an untrustworthy police force that still tries to do their job and attempt to surpass their rivals, the Red Skorpions, and solve the mystery of the ranger, Ace's death. This game is not the prettiest, it has okay textures and pretty much the same environment, but inXile pulls a Nintendo and thought laterally with withered technology. Although the environments can seem kinda repetitive, it's a desert with bits of vibrant colors and life that makes every area unique.In terms of story, everybody has some story to tell. The Desert Rangers are the law, constantly trying to help everyone out despite their history. The Red Skorpions are scavengers that tend to do things better than the Rangers, the citizens of Highpool are a big water supply with a dead mayor and hatred for the rangers, and many, many, many more. And if you think it's just some linear solve-a-mystery story, you're wrong. You're the Desert Rangers and you have a job to do. There's even a part where you have to help one of two areas and hear the area you didn't choose quickly go downhill. There's side-quests in dem darn hills and there be plenty. The only real complaint I have is that the quests can be quite vague. And I got pretty stumped on one quest only to find out there's a specific stat for the quest, and that's the ever-so-helpful skill of rapairing  toasters. Difficulty wise, this game can kick your a$# if you're not ready. Guns jam, stats are expensive, and even having a conversation will be tough without certain stats. The combat is turn-based with every character moving around a grid and performing actions with a set of AP (Action Points), every tile you go to takes one AP, attacking takes AP, healing takes AP, even things like reloading and crouching take AP. The game requires plenty of strategy and that strategy isn't just, "Don't take cover by explosives, unload, repeat," and it can make quick work of your team, in other words this game is hard for anyone with a basic, or even no strategy.Overall, this game is tough if you do something without thinking, and it will make sure you know it, but it will still help you out by making the game in a way that takes you by the ear and puts you back in the right direction like how your mother used to.WASTELAND 2 gets an 8/10, and I reccomend it to those who want a test of the brain, and strategy, over.Now for the original WASTELAND...I'll just get an  LGR link. P.S. The third video (on the store page.) has gameplay from the LGR review of the original WASTELAND, watch the LGR review and look at the third video. It'll give you a kick.

content:
y 3, 2015
												Ok, so I guess I'll give a quick review of this game.To start with: I've never played Wasteland 1. I'm a huge fan of Fallout series however. I consider Fallout 2 to be better than Fallout 1 (I'll get back to it in discussion of Wasteland 2 later on), and I've played both F1 and F2 about 5 and 10 times each respectively. Also I don't like Fallout tactics, that game is just below average, imho.Now, on to Wasteland 2:  It's not a game that I will be re-playing once I'll finish my playthrough. As you can see I'm 45h in the game, so I guess I'm  getting towards the later part of the game (my chars are lvl 25s right now). The learning curve in this game is pretty steep. The first "real" assignment that your rangers get (well, one of the possible assignments) was downright hard, with some tought combat, spars med supplies and a lot of cursing, when one of your rangers died towards the end of a long combat. To be honest, I almost dropped playing the game, because of it. However, after you overcome those 10 or so first hours, the game does open up. You get to visit more places, do more quests, grind some levels, meet new recruits, build your party and become an unstoppable force that steamrolls through anything. The locations that you visit are OK, some of the are interesting, some of them made me yawn.Quests don't always have a "good" ending, and there are situations where you no matter what you do, "stuff" just happens. Characters - well, your core party of 4 rangers can be either pre-made (an option I never used in any of the games, where you can craft your own characters), or created from scratch. You can even write their own "biography". The additional members of the team (you can have up to 7 members in your team) are acquired throughout the game. They have their own personalities, set of skills and quirks. I found some, to be more interesting than the others, and some can/will bail on you during the game, if either your leadership perk is low, or certain events happen. NPC's are all over the place, but they do their part, and some can engage with you in hillarious conversations.Gameplay - essentially the game is a mix of X-COM and "old" Fallout. Quests have multiple endings and solutions. You can travel the global map and visit locations a-la Fallout, the combat however is just like x-com with your characters having a certain ammount of APs determined by states that they can use per turn.Tone - that's why I've mentioned my F2 over F1 preference in the beginning of this review. Basically F2 had way more dark humor and the overal tone of the game shifted compared to a more "serious" and "dark/brooding" F1. Wasteland 2 is somewhere in between those two games, imho. The tone is darker than in F2, but you can still find some good laughs here.Enjoyment - overall, I think that inXile did a good job, for their first project. There are moments, where the game feels like it's "crawling" at a snail's pace, but there's plenty to enjoy here - you get an overal alright combat mechanic, a decent ammount of locations to visit and quests to complete, lots of dialogue, multiple resolutions to the quests. Basically what I expected when going into this game.Score: If nothing will change by the time I finish the game, I'd say an 8 is a fair score.Why won't I re-play the game? it lacks that unique Fallout charm. It has it's own charm, but I guess it's not enough to hold me for a second playthrough.

content:
4, 2016
												First off, If you're born after the early 80's or discovered gaming late in life this game is probably not for you. I tried wasteland 2 (not directors cut) during the free weekend. I fondly remember the first fallout- and baldurs gate games and this is just like them. People have been bashing this game as slow paced and un-imersive but I disagree. Its slower paced than most games today, yes, but this is how it used to be with action rpg's all across the board back when. Its not un-immersive, you just have to immerse yourself as there's no great visuals to suck you in. There's so much to discover just by not skipping dialogue. The game made me feel nostalgic and I had many recollections of past games in the genre. Totally worth it for ~15-20$ just for that 'blast from the past' feeling! I'll definately get it when the price is right. One con is that the weapon balancing seems off. There's a heavy bias towards assault rifles but in the whole this is a minor issue.

content:
2, 2016
												The Pros: This game is dripping with atmosphere and has some amazing writing. The core gameplay mechanics are solid, and it ultimately delivers on exactly what it promises.The Cons: The 'annoyance factor' is pretty high. The game is filled with things that aren't prohibitively terrible, but just make you sigh and roll your eyes constantly. The weapon jamming mechanic adds nothing to gameplay and exists solely to be a pain in the butt from time to time, the camera often gets stuck behind things and makes seeing certain interactive objects very difficult, the game does not automatically reload weapons after battle, combat often feels kinda slow-paced and janky, etc, etc. Like I said, the issues with the game are not dealbreakers, but there are a lot of things here which just seem downright bad from a design perspective - many of which would have been fine ten or fifteen years ago, which is the era of gaming Wasteland 2 takes a lot of its cues from - but are just not acceptable by modern sandards.  It's still a really good game and again, I'd recommend it just for the atmosphere alone - they NAILED that aspect in particular just about perfectly. But it feels like they could have done better.

content:
ber 21, 2014
												My first night playing the final version of this game I found myself up past 3am. This hasn't happened since the Mass Effect series and Skyrim. The theme of Wasteland 2 is consequence. This is very much the same as Wasteland 1, but more pronounced. Everything you do has consequences, not just the little things like missing a target on the battlefield or epic things like the survival of mankind; though, those are certainly there. Your choices decides what individuals, factions, and settlements survive. Who you help affects who will help you in turn and even make new enemies. Despite the natural technical limitations of any scripted game, inXile has managed to deliver a game that provides a near a living, breathing world as I've ever seen. Even if that world is a radioactive wasteland rasping out what could be its last breath at any moment.There is a certain level of complexity to the game, but the character system (attributes, skills, equipment, and combat) is simple enough that you can grasp them quickly. The reason for this complexity quickly becomes apparent as you find you can use different skills to try to get around the same obstacles, offering you multiple approaches to the same problem.This freedom cascades in all things: how you build characters, how you approach encounters, the soluitons you choose, and the direction you take. Where there is a certain amount of gating (e.g. you must have these rad suits to safely proceed), you are free to explore, ignoring missions and quests as you like. This exploration can be quite rewarding as you find shrines and caches, but it can also get you in trouble as you face enemies more powerful than you. Again, consequences. Enemies don't "level" with you; so if someone's too tough, just come back later. There's still some bugs, sure, especially once you leave the desert for overgrown marsh of LA, but none of them are game breaking and I'm sure they will get shaken out.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
y 3, 2015
												Ok, so I guess I'll give a quick review of this game.To start with: I've never played Wasteland 1. I'm a huge fan of Fallout series however. I consider Fallout 2 to be better than Fallout 1 (I'll get back to it in discussion of Wasteland 2 later on), and I've played both F1 and F2 about 5 and 10 times each respectively. Also I don't like Fallout tactics, that game is just below average, imho.Now, on to Wasteland 2:  It's not a game that I will be re-playing once I'll finish my playthrough. As you can see I'm 45h in the game, so I guess I'm  getting towards the later part of the game (my chars are lvl 25s right now). The learning curve in this game is pretty steep. The first "real" assignment that your rangers get (well, one of the possible assignments) was downright hard, with some tought combat, spars med supplies and a lot of cursing, when one of your rangers died towards the end of a long combat. To be honest, I almost dropped playing the game, because of it. However, after you overcome those 10 or so first hours, the game does open up. You get to visit more places, do more quests, grind some levels, meet new recruits, build your party and become an unstoppable force that steamrolls through anything. The locations that you visit are OK, some of the are interesting, some of them made me yawn.Quests don't always have a "good" ending, and there are situations where you no matter what you do, "stuff" just happens. Characters - well, your core party of 4 rangers can be either pre-made (an option I never used in any of the games, where you can craft your own characters), or created from scratch. You can even write their own "biography". The additional members of the team (you can have up to 7 members in your team) are acquired throughout the game. They have their own personalities, set of skills and quirks. I found some, to be more interesting than the others, and some can/will bail on you during the game, if either your leadership perk is low, or certain events happen. NPC's are all over the place, but they do their part, and some can engage with you in hillarious conversations.Gameplay - essentially the game is a mix of X-COM and "old" Fallout. Quests have multiple endings and solutions. You can travel the global map and visit locations a-la Fallout, the combat however is just like x-com with your characters having a certain ammount of APs determined by states that they can use per turn.Tone - that's why I've mentioned my F2 over F1 preference in the beginning of this review. Basically F2 had way more dark humor and the overal tone of the game shifted compared to a more "serious" and "dark/brooding" F1. Wasteland 2 is somewhere in between those two games, imho. The tone is darker than in F2, but you can still find some good laughs here.Enjoyment - overall, I think that inXile did a good job, for their first project. There are moments, where the game feels like it's "crawling" at a snail's pace, but there's plenty to enjoy here - you get an overal alright combat mechanic, a decent ammount of locations to visit and quests to complete, lots of dialogue, multiple resolutions to the quests. Basically what I expected when going into this game.Score: If nothing will change by the time I finish the game, I'd say an 8 is a fair score.Why won't I re-play the game? it lacks that unique Fallout charm. It has it's own charm, but I guess it's not enough to hold me for a second playthrough.

content:
y 1, 2015
												What I like about this game is it doesn't hold your hand from the start. The character building is deep enough that you have to really think about rounding your team out. For instance you might not want a heavy gunner and an assault rifleman because they use the same kind of ammo, which can be sparse. Every fight requires some strategization, from avoiding triggering environmental stuff to positioning your shotgunners so they don't also pellet the guy in front of them. The game is also difficult enough that I don't feel bad about savescumming. At first I was honestly wondering why there wasn't an ironman mode because that seems to be so popular nowadays, but I see why. This is one of the few games lately that can keep my attention for hours on end. It might not be for everyone but I highly recommend it for people who enjoy CRPGS because so far it's gone toe to toe with the classics and has me curious about Wasteland 1.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 20, 2014
												A solid return for a beloved series and another title for 2014 that shows the turn based tactical RPG of old is making a comeback in a big way. The original game inspired the Fallout series and with this game they return the the spirit of Fallout 1 and 2 with a party based RPG with tactical turn based combat. Set about 20 years after the events of Wasteland 1 (Its not neccesary to play that game, Wasteland 2 is a stand alone story. Though fans who played it will see various call outs to the original)  You play a rookie in the desert rangers, a group of people dedicated to bringing law and order to the Wasteland. Surrounded by radiation from the war, a lot of people believe the rest of the world is completely destroyed, though a series of strange events that you are sent to investigate indicates that this is not the case and as the plot unfolds its clear that there are far greater threats in this ruined world that wandering bandits.  You have a lot of choice about how you go about things and you can either be a saviour or an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ depending on the choices you make, though if you go to far down the dark side, be prepared for consequences. The world is huge and the large variety of skills you can master means that most situations will have various ways to overcome them, though be prepared to spill a lot of blood as not everyone can be reasoned with or manipulated. The plot is interesting and its fun to see how the designers portray the post apocalyptic world. It also has a suprisingly dark sense of humour and there are quite few moments that will make you smile or even laugh out loud. Despite being set in a Fallout type post nuclear world the game still manages to have its own identity and feel like its own game. I personally love both and highly recommend it to Fallout fans and fans of old school RPG's or post apocalyptic settings. If you are a fan of all three, just buy the game right now, you won't be disappointed!

content:
2, 2016
												The Pros: This game is dripping with atmosphere and has some amazing writing. The core gameplay mechanics are solid, and it ultimately delivers on exactly what it promises.The Cons: The 'annoyance factor' is pretty high. The game is filled with things that aren't prohibitively terrible, but just make you sigh and roll your eyes constantly. The weapon jamming mechanic adds nothing to gameplay and exists solely to be a pain in the butt from time to time, the camera often gets stuck behind things and makes seeing certain interactive objects very difficult, the game does not automatically reload weapons after battle, combat often feels kinda slow-paced and janky, etc, etc. Like I said, the issues with the game are not dealbreakers, but there are a lot of things here which just seem downright bad from a design perspective - many of which would have been fine ten or fifteen years ago, which is the era of gaming Wasteland 2 takes a lot of its cues from - but are just not acceptable by modern sandards.  It's still a really good game and again, I'd recommend it just for the atmosphere alone - they NAILED that aspect in particular just about perfectly. But it feels like they could have done better.

												Really enjoyed this game.+ Old-school like post-apocalyptic world-saving :-) (a bit like Fallout)+ large world+ quests with multiple choises/endings+ ~50h for a relatively fast playthrough+ large amounts of lore-text, descriptive texts- large amounts of text :-) If you don't like reading walls of text then this game isn't for you. Very little voice-acting- minor bugs (e.g. lower-tier radiation suit doesn't get thrown away if you get the higher tier; can't sell)- sometimes not enough info for quests given (I would like to see a game which does the questlog like morrowind. A transcript of the conversation.) -> needed to consult wiki for some quests- not the best graphics- could use more diverse audioIf you are into oldschool post-apocalypse RPGs, like to spend a little time to get immersed and don't mind reading text then this is the right game for you.If you want the best graphics and are a fan of 'show, don't tell' -> better get one of the newer Fallouts

												Congratulations to the team at inXile, this is truly a masterpiece that makes the former titles Wasteland & Fallout 1/2 proud to be its daddy/grand daddy. Assault Rifles far outclass the rest, in particular with other burst weapons SMGs & Heavy Machine Guns, both do much less dmg per shot but fire more to achieve a similar result. It means you are wasting much more ammo for the same effect. The bigger calibre Hvy Machine Guns should definitely be doing more dmg per shot (with more armor penetration) than AR, but fire less often, not the other way around!

content:
r 5, 2014
												First off, wait until this game has been out a few months before buying it.  It needs several rounds of patches, especially in the 2nd area.Anyway, it is rare to get a sqad based game ala Jagged Alliance, let alone one set in a post-appocolyptic world.  I did have fun exploring the world despite the bugs. I would rate the combat mechanics as a 5 on a scale of 1 to 10.  They are servicable and certanly can be improved.The skill gain system is quite dull, such as the next rank just adds 6% to some ability (hit with a guy, unlock something, disarm something, etc...).  Some of the puzzles in the game are not very intuitive.  I had to google a few of them, but hopefully if you wait a few months, there will be some nice faqs.  Even after reading the solutions to some of them, they are things I would have never figured out.  For in one area you find a screw driver.  In another room there are some odd looking tiles here and there.  No tool tip, just odd looking.  The thing is, there is no hint that you need to use the screw driver on these tiles.  Even given that, if you use the screw driver on the wrong tile (of the right kind) it tells you that you can't use the screwdriver on that.  So that would lead you to think that isn't the right use for the screw driver.  However there is one tile which looks just like all the rest of the tiles that say "You can't use the screwdriver on that" that you CAN use it on, which has the tresure you are looking for.Then there are other objects you find that have NO CLUE as to thier use, but indeed are useful to someone, somewhere.  Here is a hint, the stuff you get out of toasters IS USEFUL to SOMEONE SOMEWHERE.  It may even be useful to someone in another act.Anyhow, you might be wondering why I am recommending this to buy with the above said.  Despite all that, it is a fun game.  I enjoyed the exploration and the story.  I did not finish it because it was too buggy in the 2nd act.  Maybe I will someday because I am curious as to how the story turns out.

content:
ry 6, 2015
												Despite it's flaws, Wasteland 2 is an amazing RPG and a great follow up to it's predecessor. While inspiring Fallout, it plays more like Fallout Tactics, Jagged Alliance or even XCom by focusing on turn based team tactics. It has a few rough spots, which have been mostly patched, but glitches still pop up once and a while. There is a fantastic sense of exploration in the first half of the game, despite the second half feeling quite linear. The progression is slow and steady and a good story develops. If you'e a fan of classic turn based rpgs, or just a fan of Fallout, it's a great game to pick up, especially at it's lower price point of 40$. Plus as a bonus you get the original, which is still very playable to this day.

content:
2, 2016
												So I played this game while it was free for the weekend because the style grabbed my curiosity.The customization for character creation isn't bad, but there could be more to it. I think my biggest complaint is when you use your skills. I lost count on how many times I critically failed on something, when the chance of critically failing was like 1-5% chance. It's as if the percentages don't matter and it's all based on random chance. For example, I had to use computer science to unlock an electronic safe. I had a 98% to succeed, and I failed.....3 times in a row! This happened a lot more frequently, however, with disarming traps. Also this game leans heavily towards the intelligence attribute. If you don't have a high intelligence, it is incredibly hard to level up your characters' skills.Now the good things about the game. The storyline is pretty well done, although there could be more rewarding side missions. I like the play style of the game and the fact that you can move the camera practically however you want. I started the game on rookie, cause I have never played this game before, and it was still pretty difficult, until you got the hang of it and became OP.With all of that said, and I probably could have added more to both pros and cons, it isn't a bad game. Is it worth more than $20? No way. That's the most I'd pay for it. But it is a game worth buying. Just get it when there's a deal for it.

												Played it on the free weekend, convinced me to buy(Quick summary) - it's pretty much modernized fallout 1 and 2 if you liked those or didn't like the dated visuals but liked the gameplay like me, this is something you'd enjoy(Actual review) - As a person who loved fallout 3 and new vegas I was inspired to look back at the original games and buy them, but after about 5-6 hours couldn't stand the dated graphics any longer, they simply aged horribly. Why am I mentioning this you might ask? Well, this game is pretty much the old fallout games brought into the new age and while it's visuals arn't super impressive compared to many modern games, they get the job done and it runs with a good framerate. This game has tons of variety in weapons, weapon types, skills, etc. that makes each character feel unique and useful (although i'd recommend having mulitple people with the surgery skill so you don't have to reload cause your healer went down and died because nobody knew how to use bandages). Some cons with this game are that the camera can occasionally bug out when dealing with walls and that it suddenly has a massive difficulty curve once you reach the prison but overall it has good gameplay and systems and the devs knew what they were doing. I'd recommend it to anyone who enjoys both strategy games and adventure games with a post apocalyptic feel.if i'd be forced to give it a numarical rating i'd give it a 7.5/10, it's not perfect by any means but it's damn fun
