content:
2015
												I have just finished Wasteland 2, and thought this the perfect time to write a review.Honestly, I was very close to marking this game as not recommended, and I will explain this first. The game boasts that every player has a unique gaming experience but I truthfully do not believe this, quests and side quests are so linear that it is very easy to predict their result and I have never played a game where you gain a huge chunk of experience every 5-10 minutes, it is very easy to level up. The level cap is 50, my characters finished on level 48, levels 38 onwards are useless as there are not enough quests to warrant the skills needed from levelling. Finally, and most importantly I was really really disappointed by the last 5-10 hours of the game, it was hugely rushed and it was so blindly obvious as to what was going to happen.Now onto the good bits, and why I have decided to recommend this game. The world of Wasteland 2 is very open and after completing the first quest you are very much able to just wander off and find your feet. The biggest perk to me was building my own team of 4 very contrasting rangers, but as others have said honestly most weapon types are useless by the end game, I had 2 assault rifle users and 3 snipers including an NPC. The inhabitants of Wateland 2 are lovingly built and the game does have alot of dry humour which I found quite refreshing, and once again as others have stated, all NPCS are very down to earth and honest - most people are dead, life is ♥♥♥♥, everybody is fending for themselves, they hate rangers regardless of what you decide to do. Dont pick up this game expecting to be some end game hero of the world like BG1 and 2. You will always be jerks according to most of the population.This is what I loved so much about Wasteland. It is a very honest game and for this reason, very realistic. You can craft weapons, if you are not strong enough for body armour you are useless in a fight, you have to reload your weaons or you go in to the next fight with empty magazines, weapons jam and bullets are expensive, barter skills do not help significantly, I could go on. These are just a few parts which I loved. This game does not hand feed you, it kicks you out of the door and if you can't disarm that bomb or unlock that door or patch up that wound then you don't get some silly perk to be able to do it, you have to come back when you are stronger.I could write paragraphs and paragraphs, but in the end Wasteland 2 is very realistic and the story line is gritty and substantial. The graphics are not great but this is more than made up for by the amount of in game material to keep you busy. Overall? 7/10.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
r 1, 2014
												Well, a solid 41 hours later leaves me with a rather lacklustre sense of achievement, and a general confusion and frustration with how long it took to end. The lack of tactical options is frustrating - to say the least. Definitely an improvement over similar modern titles in the like of XCom, however compared to the classics the tactical options still fall tremendously short.I also have trouble seeing past the walls of text - in the end, I just didn't care. I didn't care about the characters, I didn't care about the storyline, the game just left me with a general sense of "meh". The throwbacks to pop culture were initally funny, but dragged on and ultimately became just another "meh" moment.The skill system became trivial towards the end of the game, where there were more than enough points to go around.Difficulty curve? The "difficult" part of the game is scaled by opponent health, which, after carrying around launchers for most of the game, quickly disappeared. I think the "hardest" part of the game was working out which option to choose, which in itself is another attempt at "grey" decisions. Spoilers ahead;I saved the AG centre. I never saw ANY repecussions in the game world for not saving Highpool, besides a slightly different map and a shout-out at the end of the game, trying to guilt trip the player because of a choice they could do nothing over. If I'd saved Highpool, I probably wouild have received the same ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.I also defused the nuke in the canyon. The monks disappeared? No cares whatsoever - I never saw any repecussions in my game, except for a slightly different map on the way out of ♥♥♥♥-central. Overall, a very solid "meh" out of 10.Didn't care about the story, didn't care about the characters, didn't care for the combat system. Not even sure why I finished it, but I did. So that's something.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
y 10, 2015
												With tons of lore and plenty of content, I found my self pouring hours in to this game. Wasteland 2 may not have the best graphics, but for a game on a budget, it did pretty good. The game definately does things better than some games that came out in 2014. However, there are a few bugs. Such as characters not wanting to follow where you tell them to and your mouse disappearing, but usually these can be fixed with a quick restart of the game out return to the main menu. I found myself laughing at the little things in Wasteland 2, as well as reading it's what seemed like endless lore, doing it's numerous side quests, and replaying the game to see the affects of the choices I did not make in my first run. In all I give Wasteland 2 a 9/10 since there are some bugs that need to be fixed and the character customization could use some work ( the characters look pretty bad and ugly close up), but in all the game is really fun.

												Crowdfunding done right!!!   This was one of the best gaming experiences I have had in a very long time.   The level of detail that went into the story made for an extremely immersive experience.   While some people may not be a fan of the genre,  overall,  this is a must buy.I will caution you, I ran into a bug towards the end of the game.  Despite my efforts I was not able to fix,  and decided to move on. number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 19, 2015
												I bought wastland 2 while it was in beta. I loved the game from the start, and actually wanted to support Brian Fargo.It was a great experince playing the beta to the finished verison. Of course any major patch would break your saves, but it's that type of game where you want to restart a few times anyway, more so to play with your Characters stats. I will say a lot of people have wrote about the game not being very tatical. There is some truth to that, there aren't too many cases where you can strage your characters for a fight, most encounters are just a straight up ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ contest. A couple of hours just exploring the wasteland and looting will turn you into one tough ranger. In the start of the game it seemed like there would be a lot of choices that would directly effect the game. Basically there is only one major choice to be made in the game and really only effects which character your going to pick up as a side kick. Some of the weapons don't hold much value, such as rocket launchers. Generally before you can use one the baddies are  on top of you already, or it's just not worth using. But it's interesting that you do have to have  players who are better with riffles than lazer weapons, which is part of the tatical portion of the game. Basically each Character should be very well rounded with two different weapons, more so till about 30 hours into the game. You can't have everyone using the same ammo. Half the game takes place in AZ and the other half in CA. CA is interesting because things just get very strange. In any post nuclear war game youe expect raiders and mutant frogs, but crazy nuns? I wish the AZ portion of the game had more of the odd ball encounters you ran in during CA. The Characters in CA are more interesting as well as the plot.What I don't understand is the water movement system. In the first half the game you need to refill your canteens which isn't a big deal. In the second half, the concept just stops. It's minor, I'm not sure why I'm even bringing it up but it seemed like a major portion of the game but slowly got scaled back. I had a lot of fun with this game, like fallout you play for the story and the ride, not so much the end result. It does have a lot of replayability, but as I said I played it from beta which meant I had several restarts. It does let you import your characters that you have progressed through out the game when you finish. A lot of the skills overlap, and there is more than one way to open a door generally. I paid 60 dollars for the game and got a little over 230 hours of pure enjoyment of the game, it was worth every penny. I just hope they make a wasteland 3 or a DLC to the game. One thing they should add is being able to make your own rangers at your base even after you started. I think that would be a fun concept.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 25, 2015
												Bbbbbbrilliant!I won't lie, I was a huge fan of the first Wasteland, so this was kind of a no-brainer for me. THEN AGAIN I was a huge fan of Diablo 2 and Diablo 3 was a pretty huge let down. Same with Master of Orion 2 to Master of Orion 3. Sequels sometimes suck, but this one totally didn't. As a game, it's pretty unforgiving, and I like that. You screw up and don't have the right array of skills, you'll pay for it. (on a side note, bring 2 people with the surgeon skill. Any level, doesn't matter, just be sure one can revive the other) Not paying attention to your ammo stores? You'll pay for that too. Murder some random civilian? Depending on who, where, and when, yeah that'll bite you pretty hard too. Most things in the wastes want to kick your ♥♥♥ or some reason or another, so you kind of have to stay on the ball. Normally I'd complain about the lack of explanation and tutorial, but I feel like they built this game to be like the games of the 80's and 90's where you sort of were thrown into things and just had to figure them out, and in spite of getting the crap kicked out of me repeatedly, I appreciate that here. On a side note, you don't need to play the first one at all to enjoy this one. It's been many years and I don't remember much from the first one, and I still had a blast with this. On another side note, there are a crap ton of 80's references a lot of folks won't get. Hell, I'm pretty sure I didn't even get most of them. My most successful arrangement so far went something like :The heavy - bladed weapons / shotguns. Obvious muscle skills. Hard ♥♥♥. The B&E sniper - exclusively sniper rifles. Safecracking and alarm disarming, etc. Kiss ♥♥♥. Auxilliary surgeon. The leader - SMGs / Energy weapons (huge in the late game). Leadership, medic, surgeon. Smart ♥♥♥. The gunner - AR / Heavy weapons. Demolitions, survival, miscellany. For NPCs on both play throughs I turned one into a second sniper (two snipers is devastating), turned another into a second melee / shotgun guy, and the last was kind of open. Go forth and turn people into blood sausages!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 26, 2015
												I've been playing Fallout 2 since I first bought it new in 98' and never got the chance to ever play Wasteland, although I was aware of it and its profound influence. I picked up this game as soon as I could afford it and have fallen in love with isometric turn based combat all over again. I first played this on my off the shelf HP desktop with just a factory AMD A8-6500 using integrated Radeon 8570D graphics. This game played well with decent performance in all situations without measuring FPS on low settings. I since have added a GTX 750 Ti and can play the game maxed out and it is running over 60fps in all situations. So with my A8 barely on par with an Intel i3, anyone can pretty much enjoy this game on low end systems. Graphics: 10/10, it is beautiful and is what you would expect from a Fallout type universe. Combat: 10/10, some nice features that remind me of FO Tactics, familiar and easy to grasp.Gameplay: 10/10, much like Fallout games there is lots to see and do, side missions and quests, hidden things, locked or blocked things you can't get to until you level up or gain a perk. Good replayability. A major tip for new players: Make sure when building your squad you incorporate certain skills. This is not like Fallout games where you could master all skills throughout the game such as demolitions, lockpick, traps etc. This game forces you to equip characters with these skills or they simply will not be able to be utilized at all until you have a character possesing that particular skill. So if you start your squad and nobody has lockpicking skill, you will not be able to lockpick any doors at all until you acquire someone that does have the skill. If you like Fallout or the genre, you will not be dissapointed! Price has consistently dropped over last few months, I paid full price and would again.

												It's a bit hard to get into at first as it goes back to alot of conventions of older games and you have to really pay attention to figure out what to do. This is an absolute MUST play for all pc gamers and lovers of all forms of art.

content:
r 31, 2014
												First what I liked:Pros: -A lot like fallout 2, which was really great I haven't played a game from start to finish like this since I can't even remember. Probably fallout. -Combat was really fun, weapons were enjoyable, deaths reminded me of fallout in a good way.-I enjoyed the vast world, and exploring.Really a great game, butCons (in my opinion)Spoiler alert.-First I have to mention the crashing, there was so much of that. I've never played a game with quite so much crashing and errors.-Where are all the secrets? I found a lot of hidden boxes and stuff like that, but truely awesome secret stuff I found myself constantly looking for and not finding.-No vaults? That was my favorite part of fallout, and yet no vaults to be found.-No mystery. You pretty much always know your objective, what is going on, with no twists to be had for the most part.Again I found myself wishing I would stumble across something epic, something amazing that changed the way I thought about the game. But no, just more of the same, kill move on, kill move on. I would definitely like to see mystery like the classic fallout games. You never knew what you were going to find at the depths of a random cave in the middle of no where.-No special encounters. Sure you would encounter a passing trader, no fun, or a shrine that gives you a quote and a skill point, but I long for something more, don't you guys remember how amazing it was to see that lightning bolt in fallout 2 and discover something completely random, and truely amazing? I kept waiting for those to appear because they are so interesting and again, are full of mystery. -Really cool followers. You guys remember the deathclaw/super mutant followers, as well as ghouls and various other creatures.  I didn't see anything remotely that cool, just a bunch of humans and of course there is the animal caller perk, but that wasn't really that cool either, the extent of the creatures you could control was so limited.-More weapons, and make them more difficult to come by, I remember in fallout 2 you were SO stoked to get your first weapon, finally a shotgun, or pistol with just a few rounds of ammo. It was incredibly more difficult then wasteland in that way. And that made it so satifying to finally start picking up some of those high end energy weapons near the end of the game. Gatlin laser mini gun, damn that thing was sweet.-No end game content, once you beat the game that's it. I would have loved if you had followed the fallout style and let you keep playing, maybe even adding in new locations and changing the areas based on what you found during the story line.So in conclusion, I hate to compare you guys to fallout so much, because the game was really nice, and fun. But you yourselves set the bar by comparing yourselves to fallout. I was expecting so much more from this honestly, and I finish the game a little dissapointed. I would still recommend the game, but I hope you guys read this, and step up the bar with wasteland 3, which I will buy, but again I really hope you raise the mystery factor, remember a really good story line leaves you with a few questions unanswered even by the end, always guessing and wondering what could happen next. It's that mystery that is the driving force, and without it, it feels like just point and shoot, continue. Most of the time I found myself skipping a lot of text because it was just so plain, and didn't really have to do with anything interesting, or "out of the box" type of thinking. Also the voice acting was not my favorite, I found myself turning down the volumn often, because it came off kind of cheesy honestly, and I understand it's a indie game but with the money you guys had, I want to see some serious skilled voice actors nail their rolls and really make you feel emotion.Sorry for all the negative feedback I hope you take it from a constructive perspective, I'm not trying to bash you guys I just want to see this game further embody the fallout genre.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 27, 2014
												Phenomenal. This is what happens when you let talent of the likes of Brian Fargo and his dream team of writers and designers (and Mark Morgan) create the game they wish to make: a love letter to classic CRPGs full of rich descriptive text and atmosphere, amazing depth in options, laugh out loud ridiculousness, and several truly chilling moments. In an age of gaming where we've grown tired of pressing the win button, Wasteland 2 throws hundreds of possibilities in your direction and doesn't even pretend to try to hold your hand, allowing you the joy of discovery and surprise as your decisions often leave no clear cut winners. You'll often find yourself under-equipped and struggling to keep your party members alive, tossing those last few rounds of ammo to a teammate and praying for their 35% hit probability to go your way after enemies have left you devastated. And right when you think you've gotten the hang of things, new scenarios will put you firmly back in your place. Wasteland 2 is a shining beacon of what games once were, and a sensational example of what they very well can be today when the fans - and not profits - come first.

content:
1, 2016
Product received for free
												For what it wants to be, it does everything right. It's an experience you could only get back in the day, with no handholding, no bottlenecked storytelling and no fast-travel. The combat is interesting as well, but with limited options. You can end up in situations that require changes in thinking and I like that. You will act differently when you are in a tight corridor againt snipers and shotgunners or vs Honey Badgers on a plain field.It got boring after a while, I played this game while it was free and I don't feel like buying it. The thing with this game is that you have to invest effort for the game to really shine; that means it isn't for everyone. You have to like reading a lot, and the plot took too long to develop so I have lost interest. You can read back on the log if you missed something, but you won't get an arrow pointing at the objective.The tone is very Fallout-y, as in, horrible and hilarious. the writing is good, in the dialogue and in the pop-ups that show up in the environment to set the mood.

content:
, 2015
Full disclosure: I am close friends with some of the developers of this game, however - I do not feel that this compromises the integrity of my review.I grew up playing the original Fallout, and other isometric-ish RPGs on the infinity engine. I've always had a soft spot in my heart for them and I honestly did not think I could ever return to that feeling.A friend picked up Wasteland 2 for me prior to release - I had my reservations when I started playing, but those went quickly out the window.Sure, it is said you can never go back to paradise -but you can come pretty close.I've just recently had the chance to finish my playthrough of Wasteland 2, the time and fun I've had from this title easily justifies the cost. However I don't think that is what I should leave as the primary point of the review.I am not one who enjoys replaying games, especially ones driven by a central narrative. I rarely find games that truly capture my attention and interest these days but Wasteland 2.. Well lets leave it at the following point:After completing Wasteland 2, I immediately wanted to reload my mid game save and play back through again with a different approach and playstyle to see how it affected the outcome of the game.I've not done that since the 90s. :)Loved this game, my game of the year for 2014.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
r 21, 2014
												Review as of 10/21/14 (and you'll understand why I included the date shortly)In brief, Wasteland 2 is a mostly-awesome Kickstarter (TM) funded game tainted by some very bad decision making.The game picks up where its predecessor left off, you are recruits for the Desert Rangers, a peace-keeping force in a post apocalyptic Arizona.  Your peace-keeping activities involve what you, the seasoned gamer, might have come to expect of the genre:  mutants, barbarians, and insane robots.  Where this game shines is in how it utilizes these very typical post-apocalyptic tropes to portray some very realistic and human settings as well as very real consequences for your actions.This is the most interesting development of this game.  Typically role-playing type games cater to the completionist crowd by making most every quest available and completable.  Wasteland 2 rejects this model forcing the player into branches of decisions and consequences which make other outcomes and objectives inaccessible.  Complicating this new quest model is that these decisions are never simple.  It is not a matter of choosing to save one good guy or one bad guy.  Instead the game asks you to decided from among two terrible choices.  Save this murderer or save this ♥♥♥♥♥♥.  The game gives you the option to sit on the fence for most of the quests, however, this comes with its own (often terrible) perils.Where this game also shines is in the little details.  Specifically the writing and music, both of which are excellent.  Even the voice-acting is mostly well done.  The game also plays like a sort of love-letter to the video game communmity.  This makes perfect sense as this game would not have been possible without the financial support of the fans of this community.The little details is also where the game falls apart.  The GUI, graphics (the world map), and combat mechanics all leave something to be desired.  Where the game falls apart is the entire last 25% of the game.  Although the game was delayed by nearly one year from its original date, and although it enjoyed a great deal of free beta testing from the Steam Early Access Program, this game was rushed to market before it was polished and complete.  The game literally falls apart at the seams in the last 25%.  This lack of polish creates nonsensical dialogue choices which makes the quests  broken.  Even worse is that the final encounters (those which shoudl be the most emotionally impactful) are broken.  In one I had to manually attack the boss to force a battle.  The final encounter is a simple matter of hacking and slashing your way to victory.  I wasted one attempt looking around for a secret way to complete the encounter and eventually realized you are simply supposed to blow everything up.  This unfortunate final encounter is partially a result of the boring combat system, partially a lack of imagination, but primarily the result of a game which should have been delayed by another year.It is easy to say this from the arm chair of course.  In another year the game probably would have run out of funding or the audience would have moved on.  InExile has been releasing rather huge patches every week since the game came out, however, one wonders how much a skeleton crew of developers on bug-fixing duty can really accomplish.  Each patch has thus far read like a bible but this game needs a church full of bibles to make the last quarter not suck.  I included the date because perhaps a year from now, if churches full of bibles, materialize, I coule recommend this game.  As it stands I only recommend the first 75%.

content:
13, 2015
												At 130.5 hours, I still haven't beaten this ♥♥♥♥ing game. This is the first time since New Vegas I actually pursued the side content actively and I love it! The Ranger customization really gives you a sense of connection to your team and there are some really interesting NPC characters you can interact with, some can even join you in your mission.The game itself is quite fun, holding simple, yet fun, turn-based combat combined with a well paced leveling system, a wide array of different skills your characters can spec into, and writing that you can tell had a lot of love put into it. I can tell the devs of Wasteland had a lot of fun and enjoyment with this game, returning to the roots of classic video games with their encouragment of exploration and higher difficulty. Overall, I'd say this game is worth your time. Though with any game it may take some getting used to. This is very different from the typical video game that comes out these days, retaining it's old concepts of exploration, branching paths, missions that can be failed without a game over (most of the time) and even have worse consequences than a game over, and requires you to manage who is talking with whom when you have a charisma guy in your party. It's still fun, and if it's on sale you should go for it.Also you can repair toasters to get random ♥♥♥♥ out of them. You can also pick up ♥♥♥♥ and sell it for lots of cash. 10/10

content:
r 21, 2015
												In my opinion, this is one of the top 10 crpgs ever made.  It has everything I look for in a crpg - party creation, good chargen and chardev, lots of ways that your skills interact with the environment, good combat, good story, great characters (like the kid that follows you around in the California base, Chisel, etc).9.5/10The only cons for me are -Would have liked 5 or 6 character creation instead of 4Too many and too much leveling that kind of makes the character development less meaningful.  A level cap of 20, 25 or 30 with slower leveling would have fit better IMO3d does nothing and adds nothing to the game but annoyance.  A fixed camera like PoE, Dark Sun, FO, etc, would have been my preferenceThat's it.  And I am well aware my cons are not really shared by the community at large.  Honestly, I did not believe inXile was capable of making a crpg, never mind a rpg I that is in my top 10 (and I've been playing crpgs since the mid-late-80s.  I am really looking forward to the new Bard's Tale from them now too.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 29, 2014
												A true Desert Ranger, what a journey it was to become one. Wasteland 2 has captured the essence of computer role playing games, the best indicator of which is the giddyness you'll feel when you think about doing another playthrough. It has an astounding wealth of good writing in it, so many encounters, quests and dialogues that are simply joyous to experience. The best thing is, that so many of these things can play out differently, depending on your party and your actions. A reactive world with a deeply emotive story.On your adventures through the sands, towns and cities, the game accompanies you with amazing music and visual style. The art and sounds immerse you, creating an atmosphere, that is both truly gritty in its post-apocalyptic splendor and darkly humorous with countless references and jokes. It's a world you want more of, a world you want to experience and are constantly thrilled to see what comes next.Combat is tactical and bloody, you will be able to attain all kinds of weapons, hilarious and deadly, and the death animations with the combat action descriptions make it purely Wasteland. Thoroughly enjoyable action from beginning to end. Different playstyles are well taken into account, playing with a bunch of melee bruisers or a squad of dead-shot riflemen, it's all equally satisfying. Though let's just say, that my favorite remains pummeling four raiders into red mist with a single well-placed burst from an automatic shotgun. Brutal and awesome.You will be creating characters of any variety you wish, and you will fall in love with them. The attribute system, skill system and a cool variety of cosmetic customization are a joy to tinker around with. As you play the game you will learn more about how the game progresses with the type of characters you've created, or NPCs you've recruited, and you'll be excited to try out different things next time. It's a game that keeps on giving.Do yourself a favor, if you've liked the 90's cRPGs, and play this game. It has been a long wait, but we finally got a game worthy of being up there at the top, with the best cRPG classics. Many games fail to deliver memorable moments, but this one, just like the good ones before it, has you fondly thinking back at the great things you've experienced with it.

content:
ry 15, 2015
												I am only 10 hours in and I am already beyond addicted! The kickstarter guys did NOT phone this game in (unlike another kickstarter game I won't mention *cough* *Shadowrun Returns* *cough*). This is the kind of game that will make you long for a return to actual RPGs and will remind you of why you fell in love with the genre in the first place. The character generation is so in depth! You have your basic stat setup (Str, Spd, etc) but all 7 of the core attributes work beautifully together. But where the game really shines is with the plethora of skills that you can choose from. You get four "core" characters and can recruit up to three more in game. I really like the 7 member squad, I don't like it when games limit you to only 4 or 5 members. I also am really impressed with how well the designers worked in making all of the skills actually useful and not just the combat skills. There are plenty of traps, locks, safes, alarms, and more that will make it essential to have a well rounded team with all of the proper skills to effectively get the most out of every environment you visit. Additionally where many games fail when it comes to "dialouge" skills--there are three in this game--and each one offers some very nice perks. The setting is nice, but does not offer much of anything new to the whole post-apocalyptic setting found in many games today (I do concede that the original game--to my understanding--spearheaded this type of game though). But it is still a fairly well written story. Also, I admit I don't know how often this will happen in the game, I have already came across a choice that has acutal in game everlasting consequences. So that's always fun.This game can be hard and unforgiving, but in a good challenging way. So if you are a veteran of this genre of game you will not be disappointed. If you are a rookie but are tired of the cookie cutter action "RPGs" and would like to try something different, then at 30 bucks this might be the game for you. I will warn the rooks out there that there may be somewhat of a learning curve, but once you get past that you will finally see what all of the fuss from us older gamers is about.

content:
16, 2015
												Wasteland 2 is a decent CRPG, Game is worth playing especially if you loved the old Fallout games and wish Van Buren was real. The character creation is intimidating at first, but the manual will explain things. For the most part it avoids having any single attribute as a dump stat, although charisma and luck come close. The skill system could use some work. Three dialogue skills is two too many, and a lot of non-combat skills are just various ways to open loot crates, although there are several cases where high repair or demolitions are needed to progress in a quest. Strangely, your attributes only affect your derived stats - the majority of which are sadly hidden from you - but have no effect on your skills.Combat is a huge part of this game, and while it is fun it's also rather simple. It uses a turn based system similar to Fallout, but you get control of each member of your party. There's an ambush attack similar to overwatch from XCOM which is pretty useful, but there aren't any aimed shots except for headshots, which are pretty boring. The weapons are seriously imbalanced, with assault rifles becoming really good about 1/3 of the way through, and godlike in the end-game.The quest design is decent; there are a handful of major quests in both areas of the game that are pretty complex and fulfilling to solve but the majority of them are short and combat focused. The quests in the first half are more polished while the back half feels rushed and incomplete.PROSThe game successfully incorporates tips and training pointers as you progress early on in the game. Rather than have to go through boring tutorials, you learn along the way. Absolutely loving the Ambush option available when you encounter enemies. Makes for excellent strategy and placement and forces you to consider approaches for maximum benefits as you encounter enemies later on.The Unity Engine is nice looking, with details in landscapes.The game is realistic in that you need to be prepared to take on encounters by having clear lines of fire along with readied weapons. Shooting an enemy who's in front of another friend isn't a good idea...A planned approach with players who have specific perks like lockpicking, etc are beyond valuable early on in the game.The devs have a wicked sense of humour with very colourful language all-around in the game...CONS-When you are investigating in real-time an area, I find the map option lacking. There is no map function already built into your display. You can alternate to the map by pressing 'm' but I'd rather have it as part of the overall picture itself as you move your characters around. -Some of the penalities associated with shooting are not realistic. I have one merc crouched while another one behind him is standing up firing with a rifle and he still manages to friendly fire the guy in front of him. Stupid, and the devs should have taken this into account.-Some of the shooting mechanics are way off. I have a merc with a rifile crouched who cannot take a shot at an enemy who is diagonally across from me. -The AP for rabbits is ridiculously overgenerous. They can scamper across half the screen and still carry out an attack. -The enemy AI seems to have crazy high AP...-No regional Pricing for India I need to wait for a year to buy at suitable price.

content:
ber 23, 2014
												To start I might already mention it as many before, as a person who enjoyed a lot first 2 fallout games I do enyoj this game very much. Why?1. It  has enjoyable and clear CHARACTER CREATION, you choose and make your crafted characters to fit a specific roles. If you like some theory  crafting then you will enyoj crafting your own core 4 characters, if not you can choose the presets. thought it is not as complicated as the ones in fallouts.2. The actual COMBAT is more like the one in Xcom thought not as thight and combat orientated, still enjoyable with potential of some annoyances which comes of how the combat starts(I might have missed something) but as far I know combat starts when you hit enemy or when enemy spots you and attacks you unless you construct a character so it will always see enemy way before hi sees youand can realiably set up fights for your team. Also some unclearances about field of wiev if you use high cover. For some maybe combat would be slightly too boring, which has a higher chance of happening if you are playing on the easy difficulty.3. The ingame GRAPHICS might not be as good as some might want them from 2014, it varies from place to place. 4. The interactable Characters, NARRATIVE, NPC dialogs, impact of chouses in quests and dialog choises is there, and creates great feel of emmersion.I havn't finished the game but as far I have goten to I would say that they have nailed everything about this section, even the voice acting that is there is very damn good(and I have to mention that in the old-school spirit most of dialogs are in text mode only) also the humor is pretty good. 5. Seems that they have fixed most of quest bugs during beta (havn't experienced any bugs this far).TO SUM UP  If you love the RPG and general story side of these kind of games (like fallout games), if you like tactical turn based combat with randomness aspect, if you like crafting characters (making your own roles) some theory crafting this is THE game for you.

It uses a turn based system similar to Fallout, but you get control of each member of your party. There's an ambush attack similar to overwatch from XCOM which is pretty useful, but there aren't any aimed shots except for headshots, which are pretty boring. The weapons are seriously imbalanced, with assault rifles becoming really good about 1/3 of the way through, and godlike in the end-game.The quest design is decent; there are a handful of major quests in both areas of the game that are pretty complex and fulfilling to solve but the majority of them are short and combat focused. The quests in the first half are more polished while the back half feels rushed and incomplete.PROSThe game successfully incorporates tips and training pointers as you progress early on in the game. Rather than have to go through boring tutorials, you learn along the way. Absolutely loving the Ambush option available when you encounter enemies. Makes for excellent strategy and placement and forces you to consider approaches for maximum benefits as you encounter enemies later on.The Unity Engine is nice looking, with details in landscapes.The game is realistic in that you need to be prepared to take on encounters by having clear lines of fire along with readied weapons. Shooting an enemy who's in front of another friend isn't a good idea...A planned approach with players who have specific perks like lockpicking, etc are beyond valuable early on in the game.The devs have a wicked sense of humour with very colourful language all-around in the game...CONS-When you are investigating in real-time an area, I find the map option lacking. There is no map function already built into your display. You can alternate to the map by pressing 'm' but I'd rather have it as part of the overall picture itself as you move your characters around. -Some of the penalities associated with shooting are not realistic. I have one merc crouched while another one behind him is standing up firing with a rifle and he still manages to friendly fire the guy in front of him. Stupid, and the devs should have taken this into account.-Some of the shooting mechanics are way off. I have a merc with a rifile crouched who cannot take a shot at an enemy who is diagonally across from me. -The AP for rabbits is ridiculously overgenerous. They can scamper across half the screen and still carry out an attack. -The enemy AI seems to have crazy high AP...-No regional Pricing for India I need to wait for a year to buy at suitable price.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 15, 2015
												I am only 10 hours in and I am already beyond addicted! The kickstarter guys did NOT phone this game in (unlike another kickstarter game I won't mention *cough* *Shadowrun Returns* *cough*). This is the kind of game that will make you long for a return to actual RPGs and will remind you of why you fell in love with the genre in the first place. The character generation is so in depth! You have your basic stat setup (Str, Spd, etc) but all 7 of the core attributes work beautifully together. But where the game really shines is with the plethora of skills that you can choose from. You get four "core" characters and can recruit up to three more in game. I really like the 7 member squad, I don't like it when games limit you to only 4 or 5 members. I also am really impressed with how well the designers worked in making all of the skills actually useful and not just the combat skills. There are plenty of traps, locks, safes, alarms, and more that will make it essential to have a well rounded team with all of the proper skills to effectively get the most out of every environment you visit. Additionally where many games fail when it comes to "dialouge" skills--there are three in this game--and each one offers some very nice perks. The setting is nice, but does not offer much of anything new to the whole post-apocalyptic setting found in many games today (I do concede that the original game--to my understanding--spearheaded this type of game though). But it is still a fairly well written story. Also, I admit I don't know how often this will happen in the game, I have already came across a choice that has acutal in game everlasting consequences. So that's always fun.This game can be hard and unforgiving, but in a good challenging way. So if you are a veteran of this genre of game you will not be disappointed. If you are a rookie but are tired of the cookie cutter action "RPGs" and would like to try something different, then at 30 bucks this might be the game for you. I will warn the rooks out there that there may be somewhat of a learning curve, but once you get past that you will finally see what all of the fuss from us older gamers is about.

Would support the devs again!

content:
21, 2015
												I liked it from the beginning... it should however be noted that this game is a slow burner.Fallout 2 was one of my favs as a child, so I'll use it as a comparison despite the fact that WL2 isn't a Fallout game. I like the Wastland 2 soundtrack, though it maybe a bit avant-garde. It makes more use of ambiance, instruments that embody complex harmonics and lean arrangement, then it'll juxtapose those tunes with some driving electronic music for combat sections. FO2 had the same thing going for it music wise and even the newer Fallout games employ some very non-traditional music when the radio isn't on. I don't think there were any original pieces in the FO series that you would hear the mailman whistling. Also, if you haven't seen it, watch the movie The Stand. I think a lot of the original music from that movie, particularly the slide guitar portions, directly influence a few tracks for the Wasteland and Fallout games.Combat, if we're comparing this to older Fallout titles, is an improvement overall. It's not as much as an improvement to as say Pillars of Eternity made upon the formula of games like Baldur's Gate, but Wasteland 2 is still less clunky and requires less fuss than the FO 1 or 2. Combat can get extremely intense though. You will be confronted with situations that require tactical engagement and that might get you through threadbare. The real draw of the game for me is the story. There is a sense of intrigue from the beginning and you're there to hunt down answers. Along the way you meet some characters and the interactions feel meaningful. Also, a lot of areas of the game are chockful of macabre grim darkness and despair, which appeal to me greatly.I say give it chance. Some of the things about the game are hella sketch especially those godawful 3D character models and the optimization is poor for what the game is, but it's got a great aesthetic and the story should keep you wandering the wastes to solve the mystery.

content:
y 22, 2015
												This game is unique.  In the parlance of our times, its 'genre' doesn't really exist anymore.  Once, there was a time in gaming when titles did not have to contain certain genre tropes in order to be easily classified and immediately accessible.  So you would do well to consider what this game is, and what it is not, and adjust your expectations accordingly.This game is fan service of the highest order.  The original Wasteland game lives and breathes inside of this one.  This is the master class on how to update a title with current technology without sacrificing the spirit of the original.  If you loved the original Wasteland, you may buy this title immediately without reservation.  It will blow your mind.  This game is for you.  They made it for you.  Praise them, and thank them for closing the loop. We have come full circle from our gaming origins, and we may now rejoice in exploding our foes like blood sausages.However, it is important to note:THIS IS NOT A TACTICAL SQUAD BASED RPG.  This is an update of a title from an era of gaming where, due to technical limitations, it was difficult to even render your party members as seperate icons.  So obviously if you are looking for compelling, deep and complex tactical turn based combat (as I often do) then there are dozens of other titles that do it better.  Its just not a priority for this game, this game is about narrative, it is from a time when narrative was king.  Comparisons to X-Com and whatnot are missing the point.Anywho.  The writing is brilliant, the world is vibrant, the nostalgia is soul shattering, the humor is mature and hilarious.  It didn't make me feel bad about myself the way Fallout did.  If narrative is your jam, you're gonna love it, the wonky camera won't hamper your enjoyment.  If you're under 30, be warned you will have to click your mouse more than you're used to.Franchise reboots are for suckers.

It  has enjoyable and clear CHARACTER CREATION, you choose and make your crafted characters to fit a specific roles. If you like some theory  crafting then you will enyoj crafting your own core 4 characters, if not you can choose the presets. thought it is not as complicated as the ones in fallouts.2. The actual COMBAT is more like the one in Xcom thought not as thight and combat orientated, still enjoyable with potential of some annoyances which comes of how the combat starts(I might have missed something) but as far I know combat starts when you hit enemy or when enemy spots you and attacks you unless you construct a character so it will always see enemy way before hi sees youand can realiably set up fights for your team. Also some unclearances about field of wiev if you use high cover. For some maybe combat would be slightly too boring, which has a higher chance of happening if you are playing on the easy difficulty.3. The ingame GRAPHICS might not be as good as some might want them from 2014, it varies from place to place. 4. The interactable Characters, NARRATIVE, NPC dialogs, impact of chouses in quests and dialog choises is there, and creates great feel of emmersion.I havn't finished the game but as far I have goten to I would say that they have nailed everything about this section, even the voice acting that is there is very damn good(and I have to mention that in the old-school spirit most of dialogs are in text mode only) also the humor is pretty good. 5. Seems that they have fixed most of quest bugs during beta (havn't experienced any bugs this far).TO SUM UP  If you love the RPG and general story side of these kind of games (like fallout games), if you like tactical turn based combat with randomness aspect, if you like crafting characters (making your own roles) some theory crafting this is THE game for you.

content:
ber 28, 2014
												Let me tell you about Wasteland 2.I was out on a mission after having managed to strike a truce with a potential enemy who'd already flattened my crew more than once. The guy who tried to land the Desert Rangers in trouble with them is scared for his life because I dobbed him in as the true culprit - even after he helped me put things right, even after I said I wouldn't. He runs off to get his scaly mates all wound up and ready to make trouble.I think about it for a split second then headshot the stupid bugger. He can have his little hissyfit, but there's no way he's stuffing up this unexpected and welcome truce, Not while my sniper's rifle is loaded.Then I realise the effect this game is having on me. I'm horrified with myself. I rationalise the decision: the guy was too dumb to live; he'd have only got more innocent people killed; he was trying to covertly start fights he couldn't finish; at least if I put him down like this the other mob wouldn't torture him to death or something. I'm even more horrified at the rationalisations. I wonder if the game even has an event path for what I just did. Would his friends jump me next time because of a bug, or did he need to actually make it back to his friends to trigger that situation? Would there still be a truce when I got back? Did I really take care of the problem? The problem. Huh. That problem had a name. And friends. Possibly a family.This game is getting me to play like an amoral hardcase for the first time ever (usually I do my best to be a good guy) - and I simultaneously love it and fear it for that. Not because it's fun but because everything is a moral grey area, every success has a bit of failure in it, and it's rare for everyone to make it out alive and unscathed.10/10

31, 2015
												I'm about a dozen hours into the game and as a fan of the early Fallout games, 'Wasteland 2' totally nails the small-scale tactical feel of Fallout combat (I never played the original Wasteland). Like the Fallout games, there are multiple ways to approach every situation, and your dumb meathead party member can be as useful as your pointdexter electronics nerd, if used right.All the environments are very detailed and each city is unique in terms of design, though the brown / green colour palette gets a bit boring after a while. Totally suits with the theme, so can't really complain too much about that.On top of that, the writing is pretty solid, with a lot of references to previous games and easter eggs as you'd expect. No Richard Dean Anderson though. Boo!Basically, if you loved the Fallout games, you'll really like Wasteland 2. If you hated them, I don't think this game will change your mind. But then, I'm pretty sure this game wasn't made for you anyway, so that's fine :)

content:
er 30, 2014
												For those of us still haunted by that fateful choice in Highpool on your Commodore 64, here is your chance to make amends and end that 30 year reoccuring nightmare...Not gonna take away from Fallout. Great series in it's own right. I missed suma ♥♥♥ laude by .02 thanks to Fallout 3 being released 2 weeks before finals exams of the last semester of my senior year at university. Yeah, that's how much I love this series.  However, the original Wasteland had a style of humor and storytelling that was unique for its time. In the early days of computer gaming, it was the first RPG to get the player emotionally involved. Every game afterwards tried to replicate this. Though they were great, they couldn't replicate it to the degree of the original. This game is the true successor to the original. It doesn't fail to deliver great storytelling and that twisted sense of humor. Not going to lie, the game has its share of issues with gameplay. (e.g. quests outcome bugs) but the devs are addressing them in a timely manner.  For those who don't require mindblowing graphics to experience a good story, this is a gem of a game. It won't dissappoint.

content:
1, 2016
												This game demands patience, managemant, and strategy.  This is something most people who are giving this game bad reviews don't seem to understand.  Despite what other people say, this is not a linear game; as a matter of fact it is far from it.  Right off the bat I have attempted to kill every single good NPC that I have encountered but only managed to kill 2 before dying due to my low level.  There are many ways to finish missions, grab loot, and tackle obstacles as well.  While it can be time consuming to learn how to balance out your squad properly and do managemant, especially coming from a guy who didnt grow up in the Fallout 1-2 era, the reward is satisfactory.  For those who got into video games in early 2000s, this is simply later Fallout with more stats and strategy.  Get this game while its on sale.

1, 2016
Product received for free
												I will be getting this game primarily to encourage the free previewing of games like this and thus further increasing their accessibility. Every once in a while you get tired of being treated to fancy schmancy cinematic spectacles and just want to relax with a nice trip through a fantasy world where you have freedom over how your adventure unfolds. You enter an abandoned building and find out that the interior power generators aren't working? No problem, you have a guy for that. You stumble across some nasty wasteland creatures? No problem, you can create a tough guy to fend them off and better increase your party's chance of survival.The trick with these types of computer games is, even if they seem shocking at first glance with all the menus and text; do not overthink things while you're playing. Get lost in the world, don't be afraid to be a little creative, and have fun!

content:
24, 2015
												Not great, but easily good enough.Wasteland 2 is a throwback to older RPGs with the text-heavy story and the turn based combat. Look, it's easy to pick holes in the game - it was launched with quite a few broken quests, the weapon balance isn't good, the combat options could be more plentiful - stuff like that. Perhaps the main storyline isn't that compelling for some folks though it was fine for me.In short there are a lot of things it could have done better. It's certainly not perfect. But I enjoyed it enough.There's 50 hours of gameplay here and most of it is old-school RPG fun. Questing, combat and exploration are all central parts of this game and they're all done well enough that the overall experience is great. I quite liked the world and the atmosphere and that kept me going during some of the duller times. In addition, the devs have done a great job of updating and patching the game. I went to play it again with the newer version and made it about halfway through before quitting. So in my book it's not a great game but it was enjoyable enough to feel like I got my money's worth. So if you're looking for some old-school RPG fun, buy this title. It may not be the GOTY, but odds are you won't be disappointed.

content:
2014
												First off, I love this game.  I recomend it highly, it was worth my 60 dollars to play it in the early release it is definitely worth the 40 dollars it is now.   It has come a long way since the Early Access review that I did, so I am updating it now.  This game plays very much like Final Fantasy Tactics or Fallout Tactics (minus the real time option).  In it you will create 4 of your own Desert Rangers and then head out into the wastes and explore, and either clean up the wasteland or kill everyone and thing in your path.  Along the way you can recruit many extra characters to your cause, each with their own personality and traits, up to 3 may travel with you at any given time. The difficulty of the game varies sharply depending on how you choose to play it.  Early on most enemies you fight will be much weaker than you are, however you are not forced to play the game in any linear fashion and as such you may wander into areas with much stronger enemies than you are prepared to face (not that you can't win but it can be brutal).  The ability to go where you want and do what you want flows throughout the entire game.  You can sweet talk people into giving you what you want, threaten them (with the proper skills) or if that fails shoot your way through.  Wall in your way?  Use a grenade.   Person make you mad?  Shoot him, or don't.  Raiders take over a town?  Negotiate or kill them it's all up to you and how you want to play.  Most choices have concequences further down the line, some amusing and some well down right destructive, even when you think you are making the right choices nothing is ever black and white. You will collect all kinds of weapons and armor, and most weapons can be customized by stripping down others for base parts.  Everything from WW2 rifles to futuristic laser weapons are represented each with an optimal range, armor penetration and rates of fire.  In battle many of your enemies will show up with different kinds of weapons, often enough you can kill them an take it for yourself.  The various enemie types also force you to prioritize targets: Do you kill the big guy with the sword made out of the one way sign (yes, they really are swords made out of sign posts and one way signs) attacking your medic, or do you take out the guy who is still too far out to hit you but is charging with grenades that will hurt everyone?  Oh and friendly fire is a thing, don't try and use a shotgun from behind your own people. Character progression is handled in an RPG like fashion with skill points gained at every level and ability points every 10.  You can be a generalst and do a bit of everything but nothing well or you can specialize each of your characters (highly reccomend you do) into different things.I broke my basic team into:a) Sniper / Lockpicks / submachine gun - gave me nice range and something when stuff got closerb) Sniper / Perception / Kiss A** / Submachinegun - can see traps still shoot far and sweet talkc) Heavy weapons / Safe Cracking / Assault Rifle - HMG to mow down eneies - rifle to consere ammod) Energy weapon / First Aid / Rifle / demolotions - can remove traps and is the field medicThen I picked up and kept in my party ae) A drunkard shotgun specialist whom I also turned into the groups weaponsmith (because drunks make the best weapons right?)f) Lady scientist who can hack any computers and is handy with a pistol (and later rifles)g) Young kid who's life I saved,  he started with brawling and ended with rifles pistols and the ability to talk to strange animals. I built my team knowing that I would go to a specific place and pick up a particular npc.. how you create your team is entirely up to you and playing around with different builds is half the fun. - Pros -- Great turn based combat.- Easy to understand mechanics- Fun!- Lots of humor built into the game- So many different ways to resolve things in the game- Ability to break your own missions through poor choices (and sometimes good ones) requiring some creative solutions to be used to move on.- Solid strategies will win most fights.  Using cover, hitting clusters of enemies with a grenade etc.- Ammo doesn't grow on trees, making conservation of rounds part of the strategy.- All different kinds of weapons with all kinds of pros / cons built into them.- Not all weapons are a straight forward upgrade, sometimes you just have to try them out.- Each person can only carry so much weight, there is no way to be Rambo and run around with 1000's of rounds of ammo and infinite first aid kits. - Cons -- Did I really just wipe out an entire town on accident? Oops.- Random battles can be major easy or completely overwhelming.  Luck plays a part.- Bah stupid AI won't stop throwing grenades at my clustered people.- Drunk bugger keeps going rogue on my party and getting himself shot to pieces.- Some fights, more so early on can be extremely difficult to get through.  The first boss fight was really bad for me as my squad was almost dead and did not expect the guy to attack me since we were talking at first- Ammo can be hard to come by in the early game, forcing you to either use weapons your team isn't skilled for or to spend all of your money on nothing but ammo instead of armor / weapon mods / first aid kits etc.

content:
24, 2015
												Not great, but easily good enough.Wasteland 2 is a throwback to older RPGs with the text-heavy story and the turn based combat. Look, it's easy to pick holes in the game - it was launched with quite a few broken quests, the weapon balance isn't good, the combat options could be more plentiful - stuff like that. Perhaps the main storyline isn't that compelling for some folks though it was fine for me.In short there are a lot of things it could have done better. It's certainly not perfect. But I enjoyed it enough.There's 50 hours of gameplay here and most of it is old-school RPG fun. Questing, combat and exploration are all central parts of this game and they're all done well enough that the overall experience is great. I quite liked the world and the atmosphere and that kept me going during some of the duller times. In addition, the devs have done a great job of updating and patching the game. I went to play it again with the newer version and made it about halfway through before quitting. So in my book it's not a great game but it was enjoyable enough to feel like I got my money's worth. So if you're looking for some old-school RPG fun, buy this title. It may not be the GOTY, but odds are you won't be disappointed.

content:
ber 19, 2016
												A frustrating game that is riddled with bugs and design flaws even after Directors Cut treatment. Ultimately saved only by good world building and writing.+Entertaining dialogue, jokes and references+Long mostly for the right reasons+Mark Morgan music+Interesting world+Actually functional pathfinding 99,99% of the time+Has decent replay value if the flaws don't bother you too much-Awful follower AI that will try to shoot through your squad every time or run into suicide charges-Strange difficulty spikes that are sometimes close to absurd and a few cheesy scripted battles-Skill systems and some other design choices are practically begging for save scumming since so many things are random-Hilariously bad in-engine cutscenes-Voice acting varies from decent to cringeworthy. Most of the game is text only, was it really necessary to include bad voice actors?-Dialogues can go in nonsensical order that causes contradictions-Quests stages can be accidentally skipped leaving you wondering what was even going on in the first place-Some quests can only be completed with one specific skill (at a fairly high level as well) and nothing else-Clunky and buggy UI that sometimes makes navigating and moving in larger areas a complete pain since there is no quick travel even inside explored and pacified areas-Camera position keeps resetting too close to the ground to be useful between map changes, forcing you to zoom it back to a more convenient distance again and again and again...-Realtime elements blend poorly with the turn based combat system-Lack of sneaking or proper ambush mechanics. Nearly all battles are best started with a sniper round in someones arm or face outside of combat-Crummy weapon balance: most unique weapons are close to worthless etc.-Various bugs including a repeating memory leak that butchered the framerate after a couple of hours of playing

content:
ber 27, 2015
												TL;DR- This game is amazing as far as RPGs go. The tactical combat is challenging and rewarding. The storyline is solid and  cohesive. As someone who didn't play the original before I got it along with this game I feel that the devs did a great job at staying true to the original while making a wholly playable and engrossing sequel, paying homage to the players of the 1st game while not entirely alienating their new market. Simply one of the best role-playing games I have had the pleasure to play in the last decade.Wasteland 2 made me feel like I was playing Fallout-Advanced Edition. Yes the post apocalyptic genre may be reaching its saturation point, but to pull it off with the style and flair that the devs did with this game is truly a feat that others should feel beholden to match in the future. Back in my day *takes a slug off of a clay jug marked XXX* players used their imaginations to fill in the holes that graphic and framerate left empty and Wasteland 2 managed to bridge that gap with nuance and gusto. I felt for my characters. I lovingly crafted their skills to conquor all that the wasteland had to throw at me. I was treated to inside jokes, 80's humor, and a difficulty that suited my playstyle (played on hard difficulty). If you're looking for a great tactical RPG, this is a sure bet. If you're looking for a storyline that will keep you playing to the end, start clicking the buy button now. Dim the lights. Crank the speakers. And sit down for a while and witness true RPG entertainment at it's best.

content:
y 1, 2015
												I can't in good conscious recommend Wasteland 2 as a finished product. It's too lackluster and has a few major issues. It plays fine, and I will probably continue playing it even after I write this, but there's two main issues at the time of writing.The first being off is the god for saken prison. Ran by raiders with no redeemable factors that turn people into slaves only be disguising them as workers. They do nothing good, everyone that you come across will say you can be the savior, march right up to the leader, and kill him, simple task, right?Apparently not, once you get there you run into a plotwall. Two turrets at 4K health each(To put that in perspective, 20ish hours in my characters only have 125ish health). Okay, fine, just bring out heavy weapons. Wrong again, they have a stupid high intiative, and a stupid high amount of action points. They fired 5ish times each, doing 300 damage per bullet. Good luck getting your party through that.Even if you *DO* manage to kill the turrets, there's apparently accounts of impossible-to-defuse landmines that 1 hit kill party members.Why is this happening? I'm not sure, but if I had to guess, one of the team members working on wasteland felt so proud of their plot twist they decided to make sure everyone can only expirence the plot twist like that. So you just have to go 'welp, i know these guys beat and enslave you, but hes's got deus ex machina backing him so we can't do anything till the game says so'The other issue is just hour 10ish. It becomes out-of-ammo gun-jam simulator. You won't have enough ammo to get into skrims, or if you do, you'll be cutting it close and it'll just be fustrating. Then when you do have ammo, your gun jams. A lot. I'm not sure how complex a double barrel shotgun is, but i'm pretty sure it's not prone to the amount of jamming it got.Now for the nitpicky stuff. Somethings just outpace your levels, but that's fine, maybe I shouldn't be rushing through the content as fast as I was. Another issue is just not being able to interact with the world. There's a girl who's (perpetually) dying, constantly groaning into your radio, asking for some one named Elroy. You can find her, confront her. But even if you're the best doc of the entire world, you can't help her, only shoot her. It may sound super nit picky, but not even given the illusion of choice sucks. I couldn't try, I could only mercy kill.There is good htngs, the game is close to being a perfect masterpiece. Combat is actually alright, atleast mid game. Things start getting faster, combat is quick but a bit tactical. It could benefit from a few small tweaks. Flanking, some more cover options, and a change to friendly fire calculations(Not as bad as fallout 2. Damn it Sulik, give me that gun.) The characters are alright, followers feel human as they comment on the scenery and situation where applicable, instead of being a silent moving turret. They have their flaws, they have their benefit, but not so much so they become a god send or dead weight.Over all the game feels... unpolished. It feels as if I'm playing in a beta, which I'm not. If it gets changed, or the mod tools get released, I'm sure this game could be something fantastic. But at the moment it's simply okay.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
y 23, 2015
												Wanted to love this game. After many, many, restarts and partial playthroughs I just ended up calling it quits. Played FO1 and 2, and Tactics when they were first released and they sit high on my list of "fond of old games." This, I did not care for at all. Enemies zerg you (that's the extent of the AI). In FO Tactics they at least had the sense to flank you, take cover, hide, runaway, switch weapons appropriately, etc. You'd think that would be something we'd see in the 21st century. Not here. They run at you or shoot, then you shoot back, repeat. The stat system is broken (not using that word as a euphamism or perjorative, there are stats that matter and those that don't. And your stats don't effect your skills at all beyond intelligence).  There are only a few viable builds to complete the game. The skills are so convoluted and could have been easily reduced by half. For instance you have: Alarm Disarming, Lockpicking, and Safe Cracking. Is there any reason these couldn't be under one skill instead of three? No. Then you have: Hard A*s, Kiss A*s, Smart A*s, Barter, and Leadership, aren't these all subsets of a larger skill like persuasion/speech or based on charisma? Well, no, not in Wasteland 2. Why are they convoluted? Probably to compensate for a game design that allows for so few actions in game beyond "kill person in this manner" or "successfully interact with this object for a reward." Weapons and armor have arbitrary penalties that exist only to impose penalties. For instance, did you know that an "assault rifle" loses all efficiency at five feet and  a board with a nail in it works MUCH better? I didn't know that, but after playing WL2 I do. Further energy weapons do lots of damage to you if they hit your armor, but if they hit your bare skin they don't do much on any damage at all. Logic! It's the guise of strategy, not actual strategy. It's strategic like rock, papers, scissors. This game has a lot of heart. It tries very hard an certainly has charm. Yet I've played browser based games with more depth, complexity, strategy, and sophistication. Really wanted something to take me back to those first days playing FO1/2 and Tactics. Instead it's better to just play those instead of WL2. Or, if you really want a strategy based around functional abilities, gear (that you build or collect), multiple means of achieving you goal, and competent AI go play XCOM Enemy Unknown/Within.I want my money back.

												Not being a fan of the original, I wasnt as excited by the prospect of a sequel as a lot of other people. However I am a fan of the genre and generally like RPGs of any type if they are well made so I thought Id give it a shot. This game IS well made, but thats about all its got going for it.There is something about this game that just doesnt do it for me. Ive just played through Baulders Gate and Shadowrun Returns and compared to them, this game is flat and boring. I have no interest in the story line and the quests themselves are too dam long and boring. Theres no clear sense of what to do next and if you do things in the wrong order, you end up having to back track all over the joint.Traveling the wasteland is a pain in the ♥♥♥. Requiring you to stop at these stupid oasis to replenish your water supply is unnessecary and adds to the boredom. I know it was part of the original game, but that doesnt make it a good idea.Games that have voice acting are fantastic, it really adds to the atmosphere and gets you into the game. This game has voice actors, but they only some NPCs use it and only with what they first say. I understand the fact you cant give every NPC a voice sue to space constraints, but those that do speak should speak every line. Im a bit mad at how much I actually paid for this game. If your thinking about getting it, wait till a sale when its like $5 or below. Otherwise your just wasting your money.

								May 1st 201459 hours on record, not 24.I've been playing Wasteland 2 for a while now and figured I should write a review. I hardly ever write reviews but I feel that this game deserves it. When i first bought it (a week or two after release) the game was buggy to say the least. A bit boring during combat and the story was dry......then the patches started rolling out. The game became beautifully designed. The artwork is amazing, the combat feels solid and easy to use. The story feels like a true rpg. I'm getting to know my characters like I did in Fallout and Skyrim. I was really excited when this game hit Steam and I had high hopes. Still being in Beta and being apart of the process has been amazing. I have enjoyed every patch and have no complaints. I can wait to see what it's like once it's fully released. If you have any doubts about not liking this game wait until full release, but if you want to buy it now and help the dev's create a game more to your liking this is the company to do it with. Thanks for reading!Feel free to message me with questions about the game if you feel like getting the average player's more in depth review. -Dantehood

content:
r 2, 2014
												I’ve only played the Original Wasteland game very briefly a long time ago, however I’ve spent countless hours playing the pre-Fallout 3 Fallout games on PC which were inspired by Wasteland. Now I’ve played Wasteland 2 for around 7 hours, it’s not a fast paced game, this has only been enough time for me to complete one of the first main missions.- Overall I was very happy with the game, personally it was awesome to see a modern Fallout-like game with a traditional isometric view and detailed text descriptions of everything seen and done in the world.- However I found that I spent way too much time having to loot one loot container after another as well as sometimes fighting identical enemies repeatedly.


YouTube™ Video: Wasteland 2: Gameplay First Look (Beta) 

			Views: 1,626		

			First Look Wasteland 2 video showcasing PC Gameplay. Wasteland 2 reviews, impressions, tips and features to get you started. Thank you for watching, like, comment and subscribe if you enjoyed!		




YouTube™ Video: SatanovichZ1 Wasteland 2 gameplay 

			Views: 11		

			This game is Wasteland 2 by in InXile Entertainment. Enjoy. Read my steam review here - http://steamcommunity.com/id/SatanovichZ1/recommended/240760 Support new Gaming YouTubers -...		

In the character creation the graphics aren’t very appealing. However when you actually play the game you don’t usually view things so closely.-----Generally the actual graphics looked good in my opinion. But personally I’m satisfied as long as it’s a competent modern three-dimensional adaptation of Wasteland and an adequate improvement compared to the two-dimensional Fallout titles.-----What I was really impressed by was actually the textual description of entities and objects in the game. They provided more interesting details about everything you see.-----I also really liked the text dialogue that my companion expressed during combat rather than being mute. It really made the character seem more alive.-----Most of the character models looked fine, especially humans who featured a lot of variety. But I really got tired of seeing the same unimpressive giant bunnies again and again.-----There were also a couple of locations which I was not impressed by. One area was just a big empty square. While another fenced you into lanes which I don’t think fit well into a world that I believe should feel very open.-----But I was really impressed by many of the other environments that I saw. I liked how you could rotate the view, this would reveal objects you couldn’t see previously.-----Many environments looked handcrafted and irregularly shaped. I think this platform has a lot of potential even for other games with a fantasy theme.I liked the character attributes and skill system. However the benefits of investing into some attributes didn’t seem worthwhile. Likewise investing in combat skills seemed to suffer from strong diminishing returns.-----I set out to play this game in an unusual way. I didn’t want to micromanage a squad. So initially I took only one ranger. This didn’t work out so well initially.-----So after playing for an hour I started over and I redesigned my starting character. This time I created a more intelligent character so that they could multi-skill and thus take on multiple roles.-----Early on there is a high level character who you can recruit named ‘Angela Deth’, I took her along with me because going solo with a low level character is actually very difficult. So the game almost let me play the way I wanted to because I didn’t have to take a whole squad.-----I don’t mind the turn based combat, but it’s one of the reasons the game is slow paced. I knows it’s more traditional. But I would have preferred a real time system where you could pause and redirect the action.-----Occasionally my companion would go out of control in combat and make actions without me directing her. How do I make her do this all the time? I’d rather my NPC teammates were more autonomous. I don’t want to have to tell them to do every little thing.-----Outside of combat for the first several hours that I played, I couldn’t move my characters individually for some reason. So I wasn’t able to rearrange my character before entering combat-----This was a bit weird. I don’t know why this happened but eventually I was suddenly able to direct them individually.-----In games like this I feel compelled to search every nook and cranny in a level for loot. Especially because you really need to do so in order to scrape up enough ammunition to fight and enough medical supplies to survive.-----I know it’s a post apocalyptic game and scavenging may be the ‘thing’ to do. But I think I easily spent half of my seven hours of game-play looting and managing my characters’ inventories. That was tedious.-----Why do I have to ransack the property of people who I am supposed to protect? How do my characters carry all those guns and where do they keep them, just to sell at a vendor?-----I wish there was a better system for acquiring better gear. Perhaps credit towards an interchangeable load-out based on each characters rank and experience levels?So yes, I definitely have my gripes about this game. But I was very happy to play it. This game proves that Fallout 3 didn’t have to make the shift to FPS. Not sure that I will have more time for Wasteland 2 though.-----I’m happy that the price has come down. The previous $60 price tag was a major reason that I had not purchased this game quite some time ago.Click here for my YouTube gaming channel
