content:
ry 24
												Not as good as Wasteland 1 and not the spiritual Fallout 3 that many Fallout fans wanted, but it's a good role-playing game. In hindsight, as backers, we shouldn't have expected inXile to deliver an amazing game; inXile hadn't developed an RPG since the Interplay days more than a decade ago.inXile learned a lot developing this game though. Signs of ambition are all over the game, with tons of reactivity from the start. But as the game progresses, you notice that many things seem to scale back in quality. There is less reactivity, and eventually the random radio chatter stops. This is more noticeable in California with the ranger HQ and the big cities. Santa Fe Springs has a relatively large map but it's never used. Hollywood in particular promises greatness if only inXile had more money and thus time. Quests can be tackled largely out of order with plenty of dialogue options to form alliances fake or real, but it's ruined by bugs or even perceived bugginess. It's definitely rough.We already know Wasteland 3 will not try to be a 100 hour game, and is instead aiming for something along the lines of Torment: Tides of Numenera which is supposedly around 40 or 50 hours. Considering the original Fallouts and Wasteland were only around 20 hours each and how unpolished the later areas of Wasteland 2 were, I think this is a good idea.

content:
17, 2014
Early Access Review
								When I played the beta of this game in 2013, I was not impressed. I was frustrated with the UI, the art direction, the scripting, and the way combat was weighed. I played the original in the late 1980s, and loved the surreal and unforgiving world it created.I came back, this month, hoping that the issues I'd complained about had been fixed. I genuinely love this series and was pessimistic about its survival. I owe the devs an apology--the beta I've played this month has been everything I could have wanted (though I could always use more toasters and mutants, if anyone is listening).I can recommend this game to fans of the first game, as well as fans of dystopian and apocalyptic games. However, it is distinct from other entries in this genre, including the often-cited Fallout series. Closer to the roots of such games than the more recent entries in the apolcalyptic genre, Wasteland 2 is tactical and played from above your party's head. You can pause between turns, and sometimes you'd better think about it first.It also has the charm of being more appropriately unforgiving--it's the !@#(*% apocalypse, the stakes are high, and I APPROVE of punishing button mashing and careless playing.Know your save file, love your save file. The game saves less often than you might want it to, so you'll want to stay on that yourself.Your characters will have to specialize, and no single character will be able to be everything. You will want to think hard about how you want to allocate specialties. It is very possible to make in-game mistakes that kill you and your party instantly, though you'd have to be pretty oblivious to make them. If the button says "do not push me," do no--actually, if you push it, you deserve what you get. The wrong comment to the wrong person can touch off wars between groups, closing whole story sections to you. The appropriate choice in dialog is not always obvious, and the best choice is not always available to you, without specializing.Depending on your level of difficulty, making use of the ability to create ambushes and lead people into them will become very useful, as is developing a character able to scout ahead.The game is still being developed, and has some on-going and minor technical issues, including an optimization problem I ran into on my rig that required me to turn down the refresh rate and render quality considerably. From reading the forums, this problem is not exactly common, but happens often enough to merit mention.The half of the game available for play right now also seems a bit short--I'm hoping that the final product will be much longer (gimmie!)It's hard to evaluate a story when you're missing the denouemont, but to this point, it has a familiar and interesting arc. Given the development, I'm fairly confident the finished product, based on the skill I've seen, will have been worth backing the project.A word of advice: do not buy this game expecting Fallout: New Vegas, or expecting a completely open, huge world filled with 1950s kitsch, naivete, and classic sci-fi allusions. Expect, instead, a world hemmed in on all sides by radiation and death, with the disaffection, paramiliatry themes, and violence of the 1980s. The devs have done a particularly good job of recalling the first game without simply recreating it.And devs, at the risk of spoiling something, the Brothers patrolling the mountain pass are just about perfect. If there's any fear close to our current, collective hearts, it's contamination.

content:
er 7, 2014
												While it's worth the 25+ year wait for it, it's not without its flaws. If you are reading this then I'm certain you've read at least a couple of the other player reviews of this game, if not official reviews from IGN, PC Gamer & the like.  Many of the reviews equate this game as being a "tactical RPG",  I would classify it more as an RPG with some (note emphasis) tactical elements, there's a difference.  Like in the "golden age" of PC RPGs, you create your inital squad members, you can recruit up to 3 others, making a total of 7.  There are quite a few NPCs to recruit also, each has their own reasons for being on your team.  Depending on your actions it can be quite temporary how long a potential recruit stays on your team.  How you mix & match your PCs & NPCs can be quite interesting. Like the PC based RPGs of yesteryear, once a character dies, they're gone forever, so save often.  The game does not hold your hands on things, some of the clues in certain quests are down right obtuse & depending on the difficulty you set it at certain other things... well you'll see for yourself.  Is the game "pretty", nope.  Is the story something I've not seen before, nope on that also.  But this games does give me something I see too little of in RPGs these days: choice & consequence.  Most of the consequences based on the choices are also not readily apparent, they have a small ripple effect that may not be seen for hours down the road; are you seriously about to reload a save from 2 or 4 or more hours ago when the consequence of such a decision is happening so far down the line?  I seriously doubt that, which is another thing I like, you have to think on most of the choices here; "How will doing X bite me in the rear?" is something you should really consider.  I did one playthrough, it took me 120 hours to finish, I had a blast in exploring & finding things.  I intend on another.  Just 'cause I liked it though & felt it a fitting sequal to the original, it doesn't mean that I'm blind to the weaknesses of the game.  In most cases I hope what I wrote n the weakness column is considered & fixed for Wasteland 3, should the franchise continue.SrengthsChoice & ConsequenceBig & long game reminiscent of the games of yesteryear.  Does not hold your hand, it's a thinking persons game.  Either have a decent memory on certain quests or use the notes system provided, you'll be glad you did.  Dark humor a-la the original Interplay Fallouts, but more subtle.  WeaknessesUI not as tweakable as I'd likeThe character customization could be way better. While I didn't expect it to be anywhere near as pretty as Divinity Original Sin, I did want my characters to look somewhat like the pics I imported to represent them.  A lot of the portraits & random areas were reused.  The battles also felt repetative after awhile, the latter being the fault of a really bare-bones tactical aspect (no called shots on body parts other then the head, no sneak skill).  I would've liked a few more optional quest areas like the Mine & Rail Nomads. Some areas were really big, I would've liked a waypoint option.  For better & worse most of the Skills didn't relate to the statistics of the characters.  At least to me they didn't feel this way.  HaasGaming wrote it best:  "If you are patient and give Wasteland 2 the time it needs to show its potential, it will be a tremendously enjoyable experience. Time definitely worth investing."

content:
y 21, 2015
												I looked forward to this game for a long time, and will admit that once I got it did not fall in love with it and so have put very limited time into it, so take my game experience with that grain of salt.  Many people have clearly loved it, and so maybe you will too, but I feel let down and consider this a title that for me has lived up neither to its hype or even to its promises.Clearly a lot of care and attention to detail went into crafting this game, as well as a long process of interacting with the community during development, and I am impressed with the features.  That they did not add up to a fun and immersive experience for me may have been primarily due to a dislike for the camera handling.  I found early on that I preferred a wide view most of the time, but the camera handles poorly for that.I also believe that the bar was set reasonably high for visual quality, but again I feel like the look achieved was not equal to the sum of the components, and possibly that has to do with the Unity engine.I have generally good feelings that Fargo's team was revived by this project and has leveraged the enthusiasm for this revival to  continue on with new projects as well as encouraging other developers doing interesting projects, but otherwise am not too excited to have been a day 1 kickstart supporter.Some 32 months after the project was officially funded we have not seen the mod tools kit that was promised.  I realize that Fargo was honest in projecting that mod tools would require further time and it will probably come someday, but at this stage of the game's shelf life I'm about ready to declare that a broken promise.  This may seem like a moot point since I haven't cared much for the game, but it is disappointing nonetheless.

content:
y 7, 2015
												So, if you take the term 'CRPG' really seriously and enjoy getting in fights about how modern RPGs aren't 'real' RPGs, and you wish it were still the late 1990s, this is a great game for you and you don't need to read the rest of my review.On the other hand, if you enjoy isometric party-based RPGs but also might like to see some progress from the last 15 years or so of gaming history, Wasteland 2 is kind of a letdown precisely because of how stubbornly it emulates the UI fiddliness of Fallout 1/2.  Get ready to remember which party member owns a shovel, switch to them, activate the shovel item, and wait while a progress bar fills up, every time you want to dig something up.  And this isn't just shovels, it's *every specialized skill*.  You're not realistically going to put together a party with more than one girl or guy who knows Safecracking or some other random ♥♥♥♥, but the game will never let you just click on the safe and have the one Safecracker open it.The maps suffer from a similar level of fiddliness.  You will have to memorize where in town that random questgiver is, or come back from a fetch quest to wander all over wondering where his shop is among a town of identical-looking dwellings.  No quest markers is fine, I don't think that the player should have telepathic knowledge of where stuff is ahead of time, but when you're looking to turn in quests (and the characters would already know where shopkeeper X is) it's just a hassle.  Isometric design also means that the level designers hide crates in places where you need to rotate the camera to find them ... which is fine, but after a while, it's not clever, it's just irritating to have to rotate the camera every time you enter a new room or potentially miss out on loot.I could go on with examples of the weird sort of micromanagement that Wasteland 2 requires of the player (there are many more), but you get the point.Bottom line, it feels like a game that came out in 2000, not 2014.  If you're fine with this, go ahead and get it (but you probably already did).  If you're not, and especially if you haven't played Fallout 1/2 to death, there's really no reason to play this instead of Fallout 1/2.

ber 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								I'm fairly new to the whole Turned-based strategy game genre at which I only played Shadowrun Returns, XCOM, and Divinity: Original Sin and now Wasteland 2. So with my experience out of the way now I might as well get on with it!Wasteland 2 has not been regretted at all for an early access purchase, as to where I will be spending a lot of my time playing this game when the game fully releases! I feel that a lot of gamers anymore lose interest into these games, because it's not action 24/7 but I would say that these games now have got my attention and this game has taken over my life so far!Pros:1.) The environment is very detailed where it doesn't look pixilated at all and from that shows the time it took the developers to give a great Post Apocalyptic experience.2.) The variety of skills to master in at which can change a lot in the future of game play from Toaster Repair, to being a Kiss ♥♥♥ to survivors. These will keep you thinking on which will be best for each character and from that can alter what your character can do.3.) Character creation is very generic as to any other RPG element, but there's nothing wrong with that at all! Create your own character and make him/her a minigun wielding badass! But if you're not comfortable with creating your own character (or squad), you have preloaded characters to choose from at which have their own specialties for you.4.) The combat system in the game can be very tense and frustrating (in a good way)! Every combat you encounter has you looking for anyway to wipe out your enemies as fast as you can from breaking through their coverage, to flanking them with your sniper. Every battle is definitely tense from where a simple 80% or above chance to hit still will miss (most frustrating thing in the world!!!!).Cons:1.) A few minor glitches in the game which is common for a early access game, but some are still effective even though you reloaded the game before that glitch happened.2.) For my perspective and for anyone else who isn't too familiar with Turned-based strategy games, I had to restart the game a couple times as to where I screwed up and once you screwed up, you might as well restart and fix your mistakes. It may not seem like a con for others, but to me it's kind of frustrating to be restarting this game just to get it right.Verdict:I highly recommend this game for when it comes out, or even if you would like to play it right before it comes out! As for anyone who is considering buying the game full price, I would say that you wouldn't be disappointed in this purchase and would be looking forward to more hours of this game!

content:
er 14, 2013
												RELEASE VERSION UPDATE: Initial beta/backers review found after.This is it. This is the big one. For many people, this is one of the most anticipated games of the year - the great inspiration for Fallout, the driver of classic RPGs, the callback to a genre slowly reviving. One of the first big huge Kickstarted games. After two years in development, how does it hold up? Spoilers: it holds up damn well.Wasteland 2 is a classic RPG in the style of Fallout 1, 2, and Tactics. In fact, the original Wasteland was the inspiration for the Fallout universe, and shares many similarities and concepts with Wasteland. You take control of four fresh-faced Ranger recruits, sent out on a task to make yourselves worthy of your badges. What ends up happening is a journey across Arizona, and then some.The game starts off with character creation. You can choose to create your own Ranger from scratch, or pick a pre-made Ranger from a list. The pre-made characters are alright, but for most people, you'll want to make your own customized Rangers. You can distribute attribute and skillpoints as you see fit, change your Ranger's physical appearance, and even stick in his/her own little bio and a custom portrait.After setting yourself up, you end up in the Arizona wasteland, right outside Ranger Citadel. You are greeted by General Vargas, a veteran Ranger and an old character from Wasteland.  Another Ranger vet, Ace, has just died in action, and you and your team are sent out to investigate his murder and finish his mission as a trial. Succeed, and you all become official Rangers.At first glance, one can immediately note the biggest downside to the game - graphical fidelity. While I personally feel that the graphics do not detract from the game, and in fact works to further the atmosphere it sets about creating, it is easy to see that the game is not about the shinies. Its easily trumped by Divinity: Original Sin in terms of fidelity, but that is not to say the game looks bad. It is simply objectively dated, even for a Unity-based game. Performance also leaves something to be desired - on a GTX 765M, the game hovers at about 40-50fps, sometimes dipping below to 30. Whilst expected for a new release, it certainly does not look like it should be choking up a moderately good mobile GPU as far as it is.  However, the graphical style the game takes is very immersive - you have varying environs, from lush greens to barren browns, and everything in between. The wasteland feels desolate and real.Wasteland 2 is set in an isometric, top-down view. You control your Rangers overhead, order them around by clicking in the world. There are two world types - the main world, showing you Arizona and the rest of the area, where you go around between smaller local maps, looking for oases for water, and avoiding rad clouds, then the local maps, which is where you explore, do missions, talk to people, shoot people, all that good stuff. Combat is turn based, engaging when you run into hostiles or turn other people hostile by shooting at them/having a negative interaction. Characters take turns in commiting actions, with each action costing certain Action Points to do. Your characters can use a slew of weapons, from going in fisticuffs, to heavy armanents such as bazookas and heavy MGs, all of which can be skilled up. Positioning is key, with certain weapons being effective at certain ranges, and cover helping you avoid damage. Damaged Rangers can only be healed up with medkits, pain pills, and trauma kits if they bleed out. There is no idle healing, which means every fight has to be planned, and you have to have enough supplies to last.Overall, I feel that Wasteland 2 offers a refreshing jump back into cRPGs, bringing the spirit of post-apocalyptic games from the past well into the 21st century. If you love turn based games, old RPGs, post-apocalypse settings, then you'll love (or absolutely hate - in a good way!) Wasteland 2. Give it a try._________________________________________________________________________________Wasteland 2: One of the first gigantic projects on Kickstarter, the revival of an era, the granddaddy of Fallout, the great leap back for inXile.Is it any good (so far?) The short answer:  yes, yes it is.Wasteland 2 is one of the biggest, most high profile projects funded through Kickstarter – indeed, funding for the game came after Double Fine Adventure’s own successful Kickstarter. The game raised roughly 3,000,000USD, well exceeding its goal of 900,000USD.The game follows up on Wasteland, which was the basis for many elements in the Fallout series. Many elements seen in Fallout can be seen here – radioactive wasteland, Rangers building up a civilized society, raiders, tech-fanatics, militant religious fanatics are all present in the game, clearly showing how much it influenced other games later on.Gameplay is very much Fallout like as well. You explore the world with your party, with the world map being just that – a map that you navigate your party blimp through. Movement is dependent upon your water supply – you lose water, you die. Thankfully, there are hidden oases all over the map, giving enough opportunities to refill water to quench one’s wanderlust. In local areas, one goes about with the whole party, with your selected member doing the interactions. Conversations follow a keyword system – anything you observe in the environment might pop up as a keyword for characters in the locale, while some words in conversations can lead to further inquiries as well. Some conversation options require certain skills to be at a certain level, and can lead to clearing certain obstacles in a peaceful manner. Combat is turn based, following an AP system similar to, again, Fallout. On this, I cannot say much – I’ve only played less than two hours, and so far, the early mobs were easy enough to wipe without having to worry about cover and positioning. Even then, I did take a noteable amount of damage, and would probably lose my party members if I continued to do so.Wasteland 2 runs on Unity – so far, in this current beta build, there are no graphical options to speak of, besides resolution and an overall graphics preset. Setting it to Fantastic with an i7-4700MQ and GTX 765M, the game looks fantastic – it pushes Unity to the edge. However, this being a beta, performance is not spectacular – fully zoomed out, FRAPS was showing around 24fps to a max of 30fps, which is barely passable. Dropping presets down to standard did not help performance, so I am assuming this is a “beta is beta” issue, and will be patched before the actual launch.Is Wasteland 2 worth your time right now for 60USD? I would say, yes – if you can get past the beta-ness of it (you’ll have to download and print the reference sheet as there isn’t much of a tutorial in game), it is a good sign of the return of cRPGs and TBS games with rich narrative and an open approach to quests. While it wouldn’t hurt to wait, if you’ve been on the fence on it and can’t wait, it’s a solid game beta.

content:

Early Access Review



Achievements guide (100%) - Wasteland 2 
A Guide for Wasteland 2
By: Carrarius

			A complete guide for unlocking 100% of the achievements in Wasteland 2, sorted from A to Z. For a 100% completion in one run: As one location (Ag Center) ir required to get at least one achievement (gorilla costume),...		


If you're a big fan of the fallout series this is certainly the game for you. And there hasn't been many lately. Wasteland 2 is what I like to call old school RPG. The early access seemed polished enough to be considered "a game" in contrast with many early versions around.It uses unity engine but delivers a good amount of graphical detail. The most important dialog have voice over which stands out in an indie game. There's a lot of complexity to keep you entertained, you can fully customize your squad.

number of helpful: 7 of 13 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 23, 2014
												*sigh* Another day, another crushing disappointment.So look, the combat is uninspired and boring. Now, it isn't bad because the options are limited, it's bad because it's design is so shallow abd the tactical options are so very few. Fundamentally combat boils down to two options: Click on target to attack or run away, not exactly deep or engaging stuff. The story is reasonably good, at least from what i've seen, but the dialogue therein emits the overwhemingly pungent aroma of particularly strong cheese. Graphically the game doesn't look too much of an improvement over fallout 2, indeed the low poly character models are just all kinds of wrong in a game being released in this day and age. Some might give Wasteland a pass for being an old school game, i'm not one of them, whilst I agree that graphics aren't everything, when you're trying to create a game like this, atmosphere and immersion are fundamental, having my eyeballed flicked every few minutes by those low res, low poly models and the peculiar animations does not lend well to the mise en scene when it comes to creating a convincing narrative. The graphical fidelity is something that struck me almost straight away and remains the elephant in the room the entire time, it's incredibly jarring and blows away immersion from the outset, the lack of atmosphere in the game is truly disappointing considering it's a game that would have benefitted exponentially from some sense of environmental depth of scene. The other aspect of this is that the animations are so poor. The way people hurry about is deeply unnatural, and indeed combat animations are every bit as unconvincing. This all adds to the game's lack of depth and continually smashes any sense of immersion to pieces.There's a whole raft of smaller things that bug me too, for instance, the lack of a day/night cycle, which even the original Baldur's Gate had, which could have added a much needed layer of depth to that chronically boring combat - creatures that only come out at night, reduced visibility, the need for different tactics at different times of night. That's just one example of the smaller things, and before anyone dons their majestic white armour and starts foaming at the mouth, consider this: The investment level was huge so far as crpg games go, so why exactly does the gameplay feel so shallow? You cannot honestly tell me it all went into the sparce voice acting or the fmv sequences, and it's abundantly clear that it didn't go into the engine, so what gives? Where did the money go?Still, all told, by far my biggest gripe is how low rent the game looks and plays. Fargo set out to make an old school game, and whilst he has achieved that, unfortunately, I suspect in literally doing so, he has failed to take full advantage of modern technology and game design techniques. Like so many dinosaurs of the industry, it seems he too has failed to adapt, just because you're making your vision does not mean that you should shun the good that has come from the advances in both technology and the games industry at large. What irks most is that this was a game with a £3m development budget, for a crpg it should have been absolutely jawdropping with an investment like that. That, above all else, is what makes Wasteland singularly disappointing, and also raises some rather pointed questions about just where the hell that £3m went, because it sure as ♥♥♥♥ doesn't look or feel like it went into the game itself in any truly meaningful way.Larian came out of left field with an absolute stunner of a game this year with Divinity, maybe i've just been spoilt by it and can't look at Wasteland in the same light when you hold the two side by side, but to be honest, when you look at what Larian achieved with a budget a fraction of the size of Wasteland, I can't help but feel that Briand Fargo, for all his good intentions, was taking the ♥♥♥♥ when he released Wasteland into the wild. Divinity is now far and away the market leader in the crpg market, and not because of a huge budget, because the guys and girls at Larian had the kind of vision and sense to use what they have available to them to the absolute best of their ability. I can't help but feel that not only was development time on Wasteland squandered, but also kneecapped by Fargo's single minded determination to make something 'old school'.the tl;dr boils down to this: if you're a fan of Wasteland 1 or the original Fallout games, and can look past a distinctly shoddy game engine, then you might find something to like here. Otherwise, wait for a very significant sale, or just take a pass altogether and play Divinity or Xcom instead, both are vastly superior alternatives that do what they do a good deal better than Wasteland ever can, or I suspect, ever will.

content:
er 26, 2016
Product received for free
												First of all I did not play the original Wasteland. But when I heard that Brian Fargo, who is responsible for the best games in the world (Fallout 1 and Fallout 2), wants to make a Wasteland 2 I was immediately interested. I bought Wasteland 2 but it waited a long time before I found the time to play and in the meantime a Director's Cut edition was published, which I received for free.This game is not Fallout. But it is an awesome game nonetheless. It combines the RPG with tactics game (with more tactics element that RPG) but in a better way that Fallout Tactics did it. The game is hard. The combat is challenging and you always have less point in the skill that you need to use right now.The plot is good with some nice plot twist at the end of the game. I was surprised as it all turned out. I enjoyed the grim future of the post-nuclear wasteland. People are struggling to maintain a decent life and you cannot help everybody. Sometimes you must choose who will live and who dies. And there are a lot of mad inhabitants (just as in Mad Max series and Fallout series you could tell that something in the radiations affects the brain cells). As I love a post-nuclear setting this was one of the best example of this unfriendly world.The graphic could be better but for me it is not a major issue in a game like this. But it is done in a way to emphasis the dark world you are playing and that was done great. Personally I think that there could be more portraits. The sounds and voice acting are satisfying. Adrian Gordon wins the award for the best performance, he was outstanding. Just listen to his 'RAIN JERKS?!'. And last but not least the music. For me it was excellent. It caught the climate of the game perfectly. And I recommend to listen to the 'Cries of a Dead World' by Miracle of Sound (it is in the credits).It is not the best game in the world but I rate it 9/10. Play it. Play it now!

er 30, 2014
												Colossally overrated. -Most skills are just keys to open up different kinds of boxes-The game is a tunnel with only one way forward. You need all the skills to open all the boxes along the way, and that's it.-Sometimes, but not often enough to matter much, the tunnel branches for a moment before it merges again.-Characters are simplified and have personalities as thin as cardboard. You'll find more character depth in most FPS titles than this.-The animations are unfinished and lazy.-Combat looks and feels as real and visceral as your average MMO title.-There's a lot of dialogue, but very little of it is meaningful in any way. You just click through it all and move forward in the tunnel.-In fallout 2, playing a character with vastly differing stats changed the entire game experience and modified the plot. Here it changes your action point amounts and HP.In short: This is not the worst game out there, but if you want to play your next fallout 2, keep waiting. It isn't here.

er 12, 2014
												A truly disappointing experience..It boggles the mind, how the developers managed to secure triple the budget of Divinity Original Sin yet come up with such an unpolished mess of a game. I am a huge fan of Fallout 1 and Fallout 2, and this game fails to deliver on every single factor of what made Fallout 1 and 2 such instant classics. Character skills are only there to give the illusion of variety, when really a locked chest will yield the same or sometimes WORST loot when compared to an unlocked one.Combat strategy is extremely straight forward, there are no skills whatsoever, all characters just shoot. Cover is very buggy, an obvious stone slab that seems to provide cover may actually not provide any benefits whatsoever(you have to go into combat to find out what actually IS cover)Storyline is linear as well, giving the illusion of an open world but will only allow more exploration once a criteria has been met.Quests MUST be done in a certain order or you will fail..  The *hard* choices that the developers promise seemed forced. There isnt a single hard choice that feels as though the options are justified, the game always makes you feel like you are just as dumb as the characters involved when better options are clearly out there.A very unpolished experience overall and a major disappointment, my search for a true fallout sequel continues...

number of helpful: 17 of 33 people (52%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2015
												This is an adequate game. When I had a lot of free time, I didn't mind investing a few tens of hours to appreciate W2's strong points. Now that I have less time for gaming, there are enough better games that I won't play Wasteland 2 again (although I'll probably reinstall to look at the Game of the Year version).In this review, I'll compare it to X-COM: Enemy Unknown and Skyrim, which seem like natural comparisons for different aspects of Wasteland 2. (I assume Fallout 3 is a more natural comparison, but I never played it.)Good partsWeaponsmithing: Interesting and fun. Deeper than the smithing system in Skyrim but easier to understand.Roaming freely: Exploring in W2 isn't as rewarding as Skyrim, but the hybrid turn-based system combined with exploring makes Wasteland 2 feel, if not bigger, at least freer than X-COM: EU.NPCs: Several but not all NPCs are well-written. NPC interactions add something that wasn't in X-COM: EU, but they're not at the level of Skyrim.Bad partsLack of tension in combat: X-COM: EU's well-designed maps and the soldiers' vurnerability made combat a taut, exciting chess match. In Wasteland 2, the lack of cover, friendly fire (by itself a great addition), and soldiers durability (on seasoned difficulty), made combat an exercise in lining up American Revolution-style and rolling your dice against the enemy. On seasoned difficulty, my soldiers never went down except to friendly fire. Ranger difficulty made combat more difficult, but the outcome of combat never felt like the result of skill or strategy.Mediocre writing: For me, the writing was good enough to made up for the uninteresting combat through the end of the Arizona section. The Rail Nomad camp and Happy Valley set up interesting scenarios. However, the narrative lost momentum after the start of the California section. When the game essentially copy-pasted the Rail Nomad scenario for another level, I lost interest.Skills: More than half of the skills feel like they were added to pad the game and provide a sink for skill points. For example, Skyrim had one skill for picking locks. Wasteland 2 has 5 or 6 skills that serve exactly the same function. What's the difference between lock picking, toaster repair, and brute force? Nothing. Skyrim's two melee combat skills are fundamentally different and highly customizable. Wasteland 2 has 3 melee combat skills that all work exactly the same. Skyrim had one speech skill. Wasteland 2 has 3 speech skills that all work exactly the same. Skyrim has two healing skills (restoration and alchemy) that could not be more functionally different. W2's two healing skills are almost exactly the same (although some of the status effect descriptions are funny). At least half of the skills in Wasteland 2 are unnecessary clones of other skills.Overall, Wasteland 2 has some strong points that are overwhelmed by it's weaknesses.

content:
, 2015
												“Bottle caps?! We only accept scrap.”Greetings to you, traveller! We welcome you into our wasteland with water in our cans and radiation in our lungs!You may not understand our wasteland, you may even fear it. Do not worry, we have all struggled in such ignorance or died of thirst in the desert. To understand what the wasteland is, is to understand the Great Glow. Everything is part of it, but it is the mushroom cloud that expresses it most directly.But, do you not need to seek the next mushroom cloud to find the Great Glow? The answer is no! Look into the eyes of a mutated animal that is about to attack you. See that energy, that life there? That is the Great Glow.  Of course the blessing of the Great Glow is not for free, for nothing in life is free. Study the various wasteland guides to truly understand the Great Glow, the nature of the mushroom cloud, and understand why salvation lies only through their wisdom.  And always keep these rules in mind:1. Tread lightly and carry a big gun and/or stick.2. Every animal with the prefix ‘mutated’ considers you to be its lunch. 3. If your Geiger counter starts going off the scale, you should turn around.  4. The only thing worse than a robot the size of a truck with a circular saw and a laser beam, is a robot the size of a house with a minigun, a flamethrower and half a dozen minions that are coming right for you.5. Toaster repair is essential for a good breakfast.Fun fact: The credit song “Cries of a Dead World” by Miracle of Sound perfectly captures the atmosphere of Wasteland 2. --My rating system consists of six categories in descending order of importance:-	Atmosphere-	Combat & Controls-	Details-	Tactical gameplay-	Characters-	StoryBased on the performance each category will receive one of the following grading: -	S-Rank: excellent-	A-Rank: very good-	B-Rank: solid-	C-Rank: satisfactory-	D-Rank: inferiorIf the S-Rank is awarded, a quote from the game or personal comment will be added as a token of my respect (in brackets).--Atmosphere: S-Rank(This oddly dressed merchant sports a slight tan, huge arms and legs, a bear belly, and big beard with two white stripes in it. Under normal circumstances the pink tutu around his belly would look odd, but somehow Ratboy makes it work.)Combat & Controls: S-Rank(If yer sober, that’s the best yer gonna feel all day.)Details: S-Rank(Shoving your hand into a roiling vat of glowing radioactive gloop is probably one of the worst ideas you’ve ever had.) Tactical gameplay: S-Rank(A little more persistence, a little more effort, and what seemed hopeless failure may turn out to glorious success.)Characters: A-Rank Story: A-Rank--To conquer all achievements of Wasteland 2, you will most likely spend more than 100 hours. You can get them all in one play-through, assuming you watch out for the ‘Wasteland Historian’ achievement.   There are no multiplayer achievements. Two very useful guides can be found on the links below (thanks to Carrarius & Tigi). 


YouTube™ Video: Steam Game Reviews - Wasteland 2 

			Views: 3,640		

			Hello everyone! We will be reviewing games while giving tutorials and advice as we play. In this episode, Ryan takes a look at Wasteland 2.		




Wastleland 2 - 100% Achievements guide 
A Guide for Wasteland 2
By: Tigi

			Finally guide is 100% completed, it took about 110 hours playing, testing and writing guide. Achievements are sorted by order you can get them, so you don't need to play game twice, save load will be enough.		


Achievement difficulty: 8 of 10Common:- Singleplayer [+2]Special:- Blast from the Past [+1]- Not Monkeying Around [+1]- Relics of a Bygone Age [+1]- They Walk Among Us [+1]- Too Much Time on Yer Hands [+1]- Wasteland Historian [+1] --Wasteland 2 (PC) – Turn-based role-playing game (Post-apocalyptic Science Fiction) – 2014-Wasteland (PC) – Classic turn-based role-playing game(Post-apocalyptic Science Fiction) – 1988 Link to Steam review for Wasteland.

number of helpful: 27 of 53 people (51%) found this review helpful
content:
r 1, 2014
												I so want to like this game... The story is nice, the writing is good, but the combat is awful. The gameplay is dated, maybe it can appeal to retro gamers or people who mistake boring mechanics with hardcore. There is a lot of boring combats, which is slow and crappy.The hard consequences that the game touted are...subpar so far. Fallout New Vegas felt more alive and your actions had more weight than here.To talk in details about the combat system, think fallout without any combat options (no called shots) and moronic AI. You just trade blows with hard-hitting melee sprinters or eagle eyed ranged NPCs that suffer from a preference to eat lead by leaving cover if someone is next to them. It's turn based, but with no tactics (you could call the cover system tactical if you were very nice) and as such it ends up being slow.The character creation system is poor and having no perks and lackluster attributes leave not so much to the imagination. The skills are varied and made necessary if you don't want to trudge throught the combats.The dialogues are sometimes a tad strange and you end up with some stereotypical NPCs. They try to put a veneer of gray on your choices with cynicism and "realism", but it often fall flat IMHO due to the comedic nature of some situations.A lot of the quests are fedex quests made painful by the lack of fast travel, slowness of movement and the ubiquitous boring slow combats. The so-called inhospitable wastelands are filled with oasis, making the presence of the water mechanics... strange to say the least as it never occured to me I could lack water.The "open world" is level locked, so even though you could probably go wherever you want, the choices are often limited.If you have most of the skills (and with the 3 NPCs you can recruit, it's easy to keep nearly all of them maxed) you'll be rich and never have to worry about ammo.I understand the devs wanted to cater to the nostalgics of Wasteland 1, but gaming has evolved and some mechanics are better left dead in the 90s.In short, a promising game with crappy combats

content:
er 18, 2013
Early Access Review
								I honestly can't see how there are so many positive reviews on this garbage at it's current state, i'm honestly starting to believe I may have recieved some "nega copy" from the depths that should be played by no man alike.Let me just start out with this; as a fallout 1 and 2 childhood fan, i truly looked forward to this title after seeing it raise about three million dollars. Now if you don't know already, three million creates hype for those who don't even understand the cultural relevance of the first wasteland, so this early release had something to live up to. Hell even the early reviews state that the game is promising, so maybe i'm not the one understanding what the word 'promising' means any longer. See when I think of a 'promising' three million dollar game, I think of an enjoyable yet somewhat bumpy experience at this point of development, not some poorly put together thing called a game that can't function past fifteen minutes without bugs annihilating everything in their path. And the best part, that during those fifteen minutes of play I recieve, even the bugs aside, the game is boring. Nothing, and I mean nothing, compels me to go forward with the lackluster story, the combat is atrociously broken and slow, and the whole experience feels like it was made by two men in a basement with a few connections to decent voice actors who had no idea what on earth they were doing, not a skilled development team with a ludicrous amount of money at their fingertips.But hey. I'm a glass half full kind of guy, so maybe this piece of trash is another man's treasure.

content:
r 3, 2014
												This is an example of when Kickstarter works with a trust established company. I backed the game but didn't play it in early access so my comments are regarding the final release.Firstly the combat is all about turn based tactical choices, the closest comparission would be Xcom Enemy Unknown and Shadowrun (Cover systems, Action points to spend per turn.etc.)You take the role of 4 Desert Rangers in a post apocolyptic wasteland years after nuclear war has annihilated the planet. (Its the original concept to the Fallout series, so fans of that will get it instantly)So far I have sunk over 45hours into this game and only in what you would call "Act 2" to avoid spoilers. Think Baldurs gate, Divinity series, Torment, Neverwinter Nights in terms of side quests, loot and rewards for exploration of the world. Story is engaging and entertaining but could be seen as means to an end for the 4 protagonists rather than an epic personal journey. Saying that though, the different stories and factions to discover through the world gives you incentive to carry on into the end game with curiosity. I couldn't stop playing this game, it will make you curious to explore and see what lies south of that radiation well.

content:
y 1, 2015
												+ Branching quests with multiple viable solutions and diverse outcomes.+ The choices you make affect the world in meaningful ways.+ Tons of content with very little filler (unlike Dragon Age: Inquisition).+ Solid writing.- Assault rifles are OP and make every other weapon type seem comparatively useless.- Combat doesn't have a lot of depth or variety.- Game was pretty buggy at launch, particularly the late game (though this may be fixed by now).- Graphics ain't too pretty.- Some skills are overly specialized (like Toaster Repair and Blunt Force).- It's easy to screw yourself over if you don't have a lot of experience with CRPGs.Conclusion: If you enjoyed the first two Fallout games, you will likely enjoy Wasteland 2. If you didn't, you probably won't. Also, if you only care about combat and don't care about things like quest design or reactivity, you'll probably get bored.

content:
ber 23, 2014
												I'm currently writing this review through gritted teeth and clenched fists and I'm trying hard to stay objective and clear headed.  Firstly I'm list the positive things.The atmosphere of this game is excellent and it truly feels like a real post apocalyptic world.  Immersed in this environment are numerous choices you must make that really do affect different outcomes.  Many games offer multiple conversation lines that lead to the same answer regardless of what you choose (giving the illusion of a more broad conversation) but in this game there was clearly a lot of thought put into the writing.  The replay value of this game is definitely immense.  I've read different reviews on different sites, and some of the weaknesses others have mentioned about this game, I actually see as strengths.  As an old-school gamer and a big fan of deep RPGs, I'm not looking to have things served to me on a plate.  So having to rotate my camera around, to see chests behind trees or whatnot, isn't a hinderance but actually adds to my gaming experience.Also with the large number of skills and their gradual progression, it makes possible something else I really enjoy in video games; which is revisiting old places with higher skills to make new discoveries.  That's why I always have one character with high perception skills.  Some have complained that combat in this game is repetitive.  I don't agree, I enjoy dividing my party and placing snipers at high points and using high AP characters to lead enemies into ambushes.  That's just one of the many tactics I use during combat.  I could go on and on about the positives.  Now here's the negative:I can't play it for more than an hour without a crash.  The game is extremely unstable.  I've tried every workaround mentioned by inXile staff and not a single one has worked.  I did have the Early Access version (which had the same crash problem) but I uninstalled it before I installed the released version.  Nothing works.  Now I'm just waiting for a patch that will fix these crashes before I can play again because it's really ruining the experience.Another annoyance is the right-click move button.  I need to click an area a few times before the party will actually move there.Other than that, the game is great and I highly recommend it.  I only wish these crashes would stop.

content:
r 27, 2014
												Played 31 hours in 3 days. 10 hours in to first play through decided I didnt like my setup Main menu'ed and New game.  The Game is amazing the Character creation can take an hour or more trying to fit all the skills your want in to 4 characters you quickly learn you cant have what you want, time to pick what you think you'll need.  While I see alot of comparing it to Fallout 1&2 no one mentions how close the game is to Fallout tactics the combat is almost a clone.  Fallout tactics was also a squad based game with the same Map system for travel.All in all I love the game, Best $40 I have spent this year the replay value is high and it makes me feel like I was a teen again, Playing Fallout on a computer that could barely run doom. ( Edit ) Having Completed the game I feel I should fill out the reveiw Some more.  First The Battle system does get a little bit boring shall I say? but its to be expected in a battle System of Turn Based and Guns in the end you know what is going to happen you'll hit that wall for every shot hits. The AI does tend to simply Rush at you rather than use cover but again to be expected from this type of game ( Fallouts where all the same )  But the story and the choices you make unlike normal RPG they carry a certain weight too them which after the first one or two you make and you realise this you start to question your actions, what to say to the NPC's what the out come might be and how to push it the way you want.  All in All I loved the game it felt Fleshed out and complete to me, I did not see any of the bugs the others have added to their reviews infact the only issue I did was that the Camera locked at one point and I had to Alt + Tab to fix it.  I will Play again, many times. I feel that if you want a game where choices do matter and who you Shoot changes the game this is the game for you.  I look forward to some DLC too. 10/10

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
r 10, 2014
												Phenomenal, just what I had expected and more.After 50 hours I have finally beaten the game and that with skipping some side quests mainly in the second half of the game, Rarely does a game give you so many choices alot of which are tough moral choices that have very real effects on the game, every NPC except on is killable (The commander in Sante Fe), you can play the game in every way you can think of and killing everyone or betraying the rangers are legit options that you can make and they wont stop you from progressing in the game (they will make the game harder though and I am going to start a game where I am going to kill everyone right after I finish writing this) and dont think killing everyone doesnt have benefits, unlike in other games if you kill a marchant all of what he was selling is takeable.Some people claim that the combat is the weak part of the game but I have to disagree, the combat feels great, it can get annoying sometimes with some extremely hard fights and with some enemies being able to run completely insane distances.The story is well writen and there is not a single "bad guy" that fights you because you are evil no one is really bad or good, most of the people in the game are in the grey area, they are all driven by ideology,religion or another motivation and even stories of tiny side quests often have interesting plots and twists.Everything you see is described in a log of sorts in the lower right side of the screen which adds to the over all immersion of the gameNo game comes without flaws though, the game is often buggy mainly in the second half of the game, the game also lacks voice narration and has alot of text which resulted in me skipping alot of text, also alot of times when confronted with a moral question by a so called "bad guy" alot of times it felt to me like I can only say that I agree with him or something that sounds like "What you are doing is injust and we fight injustice" when I actually didn't really play the good guy, I was very much in the grey area, doing things the rangers don't approve of and even lieing to my command after killing civilians and often avoiding the peaceful solution and dealing with problems guns blazing and there was not really a good way to represent the fact that what the bad guy is doing has no benefit to me, at least in my opinion.Over all this is a one of the best games that I have ever played, everything from the atmosphere to the gameplay is awesome.10 Repaired Toasters/10.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
r 18, 2014
												Having played the original Wasteland and every Fallout game released, (Yes, even that one for the X-Box. You know the one I'm talking about), I was pretty much expecting a better version of Fallout Tactics with a deeper, richer story line. The result? I little underwhelming, but overall a good experience.Tight, turn-based tactical combat with a rotatable isometric view mean that other than a few oddities that occur with objects that are "between the camera and the view," the control is pretty solid. The game rewards you for good tactics and positioning with every weapon skill having it's pro's and it's cons. You're not penalized for having a diverse team and the biggest problem of simply having a team of grunts with no real other skills is simply that a lot of side missions will be more difficult, if not impossible.The downside... the story feels a little "been there, bought the t-shirt." And not just for a player of wasteland. There really isn't anything in this world that the game presents that genuinely feels original in any way, with the unfortunate majority of the various groups you come across feeling like someone blew the dust off and gave it a new coat of paint. Not a slapdash job though, but a loving restoration with a few embellishments here-and-there. The big disappointment was the final mission/ending. If any part felt like you'd played it before, it was this one. *sigh*Still, an enjoyable game for Hardcore fans of the Post Apocalyptic genre, or relative newcomers. But anyone else may want to give it a miss if retreading familiar ground doesn't catch their fancy.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
13, 2015
												I recommend this game to anyone that likes a mix of Strategy with RPG elements. If you like Shadowrun I would highly recommend this to you. Especially if you like the Fallout series because the RPG element in this game is pretty much similar. Think Fallout meets Shadowrun.Anyway, before you do start the game, if you're familiar with Fallout, like in Fallout, do some research about stat gains and what it gives, and how those stat gain affects your gameplay so that you know what you can cap early on. Same goes for your skills. Except that when concerning skills, you would wanna check up on what skills are commonly needed in the wasteland to survive. Otherwise, you're going to dislike the game even before you're halfway through with it.My only issue is the formula derived for chances because it seems pretty wonky. For example, most of the times something which is  91% and above and your 1% of critical failure, you would expect it to pass without a critical failure. At most you'd expect just a failure, if not at all. But from what I noticed, it seems this game's chance formula is failure baised. Because even if a high passing rate with 80-90%, critical failure when opening doors and unlocking stuff are pretty damn common for a 1% critical failure.However, if you can live with that issue, then by all means GET THE GAME ALREADY!

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
1, 2015
												I probably put over 200 active hours into this piece of crap. I spent most of the time disgustingly frustrated with the gross lack of direction.I desperately wanted to love it. I don't think there's a game I've ever played more than Fallout 2, and this seemed to have all the makings of a similar legend made reality. The back and forth is disgusting for some of the quests. The inability to figure out exactly what the hell you're supposed to do to solve many of the quests is maddening. The skill gap between yourself and some NPCs is also unexpectedly obnoxious.When you launch the game and see the Red Boots DLC for $49.99 and you know you're being trolled, it's kind of funny. Until you realize that the entire game is one massive troll job. The developers crapped the bed with the UI. Things that could've taken fewer clicks which you must do incessantly get very old. Inventory management sucks. Selling equipment sucks as well because no one has any money to compensate you. Getting tokens to cash in at base? Useless. You'll find better crap in the wild. Everything just feels as if the developers didn't actually play the game to realize just how frustrating it is.The game could have been finished in 25-30 hours if not for never knowing what the hell you're supposed to do, and if you didn't have to run from one end of a map to another to complete some uninspiring objective. Skip it or wait until it's $4.99 because at 50% off for a Steam sale, you deserve a refund. I paid $39.99 long ago.I paid top dollar for this at release and was determined to see it through to the bitter end. I'm sorry I did.

content:
y 6, 2015
												This is really fun game, when i play this, it just reminds me a of a crossover between Mount and Blade and Shadowrun.The game "travel" system is like mount and blade where you take your group on a journey through the wastelands of arizona trying to do all the nobel stuff that rangers do. The problem is that you have to avoid radiation and check your water levels so you dont die of thirst or radiation poisoning. while that may seem easy it can be pretty annoying to have the shortest route blocked by radiation and to take a detour means that you have to waste all your water and you end up with a dehydrated and tired group walking into an encounter. The encounters on the map are about as annoying as pokemon, imagine walking through a big grass field for an entire game of pokemon, imagine how many encounters that would be. EXACTLY! Besides those issues the world map is very well done and contains many other things to find like travelling merchants, treasure and watnot.The encounters are completely random, but most of the time you'll just be fighting either, bandits, animals, etc... but for the others it can be things like merchants, towns etc... so you get the point of encounters.The character leveling up system is interesting, at the start of the game you can either pick from a list of default characters or customise and create your own. it gives a pretty balanced set of skill and ability points to start you8r character on a certain playstyle. At the start of the game it will provide ytour characters with starting weapons based on their skills. To level up simply get enough XP and then use your radio(explain later) to call command, they will says soemthing like  "CONGRATZ YOU GET A PROMOTION" then you get the appropriate ability points to use one your character(s).The Radio is a unique part of the game, you use to pick-up sidequests, recieve calls/updates from command, and get issued field promotions. you will just get random transmissions, important dialoge and other watnot from the radio, also the frequency changes by itself so you dont need to worry about that.Combat is much like certain classic games, your characters initiative skill determines what order your turn is in, and works as a top down turn-based rpg. all of your actions require Action Points so it's important to conserve them, any excess points will be carried over to the next mission.not gonna talk about the storie because spoilers mate GO PLAY IT YOURSELF!so yeah...9/10 would kill a raider again

content:
22, 2015
												To me, Wasteland 2 feels like Fallout and Baldur's gate/Icewind Dale got dumped into a blender, and the result is a great old-school, hardass (true to the Wasteland name, it is a ballbustingly hard game!) RPG. The game looks very good graphically, and the story is, so far, pretty good. Like the original Wasteland, you have a plethora of skills to choose from -- weapon, utilitarian, dialogue, and the selection of weapons is also pretty good, although if you like energy weapons, I'd suggest waiting before taking points in the skill, as it will take a while before finding some. In short: This game is awesome! If you enjoyed the old Fallout games, and any of the Infinity Engine RPGs, this game is a MUST PLAY. inXile has done a stellar job with this one, and I HEARTILY agree with PCWorld saying this is GoTY of 2014 -- it absolutely is!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
y 9, 2015
												Incredibly immersive character development and plot-- and adequate graphics for even the most shallow gamer. I managed to find a few plot glitches and 1 graphical error, but I'm lead to believe that they will be resolved by the devs in time. It has some roguelike elements, such as the irreversable death of party members-- the permanent results of your decisions, and the cold pain of knowing you could have done better if you had "only known." I give it a solid A, being bumped to A+ when the graphic and plot progression errors are smoothed out. The game has some pretty extreme replay value, not to mention huge potential for steam workshop additions, and further additions by the developers.This has to be one of the VERY FEW crowd funded games I've played that wasn't an overhyped sack of crap.

												Overall (8/10): The true fallout 3Pros:- Great, long storyline with rewarding sidequests- Fallout fans favourite, the dark humor (exclude fallout 3 fans)- Freedom to choose your fraction, including destroy your own Rangers at the beginning of the game- Map, items, the decoration on the map, is just too detail and everything got a reason to be placed there and well described- Every small decisoon comes with consequences, you'll never notice until the end game story.- Worth buying during discount- You'll wanna play again after end game- The environment vibrance is outstanding- You can shoot the kids (juviles)Cons:- Unable to change the NPC attire, except your own premade rangers- The NPC can't comment humourly at the same time- Least armor option- Too frequent radio back to tower to level up, annoying.- Too many boxes with dynamites that doesn't even make sense- The 70% success rate in this game means 10%, you always get the failure and critical failure- The character optional looks are dull and limited, same goes to the inital available attires.- Annoying dog padding sound (only 1 type of voice)

content:
0, 2014
Early Access Review
								Currently I have access to the beta and here are the notes I am forwarding to Inexile.  In general:This beta is stable, more stable than many "finished" game releases I have dealt with in the past.  Not one slow down, not one hang, not one crash.  Amazing for a beta.The game is exactly what I wanted.  Something very similar to the old school FALLOUT games.  Lots of dialog, mature subject matter in some places (not suitable for children though no swearing yet), and no funky dialog like you sometimes get with translations from some other language into english.Though I am attaching my beta notes which suggest several issues, I give this game a 4/5 stars in its beta state, and hope beta problems I did find are addressed.  None of the things I note prevented game play.Build #42098#1  Inventory Review (right click on mesh top).  The descriptive text has a spelling error.  "This laced top will have to fellas tying themselves in knots".  Might warrant a review of item descriptions for correctness.  Maybe the user community can help with this.#2  No obvious way to transfer items between characters other than tediously dropping items to the ground and having a different team member pick them up.I was wrong with this one.  If you notice the cursor icon when left clicking an inventory item, in the upper left corner is a little white arrow.  This arrow needs to be in the icon window of target PC, the item will transfer to that PC inventory when you drag and drop.  My bad.#3  Fraps keys do not seem to work so getting screen shots does not work.  Was hoping the game would have a hot key for screenshots too.#4  Rotate of camera is not particularly smooth and seems to get stuck at times requiring a continued restart of mouse movement.  This makes working your way through some maps very difficult.#5  Do not see a way to change the angle of view.  One can zoom and rotate but not change the angle of view in order too at a greater distance or less distance.  This is certainly not a requirement and for most will likely not affect gameplay but most games that allow rotate and zoom allow angle change to the view.#6  Pictures in inventory after right clicking to get additional info have jagged edges.  What happened to AA?#7  The overall feel of the interface is not as gritty as I would have liked.  It is difficulty not to compare this game to the likes of Fallout and Fallout2, and I will refrain from doing so as much as possible.  In this case though it is an excellent way to describe what I mean.  The fallout interface had the feel of the game.  This interface does not.  It is too clean and lacks details and imagination.  The interface is functional for game play but could have been far more visually appealing.  I believe this significant because of the amount of time spent in the inventory and character screens so time spent updating these interface elements would go a long way to improving the feel of the game.#8  Either audio is having problems with dialog, or some of the dialog has not been done.  For example, entering Highpool, half the dialog you have over the radio is not audible; you can only read it.#9  9mm and .39 ammo look the same.  Caused me to run out of ammo by accident on one of the PC.#10 Very dissappointing textures in some places.  For example, a raider encounter on the way to the prison.  Looks like some buildings burried in sand?  But are these visuals the best you could do?  They are rather poor, lacking interest and detail.  I am chalking this off to this being a beta with some areas not yet completed.#11. After doing goat hill, and dealing with some scorpions raiders, one of the dead raiders was blinking in and out of existence.  Not a problem for game play but an interesting bug maybe.

content:
ber 21, 2014
												I love many things about this game. I dislike very few things.But what is most important is that this game has the wondrous feeling of escapist post-apocalyptic exploration flavor I thought we had lost forever.When Bethesda butchered Fallout III (and although Obsidian salvaged it) -- I had no hope that I would feel the way I did in the late 90s again. I was an impressionable kid, getting owned by floaters and centaurs, unprepared, Sulik bursting like a dumba$$ riddling Vic with holes-- but I loved every moment of it.Wasteland 2 took me to that place once again, especially as you progress through the game, it becomes an old school classic that we were sorely missing in our lives for the past 20 years.This game is an heir to the likes of Baldur's Gate 2, Fallout 1&2 and of course the grandfather of them all, the original Wasteland.Thanks Brian & Co. for the liquifying energy weapon animations. Thanks for the non-linear love this game got. Thanks for all the times you listened to the community and backers. Thanks for sticking to your ideals and not caving in like Bioware at the onslaught of console idiocy. Thanks for Ertan the Satanist.Thanks for returning us 90s kids back to the world intelligent, brutal and immersive cRPG gameplay.

content:
ry 24, 2015
												Basically this game is a lot of fun and challenge for the most parts. But lacks some content which made Fallout and other similar games the best.Combat:One of the biggest downs is the non avaible sneak mode. Once your spotted (and you will be at a very long range usually)every enemy near the one who spot you will enter combat. That part is okay i guess, because if you get spotted by an enemy human guard IRL i guess he would scream for help and the other would still be coming because of the gunfire.But usually there is huge open areas which are impossible to sneak through without taking a totally different way which anyhow leads up to a combat situation just from an other entry point. So forget about playing sneaky because there are no stealthboys in this game. And also the hit ratio seems messed up (or im just really unlucky).Questing: I have really enjoyed the quest, its no pointing fingers in this game. You just get a general tip of the whereabout of whatever you'r searching for. It's no arrow pointing you exactly to the location to go. Which is really nice. If you do the "right" thing in a questline its a huge chance you end up with better supplies and another follower to your party (which is always nice because combat is unforgiving, if you play on normal or ranger difficulty).Lots of random loot you find will be of interest to various NPC's throughout the world (not the junk items, altho it says in tooltip that you never know who might be interested in a junk item. Still haven't found any use of em)World: Like many others said before me, its too much space with not enough content. And too many preset combat situations when walking on the map from zone to zone. Bugs: With the most recent patch i havent encountered many. Just one where monk suiciders go through stairs and walls.Overall: 6/10 Lots of fun but without enough depth to satisfy you'r RPG experience. Too much sloppy work on character development (like there are only a few of your party members on whom you can customize pants, jacket and hat) Many of them got just preset apperance.

content:
ry 21, 2015
												Wasteland 2, oh Wasteland 2. I had more than a handful of bugs happen to me. I fought with the camera nearly the entire time of my play through. I understand why some people didn't like it. I felt frustration and almost stopped playing more times than I can remember, but boy does this game have charm. I played in Seasoned difficulty, it was painful but I was careless.If you are looking for another Fallout in the traditional form, this comes the closest. There are a few things I wish I knew from the beginning, things the game doesn't explain. The further you go into the game, the more these are revealed, and yet there are even more unexplained things scattered around the wastes. Things I couldn't figure out. Things no one has. I was a cat thrown into a laser disco. In the brief flashes of light between the waves of shadow, you were sure you saw the grin of a dog. Then the shadows come back, and the figures move, and behind all the masks are things moving to the groove of some unheard music. You know there are other cats around somewhere. But the shadows continue to dance, and it looks like one is following a laser though maybe it is not. And you don't know who is who, and what they want, but you know the only way out is through the crowd and the shadows, or you could just follow the lasers. Though in between the lights, and in between the macabre dance, a few beautiful notes licked at the edges of your perception. You could tell something beautiful was around the corner, and you weren't sure where it was going or where you were coming in but you had to find out, you had to let yourself be engulfed in the dance. The Wasteland dance.

content:
ry 17, 2015
												First cRPG I've ever played from start to finish. A wholy engrossing experience with a decent main story and some great side-quests (that are essentially so good and dynamic they become part of your own main story). Lots of customization and ways to solve different problems. The game is incredibly hard in the beginning but if you build a decent team it opens up after a few hours and by the end you should feel like a badass, though never totally over powered. The combat is a good mix of tactics and gear dependency and overall is very satisfying. When an enemys weapon jams just as he is about to kill one of your characters is exhilarating. Tons of weapons and armor along with vanity items and all kinds of other junk. A modern classic in every sense of the word. I bought it for 20$ at a sale and I would buy it for tripple that price. Can't recommend it enough if you can stomach the difficulty and have the time to spare. All around superb game. Buy it, buy it, BUY IT!

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
r 29, 2014
												While I missed the original Wasteland I got to play every game in the Fallout series. I believe that this game is a worthy successor, albeit not as good as the early Fallouts. It has the same perspective as Fallout 1 and 2, but is now using a 3D engine. The game is a fair bit more combat heavy compared to Fallout 2, but unlike Fallout Tactics has a far deeper role-play element to it.Details+ Character creation is quite deep with plenty of attributes, skills, and derived stats. You get to create four characters at the start of the game and up to three more NPCs can join your group at a time. There are enough skills to make you want to create specialized characters for different purposes. There are skills for using different types of weapons, social skills, ability to perform certain actions such as lockpicking, safecracking, using computers, medical skills, etc.+ Combat is turn-based and has a feel very similar to the early Fallout games except that you get to control a party instead of just one character. NPCs that join your group will sometimes choose to do their own thing if you do not have a character with high enough leadership. You get a certain number of action points to perform actions during a character's turn such as moving, using one of the weapon's firing modes or an item, reloading, and so on. Cover exists and increases both aim and defense of a character in it. When and how often characters get to move depends on their combat initiative.+ Game is long and completing it with all of the sidequests can easily take 60 hours. There are plenty of different locations to explore and while there are radioactive walls that prevent you from going to certain places before you are supposed to in the story line you generally get to decide where do you want to go.+ Story and writing are both solid. A lot of quests have multiple solutions and in a number of cases social skills can help avoid confrontation. Decisions you make will affect the ending and the ending itself will clearly show the results of your actions with slides explaining what will happen to every place you have visited.+ Great ambient soundtrack from the same composer who created music for Fallout 1 and 2 as well as Planescape: Torment and a number of other games.+ While overall graphical quality is quite poor by today's standards and character models especially could use an improvement, I feel like the designers and artists have made the most out of a kickstarter budget.- Most of the loot in the game is completely random and changes on reload encouraging save scumming. It is completely possible to crack a well-protected safe only to find a few bullets in it while a game reload could give you a nice weapon instead. Furthermore most of the loot is broken down into tiers based on location or your place in the story line so there are often points in the game when you know your party is equipped with best equipment possible until you progress further making looting until that point completely unexciting and even becoming tedious with how plentiful containers are. Also a number of items that are marked as junk end up having a purpose in some of the quests.- Some balancing issues make certain weapon types completely useless throughout the game. If you choose wrongly in the beginning you will feel screwed later on.- Due to how plentiful combat is higher difficulty levels require very specific character builds to make the most out of combat initiative and action points in order to progress. If you want to create a role-play party my advice is to stick to the default difficulty level.- The game still had plenty of bugs upon release, especially in the second half of the game. The very last few areas also feel like they have been a bit rushed, but at least the game ending is satisfying.

												I'm a die hard Fallout and Wasteland fan. While Fallout 1, 2 (which i consider being the greatest game in history of mankind) and even Tactics and where great games, Fallout 3 and New Vegas where FPS abominations, now worthy of Fallout name. So i've waited and waited for a true Fallout successor. Then i've got Wasteland 2. Am i disappointed? Hell no! Wasteland was father of Fallouts and Brian Fargo was father of both. You can feel his touch in every aspect of Wasteland 2. From wonderful post-apocalyptic setting, through deep development of Your characters, interesting quests and NPCs... ending with what made Fallouts such great - adult, dark humour and morally grey world, which You can shape as You want.TL:DR - forget about Fallout 3 and New Vegas. Wasteland 2 is the true successor of old Fallouts. While in terms of gameplay it feels more like Tactics, all in all it's a wonderful and complex RPG, in which You'll spend tons of hours playing. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.
