content:
r 8, 2014
												While the game is good and all, there is a fair warning to be said. If the first half of the game (Arizona) is more or less complete and bug free (at least from my side, there are still a lot of bug for some people), the second half (California) is full of bugs, from minor to gamebreaking. In its current states, the second half of the game is what you expect from an early access, not a release.In this state I can't recommend this game, which is sad considering how good it is in the first half, but the second half of the game can't be considered as finished. And you can blame the devs for it, since we asked to be able to test it, and they refused, arguing their QA team was working on it and it would be perfect.Basically, the more you go toward the end, the more bugs you'll find, and the more likely you will encounter a game stopping bug.Anyway, here the pros and cons of the whole game.Pros :-Lots of story. Expect a lot of talking. This is a hit or miss. Expect more talking than action, unless you shoot everything on sight.-Background. Fallout/Wasteland and their universe are a hit or miss. If you like mad max, you'll like it.-Humour, but not ridiculous. While there are a lot of easter eggs and jokes, mostly about 80' stuff, they are well done, and they are all logical in the universe. There is no joke for the sake to make a joke, as you would be able to see in fallout 2 (the Star Trek shuttle, broken dreams inn,...). -Replayability. There is a LOT of endings and choices to be made. Ranging from small to big. And not only for the main quest, but for every area.-Graphics. While it's VERY ugly when close, I find the game quite pretty from afar, and the places are really well done. I honestly enjoy it a lot.-The possibility to build your own 4 rangers party (you'll be able to recruit 3 more NPC into your party, with their own moral compass etc...). It's basically like Icewind dale, or NWN2 Storm of Zehir for party creation. As for the NPC you can recruit, do not expect Bioware's interaction, they will leave or stay according to your action, and have something to say at various place in the world. Some of them are even granted small cutscene and special interaction, and can help you dealing with something special, but it's extremely rare.Cons :-Currently unfinished. And by that, I mean some area are missing triggers, some NPC are not even named (being generic NPC), and even some area are not done (casino being outside of the building, and an excuse about unfinished work inside for example).-Full of bugs. Including gamestopping bug that prevent you from completing the game. Or less annoying, to complete an area.-Combat system. While I like it, I wish we had a lot more cover and environment to use. So far, having a single place to take cover in a fight is quite rare. Being able to take cover with your entire team is extremely rare.-RNG badly done. The game is basically inciting to savescumming if you want to open chests and whatnot. Only to find 10bullets inside a chest with 60% chance to open with the maximum skill. Why isn't it a straight check instead of some useless RNG ? -Some choices not impacting the rest of the game. Granted, only really happened in the second part of the game which is unfinished, but it's still annoying to kill several patrol of some faction, having them calling everyone on radio to say how evil you are, and still being greeted like a hero in their HQ.-Lack of weapon balance. Heavy weapons are useless, just like shotguns. While Assault Rifle and SMG are usefull for the entire game. And energy weapons being the best weapon for the mid/late game.-Lack of variety in weaponsmithing. While you can mod your guns, the mod only increase in the bonus effect, not in variety. For example, scope only provide better range, nothing else. More choices would have been cool. Also, the heavy weapons can't be modded, making them even less interesting.-Lack of stats balance. Some stats are useless, like luck, giving a chance to earn a small benefit, while another stat will provide the same bonus, with some others,  and is guaranteed. Also, combat initiative is a lot more interesting than action point, forcing you into a build, more than anything else.-Traduction unfinished for any other languages than English. It's not a problem to me (playing in English), but it can be for you, if you are playing in German or French for example.Once I'm able to finish the game, and the various side quests which are currently broken, I'll edit this review.

content:
r 6, 2014
												Edit for the director's cut edition:One year and a director's cut after, the game still suffer of the exact same problems:  - There was no UI improvement. - There was no character building rebalance: 3 attributes out of 7 are still useless. - There was no loot rebalance: Almost every container use the same random loot list.The Quirks and Perks system feels rushed and unimaginative: most are just small bonus without any effect on gameplay.In conclusion:The DC edition don't change anything meaningfull (sic).Wasteland 2 still feels like a cheap reboot of fallout tactics: it is an ok (neither bad nor good) tactical-RPG. /End of edit4/10Wasteland 2 could be a great game but right now (october 6, 2014) it is rigged with too many bugs and balancing issues. IMHO, this games was not ready for full release.Pros: - Dialogues are well written. - The huge amount of references and nods to the 80s. Cons; - Not much strategy involved in fight, enemy AI is really meh... - A lot of skills feel redundant and artificials (5 of them are just for opening different type of door or container). - Attributes are balanced for min-maxing character, builds with 2 to 4 dump stats are recommended. - Weapon balance is terrible: Assault rifles are OP, Sniper and SMG are OK, there's only one good Energy weapon in the entire game, the rest is garbage.  - Too much randomness in loot and skill success, savescumming will lead you anywhere. - Poor optimisation. For example, any activated alarm makes the game unplayable because of lag. - Bugs: a lot of bugged quests, inventory management problems (clicking dragging fail 2 times out of 3).  - Lack of meaningfull choice: most quests are one-ended and those who aren't generally only leads to flavor consequences. Conclusion: this game need either a huge balancing patch or modding tool.Draegnar

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
r 4, 2014
												I cant recommend it yet. The Models need serious attention, and its clear that some areas received a lot of love and care in their construction and others are very much still Beta-Playtest blanks; and this is in the intro areas, Im talking about Citadel, Ag Center and Hightower.  Stat, loot and skill balancing needs work, and there's some very *very* clunky and poorly thought out UI choices, which Im unsure of whether they can blame that on Unity or not. Considering the LOD that the Cenega XCOM games, and most recently the *actual* Xcom games recieved, the turn based combat here doesnt seem retro, it just seems amateurish. not being able to force 'combat mode' so you can properly position your people to spring ambushes is particularly awful if you're trying the higher difficulty levels.Admittedly most of my gripes come down to mechanics; but the HardAss/KissAss/SmartAss mechanics ties directly into the players experience of the plot, and to split this out into three stats rather than a single Social check results in the player experiencing their characters as belligirent, smarmy or conniving caricatures, rather than intelligent people making choices. I keep putting the hours in, hoping it'll turn around, but for now Im really rather disappointed: this comes across less like a sequel to wasteland, and more like the original wasteland creators haven't played or written a game since then; and then came out of hibernation, dug out UnityInANutshell and promised all us whippersnappers a good time.

content:
y 6, 2015
												This is really fun game, when i play this, it just reminds me a of a crossover between Mount and Blade and Shadowrun.The game "travel" system is like mount and blade where you take your group on a journey through the wastelands of arizona trying to do all the nobel stuff that rangers do. The problem is that you have to avoid radiation and check your water levels so you dont die of thirst or radiation poisoning. while that may seem easy it can be pretty annoying to have the shortest route blocked by radiation and to take a detour means that you have to waste all your water and you end up with a dehydrated and tired group walking into an encounter. The encounters on the map are about as annoying as pokemon, imagine walking through a big grass field for an entire game of pokemon, imagine how many encounters that would be. EXACTLY! Besides those issues the world map is very well done and contains many other things to find like travelling merchants, treasure and watnot.The encounters are completely random, but most of the time you'll just be fighting either, bandits, animals, etc... but for the others it can be things like merchants, towns etc... so you get the point of encounters.The character leveling up system is interesting, at the start of the game you can either pick from a list of default characters or customise and create your own. it gives a pretty balanced set of skill and ability points to start you8r character on a certain playstyle. At the start of the game it will provide ytour characters with starting weapons based on their skills. To level up simply get enough XP and then use your radio(explain later) to call command, they will says soemthing like  "CONGRATZ YOU GET A PROMOTION" then you get the appropriate ability points to use one your character(s).The Radio is a unique part of the game, you use to pick-up sidequests, recieve calls/updates from command, and get issued field promotions. you will just get random transmissions, important dialoge and other watnot from the radio, also the frequency changes by itself so you dont need to worry about that.Combat is much like certain classic games, your characters initiative skill determines what order your turn is in, and works as a top down turn-based rpg. all of your actions require Action Points so it's important to conserve them, any excess points will be carried over to the next mission.not gonna talk about the storie because spoilers mate GO PLAY IT YOURSELF!so yeah...9/10 would kill a raider again

content:
r 4, 2014
												Edit after a few more hours of playBacked on Kickstarter with BG2 nostalgia. Too much of a mixed bag for me. - Writing, atmosphere and emotional engagementLet's be clear, that's why we're here. Boy have I missed playing a squad of lively characters with believable, coherent personalities (yeah I'm looking at you Bethesda). You start with 4 PCs and can have 3 NPCs at a time. The writing is good but very unequal from zone to zone, sometimes great, sometimes annoying. - Strategy, tactics and intellectual engagement Tactics are OK but get boring quite quickly. More complexity and diversity would have been nice, like with expanded science/crafting/mechanics skills and lots of consumables and craftable devices to adapt to each encounter (to have something akin to the wizards in BG2). Strategy is annoying. Your choices are too uninformed early on ; for me the beginning was very hard whereas it got too easy after I got the mechanics. Non-combat skills are universally unnerving. They are designed so that you can only get a fraction of the game per playthrough, unless you save and reload a lot, so you are left to pick between playing the game 15 times or reloading all the time. - Design and engineeringI haven't played the beta. The game is fluid and bug free on my 64-bit Ubuntu rig (still looking at you Bethesda). I initially had 1 glitch in 40 hours, but then there was a bug that made me lose 4 hours of play and that's kind of a dealbreaker for me. Loading times could have been faster, and the UI could have been better (more visible highlight mode, unified and codified representation of possible interactions (wasted one real-life hour in highpool because the highlighting of the Surgeon skill is different form that of Disarm), a panel with all the skills from everybody ...). - GraphicsLet's be clear, that's not why we're here. Isometric 3D works for me, other than that, don't care. Sometimes it's too 3D : stuff gets in the way and it's hard to click where you want (whatever). - SoundMusic OK but not memorable - would have loved some epic music. Voice acting sometimes dull, sometimes great, sometimes non-existent.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
r 29, 2014
												While I missed the original Wasteland I got to play every game in the Fallout series. I believe that this game is a worthy successor, albeit not as good as the early Fallouts. It has the same perspective as Fallout 1 and 2, but is now using a 3D engine. The game is a fair bit more combat heavy compared to Fallout 2, but unlike Fallout Tactics has a far deeper role-play element to it.Details+ Character creation is quite deep with plenty of attributes, skills, and derived stats. You get to create four characters at the start of the game and up to three more NPCs can join your group at a time. There are enough skills to make you want to create specialized characters for different purposes. There are skills for using different types of weapons, social skills, ability to perform certain actions such as lockpicking, safecracking, using computers, medical skills, etc.+ Combat is turn-based and has a feel very similar to the early Fallout games except that you get to control a party instead of just one character. NPCs that join your group will sometimes choose to do their own thing if you do not have a character with high enough leadership. You get a certain number of action points to perform actions during a character's turn such as moving, using one of the weapon's firing modes or an item, reloading, and so on. Cover exists and increases both aim and defense of a character in it. When and how often characters get to move depends on their combat initiative.+ Game is long and completing it with all of the sidequests can easily take 60 hours. There are plenty of different locations to explore and while there are radioactive walls that prevent you from going to certain places before you are supposed to in the story line you generally get to decide where do you want to go.+ Story and writing are both solid. A lot of quests have multiple solutions and in a number of cases social skills can help avoid confrontation. Decisions you make will affect the ending and the ending itself will clearly show the results of your actions with slides explaining what will happen to every place you have visited.+ Great ambient soundtrack from the same composer who created music for Fallout 1 and 2 as well as Planescape: Torment and a number of other games.+ While overall graphical quality is quite poor by today's standards and character models especially could use an improvement, I feel like the designers and artists have made the most out of a kickstarter budget.- Most of the loot in the game is completely random and changes on reload encouraging save scumming. It is completely possible to crack a well-protected safe only to find a few bullets in it while a game reload could give you a nice weapon instead. Furthermore most of the loot is broken down into tiers based on location or your place in the story line so there are often points in the game when you know your party is equipped with best equipment possible until you progress further making looting until that point completely unexciting and even becoming tedious with how plentiful containers are. Also a number of items that are marked as junk end up having a purpose in some of the quests.- Some balancing issues make certain weapon types completely useless throughout the game. If you choose wrongly in the beginning you will feel screwed later on.- Due to how plentiful combat is higher difficulty levels require very specific character builds to make the most out of combat initiative and action points in order to progress. If you want to create a role-play party my advice is to stick to the default difficulty level.- The game still had plenty of bugs upon release, especially in the second half of the game. The very last few areas also feel like they have been a bit rushed, but at least the game ending is satisfying.

content:
y 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								I recommend this digital deluxe edition to 1) everyone who liked the original wasteland, fallout 1 and 2 or fallout tactics and want such games back, 2) people who like to support crowdfunded games by independent producers, 3) people who want to participate in a beta process.The game is obviously in a beta stadium, but the game looks overall promising. If you want games with tactical, turn-based combat and adult but funny rpgs in isometric perspective with an open world and choices and consequences heres a possibilty to make such a game come true. Big publishers dont seem to want to finance such games. So the gamers have to, allowing the developers to produce a game without restrictions from publishers.You get some digital goodies and the game when its finished. The current beta is also lengthy, at least about 8-12 hours. There are still some major bugs to be fixed, optimizations to be done, some mechanics to be included, and some heavy balancing issues to be solved, but according to inXile the beta should get updated regulary and they also said, they are going to add a few maps to the beta over time. If you want to debate aspects of the game and report bugs to make the game better, you have possibilties to voice your opinion - if you like to.

Through one playthrough I managed to sink in about 49 hours and still had a bunch of content left untouched. Infact I actually finished the game early simply because I took a wrong turn. So for those worrying about content, worry not. This had more than enough to satisfy you. On the flip side however, there are a lot of bugs in this game and I mean a LOT. All of them are solvable pretty easily but unless you save often I expect there will be countless moments of rage as a very specific quest condition isn't met requiring you to load to a previous save. Although this is beta the bug problem is still very real. But all in all it's still a great game and I recommend you to get it for the chance at spending an hour creating characters that you love and then losing them in the first encounter with wasteland creatures.

content:
y 6, 2015
												This is really fun game, when i play this, it just reminds me a of a crossover between Mount and Blade and Shadowrun.The game "travel" system is like mount and blade where you take your group on a journey through the wastelands of arizona trying to do all the nobel stuff that rangers do. The problem is that you have to avoid radiation and check your water levels so you dont die of thirst or radiation poisoning. while that may seem easy it can be pretty annoying to have the shortest route blocked by radiation and to take a detour means that you have to waste all your water and you end up with a dehydrated and tired group walking into an encounter. The encounters on the map are about as annoying as pokemon, imagine walking through a big grass field for an entire game of pokemon, imagine how many encounters that would be. EXACTLY! Besides those issues the world map is very well done and contains many other things to find like travelling merchants, treasure and watnot.The encounters are completely random, but most of the time you'll just be fighting either, bandits, animals, etc... but for the others it can be things like merchants, towns etc... so you get the point of encounters.The character leveling up system is interesting, at the start of the game you can either pick from a list of default characters or customise and create your own. it gives a pretty balanced set of skill and ability points to start you8r character on a certain playstyle. At the start of the game it will provide ytour characters with starting weapons based on their skills. To level up simply get enough XP and then use your radio(explain later) to call command, they will says soemthing like  "CONGRATZ YOU GET A PROMOTION" then you get the appropriate ability points to use one your character(s).The Radio is a unique part of the game, you use to pick-up sidequests, recieve calls/updates from command, and get issued field promotions. you will just get random transmissions, important dialoge and other watnot from the radio, also the frequency changes by itself so you dont need to worry about that.Combat is much like certain classic games, your characters initiative skill determines what order your turn is in, and works as a top down turn-based rpg. all of your actions require Action Points so it's important to conserve them, any excess points will be carried over to the next mission.not gonna talk about the storie because spoilers mate GO PLAY IT YOURSELF!so yeah...9/10 would kill a raider again

content:
1, 2015
												I probably put over 200 active hours into this piece of crap. I spent most of the time disgustingly frustrated with the gross lack of direction.I desperately wanted to love it. I don't think there's a game I've ever played more than Fallout 2, and this seemed to have all the makings of a similar legend made reality. The back and forth is disgusting for some of the quests. The inability to figure out exactly what the hell you're supposed to do to solve many of the quests is maddening. The skill gap between yourself and some NPCs is also unexpectedly obnoxious.When you launch the game and see the Red Boots DLC for $49.99 and you know you're being trolled, it's kind of funny. Until you realize that the entire game is one massive troll job. The developers crapped the bed with the UI. Things that could've taken fewer clicks which you must do incessantly get very old. Inventory management sucks. Selling equipment sucks as well because no one has any money to compensate you. Getting tokens to cash in at base? Useless. You'll find better crap in the wild. Everything just feels as if the developers didn't actually play the game to realize just how frustrating it is.The game could have been finished in 25-30 hours if not for never knowing what the hell you're supposed to do, and if you didn't have to run from one end of a map to another to complete some uninspiring objective. Skip it or wait until it's $4.99 because at 50% off for a Steam sale, you deserve a refund. I paid $39.99 long ago.I paid top dollar for this at release and was determined to see it through to the bitter end. I'm sorry I did.

content:
ber 20, 2014
												I was skeptical that a crowd funded game with a 60 dollar initial pricetag would actually end up being a solid title. Thankfully, I was proven wrong. I picked up the game for 40 dollars and so far it has been worth every penny.Gameplay- This isn't a game that holds your hand every step of the way, often times you need to think about what you are doing or saying (dialogue) and if you mess up it might give you an undesirable result. Personally, I enjoy it since I feel like everytime i go anywhere new there is a chance to find some need little tidbit or item that normally would not stand out.Characters- While it is unusual to find an RPG these days that allows the creation of a party (only other one i can think of is might and magic legacy), it provides an opportunity to make characters specialize in different fields. For example, I have a hand to hand bruiser that has meathead skills (break, hard ♥♥♥ and mechanical repair (not meathead but the best i could do)). Then another character has sniper computer science and smart ♥♥♥. Another cool aspect is that you can assign characters religion, nationality and even their favorite pack of smokes- who knows maybe there is a little easter egg somewhere if you have a jewish asian etc. Also there are optional companions along the way, which can add 3 more faces (max) to your party.Combat- Being as it is turn base, it takes patience, but at the same time it allows the methodical approach. A lot of people don't like weapon jamming (requires an action similar to a reload), but i like it considering it adds more variability. If you have like Classic Turn-Based combat then you will enjoy this.Loot- I dont like how treasure was dealt with in this game. I find myself normally picking up heaps of junk or 6-7 of the same crappy gun i've been using. It also seems a little odd that there is such an abundance of ammo in an apocalytic wasteland. There are also some hidden items that can be turned into npcs for rewards, so keep an eye out!The World-  The game utilizes a travel mechanic that places the part on a "board" in which they have to travel to different locations all the while you can be attacked by raiders and be mindful of your water supply. As for whether the game is open ended or not, I would say yes to an extent. Even though there are optional side objectives, the path always leads you in the direction of the mission. It is similar to the Mass Effect Series as both have the option for exploration and side missions, but the story missions are required to advance.Overall-Have you played Divinity: Original Sin (check)Have you played Shadowrun Returns (check)Have you played Fallout 2 (check)Did you like any of them (check)Then you will love this (check)

content:
0, 2014
Early Access Review
								Currently I have access to the beta and here are the notes I am forwarding to Inexile.  In general:This beta is stable, more stable than many "finished" game releases I have dealt with in the past.  Not one slow down, not one hang, not one crash.  Amazing for a beta.The game is exactly what I wanted.  Something very similar to the old school FALLOUT games.  Lots of dialog, mature subject matter in some places (not suitable for children though no swearing yet), and no funky dialog like you sometimes get with translations from some other language into english.Though I am attaching my beta notes which suggest several issues, I give this game a 4/5 stars in its beta state, and hope beta problems I did find are addressed.  None of the things I note prevented game play.Build #42098#1  Inventory Review (right click on mesh top).  The descriptive text has a spelling error.  "This laced top will have to fellas tying themselves in knots".  Might warrant a review of item descriptions for correctness.  Maybe the user community can help with this.#2  No obvious way to transfer items between characters other than tediously dropping items to the ground and having a different team member pick them up.I was wrong with this one.  If you notice the cursor icon when left clicking an inventory item, in the upper left corner is a little white arrow.  This arrow needs to be in the icon window of target PC, the item will transfer to that PC inventory when you drag and drop.  My bad.#3  Fraps keys do not seem to work so getting screen shots does not work.  Was hoping the game would have a hot key for screenshots too.#4  Rotate of camera is not particularly smooth and seems to get stuck at times requiring a continued restart of mouse movement.  This makes working your way through some maps very difficult.#5  Do not see a way to change the angle of view.  One can zoom and rotate but not change the angle of view in order too at a greater distance or less distance.  This is certainly not a requirement and for most will likely not affect gameplay but most games that allow rotate and zoom allow angle change to the view.#6  Pictures in inventory after right clicking to get additional info have jagged edges.  What happened to AA?#7  The overall feel of the interface is not as gritty as I would have liked.  It is difficulty not to compare this game to the likes of Fallout and Fallout2, and I will refrain from doing so as much as possible.  In this case though it is an excellent way to describe what I mean.  The fallout interface had the feel of the game.  This interface does not.  It is too clean and lacks details and imagination.  The interface is functional for game play but could have been far more visually appealing.  I believe this significant because of the amount of time spent in the inventory and character screens so time spent updating these interface elements would go a long way to improving the feel of the game.#8  Either audio is having problems with dialog, or some of the dialog has not been done.  For example, entering Highpool, half the dialog you have over the radio is not audible; you can only read it.#9  9mm and .39 ammo look the same.  Caused me to run out of ammo by accident on one of the PC.#10 Very dissappointing textures in some places.  For example, a raider encounter on the way to the prison.  Looks like some buildings burried in sand?  But are these visuals the best you could do?  They are rather poor, lacking interest and detail.  I am chalking this off to this being a beta with some areas not yet completed.#11. After doing goat hill, and dealing with some scorpions raiders, one of the dead raiders was blinking in and out of existence.  Not a problem for game play but an interesting bug maybe.

content:
ber 21, 2014
												I love many things about this game. I dislike very few things.But what is most important is that this game has the wondrous feeling of escapist post-apocalyptic exploration flavor I thought we had lost forever.When Bethesda butchered Fallout III (and although Obsidian salvaged it) -- I had no hope that I would feel the way I did in the late 90s again. I was an impressionable kid, getting owned by floaters and centaurs, unprepared, Sulik bursting like a dumba$$ riddling Vic with holes-- but I loved every moment of it.Wasteland 2 took me to that place once again, especially as you progress through the game, it becomes an old school classic that we were sorely missing in our lives for the past 20 years.This game is an heir to the likes of Baldur's Gate 2, Fallout 1&2 and of course the grandfather of them all, the original Wasteland.Thanks Brian & Co. for the liquifying energy weapon animations. Thanks for the non-linear love this game got. Thanks for all the times you listened to the community and backers. Thanks for sticking to your ideals and not caving in like Bioware at the onslaught of console idiocy. Thanks for Ertan the Satanist.Thanks for returning us 90s kids back to the world intelligent, brutal and immersive cRPG gameplay.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
er 24, 2013
Early Access Review
								So far so good, Wasteland 2 is shaping up to be a great buy but in its current state I would hold off unless you a) like beta testing or b) are nostalgic for Fallout 1+2.The game is much more combat focused than the early Fallout games but its combat system is definitely an improvement over those games. The visuals are also very pleasing and level of detail is nice. Your actions do have consequence to the world and some choices will cause certain areas to be inaccessbile, this makes me think that multiple playthroughs will be necessary in order to experience most of the comabt.Other than the obvious issues associated with being early in beta such as missing or limited content there are some major issues.  There is little feedback for most of the skills and during combat it is hard to tell how many action points some actions cost. There are also numerous bugs and pathing issues that can be frustrating but most won't ruin a playthrough.I would hesitate to buy this game now while it's in its infancy and with its current 60$ pricetag it is a sizeable investment. Down the road when it becomes more finished I would highly recommend this game. Based on the current direction I am estimating that this game will be a very enjoyable RPG.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
r 15, 2014
												Finally, after all these years, we get a proper spiritual sequel to the first Fallout games. In fact, Wasteland 2 looks and feels so much like a Fallout game that it took me some time to accept that I had no Pipboy, Vault suit or funny perks.It's a really engaging game with an interesting story (without being revolutionary in any way), with the usual moral dilemmas and multiple paths to complete objectives. And it's great value for money; I personally spent 86 hours on a single playthrough! Granted, I like to take my time more than most, but few games offer me that much nowadays.It's not a perfect game though; the ending is lackluster and the latter half of the game (with one area in particular) is riddled with some rather annoying (but not gamebreaking) bugs. But eh, I guess the bugs is just another aspect  that emulates the good old Fallout games...All in all, I'll definetely recommend this for fans of post-apocalyptic settings, roleplaying games and the Fallout series in particular.8/10 (perhaps even 9/10 if they fix most of the bugs)

content:
4, 2015
												The game starts great - many people find it annoying, but I loved how brutal was the game to a newbie who doesn't know how to optimize the characters. Yes, you are unable to open a lot of locks, and you often can't talk the crooks out of doing bad stuff, but it's more realistic this way, and I never got the feeling I was stuck. It only made me want to play again to see the things I've missed. There are other ways to accomplish a goal even if you think you're too low on resources to do it. Combat feels right even if it's less tactical than, say, Jagged Alliance's, and the scarcity of ammo only adds to the atmosphere.On the other hand, the base story is kinda flat, and the game is slightly buggy and unpolished in some places, but there are still enough details to distract from it, so it didn't bother me most of the time. More problematic is the lack of cues for completing side quests, and it's easy to miss important locations/people, or do things in a wrong order. The end is probably the most disappointing part, as the final battles are quite anticlimatic (the badass scorpion robot on the start screen looks like a plush toy and does about as much damage to well-equipped characters). Still, the rest of the game was enjoyable enough to be worth my time.

content:
2014
Early Access Review
								This review is based on the early access so I will try to be reasonable with how I feel about the game.The game reminds me so much of Fallout 1 & 2 with support for higher resolution. The graphics are nothing spectacular but it doesnt have to be since the game focuses more on user experience and immersion. Yes immersion! I'm not a big fan of reading especially long dialogs but this game does it well by letting you visualize what's happening in the world via text (type writer) and npc barks. It totally allows you to use your imagination without even realizing it. Yes, there are a bunch of typos that I've noticed which affects my experience personally, but then again it's still on beta. I like the fact that the quest log system does not treat you like a dumb person, unlike Fallout 3 where it shows you on your compass where you need to go. Instead the log gives you details of what you've accomplished so far and what you need to do next. I'm playing the default difficulty (seasoned) which is very challenging and the loot system is well thought of. The scarcity of ammos and health pickups allow you to decide whether you should go back to citadel (home) by travelling which is by the way is very very dangerous, or just keep pursuing hoping that you'll maybe get lucky and find some loot or vendors along the way. There are also a lot of interesting items you may find such as sega genesis console, neogeo, and even a used condom. I think they are irrelevant to the game but it's defnitely entertaining. I probably won't sell them. It would really be awesome if the developers can go even further with it and allow you to give it to a person in citadel to place it in citadel collection room or something, to display your awesome finds.The controls are pretty good, it's could be improved though. But I liked the fact that I can play it with just the mouse, so I don't have to hunch down in front of my keyboard. I can just sit back, relax, with one hand on the mouse. It accomodates old gamer like me who's retired and doesn't have to work and just allow the kid inside me to just enjoy what I've missed when I was growing up working too hard. No more stiff necks and sore elbows. But like I said it can be improved. Also, if I may add, I really like how the cursor system was in fallout 1& 2. I think it's actually one of my favorite and memorable to me that right-clicking changes the cursor behavior to walking or action command. I can't remember if it was double click the walk mode to run but that would be awesome option. instead of holding down shift key.I like that they stayed away from static camera, but sometimes I wish there's an option to turn it back to static camera because the camera can get a little clunky sometimes. When you're tryign to find the travel zone it can get very frustrating, I think the way to solve this is by minimap (starcraft like)  which you can click on an area in the minimap and move the camera to that spot, which is currently not in the game. Speaking of map, I wish they have the option like in fallout 1 & 2 to have some kind of a town map that you recently visited to allow you to just go directly to a certain part of the town instead of walking all the way from the travel zone just to talk to one guy, then walking back all the way again to get out of the town. By the way the first time i took a ride at the crane elevator at highpool i was like, "Oh cool", but after doing that for about 10 times I'm like "Okay...", then I'd noticed one of my party member was left behind so i have to go through the cutscene again just to get my other team mate. I know it probably took some time and even effort for whoever designed this but it get's annoying especially when you're on the go. I'm not sure if there's vehicles in the game that you can ride like in fallout 2, and if there is it'll be awesome if you can customize it to add protection from radiation and and dehydration and allow a faster travel with options to attack random encounters using a higher outdoorsman skill. Also what's up with kick ♥♥♥, smart ♥♥♥, and hard ♥♥♥? I mean, does it really need to have 3 separate skill for each one? I hope they make this into just one skill, I don't know like just Kick ♥♥♥. I'm kinda glad that it's still in beta, which leaves a lot of room for improvements, I just hope that the deveopers are as open as they should be for suggestions and improvements. And I look forward for this awesome game to get even more awesome.Bottom line is I'm totally recommending this game if you can tolerate grotesque, rude languages, violence, drugs, prostitution, and sad reality of the world to come after the apocalipse.I know I've written a lot already, but I will add some more as I progress with the game.Thank you InXile for making this game.

ry 1, 2015
												I'm a die hard Fallout and Wasteland fan. While Fallout 1, 2 (which i consider being the greatest game in history of mankind) and even Tactics and where great games, Fallout 3 and New Vegas where FPS abominations, now worthy of Fallout name. So i've waited and waited for a true Fallout successor. Then i've got Wasteland 2. Am i disappointed? Hell no! Wasteland was father of Fallouts and Brian Fargo was father of both. You can feel his touch in every aspect of Wasteland 2. From wonderful post-apocalyptic setting, through deep development of Your characters, interesting quests and NPCs... ending with what made Fallouts such great - adult, dark humour and morally grey world, which You can shape as You want.TL:DR - forget about Fallout 3 and New Vegas. Wasteland 2 is the true successor of old Fallouts. While in terms of gameplay it feels more like Tactics, all in all it's a wonderful and complex RPG, in which You'll spend tons of hours playing. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.

r 4, 2014
												I was hoping for a Fallout2. What we got was... something that tried to be Fallout2 and fell way, way, way short. Part of it is the skill system, part of it is loot distribution, part of it is the linear nature of the story, and map design is also pretty bad. The game can be super easy/trivial on the parts I want to be challenging, and needlessly frustrating on the parts that should be simple. There are no "multiple ways to solve a problem" there is one way, except they don't always tell you what that "right way" is. The game is a decent time-waster. It's not terrible, I certainly put more time into than other games. But I'm not going to remember it in 5 years.  But this really was billed as a 2nd coming of F01/F02 and it's not. It was a let-down, given the promises.

content:
r 10, 2014
												So, I've 42 hours on the clock and am only half way through this game (starting off to california right now). What should I say about this game? Well, I'm 31 years old and this is (PC) gaming like I was used to back in the 90s.- No dumb "?" above questgivers- a party which you can create by your own imagination... with the chance to really f*ck up- really interesting world with (comic like) brutality, irony and funny references to especially gaming and apocalyptic movies at nearly every point of the maps- as of now, not the best story in the world, but it fits- sometimes really hard battles (playing on the third of four difficulties)- a few minor bugs, but no showstoppers so far- tons of sidequests and decission to make which actually matter- endless amount of flavor text which is really nice to read, but not necessary for completing the game- unfortunately very rare interaction between party members - some of the larger maps could be disorientating due to size and lack of a useful mapTo sum it up. If you like older RPGs like the Baldurs Gates, Fallout 1 and 2, Arcanum or even the oringinal Wasteland, GO GET IT, DONT WAIT FOR ANY SALE! The developers really delivered what they promised and they deserve their money! Hopefully we'll get a good Addon or even Wasteland 3! For me this is the first true sucessor to Fallout 2!Thumbs up!

content:
y 13, 2015
												I am happy to say that this was probably the best game I purchased off of STEAM for the entire year. PROS:~Super rich detail in everything.~Maps are huge. ~Ability to create your own 4 person squad from the get go. ~The ability to have a max of seven people in your party! How awesome is that!?~Lots of guns. ~You can set up ambushes/surprise attacks. Also, attacking from higher ground and behind cover equals PWNAGE! I've even had enemies throw grenades at me from low ground only to have them hit something and hit their allies instead. Awesomeness for sure!~Every single skill is usable unless you don't want to. And that simply makes some aspects of the game much harder. CONS: The game is extremely well done, and the only issues I could possibly have with it are not being able to zoom in on the map display, which can make missing parts of maps an easy thing to do, leaving you wandering back and forth until you get frustrated. Then again, I may not have noticed where I was supposed to go. Either way, it's an extremely minor thing, especially when the maps for most places are quite huge, many consisting of other areas you have to travel to in order to search the area fully. The other thing I would have liked is voice acting for everything. But I suppose I am spoiled like many others these days, where pretty much every game out now has voice acting throughout. Overall, two little things that don't deter from my experience whatsoever.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
y 31, 2015
												Wasteland 2 is a party based RPG set in a post nuclear war USA. The player controls a squad of Desert Rangers, whose mission is to protect civilians and maintain law and order, but now an army of robots want to wipe out Humanity, and its up to the Rangers to stop them. I never played the original Wasteland, but I'm a massive fan of RPGs, and I certainly found alot to enjoy in this game.Combat is turn based on a square grid, with each action such as moving, firing, reloading and healing costing ability points, similar to Xcom or Shadowrun. Its very tactical, and you also have to pay attention to factors like cover, line of sight, weapon range and friendly fire. The maximum party size is seven, four of which are created by the player, and the others have to be recruited as you progress through quests. There is a wide variety of abilities to put points into when levelling up. You can use several different types of guns and melee weapons, but also non-combat skills including lockpicking, safecracking, computer hacking, trap disarming, machinery repair and more. These skills are very useful because many quests can be completed in multiple ways, by finding alternate routes to enter a building or unlocking extra dialogue options.The story is really good and there are lots of interesting characters and groups. From drug gangs to slavers and religious fanatics, there's always somebody more crazy in the next town. Many quests involve a conflict between two or more factions and the player has freedom to choose who to support, but you'll rarely find an obvious "good guys" faction, more often its a case of "which is the lesser evil?". Dialogue is mostly text based, with only the major characters being voiced, but its all well written with lots of dark humour.I didn't encounter any game breaking bugs, but occasionally I thought certain quest progressions could have been better. Like the time I drank from a water well, got infected with a disease, and used a normal inventory item to cure myself. Later I found the town's doctor, who asked me to investigate why the people were getting sick. I didn't have any option to say "dude, its your well". The only way to progress the quest was to travel to another town to find a special microscope so the doctor could check out some samples, and discover what I already knew several hours of gameplay earlier.I also didn't like that inactive companions didn't seem to gain XP. One of my earliest recruits was kind of annoying, constantly complaining about literally everything, so I wanted to ditch him. But every new recruit I found after that was several levels lower, and I didn't want to be weaker in combat, so I was stuck with him.Except for those complaints, Wasteland 2 is a really great game, and I definitely recommend it to RPG fans, although genre newcomers would be better off starting with something less complex. It took me 68 hours to finish and I didn't complete every side quest, which is excellent value for money at full price.

r 15, 2014
												You have already read the reviews of others and the positive ones are correct about the game. Although I would like to inform you of a few caveats.The game difficulty is well balanced at the normal suggested difficulty setting but starts to break while it is increased. Unlike Fallout Tactics, as the difficulty in Wasteland 2 increases the only change is quantitative. Your aim probability decreases, enemies do more damage etc. but the AI remains the same. Beating a battle set piece doesn't make you feel like you played well it mearly feels like you got lucky over and over again.One last pet peeve. The issue here is the half turn discrepancy between setting up your squad before combat and the first turn of combat. Since you can see battle coming you are able to plan ahead for it by setting squad order but the second battle starts all of your squad move just a little out of place and destroy all chance of strategic combat.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
r 20, 2014
												Short version: this is not a great game. It will not be remembered for years to come as a high point of the genre. It will not spawn remakes and imitators. But it's still good enough, and frankly, if you like your combat turn-based and your texts long and well-enough written, you have no choice this Autiman, but to spend some time playing Wasteland 2.Now, let's dig in to see what went wrong.Character developmentAt first, character development looks good enough. For the first half of the game, you will value every Skill Point you get. Unfortunately, after that it becomes evident that character development is quite limited in Wasteland 2. You can spend Skill Points to get slightly better at hitting enemies. Or opening locks. Or disarming traps. Et cetera. But if you try to make two characters with the same specialization (say, Sniper Rifles), you will develop them in pretty much the same way. There are no ways to make a character unique: no Perks, no Feats, nothing of that sort. Why didn't the developers add such feature to the game, I can't imagine. It's not like it would require expensive voice-acting or even additional 3d models...At the very least, they could have borrowed a page from Shadowrun's rulebook, and give special abilities or bonuses at certain levels of skill. I don't really see a need to give my Sniper 10 in sniper rifles, when all it gets me is a few more percents of To Hit chance!CombatCombat here is turn-based and slightly more varied, that in Fallout 2. This is all good that could be said about it. Lacking abilities, this game offers little in a way of infulening the outcome of combat in dramatic way. This is especially dissapointing after GREAT combat in Divinity: Original Sin.In terms of combat, Wasteland 2 is far behind not only D:OS, but also both Shadowrun and X-Com. This is made worse by strange balance, which allows enemies to mostly negate all your careful placement of characters by running a very long distance in a single turn (this is not a bug: with bug, they had pretty much unlimited running range, now it's just too big).StoryShould you expect a great, thoughtfull story from a game that has Toaster Repair in its list of skills? I guess you shouldn't. But I still was disappointed by a pretty cliche main quest.Another bad mark here is tired trope where heroes take about 15 minutes to solve problems which locals could not solve for years. Negotiate a peace between two warring tribes? A bit of shooting and one dialog. Convince a community to stop ritual cannibalism? Two dialogs! Now, you shouldn't probably make the player feel like they are negotiating for peace in Middle East, but this is borderline insulting.DialoguesDialogues here are all right. Text are well-enough written and I had no wish to skip them.Still, there are to little Skill Checks, and lack of complex trees lead to shallow experience. Compare this to Arcanum's dialogues with Persuasion...WorldPost-apocalyptic games, books and movies are not known for a well-tought-out worlds. They are often seem more like a zoo. "See here, children, this farmers worship an unexploded nuke; and those town took their god from an old folk song!"Wasteland 2 did nothing to change it. Still, some are turned off by what they consider over-the-top sillines, especially in the very beginning of the game, in Ag Center. I, for one, found acceptable, but no engaging, and the rest of the game is the same. This world does not seem alive, I can't feel anything for it, it's just a backdrop for some fighting, questing, looting and trading.SummaryRiotPixels, gave the game 78% out of 100. I think this is exactly the right score for such a game. inXile failed to make a masterpiece, but, well, it's still a good, playable game. You can spend some fine time with it. Just don't place too much hopes in it, so as not to be disappointed. I, for example, do not regret backing it on Kickstarter, and will back other inXile projects in future. I mean, what's the alternative? How much turn-based RPGs are there every year? Two? Three? Another one is good, even if it's not a great one.

content:
r 19, 2014
												Wasteland 2 was one of those games that really speaks to older generations of games. There are many good as well as bad design features, but overall it's an enjoyable experience if you're willing to put yourself through it. Upon starting up your first game you create a party of four Rangers and can choose their stats and skills, select character appearance options, and write a quick bio should you so desire. Of course, one of the things that is limited by the standards of old crpgs is that you can't play your character too far off the path of the desert rangers, but still the story is interesting and features a lot of unique ideas that might just get you to crack a smile. Now there is a ton of dialogue and text in this game, but of course that means a lot of conversation options come up time after time. You'll find your self clicking things to get them out of the way, and of course sometimes this can get you into confrontations without any clear indications. Since I like to schmooze my way through many of these it was kind of annoying that there werent more options to use the skills associated with conversation, but at least they were there. The combat mechanics were probably the most fun. I played this game at the second highest difficulty on my first try and didn't have too much trouble. There are some frustrating things, like enemies walking 150 tiles across the map straight up to your characters on the first turn and punching them in the face, but so long as you're prepared you can usually deal with this by lobbing out grenades and rockets. That being said, there are plenty of different weapons to take advantage of and they are all useful and unique in different ways. Some character stats are more useful to combat than others, so it helps a ton to diversify your party because the situations that arise require different skills and weapons. Some enemies are tough to take out with light weapons, but easy targets with energy guns, and vice versa. As a piece of advice you will be binding quick save to the key closest to your keyboard hand, and pressing it often. There are times where it is not always clear what you have to do, and if you do them in the wrong order you can get into situations like endless combat for HOURS before you give up and reload. It's truly unfortunate that unorthodox situations do this to the player, as it feels restricting at times. I remember early in the game trying to expedite a mayoral race, and did as many helpful tasks as I could save for one that I could not find. Turns out the doctor, who said he didn't need any help, actually needec you to use your surgeon skill on his patients... seriously? I spent hours trying to figure this out before looking it up. Another gripe is that you will spend hours just walking across maps, for no purpouse other than you're going back and fourth for quests. There are sometimes ways around this that open up after having done enough to open up a quicker passage, but usually by this point it doesn't even matter anymore. You'll experience this enough to come to hate the experience. You'll be getting out your chair to find something to distract you for three minutes while your party walks around, and sometimes you have no idea if where you're going is going to help your quest. Truly this was the most frustrating aspect of the game. Yet another thing, many characters have the same portraits, even important ones at times. I really wish that they had taken the Baldurs Gate appreach and only gave important characters unique portraits. And the portraits, they look like they were painted by a college student. They werent bad, but felt lacking. Sometimes it made the characters you meet less unique, as they just sort of blend into each other. Now it might seem i'm going off on the negative aspects of the game, but these are things you should know before you start playing. It's by no means perfect, but hightly enjoyable. Comparable to Shadowrun Returns, where as shadowrun had a really focused story and an enjoyable simplicity, Wasteland 2 has a very big and diluted feel with explosive chests falling out of the sky and arguably more interesting combat mechanics and a big world.

												Finally an RPG like to good old days! Those who loved games like Baldurs Gate and Icewind Dale will also love this one. At least for the majority of the game. I found my self kind of hoping for an end for the last hours. Because the story, location and more was a bit off. But the 100+ hours up to that point was simply great! The first part of the game was better than the second half all over. But I think that is mostly beacuse you felt so overpowered in the later parts of the game. Even with a harder than normal difficulty. There are a few bugs still left in the game, but not anything game breaking. Like the view suddenly acts up, and you have to reload. But those bugs happens so few times, that it's really not fair to put the game down because of them.If you love old time RPG and don\t mind quite a bit of save and load scumming, then this game IS for you.

content:
er 28, 2014
												I like the setting, I like story, I like the gameplay, I like the gore, I like the character builder, I like almost everything. But like always there is one big thing what the developers have messed up really bad.There are many Recruitable NPCs who are too squishy concerning their attributes and skills. Some RNPCs (or even everyone?!) don't have the same amount of attributes like your selfmade characters. Why?! I don't know... Furthermore their attributes don't fit to theit skills.And another point... There are still too less RNPCs. Before starting a game, I figured out how I want to play the game. I've read on some community-sites, that you should match your selfmade NPCs with the RNPCs who are waiting for me in the wastelands. With the given RNPCs I am not able to play the game as I want, not so satisfying. There are always some skills missing I'd like to have in my party. For example I'd like to have all three speech kills (Smart ♥♥♥, Kiss ♥♥♥, Hard ♥♥♥) but then I don't have enough skill points to spend on other important skills. I hope there will be a patch who changes it. The combat system could have been much more interesting. It only contains very basic stuff and in most cases the AI isn't very smart. Sometimes enemies are looking for cover but it happens very often that they stand in front of you with no cover. Melee fighters are always rushing to your party, even it is very obvious they won't survive it. Enemies with pistols are also quite stupid. They run to you and try to shoot you, even if you have more guys alive. Riflemen and snipers are smart and take cover and try to get higher positions than you.Anyway, it's a good RPG with many choices and possibilities. I'm playing it currently on Ranger-Difficulty (3rd difficulty of 4) and I must say, it's still pretty fair. Combat is challenging, but you always find enough equipment to patch your guys up.The atmosphere very good, most RNPCs have unique dialogues which are quite funny. All the descriptions you get during the game are also so good. There is very much too read, but it's worth the time to spend with it.So the points which deny a "very good" or "excellent" are:- too less RNPCs- RNPCs with bad attributes and skill which are not matching the given attributes- just basic combat system- "bad" AI (for melle and pistol fighters)Oh, and on ranger difficulty you don't want to miss your outdoorsman-skill. :)

content:
y 30, 2015
												Well, I recommend the game, but it isn't without it's problems.The story was interesting and the roleplaying was good.  I felt some situations were set up as gotchas, where the obvious choice inadvertently made you a child murderer or shafted you in some way farther down the chain.  That being said, despite a few "Oh ♥♥♥♥ off" moments, overall it was a positive gaming experience, perhaps made better for the unknown ramifications of your choices (however much I don't like gotchas).  Several quests chains possessed weird bugs that made accessing the 'best' path counter-intuitive or impossible to achieve, which was annoying after putting in the time and legwork to get those results.  The tactical combat was good, but the pre-battle set up was lacking in interesting choices.  Long range characters were the best, because they can fire at enemies to start a combat, where medium or close range characters could not.  In fact, trying to set those characters up strategically would often cause the enemy to start the battle and get to go first, ruining the 'advantage' of setting up in the first place.  In the end it just made more sense to run up to within long range, crouch the party, and open fire with snipers.When I finished the game I wasn't inspired to play through it again, and I'm not sure that's a shame.

content:
y 1, 2015
												+ Branching quests with multiple viable solutions and diverse outcomes.+ The choices you make affect the world in meaningful ways.+ Tons of content with very little filler (unlike Dragon Age: Inquisition).+ Solid writing.- Assault rifles are OP and make every other weapon type seem comparatively useless.- Combat doesn't have a lot of depth or variety.- Game was pretty buggy at launch, particularly the late game (though this may be fixed by now).- Graphics ain't too pretty.- Some skills are overly specialized (like Toaster Repair and Blunt Force).- It's easy to screw yourself over if you don't have a lot of experience with CRPGs.Conclusion: If you enjoyed the first two Fallout games, you will likely enjoy Wasteland 2. If you didn't, you probably won't. Also, if you only care about combat and don't care about things like quest design or reactivity, you'll probably get bored.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
r 3, 2014
												This is an example of when Kickstarter works with a trust established company. I backed the game but didn't play it in early access so my comments are regarding the final release.Firstly the combat is all about turn based tactical choices, the closest comparission would be Xcom Enemy Unknown and Shadowrun (Cover systems, Action points to spend per turn.etc.)You take the role of 4 Desert Rangers in a post apocolyptic wasteland years after nuclear war has annihilated the planet. (Its the original concept to the Fallout series, so fans of that will get it instantly)So far I have sunk over 45hours into this game and only in what you would call "Act 2" to avoid spoilers. Think Baldurs gate, Divinity series, Torment, Neverwinter Nights in terms of side quests, loot and rewards for exploration of the world. Story is engaging and entertaining but could be seen as means to an end for the 4 protagonists rather than an epic personal journey. Saying that though, the different stories and factions to discover through the world gives you incentive to carry on into the end game with curiosity. I couldn't stop playing this game, it will make you curious to explore and see what lies south of that radiation well.

content:
er 17, 2015
												I like Wasteland 2.  I really do, I just have so many other things that get in the way of finishing my play through.  The Director's Cut offers a slew of minor fixes that make playing the game more enjoyable.  There are a ton of other reviews that will give you a nitty gritty rundown of the features, foibles, and atmosphere.  What I'd like people to take away is that this was developed by a tiny company of ex-Interplay veterans and brought to daylight through Kickstarter.  It is worth mulling that over, because as inXile marches forward we may be seeing a real paradigm shift in how games are made and distributed.  Cutting the third-party publisher out entirely has allowed this game - a labor of both love and commerce - to come directly to us.  We can shed the slimy feeling of lining the pockets of the artificial timeline money grubbers.

content:
r 20, 2014
												Wasteland 2 brings a unique style to RPG games. Giving off a fallout type of vide through out the whole game had amazing easter eggs to find and tons of interesting dialog. The combat was great and simple, Despite the minor bugs involving the camera glitching out durring combat but fixing itself after the next turn. Wasteland 2 state that there is 80+ hours.This may be true for some, yet for me it left me wanting more after finishing the game in under 60 hours. (All quests, side quests, locations, caches, characters, easter eggs, and pretty much everything was achived with a amazing immersive experience.-For me at least in under 60 hours) All and All wasteland 2 brings back the nostalga of the original wasteland and orginal fallouts. I would have to recommend this to everyone that loves the first wasteland and the fallout franchise. Although i would say i was abit annoyed by the fact it isn't open ended in terms of being able to continue to play and explore after the ending credits. I cannot however recommend this at its current pricing. the amount of content is great yet still is lacking in key areas. Best to wait for sales unless its a must have right now.

content:
r 4, 2014
												The AI is replete with bugs and are highly inconsistent, making most tactical decisions irrelevant. Sheer firepower is the only thing that gets you through the firefights. Your sniper can be crouching in an elevated position and blocking the only way up, and the enemy WILL run the equivalent of 30 odd action points to circle the position just to stand beside your sniper. Likewise the AI npc follower WILL make the same circuit just to stand in front of the enemy to die. Doesn't help that the AI followers have 1 or 2 bullet shot's worth of hp and can't be healed. Even under normal circumstances depending on the AI's whim and fancy they ocassionally develop a sudden ability to produce more ability points than otherwise deemed possible so that they can come and hug your characters in a loving embrace. The AI npc inconsistency has the potential to utterly ruin your attempt for a perfect quest clearance for at least one of the compulsory quests.There's a general lack of ammunition and medipack drops at the start of the game, so each encounter has to be carefully planned and executed. Unfortunately, in the early parts of the game, much of the available ammunition can only be found in locked/trapped safes/chests/boxes, which require a significant investment into the necessary non combat skills, which affects the distribution of limited stat points for combat skills, further wasting limited ammunition. Not a bad thing in itself, but would require careful planning.A corollary to the above is, on the long run characters starting with high intel and charm will significantly outstrip all other characters in every single way. One of the earliest followers you can get is characteristic of this. Low intelligence results in inadequate points to spread amongst auxiliary abilities, which results in bombs exploding, locks breaking, alarms ringing, bone fractures, skipped conversation choices and blue screens of death, and crucially, low supplies.Other than this, an excellent, excellent game. The story is brilliant and the choices you make in the game have implications and depth, though a number are more akin to morally abstract implications.P.S. There is a hidden choice at the start of the game, though it makes your playthrough a little harder than the standard choices. And remember to pick up the damned shovel.

content:
r 1, 2014
												Fallout 1 and 2 remain favorites of mine. While the FPS updates of Fallout 3 and Fallout: New Vegas were great in their own way, inExile's Wasteland 2 is the true "successor" to Fallout's vibe and gameplay.This makes sense when you realize the Fallout universe was created as an IP-claim-avoiding homage to the original Wasteland.Many of the great people that worked on Fallout 1 & 2 have returned to make Wasteland 2, including great work from Chris Avellone on writing and design and the return of Mark Morgan's beautiful ambient music.It's worth noting this is game is thematically dark, with far less of the goofy humor that started to undermine the Fallout series. There's swearing, sex, drugs, lots of graphic violence, and many, many morally ambiguous choices.I haven't even finished the game yet, but I am already planning a second trip through the wastes. Highly recommended for fans of Fallout 1 and 2, Torment, Baldur's Gate, and post-apocalyptic fiction.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
28, 2015
												Wasteland 2 is a good game, but overall fell short of my expectations. The funny thing is that the mediocrity of Wasteland 2 reminded me how great Fallout New Vegas was and I finally finished my walkthrough of that game, rather than continuing with Wasteland 2. Both games attempt the same thing in so many ways, but Fallout just does it better. The writing, the quests, the immersiveness... Even though I actually prefer isometric RPGs to Fallout's ego perspective, Wasteland's implementation of it has a wide variety of shortcomings. The world feels much more static because environmental objects cannot be manipulated, the different areas are much smaller in size, and the overall level of interaction is much lower.Other downsides to be aware of:- AI is very dumb- Percentage based skill checks lead to a lot of reloading (it probably would have been better to have a binary 100% or 0% chance).- Balancing of different weapon types is off (melee based characters seem weak, assault rifle beats everything)- Battles are not tactical enough (more types of cover would have been nice, more firing modes, more environmental interaction, better system for explosive weapons)In spite of all this critique, I enjoyed the "classic" feel to the game and the very post-apocalyptical setting that inspired the original Fallout. Thoroughly enyoable, but definitely not a must-have.

content:
y 24, 2015
												Another entry of the "CRPG revival" or whatever. Kickstarter funded old-school RPG games.Wasteland 2 sets out to be a modern take on the old-school style of RPG, and in this it succeeds greatly. Tons of skills, lots of character customization, lots of dialogue options, tons of sidequests, etc. It's well done and overall I had a pretty good time playing it.The combat gets to be a bit same-y near the end of it, but the game was interesting enough to keep me motivated all the way through it. The story was pretty decent, although pretty "par for the course" for post-apocalyptic RPGs. I haven't played the first wasteland, but the story is basically the same (from what I can gather), and it's also very similar the stories from the first few Fallout games. Not to say it's bad, but it really isn't anything special.I did the majority of the side quests I found, and there are a lot of easter eggs and hidden things to find. Definitely a lot of bang for your buck without feeling like you're just checking stuff off a list (I'm looking at you, Dragon Age: Inquisition).If you're looking for a game where you can accidentally set off a trap and kill your entire party within the first 30 minutes of the game, then this game is for you.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 21, 2014
												Well now, that is something. I had other work to do and I didn't sleep nothing today.Game is great, and better with every passing hour.It's a sequel to Wasteland, but if you never played the original, it feels like a combination of Fallout and Jagged Alliance.There is  sense of direction, the world follows certain triggers, so it is not as open as Fallout was, but there are a lot of choices and changes based on your actions are visible.You have 4 party members plus 3 recruitable NPCs, so specialization is a must. Learn too many skills on one char, and you will not be good at anything.As per main attributes, builds are often similiar - you NEED inteligence to get skill points and you NEED action points to fire guns. Others you can modify a bit (more luck for crits or str for hp for example?).Customization of characters is pretty decent. I chose the difficulty one above the lowest and it seems pretty solid.At the beginning I never had enough cash, later you swim in it.Overall, the story is fun and gameplay very addictive. You travel the world map, clear all the areas you stumble upon.A thing to note - almost no map areas are wasted, there is always something going on, a quest, an npc, a hidden cache, etc.Highy recommended 9/10 for me :)I like this succesfull kickstarter game way more than Divinity: Original Sin.

content:
2, 2016
												It's strange because I feel drawn into it and I want to play more but there are a bunch of little things that irk me.  A character starts with a rifle, an M1, that should be using 7.62 but it uses 5.56.  Then I find more rifles that use 5.56 but do less damage than a 7.62x51.  No.  Or a Makarov pistol (really nice touch by the way because I own a real one) that uses .38.  No, it uses 9x18.  If it used 9mm I'd let it slide.  The camera sucks but I still want to play more.  Standard fare quests but I want to play more.  However, there are some feel good quests that do make sense for the world we're in.  I like the combat, it's simple but also offers some tactical maneuvers.  Use ambush and draw in the enemy.  Even my melee character can ambush from behind his cover.  Had a couple wipe outs, and a few close calls, I might even up the difficulty.  Friendly fire is a nice feature.Decent variety of character options.  I've got a melee bruiser, a Buddhist Rambo Kung Fu Surgeon, a charismatic lady leader, and a techy bomb thrower.  I enjoyed watching my Buddhist Rambo punch a guy, land a critical, and his entire torso exploded, limbs and head flying off.  Lovely.  Oh and a guy named Richard Stroker....It feels lively, like civilization can be saved.  I like whole Rangers angle, after playing some more I actually felt like my team was making a difference, we were part of something important.  Even saw the A-team which made me smile wide.It's a tad rough around the edges.  Good for a slightly older generation of gamer, there are some very nice tributes I've found so far that a teenager now may not pick up on.  Use some imagination to fill in the gaps and it's good fun.

content:
ry 2
												If you like these kind of game, then yes. Big yes. It has its flaws, but the ending was trully awesome. It felt like i achieved something and i am looking forward to W3. Carry on rangers, carry on...I cant pass this as a comment so i will put it here.: Added after request!True i went short with this, however, if you are interested, i can write more about it. My personal biggest flaw was rushed second sequence of the game. While the different  factions are really nice, it seems to me that there was ment to be much more  and lack of creativity. The known problem of "i will do this for your and then i can use your radio" that goes through the whole game. Another one would be: In the first sequence, you can aim for peace between two sides. Guess what, almost same situation is in the second sequence. Its less obvious, but its there.Game can get a little bit tedious after "some" time of playing, but thats probably my personal feeling. Also, energy weapons, i think they still dont work in the way they intended. When the only energy weapon recomended by ppl to use is a special one you got from kinda hidden and not so obvious "quest" , you know something isnt working.Dont mistake me though, the "final battle" was awesome, but thats becouse it happened in first sequence and i got all the help from ppl i helped in the first sequence. Its the rushed run through the second, specially visiting the base of the main antagonists. I feel like lots of dialogue was cut. Thats why first sequence just feels "richer" then the second. No information what happened to somebody where there obviously COULD have been something, like a note or a body on surgical table and similiar examples.Its good idea to read some guides before starting your first playthrough. Not gameplay guides, but how to make your party. So you know that inteligence is pretty good, but has some defoult spots, so less or more doesnt make a difference. That some skills are more usefull then others and stuff ect. Or you can go blind as i did on my first try, not with director edition though, but still, that was derpy.I guess this would be all, can add some things if you have some questions.

They should have some type of territory or buddy system that if you help them out you actually gain something like they best warrior follows you and not just to drive the story plot. So I’m asking not throw flaver text but give me a reason to care about them and not just mow them down.Side note the lag and other dumb issues will in time be resolved so I wanted to keep these out.The GoodThere is a lot in here first. The voice acting is very good from what I expected to be just text and that is it.The different weapons that the game lets you chose and upgrades so that your play style is your falt if it does not work (wish there were more customizing)How realistic this game is and how you can do things is not just because the game says so but makes sense.The attachment to your squad that if the medic dies or sniper dies its back to square one.The way the game is set up. It slaps you around and treats you like a grown man and not like a 3 year old holding your hand.I can go on but if you like xcom and fallout 2 you will love this game.

content:
1, 2014
Early Access Review
								Many years ago as a young teenager, I beat the first Wasteland game. My copy was on a couple of 5 1/4's, and my drives were single sided, so there was some floppy flipping involved. And there was the paragraph book. But I cherished that game like no other at the time. For me it was in a class of it's own, way more interesting then the bard's tales or m&m's or wizardry's, with a silly sort of dark humor built in. Blowing up the hotdog stand just about made me pee myself laughing. I was very happy to see it lovingly resurrected as a kickstarter project, but didn't find out about it until I saw it on steam, so I missed out on backing it. So I went ahead and grabbed the steam beta copy. After playing the beta copy for a little while, it is very obvious that this is a very well done game with high production value. The voice acting is the best I've heard in a game in a long time. The combat is satisfying and fair. The ui makes sense. Objectives feel worth doing. You would be doing yourself a dis-service if you didn't pick up a copy of this game.
