content:
, 2014
Early Access Review
								The game is quite polished now, although there are still some annoying bugs, but most of them can be fixed by restaring a game. Not how it should work; but oh well..I wanted to dislike this game because it was expensive and my first impressions were not thatt good. Mechanics seemed to be clunky, dialogues were cheesy.Now after 24 hours of gameplay in total, I can say that this game is pure genius. PeriodIt so much reminds me of the good old RPG games. I am always thrilled to see a new area, meet new NPCs, get new quests. What is odd because I met such a game years ago is that it will not spoonfeed you the solution. You will need to figure out how to solve things.Maybe my biggest plus for the game is the map editing. Almost all of the maps are interesting with many hidden things, side areas, various ways to approach a combat. Very intelligently designed.Of course it still needs polishing, my biggest pain is that even if I spent countless hours playing it, probbaly the nexy big patch will reset my progress. Also it would be very good to notifiy in game if an area is not accessibe yet. I spent quite a time trying to find out how to get in the prison then I read that it is not available yet...All in all, it is an awesome game, Brian Fargo is still the god of intelligent and quality RPGs.

content:
y 24, 2015
												Another entry of the "CRPG revival" or whatever. Kickstarter funded old-school RPG games.Wasteland 2 sets out to be a modern take on the old-school style of RPG, and in this it succeeds greatly. Tons of skills, lots of character customization, lots of dialogue options, tons of sidequests, etc. It's well done and overall I had a pretty good time playing it.The combat gets to be a bit same-y near the end of it, but the game was interesting enough to keep me motivated all the way through it. The story was pretty decent, although pretty "par for the course" for post-apocalyptic RPGs. I haven't played the first wasteland, but the story is basically the same (from what I can gather), and it's also very similar the stories from the first few Fallout games. Not to say it's bad, but it really isn't anything special.I did the majority of the side quests I found, and there are a lot of easter eggs and hidden things to find. Definitely a lot of bang for your buck without feeling like you're just checking stuff off a list (I'm looking at you, Dragon Age: Inquisition).If you're looking for a game where you can accidentally set off a trap and kill your entire party within the first 30 minutes of the game, then this game is for you.

content:
2, 2016
												It's strange because I feel drawn into it and I want to play more but there are a bunch of little things that irk me.  A character starts with a rifle, an M1, that should be using 7.62 but it uses 5.56.  Then I find more rifles that use 5.56 but do less damage than a 7.62x51.  No.  Or a Makarov pistol (really nice touch by the way because I own a real one) that uses .38.  No, it uses 9x18.  If it used 9mm I'd let it slide.  The camera sucks but I still want to play more.  Standard fare quests but I want to play more.  However, there are some feel good quests that do make sense for the world we're in.  I like the combat, it's simple but also offers some tactical maneuvers.  Use ambush and draw in the enemy.  Even my melee character can ambush from behind his cover.  Had a couple wipe outs, and a few close calls, I might even up the difficulty.  Friendly fire is a nice feature.Decent variety of character options.  I've got a melee bruiser, a Buddhist Rambo Kung Fu Surgeon, a charismatic lady leader, and a techy bomb thrower.  I enjoyed watching my Buddhist Rambo punch a guy, land a critical, and his entire torso exploded, limbs and head flying off.  Lovely.  Oh and a guy named Richard Stroker....It feels lively, like civilization can be saved.  I like whole Rangers angle, after playing some more I actually felt like my team was making a difference, we were part of something important.  Even saw the A-team which made me smile wide.It's a tad rough around the edges.  Good for a slightly older generation of gamer, there are some very nice tributes I've found so far that a teenager now may not pick up on.  Use some imagination to fill in the gaps and it's good fun.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
er 31, 2014
rating: recommended at sale price (<20€)similar games: Fallout series, Shadowrun Returns, X-Com (to a degree), some Bioware gamestarget audience: fans of RPGs who want meaningful quests and good dialogueWasteland 2 does many things right but also many things wrong. The biggest problem I have with the game is that it is too long. If they cut out a little bit here and there I woudlnt loose motivation to play this, but after 30h, which is a lot, it kinda got dull.Another big problem is that if you want to open a safe for example with safe-cracking and you have 50% chance of opening it, you can just save the game before opening it and then keep loading the save file and try to open it. Of course you can decide not to abuse this, but the game itself could prevent this easily.But I had a good time with Wasteland 2. I didnt finish it, but thats okay. I really like the combat system which seems simple at first but is really enjoyable in my opinion unlike games like Shadowrun Returns. What I like the most is that you dont have just 2 moves for every character but every character has different amount of action points and every action the character can do costs different amount of AP and every weapon has also a different AP cost. This is a very flexible way of balancing the game and it works.I also like the visual feedback when you overkill an enemy he just explodes or his arms go off or something. The graphics of the game are bad though which wouldnt be that big of a problem if it had a distinct art style but its just dull graphics from early 2000s.The quests are really well designed and feel relevant and the characters you meet are also not bad. However I had some bugs here and there which prevented some quests from getting completed, but those bugs might be fixed now.What is a bad design decision in my opinion is perma-death. When one of your characters die, he is dead forever. The thing is having 1 more or 1 less character in your party makes a HUGE difference, so every time one of your characters die you are pretty much screwed and you have to reload a previous save game. Only place this would make sense is when people who can join your party can die, but when one of your primary characters die it should be game over.And I also dont like how you can make people join your party because as I said it makes a very HUGE difference how many people are in your party, so depending on how you skilled your characters and how many people you find or miss the game is either extremely easy or unfair. In my opinion the game should stick to a 4 character limit and balance the game with that in mind and give you a game over when 1 character dies. What they could do is increase the limit at certain parts of the game and offer you an additional party member or so. It isnt balanced well currently though.I mostly talked about the bad stuff in this game but overall its still really good, I recommend it.

content:
3, 2015
												An old-style RPG, almost to a fault. I will say, it very much does feel like the logical extension of the original Wasteland/Fallout, had Fallout not gone the way of Elder Scrolls.There's some nice tactical turn-based combat here, but it's not especially deep. Similarly, the story is certianly inoffensive as far as quality, but it didn't really grab me, either. I got some nice nostalgia jolts from the presence of dialogue trees and inventories, but there's also plenty of clunky interfaces and awkward questlines.This is a game that feels out-of-time. It's not pushing anything forward, but it does play more or less like you'd expect a game from 1998 to play. As such, I think I appreciate it more in idea than in execution. And I'll say this much, if you're looking for an RPG that's long like old RPGs used to be, then buddy you will not be dissappointed.With Steam's binary scale, I think this one is more on the "recommend" side, but I'd throw in the caveat of "fourty dollars is perhaps a bit high." I liked it, but I didn't love it.

content:
ber 21, 2014
												Well now, that is something. I had other work to do and I didn't sleep nothing today.Game is great, and better with every passing hour.It's a sequel to Wasteland, but if you never played the original, it feels like a combination of Fallout and Jagged Alliance.There is  sense of direction, the world follows certain triggers, so it is not as open as Fallout was, but there are a lot of choices and changes based on your actions are visible.You have 4 party members plus 3 recruitable NPCs, so specialization is a must. Learn too many skills on one char, and you will not be good at anything.As per main attributes, builds are often similiar - you NEED inteligence to get skill points and you NEED action points to fire guns. Others you can modify a bit (more luck for crits or str for hp for example?).Customization of characters is pretty decent. I chose the difficulty one above the lowest and it seems pretty solid.At the beginning I never had enough cash, later you swim in it.Overall, the story is fun and gameplay very addictive. You travel the world map, clear all the areas you stumble upon.A thing to note - almost no map areas are wasted, there is always something going on, a quest, an npc, a hidden cache, etc.Highy recommended 9/10 for me :)I like this succesfull kickstarter game way more than Divinity: Original Sin.

content:
r 12, 2014
												You want true Fallout 3? Here it is, no excuses.The buts :1) Combat is rather simplistic, a cover system, ducking, fire mode selection and an ambush option (spend some ap to shoot dudes who come into range next turn, useless imo) might please purists, might annoy if youre used to stuff like JA2 or Silent Storm.2) Simplified Armor system, no more tresholds and jazz. Weapons have a penetration rating (nyuk), resulting damage is normal when the armor rating is same or lower, if its higher damage is reduced.3) Resulting from that is a bizarro design decision where energy weapons do more damage versus a higher armor rating - e.g. a death laser kills you in power armor, but tickles if youre naked. Theres already pages of discussion elsewhere and the devs announced an enemy loadout change in some areas. Its still stupid imo.The bugs :1) Enemy movement AP glitches have dudes stroll ridiculous distances. All thats missing when some guy walks two screens and stops next to your sniper is the Benny Hill music. Announced to get fixed2) The last big hub of the game has an impressive array of intricate, multi-solution quests which are held together by spit and baling wire. Look at them wrong and marvel at duplicate characters, time travel dialogue and other sorts of broken flag funnies. Its almost a metagame in itself not to upset the straining scripting in that part too much. Announced to get fixed - 4/5 of the game are solid, id wager if you pick it up now it should be patched by the time you reach that part.   Heartily recommended despite parts of the endgame being a broken mess (wasnt this early access and ♥♥♥♥?)

content:
r 29, 2014
												Wasteland 2 provides a great RPG experience at a good price. For players of the first Wasteland game, it's a must-buy, and newcomers (particularly those who enjoyed games like Fallout 1&2) will find a lot to love.The character creation system is very nice, and while I fretted over skill and attribute points at first, I found that the game is so huge and there are so many different paths to take that you will find a rewarding, engaging, and different story with each party that you form (and you will likely want to play it through with a different setup at least once).The choices you make can have long lasting impact on gameplay, and for that reason it's one of the few (maybe the only?) that I played through again immediately after finishing.It's funny, entertaining, and well worth the price; to top it off it's a great example of crowdfunding done right.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2015
												Ah. Where to begin. Story: The basis is that you are a squad of rookie 'Desert Rangers', part of a type of law enforcement agency looking after settlements in post-apocalyptic Nevada. On your first assignment you're sent to find out the cause of death of another Ranger named Ace, which ends up laying the basis for the first half or so of the game. Early on, you're told to go save one of two critical settlements that are in distress. How silly is this? A tiny squad of newbie rangers being sent to secure a settlement on their own. On top of this, if you visit the settlement you didn't choose, you'll find it destroyed-as if the Rangers couldn't send another squad to help protect a MAJOR settlement, but the cherry on top is upon returning to the ranger base, you're greeted by a team of 'elite' rangers that seem to have been sitting with their thumbs up their *** instead of doing their job. Halfway through the game, the plot shifts from "protect the people" to "suddenly robots"Story Summary: 4/10Lackluster and mediocre. Gameplay:The game is very heavily RNG based. Funny then that the developer decided to pick an engine notorious for having issues with its RNG. It's kind of a 'no way, haha' moment when you miss a 90% chance shot the first 5 times, but you could imagine this soon gets tiresome. This is a really nasty thing, as the majority of actions rely on RNG. 60% chance to pick a lock? You're gonna fail and break it too.2% chance for your gun to jam? Better believe it'll jam every second turn. 90% chance to break down a little wooden fence? Broken leg. On top of this, enemies have ridiculous movement speed making any and all tactical positioning irrelevant because they'll close the distance in two turns. Oh, and to rub salt in the wound, all enemies but robots move dreadfully slowly, meaning if there's more than 6 enemies, you'll have to wait a good 2 minutes between turns. You'll be traveling across the map a lot, and there's not fast travel option for locations already discovered. This can get very monotonous very fast. Gameplay summary: 3/10RNG is awful, tactics are useless. Graphics:Not bad. Not the best, but decent, Graphics Summary: 7/10Okay.Audio: Not too many voiced lines, but the ones that are voiced are good quality. Not much music to speak of, mainly ambiance. It can get annoying to hear enemies make the same grunts turn after turn. Audio Summary: 6/10Meh.Overall:Though it can be enjoyable when you get exceptionally lucky, the majority of the time you'll be saving before each attempt at lockpicking, and praying to the RNG gods that they don't smite you when you dare to try to kill something. Overall Summary: 5/10Buyer's remorse.

content:
ber 23, 2015
												I really wanted to like is so I forced myself to finish it.Worst part about the game is that you suffer for the decisions you made withen the first 5 minutes of play for the entire game.  You really need a character with a level 10 in every skill to do well in this game yet you are limited on party customization outside the new game screen.  Fallout Tatics and X-Com have a much better system for this where you simply recruit new characters.  Never really cared about any of the playable characters even though I was stuck with them the entire game. Second worst thing is that this is a split map, once you complete map 1 you cannot go back and pick up the pieces that you missed.  This sucks if you are a completionist.  Not only that you loose one of your best party members that you leaned on for roughly half the game.  I almost quit when this happened.If that isn't annoying enough there are some quests are just plain bugged and are not possible to complete.There is some interesting quests and choices that can be done in this game.  But progress in the storyline is very slow, and grinding at some points. Wasteland 2 is a long game, not because of the story but because of the pacing.Fallout 2 has great story pacing, never a dull moment; Fallout Tatics / X-Com has great squad based combat with ambushes staged around every corner; Wasteland 2 just failed to achieve greatness at either. It is just OK.

content:
8, 2016
												While a failure of overambition, and as a result clearly rushed, it is still one of the better isometric RPG's of the past decade.Its biggest failing, and it is one that is common in narrative RPG's which centers on an entire player created party instead of a single character, is that the story simply fails to draw you in.You are just not given a reason to care about your characters as anything other than stat sheets, and as a result the entire world becomes less engaging.The combat is, unfortunately, rather shallow and there is therefore entirely too much of it.Far too many areas are riddled with things to kill, and even the overland map has an abundance of random enemy encounters. There is a good variety of enemies, but when your tactical options are limited to shoot, move or overwatch, that does not matter as much as it should.Various classes do get a few special attacks at later levels, but it is not enough to add any actual depth to the combat. You never find yourself wondering what the best tactical option is beyond what enemy to focus on, or if you should use explosives (aoe).On the positive side, there is a great deal of reactivity in the various quests you uncover and the world is populated by plenty of well written characters. Overall the writing is pretty good, the world is interesting and the art work is excellent.While perhaps not the "real fallout 3" its kickstarter backers where hoping for, it is still a great game and definetly worth a playthrough.

content:
1, 2014
												This game is simply awesome! Fallout 1&2 are my best games ever and it seems it will be the same with Wasteland 2. It has fascinating story line, wonderfull turn based combat with tactical depth and great character system. It's a true cRPG unlike dozens of FPS with RPG elements out there. It's what true Fallout 3 should be. Story and gameplay are logical, it has intuitive interface (but needs some tweaking - it's beta, right?), nice graphics and wonderfull music made by Mark Morgan - remember City of Dead or Radiation Storm from Fallout? Yes, it's the same guy. Can't wait for the final version. EDIT:After playing the final product it seems this game is much worse than Fallout. There are too many bugs and illogical decisions that make this game very frustrating to play. Some of them weren't present in early access and some others I hoped to be fixed. <Sadly, they weren't.> edit: They're already fixed!EDIT2:After playing director's cut version I have to correct my previous edit. This game is AWESOME! Annoying things like too short sniper rifle range and too big walking distance of enemies were fixed. Furthermore, I discovered this game is non linear. And I mean really non linear. There's so many different things that can happen. It really has the Fallout spirit and I know what I'm talking about. I'm close to finish Fallout 2 for 20 time maybe, so it's not nostalgia that influences my opinion. Wasteland 2 is simply wonderful.

								For those who loved games like Fallout, Fallout 2, and Fallout Tactics, You will love this game. So far it is fun, but I do have my gripes about it, one is the interface moving our team around is a little clunky, next would be the character models, these would be fine if it was the early 2002-2004, but with other games to compair it to, these could had been done a lot better they are very well super low poly to the point they look funky. Same with the textures, if we where all playing pc games on say on the first xbox's hardware it would be acceptable but its 2014. I really hope that the art end of this game is not done yet in terms of improvement. But I am guessing its about as good as its going to get visually. The other very limited weight/carry capacity, you do your first set of missions up to the first radio tower,  all of your inventory spots are about full, by the time you make it to the second tower your way overloaded, and a town/vendor to sell to  is far far away... and requires you to go though a radiation field, or go way out of your way around it, if you happen to get into a fight guess what you will pick up more stuff that you really have no room to carry. Hopefully the devs can find a solution to this. Overall great game, but it has many areas of improvement needed, from clunky controls, low polly assets that are almost waving like they are made of water when moving. To the tiny annoyances of inventory and not having a way to offload your loot at more locations besides out front of the ranger station at start of the game.

content:
er 24, 2016
												For a game that is supposed to be focused on tactics, W2's offering are pretty weak when compared to something like X-Com 1 or 2.  It doesn't feel like you are taking advantage of environmental factors, cover, or terrain features very much at all.  Combat degrades into a back and forth "you attack, they attack" while everyone is just standing around.  The RNG elements are also heavily implemented and just total sh*t, in my opinion.  Case in point:  On one of the earlier missions you have to fight these giant mutated rabbits, which apparently are so amazing at dodging, your entire squad will take multiple shots at them and totally whiffing.  I had no chances to grind beforehand and didn't see many options to level up my squad's skills so I was forced to reload over and over, hoping for RNGesus to come save me.  It's not as if they even made an dodge animation, just a "miss".  At least show the damn things dodging for Christ's sake.  I find the other reviews to be overl positive for this game and found myself wanting to turn it off and delete it ASAP.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
r 23, 2016
												Brian Fargo really re-creates the late 90's magic here with the sequal to the original Wasteland. Most will know Brian ran Interplay studios which created and produced the Fallout 1, 2 and Tactics games. Such a shame it was sold...This feels so much like Fallout 1 and 2. The big differences being you are managing a party of up to 6 or 7 characters not just the one. Combat is far more frequent (a little repetitive) but the game has that same post apocolyptic feel with great writing, dark humour, sarcasm and just general wittyness that I remember from Fallout 1 and 2. I feel a little sad that I missed the original Wasteland, I should really get that going somehow and play it too.I have about 19hrs or so in Wasteland 2 and am only up to Dimonta (a place you must visit as a part of several different quests including the main). Now I know a little about what's to come as I've read teasers here and there (without spoiling the story for myself) and because of this I know that this game is huge. Just monstrous really. I think what makes it so big is the fact that there are loads of side quests that really draw the game out and the fact that there is a lot of back tracking sometimes in order to beef up, resupply and then carry on. But regardless of this I find it a treat finding all sorts of new weapons and modifying them to get that awesome assualt rifle bypassing armour by 10-15% with a few mods. I also love all the 80's and 90's pop culture references in there such as Cabbage Patch dolls, MAD magazines, D20 dice, trolls and many more. Those little items you stumble accross gives you a strong sense of nostalgia especially so if you grew up in those periods. I think there a real treat. I won't even go into the "toy snake" you find ha ha.The Director's Cut is definitely where it's at. Heaps more recorded dialog and just general performance increases and polish. I wouldn't bother playing the original Wasteland 2 and I don't think you can anymore? The game is also fairly stable with one wierd CTD (nothing in my event logs either) out of that 20 hours. It runs well and for the most part looks ok. I feel like some areas are a little bland and could have used a going over but aside from that the world looks good.Some areas feel a little empty. I know it's post apocolyptic but some more NPC's to engage with would be nice. The writing really shines when you do talk to those few NPC's that can talk. Overall the main quest story hasn't kicked in a whole lot just yet so I can't comment on it.Anyways it's not a perfect game and this is proven in the repetitive combat. There is some advantage to finding cover and ensuring your perks and skills line up to how you want your characters to operate but it's always the same. Battle starts and you find cover and then off you go until the enemy is dead. The AI enemies are good at taking cover and trying to flank but once you've seen it a few times I think you can say you've seen it all. I've heard that there are boss fights but I am yet to reach one so I can't comment on that either.Despite these flaws, the game isn't too bad. Give it a try if you love Brian Fargo, Interplay and the original Wasteland and Fallout series. I think you'd like it. I give it a 8 out of 10 overall.TLDR: Good writing, a little empty with repetitive combat but reeks of pop cultural references from the 80's and 90's that will have you thinking back to those times. Overall not a bad game but not perfect either.

content:
ry 10, 2015
												The game play is fun, characters are well written and the quests are a nice change from the standard fetch, kill or escort.  I had fun playing until I got to Hollywood and the game turned out to be a load of bugs held together with spider's web.While the game engine itself is fine if a bit click-heavy, there are some serious, game-breaking bugs in the quests; you have to use a walkthrough if you hope to complete the game.  The problem stems from quest triggers not firing unless some very specific events take place in the right order: visiting one location before another, talking to NPCs in the wrong order, finding an item before being given the quest to fetch it, these will all break the quest line.  Most quests seem to work or you can reload a save from within the last half hour to remedy the hang up, so all goes well for a time.Unfortunately when you get to Hollywood it all goes down the poo chute.  This is part of the main quest line, you can't just give up and move on when it all goes wrong, which it will.  You either have to keep a huge archive or saves or use a walkthrough if you hope to get through the minefield of broken quest triggers.  I did neither, now I have to start over after 70 hours.  There is also no indication that you're doing it wrong, you have to go exploring to find the quests points and it's so easy to explore just a bit farther than you were meant to.Some parts of the game seem to serve no purpose - water for example.  In Arizona you use up water when you travel.  Ok, nice gimmick to make us choose where to go, how far to roam etc.  But oases are far too common, you will never be in any danger of running low on water.  It's not used at all in LA but you still have it weighing your party down.  There's also no way to drop unwanted/broken quest items, you can only store them in a box at the base.The main thing I didn't like is the constant save-reload of every action multiple times: the chance to pass a skill test shows little correlation with the pass/fail rate - I can fail regularly fail 60% and above chance to succeed, miltiple times in a row, but also regularly succeed in a 10% chance first time.  I get really fed up of repeating this stuff over and over.  It reminds me of the 30 minutes I spent playing Fallout 1 and being unable to kill the very first enemy.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 16, 2015
												This is a good game in a lot of ways. It captures the turn based and RPG elements well. Its flaws are many and deep ,though. The characters and dialog tree are fine, but having 3 different skills to effect dialog is excessive and takes away from the game. Hard ♥♥♥ seems most valuable. The graphics are not anywhere near modern. If you want to see a good turn based game well implemented, check out any of the new XCom titles. They are turn and squad based but look good too. I guess at the end of the day, I think the developers got lazy and cut corners. Portrait Icons, for example, are recycled throughout the game. So the portrait of the guy you were helping in one town is now the portrait of a guy you are fighting, or even a whole gang. Worse, the portraits often have nothing to do at all with the character. Even seemingly main characters have generic or even mismatched portraits. In a game with a limited graphic demand and limited eye candy appeal, those portraits are important to telling the story. InExile just mailed it in on that and many other things after cashing a huge Kickstarter check, and that really lessens the game. Voice acting is limited and really bad compared to any other title I have played in a while. The voices of Matthias and General Vargas, in particular, are horrible. For its current list price of $40, it is not at all what I expected. Expect to be disappointed in a lot of ways, and frustrated a lot of the time in an otherwise fun game.

content:
15, 2015
												XCOM was a big favourite for me, so I was looking for similar turn-based tactical games. Wasteland 2 was a disappointment for me, mainly because the combat is very boring to several reasons: - map is not properly designed for the combat, not enough cover (or something which looks like a cover turns out not to be a cover once the game turns into turn-based) in many cases simple open area - enemies have terrible AI, they just keep running towards you, until they are in firing range, then they start shooting someone randomly - melee is useless, most efficient is assault/sniper - no way to properly prepare for a battle, you cannot position your soldiers, because you don't know what is cover, and how the grid layout looks like (that only becomes visible when the game switches to turn-based)So after a while I realized that the most efficient is to use only weapons with long range (sniper/assault/heavy), and being defensive, just wait until they come close enough, and shoot them. Many of the combats was just going into position with the group, crouch everyone, shoot something with the sniper to initiate the battle, then keep shooting the closest enemy with everyone, without moving at all. No tactics, boring like hell. I was really trying to be more offensive, but it doesn't work.Story is OK, but the character progress is boring, you pick a few skills for each character at the beginning, and then just put skill points on those as the character levels up. Lots of the skills are just to open boxes for loot. Graphic could also be better.I played most of the time in offline more, so I played way more than just 0.3 hours.

content:
13, 2015
												After finishing Wasteland 2, I decided to write a review.   If you LOVED Fallout 2, you'll SORTA LIKE Wasteland 2!  If you've never PLAYED fallout 2 and are interested in Wasteland 2, instead; go buy or at least look at Fallout 2, right here on Steam. This game kept me entertained for a solid 60 hours.... and then Hollywood... The buggiest land to exist in all video games, ever.  For the most part, the game is a load of fun (just not Hollywood). Great detail, good pathing on almost all maps and the AI is fairly balanced, if not a little clunky at times....   Wasteland 2's dialogue is sometimes some of the funniest stuff I've read in a long time. The random things NPC's say, etc. The storyline is serious and there's no slapstick comedy or anything like that, no poop jok---- well... okay, there are poop jokes but 95% of the game is serious and VERY well written.  The camera, however, is downright awful and the towns interior maps are hard to keep track of without map markers.  It feels rushed. Like this was supposed to be something much longer and bigger.  They call it the spiritual successor to Fallout 2, yet my one playthrough of FO2 on steam yielded around 140 hours ish. This, only 75.  My number one complaint is the ending credits (what happened to the world after you saved it slideshow)  Even if you complete almost every task in the game, you won't get credit in most cases. The game will go against what you actually did; for example: I made a certain mercenary group become extinct, took over their prison and helped a town they were terrorizing. At end credits, the game had said that the gang I killed were stronger than ever and had never given up that town. -- 4/10 --The hours I've put into it make it worth the cost. If you don't have Fallout 2; go buy fallout 2 instead.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 10, 2015
												The game play is fun, characters are well written and the quests are a nice change from the standard fetch, kill or escort.  I had fun playing until I got to Hollywood and the game turned out to be a load of bugs held together with spider's web.While the game engine itself is fine if a bit click-heavy, there are some serious, game-breaking bugs in the quests; you have to use a walkthrough if you hope to complete the game.  The problem stems from quest triggers not firing unless some very specific events take place in the right order: visiting one location before another, talking to NPCs in the wrong order, finding an item before being given the quest to fetch it, these will all break the quest line.  Most quests seem to work or you can reload a save from within the last half hour to remedy the hang up, so all goes well for a time.Unfortunately when you get to Hollywood it all goes down the poo chute.  This is part of the main quest line, you can't just give up and move on when it all goes wrong, which it will.  You either have to keep a huge archive or saves or use a walkthrough if you hope to get through the minefield of broken quest triggers.  I did neither, now I have to start over after 70 hours.  There is also no indication that you're doing it wrong, you have to go exploring to find the quests points and it's so easy to explore just a bit farther than you were meant to.Some parts of the game seem to serve no purpose - water for example.  In Arizona you use up water when you travel.  Ok, nice gimmick to make us choose where to go, how far to roam etc.  But oases are far too common, you will never be in any danger of running low on water.  It's not used at all in LA but you still have it weighing your party down.  There's also no way to drop unwanted/broken quest items, you can only store them in a box at the base.The main thing I didn't like is the constant save-reload of every action multiple times: the chance to pass a skill test shows little correlation with the pass/fail rate - I can fail regularly fail 60% and above chance to succeed, miltiple times in a row, but also regularly succeed in a 10% chance first time.  I get really fed up of repeating this stuff over and over.  It reminds me of the 30 minutes I spent playing Fallout 1 and being unable to kill the very first enemy.

content:
ry 16, 2015
												This is a good game in a lot of ways. It captures the turn based and RPG elements well. Its flaws are many and deep ,though. The characters and dialog tree are fine, but having 3 different skills to effect dialog is excessive and takes away from the game. Hard ♥♥♥ seems most valuable. The graphics are not anywhere near modern. If you want to see a good turn based game well implemented, check out any of the new XCom titles. They are turn and squad based but look good too. I guess at the end of the day, I think the developers got lazy and cut corners. Portrait Icons, for example, are recycled throughout the game. So the portrait of the guy you were helping in one town is now the portrait of a guy you are fighting, or even a whole gang. Worse, the portraits often have nothing to do at all with the character. Even seemingly main characters have generic or even mismatched portraits. In a game with a limited graphic demand and limited eye candy appeal, those portraits are important to telling the story. InExile just mailed it in on that and many other things after cashing a huge Kickstarter check, and that really lessens the game. Voice acting is limited and really bad compared to any other title I have played in a while. The voices of Matthias and General Vargas, in particular, are horrible. For its current list price of $40, it is not at all what I expected. Expect to be disappointed in a lot of ways, and frustrated a lot of the time in an otherwise fun game.

content:
15, 2015
												XCOM was a big favourite for me, so I was looking for similar turn-based tactical games. Wasteland 2 was a disappointment for me, mainly because the combat is very boring to several reasons: - map is not properly designed for the combat, not enough cover (or something which looks like a cover turns out not to be a cover once the game turns into turn-based) in many cases simple open area - enemies have terrible AI, they just keep running towards you, until they are in firing range, then they start shooting someone randomly - melee is useless, most efficient is assault/sniper - no way to properly prepare for a battle, you cannot position your soldiers, because you don't know what is cover, and how the grid layout looks like (that only becomes visible when the game switches to turn-based)So after a while I realized that the most efficient is to use only weapons with long range (sniper/assault/heavy), and being defensive, just wait until they come close enough, and shoot them. Many of the combats was just going into position with the group, crouch everyone, shoot something with the sniper to initiate the battle, then keep shooting the closest enemy with everyone, without moving at all. No tactics, boring like hell. I was really trying to be more offensive, but it doesn't work.Story is OK, but the character progress is boring, you pick a few skills for each character at the beginning, and then just put skill points on those as the character levels up. Lots of the skills are just to open boxes for loot. Graphic could also be better.I played most of the time in offline more, so I played way more than just 0.3 hours.

content:
ry 15, 2015
												After 50+ hours into the game, it started feeling like doing homework. 69 hours in, I had a blinding flash of the obvious: I was not required to continue playing. How liberating!It had its points. The combat mechanics were kind of fun. The post-nuclear America setting is always a good time. Some of the subplots were clever. The weapon-smithing was very satisfying.But the downsides were inescapable:* Some of your NPCs are fun, but your main characters are pretty much ciphers. Not very engaging.* The skill system is an annoyance. It is less about making interesting tradeoffs than making sure that you have someone maxed out in each of the 4 different "opening things" skills. It is less about looking forward the neat things that you get to do when you go up a level, than that you get to keep pace with the boxes that are inexplicably getting harder to open.* OMG, running back and forth across the map all the time. When I have to have a book sitting next to my computer to occupy myself during your game, there is a problem.* The characters and key items don't stand out well. You're constantly hitting the "highlight all" button, spinning around and trying to see if there is some bit of scenery that you're supposed to be interacting with.* It has an encumbrance mechanic. And if that wasn't enough: for many items it won't be clear when you'll find someone who needs it. So you have the choice of carrying it around all the time, or stowing it, finding the person who needs it, running across the g-- d--- map. Again.If you want an isometric tactical game, play the new xcom. If you want that + engaging plot, grab Shadowrun Dragonfall.

content:
r 18, 2014
												This is definitely an old style game, meant mostly for people who loved the first Wasteland, the first two Fallout games, and  generally people that played computer videogames in the 90s. It does seem to try and trade off aesthetic quality for some kind of nostalgia feeling that in a way condones how the game looks and moves on the screen, and how some aspects not only seem rough and unpolished but even not finished.Those that think they're gonna buy an RPG with this game might be let down to find out that this game feels and plays more like a Desperados game than an actual RPG, except the tactical aspect is shallow waters, and moves like crouch and headshot are practically never used: you end up doing a little more than spamming attack on the enemies. There are stats(which, oddly enough, do not affect your skills, so how much charisma you have counts nothing on how good a barter you are or how well you can persuade, and so on), dialogues and choices but the game ends up boiling down to a turn-based shooter, where non combat skills and attributes don't count as much as how many points you have put in your shooting skills.Too many times i felt that a certain situation should have hadthe possibility of being dealt with with wits and a good dialogue, since dialogue based skills are there for the characters, and not just circumstantial fights. You can SOME times select a Hard ♥♥♥/Kiss ♥♥♥/Smart ♥♥♥ answer that will gain you some advantage, but it simply isn't worth spending skill points on three separate things you will be using so rarely along the game. It often feels like those alternative options were not YET implemented, because of time and resources, and not just not meant to be there at all, but that is just a feeling. Which makes some situations kinda awkward to play.. It also needs to be stated that the game needs 21GB of free space on the hard disk, and patches come at sizes of more than 1 GB, which is kinda hard to explain for a game of this nature, since there aren't many cinematics at all and a lot of the dialogues are text-only.In the end, though, the game is ok and even fun to play, especially for those that are feeling nostalgic. It just seems to rely on the nostalgia a bit too relentlessly.

content:
r 27, 2014
												I'm a huge fallout fan, so this game was highly anticipated for me. I tried playing the classic fallout games a few times, but unfortunately their age made the games far too slow and painful to progress through despite their amazing visual style and overall presentation. I picked up Wasteland 2 to fill that experience I always wanted, but unfortunately it just couldn't do it. Overall, the game is very unpolished, and just doesn't have the fit and finish I would expect from a game that's been in development for nearly three years. Incoming gripe-fest: I can't say too much on the story or progression yet, as I'm not too far into it, but I feel like the game keeps you in areas far longer than you should be in. The Ag center quest took me nearly SIX hours in total, and I don't feel like much was accomplished in that time. The quest system is fairly ambiguous as there are no map markers or anything to even send you in the general direction of a task. I've had bugs make me reload a save from nearly hours earlier just for it to happen again(pathfinding is wonky). The lack of lore is another thing that pains me. The game doesn't go too far into what's going on in the world other than forcing DESERT RANGERS! down your throat for the first hour. Scavenging is weird: there are SO MANY obvious loot crates just sitting around for no apparent reason other than to give you ammo- there is so much ammo that it is never a problem in the slightest. And on the off chance you actually find a hidden safe, for the most part it is RNG, so it is likely you will just find .38 ammo over and over again.The game does have its merits though despite being quite janky. There is a LOT to do, and for content-per-dollar, I'd say you get a lot out of it. So if you're looking for a game where there is tons to do and you can play it for hours on end, this is a good choice. However, if you're like me and enjoy games with a higher quality standard, you should steer clear-at least until the game is well patched. The game is definitely a fallout fan's paradise in concept, but it just can't live up to it for so many reasons. I could rant all day, but in the end the only thing that matters is: How big of a Fallout fan are you?

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
r 31, 2014
												I was looking forward to this game and I waited until it was released.  I feel sorry for the people that paid 59.95 for something that was then released for 39.95.  I am wondering what on Earth they used all that money for?  It is not the graphics as they are mundane at best even at the highest settings.  The graphic design is amateurish.  Although there are many games that are graphically impressive and the play value is less than satisfying.  Unfortunately this game fails at that as well.  One aspect of the game is it’s supposed to adhere to some kind of reality.  Such as a rifleman being unable to shoot well, if a target is pressing them with a melee weapon or the weapons being old and prone to jams in the middle of combat.  Now one aspect of reality is a human being can see in a 180 degree arc barring any physical problems.  Yet in this game the player has to constantly twist and turn, pan, zoom in an out and mouse over everything in sight so as not to miss anything that is obviously needed to complete the mission goal.  Another sore point for me is the random encounters that occur when traveling on the world map.  Every encounter is on the same one of three possible areas.  Every encounter drops the player at one seemingly random entry point.  The player might reach the enemy in two turns, but the enemy can cross the entire screen and still be able to attack multiple times.   Assuming the player survives, they loot and then get to pan all over the screen looking for the exit point.  There is nothing else in a random encounter aside from the NPCs to be killed.  No random loot, no hidden chests, nothing at all.  So why the busy work to locate and then run to an exit?   And the exit is a Globe of some kind on pedestal.   Forget the boring senseless random encounters, look at the exit point.  Is that Immersion into a game world or what?A word to anyone buying this game if you have small children in the house when you play.  Play with the sound off or use headphones.  I am not prude by any sense of your imagination but this game spews profanity like a drunken sailor on leave at a bordello on the docks.As to difficulty, I can’t put my finger on the problem but boredom comes to mind as well as the old line seen in old adventure games "you can't do that now"  It doesn't actually say that, but that is the feeling the player gets when you examine a trap and it says 98% chance of success and 5% chance of critical fail and your explosives expert fails 3 times in a row and then it blows up in his face.   Now the % to fail or succeed is the game comparing the traps level to the team member’s skill level.Now, like all games all new teams start out at level 1 and as you gain experience you gain levels.  All standard fair, right?  So how come the first NPC team member you can add to your group is a level 15?

content:
er 3, 2014
												Video games critic “Yahtzee” once remarked that he didn’t understand single-player RPGs. What is the appeal? With their emphasis on story over gameplay, why not just read a (good) book? Why interrupt the (maybe good) story with some of gaming’s weakest gameplay? Since then he’s likely discovered that there ARE good RPGs, and that good RPGs don’t emphasize story over gameplay; rather they emphasis both. In fact, the only key difference between an “RPG” and, say, a shooter like Half-Life is that in an “RPG” the development of your avatars’ virtual skill is emphasized (via leveling up, getting more powerful items, etc.) over your muscle memory skills.And here we have Wasteland 2, and like most old- AND new-school RPGs, it manages to emphasize neither gameplay nor story.You may at first find this hard to notice if isometric (“old-school”) RPGs are new to you. Even I was smitten. So turned on was I that, a dozen hours into the game, I donated $30 to InExile’s Torment project (OOPS!), to be followed an hour later by Wasteland 2’s depressing emptiness finally crashing down on me (♥♥♥♥!!!). Its gameplay proved to be just drudgery. To get a picture of it, imagine XCOM, but not anywhere as good, and with the saving angel of “reloading the last save” always being available? Now consider that to play without the reload function would render the game impossible to win within a lifetime, OR SO easy (because you can change the difficulty at any time) that there’s hardly any drama at all. Now add to this an inventory system that demands so much of your “play” time (a time-destroying chore similar in fun to data entry, except you don’t get paid). Then throw in the various versions of locked doors and chests and whatnot that all have their own skill trees. I want to underscore the fact that this last feature is neither fun nor intellectually stimulating, and that you need to do it to win the game. If, InExile, you are going to make your players spend a lot of time deciding where to invest their skill points, then at least make the payoff’s worth it. Make it so there are AWESOME rewards for opening stuff—a cool joke, a sexy weapon or armor set that you won’t find from enemies or shops—not just , soon-to-be-forgotten items. [There are also bugs, which, to their credit, they’re continuing to address.]Now for some almost good news. The writing is almost good. Because of the setting—a nuked one—they, like Bethesda, have gone the mostly-serious tone route. There are moments of cruelty in the game that invoke the horrors of real, demonic human beings, atrocities that happen in, say, Syria and the Congo. And sometimes it’s effective. For example, there’s a scene where a character died a horrible death, and as he or she lay dying, he or she told my party to deliver something to another character in some town. Well, I went to this town and got distracted. And many hours later, across the Arizona map away from the town, I thought, “Oh ♥♥♥♥! I forgot to deliver that object!” And I trudged across the game world back towards that town, knowing that it would put me in boring battles with weaker enemies. That is a moment of video game art that taught me something about myself.Moments like these are rare in the game, and the writing is mostly grim for no other reason than to remind players that nuclear holocausts are bad. As for strong characters; I think the leader of the Desert Rangers is named General Vargas. There’s also the Matthias guy. Aaaaand those are all the names I remember from my 50+ hours of playing.As for the plot, it’s an uninspired, boring cliché. To give you an idea of how zero it is, consider this. During the first half of the game, in the Ranger HQ, there’s this nuclear weapon in a museum. And when you press the wrong button, the place explodes and you get a Game Over screen that says, due to there being no Desert Rangers, Matthias and his Robot Army conquer the human race. In other words, InExile do not care about their own story enough to make a truly mysterious (or at least funny) enemy; this of course explains why the plot twists are so pathetically predictable that they basically don’t exist.The NPCs talk a lot of “who is this Matthias person” emptiness, to which I respond, “OH C’MON, HE’S OBVIOUSLY A BORING ROBOT HITLER!”[Robot Hitler, by the way, would be a more compelling, entertaining villain than Matthias.]So if the intellectual bits are rare, and the characters are boring, and the plot is boring, then is it funny?Nope. There’s at least one homage to a famous comedy. But basically that’s it. Visually they could have done many funny things—this is a 3D computer game, after all—but basically we got nothing. What missed opportunities…..To underscore how much these devs missed the mark, consider this: early in the game there’s a place you can opt to rescue from a giant flora infestation. What the developers could have done with this was pit your Rangers against, say, killer salads, aided by giant, banana-toting bananas. But what did InExile do? ZOMBIES! They made it so the plants infected the local fauna, turning them into zombies. Jesus Cliché Christ.As for the graphics in general, it’s black, brown, green and grey. There’s some red for blood. I do like the bullets flying and the body parts falling, especially when said body parts fall because someone hit the person with a blunt object. I also like some of the lasers. And the large robots look cool. Mostly I like the fact that you can dress your group like the Three Amigos. That was fun for twelve seconds.The game also features sound.SCORE: 3/10Back of the Box Statement: “Is there too much happiness in your life?”

												EDITED:Now that i finished it, i can say for sure that its awarded the Best game i played the year 2014.*Stands still and salutes near Ranger Citadel*Shadows on a scorched horizonLike a wall we standArizona roarin', risin'From the scalded sandThe cries of a dead worldCallin' out in painRed skies on the desertAre the blood in a ranger's veins Old review:I just couldn't help myself with waiting to finish the game to write my review on it. Its sooo good that i just HAD to let everyone know that you sir/ma'am have to try it out.  Its (imo) a new kind of RPG. So f you're like me and don't wanna buy similar games you just found treasure here.  It has much depth (character creation alone took 2 hours to do it properly), combines Xcom style of battle but in an open world and not simply stages, many rpg elements and customization, many weapons, proffesions, stats, nice difficulty settings (for casual and masochists players). The storyline is very strong in here, it is the type of game that you can easily spend hours a day to play it because it just has things to do, and your goals are clear and logical. I found myself spending the whole day (12h) playing it non stop and i usually don't do that with any game.  I hate games where you got to play the game the whole day to get it done. But here..i beg the game to let me keep playing some more hours each day. 10/10 almost broke up with my girlfriend b0ss

content:
ber 23, 2015
												I really wanted to like is so I forced myself to finish it.Worst part about the game is that you suffer for the decisions you made withen the first 5 minutes of play for the entire game.  You really need a character with a level 10 in every skill to do well in this game yet you are limited on party customization outside the new game screen.  Fallout Tatics and X-Com have a much better system for this where you simply recruit new characters.  Never really cared about any of the playable characters even though I was stuck with them the entire game. Second worst thing is that this is a split map, once you complete map 1 you cannot go back and pick up the pieces that you missed.  This sucks if you are a completionist.  Not only that you loose one of your best party members that you leaned on for roughly half the game.  I almost quit when this happened.If that isn't annoying enough there are some quests are just plain bugged and are not possible to complete.There is some interesting quests and choices that can be done in this game.  But progress in the storyline is very slow, and grinding at some points. Wasteland 2 is a long game, not because of the story but because of the pacing.Fallout 2 has great story pacing, never a dull moment; Fallout Tatics / X-Com has great squad based combat with ambushes staged around every corner; Wasteland 2 just failed to achieve greatness at either. It is just OK.

content:
er 3, 2014
												Video games critic “Yahtzee” once remarked that he didn’t understand single-player RPGs. What is the appeal? With their emphasis on story over gameplay, why not just read a (good) book? Why interrupt the (maybe good) story with some of gaming’s weakest gameplay? Since then he’s likely discovered that there ARE good RPGs, and that good RPGs don’t emphasize story over gameplay; rather they emphasis both. In fact, the only key difference between an “RPG” and, say, a shooter like Half-Life is that in an “RPG” the development of your avatars’ virtual skill is emphasized (via leveling up, getting more powerful items, etc.) over your muscle memory skills.And here we have Wasteland 2, and like most old- AND new-school RPGs, it manages to emphasize neither gameplay nor story.You may at first find this hard to notice if isometric (“old-school”) RPGs are new to you. Even I was smitten. So turned on was I that, a dozen hours into the game, I donated $30 to InExile’s Torment project (OOPS!), to be followed an hour later by Wasteland 2’s depressing emptiness finally crashing down on me (♥♥♥♥!!!). Its gameplay proved to be just drudgery. To get a picture of it, imagine XCOM, but not anywhere as good, and with the saving angel of “reloading the last save” always being available? Now consider that to play without the reload function would render the game impossible to win within a lifetime, OR SO easy (because you can change the difficulty at any time) that there’s hardly any drama at all. Now add to this an inventory system that demands so much of your “play” time (a time-destroying chore similar in fun to data entry, except you don’t get paid). Then throw in the various versions of locked doors and chests and whatnot that all have their own skill trees. I want to underscore the fact that this last feature is neither fun nor intellectually stimulating, and that you need to do it to win the game. If, InExile, you are going to make your players spend a lot of time deciding where to invest their skill points, then at least make the payoff’s worth it. Make it so there are AWESOME rewards for opening stuff—a cool joke, a sexy weapon or armor set that you won’t find from enemies or shops—not just , soon-to-be-forgotten items. [There are also bugs, which, to their credit, they’re continuing to address.]Now for some almost good news. The writing is almost good. Because of the setting—a nuked one—they, like Bethesda, have gone the mostly-serious tone route. There are moments of cruelty in the game that invoke the horrors of real, demonic human beings, atrocities that happen in, say, Syria and the Congo. And sometimes it’s effective. For example, there’s a scene where a character died a horrible death, and as he or she lay dying, he or she told my party to deliver something to another character in some town. Well, I went to this town and got distracted. And many hours later, across the Arizona map away from the town, I thought, “Oh ♥♥♥♥! I forgot to deliver that object!” And I trudged across the game world back towards that town, knowing that it would put me in boring battles with weaker enemies. That is a moment of video game art that taught me something about myself.Moments like these are rare in the game, and the writing is mostly grim for no other reason than to remind players that nuclear holocausts are bad. As for strong characters; I think the leader of the Desert Rangers is named General Vargas. There’s also the Matthias guy. Aaaaand those are all the names I remember from my 50+ hours of playing.As for the plot, it’s an uninspired, boring cliché. To give you an idea of how zero it is, consider this. During the first half of the game, in the Ranger HQ, there’s this nuclear weapon in a museum. And when you press the wrong button, the place explodes and you get a Game Over screen that says, due to there being no Desert Rangers, Matthias and his Robot Army conquer the human race. In other words, InExile do not care about their own story enough to make a truly mysterious (or at least funny) enemy; this of course explains why the plot twists are so pathetically predictable that they basically don’t exist.The NPCs talk a lot of “who is this Matthias person” emptiness, to which I respond, “OH C’MON, HE’S OBVIOUSLY A BORING ROBOT HITLER!”[Robot Hitler, by the way, would be a more compelling, entertaining villain than Matthias.]So if the intellectual bits are rare, and the characters are boring, and the plot is boring, then is it funny?Nope. There’s at least one homage to a famous comedy. But basically that’s it. Visually they could have done many funny things—this is a 3D computer game, after all—but basically we got nothing. What missed opportunities…..To underscore how much these devs missed the mark, consider this: early in the game there’s a place you can opt to rescue from a giant flora infestation. What the developers could have done with this was pit your Rangers against, say, killer salads, aided by giant, banana-toting bananas. But what did InExile do? ZOMBIES! They made it so the plants infected the local fauna, turning them into zombies. Jesus Cliché Christ.As for the graphics in general, it’s black, brown, green and grey. There’s some red for blood. I do like the bullets flying and the body parts falling, especially when said body parts fall because someone hit the person with a blunt object. I also like some of the lasers. And the large robots look cool. Mostly I like the fact that you can dress your group like the Three Amigos. That was fun for twelve seconds.The game also features sound.SCORE: 3/10Back of the Box Statement: “Is there too much happiness in your life?”

content:
ry 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								OK...now this is the game. This is the successor to the grand father of cRPGs, the spiritual father of FALLOUT...This is Wasteland 2!The game is still in beta (or early access, what ever you want to call it). It is also still suffering from optimization issues, bugs, and clunky game design.HOWEVER, these things do not hinder the game. In its state, is is solid, and plays very well. It feels like a true port-apocalyptic game, and it can definitely stand up to FALLOUT of STALKER. The story telling is wonderful, combat works and feels great, the atmosphere is just perfect, there is a bit of humor and secrets, many new and unfamiliar enemies, andTONS of customization. You can tactically set up your team and develop them as they level up, or you can build your own character from the ground up. It is just overall a well done project.It is still being developed, and new updates will be coming out for it. The UI will be fixed, it will be optimized, much more will be added...and in the end, this wonderful, promising stone will be polished to be one of the greatest cRPGs done.I know, the price tag is a little steep. But, if you are willing to buy it, and if you are willing to put up with a (currently) incomplete game, and if you are going to commit yourself to giving back to the devs, then it will be a worthwhile purchase. Additionally, this is a great game if you loved FALLOUT (esp. the first 2 and tactics) and Wasteland. Should you buy it? It depends, you might not want to, and you are certainly not being forced to. But if you do, know you are contributing to a constantly developing and promising sequel to a beloved game.

Early Access Review
								Lost it's appeal. I worked out what it was: There are too many systems. Too many skills and stuff that I can't be bothered with.From the activatable perception skill, "Positional play" AI that can see for miles and only knows one tactic, garbage friendly fire, too many gun types (7) and an exclusive skill system - a guy who can pick the eye out of a raider at 25m can't hit a mutant maggot 2m away with a shotgun. Repairing a "toaster" isn't the same as repairing another type of toaster. I was brought up on the Bards Tale series, Dragon Wars, Wasteland and Fallout. You can tell instantly that this has the same level of completeness and polish, but as good as that is, amazing amount of detail as it has, it still left me cold. Perhaps wandering round Skara Brae all those years ago with my imagination, squared paper and pencils left me expecting something different. "Burger".

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
13, 2014
Early Access Review
								Finally broke 100 hours with this gem.  This game is EXACTLY what was promised, and delivers where it counts.  Fans of the original game and the post-apocalyptic genre should eat this right up.  There's at LEAST 25 hours of content in the Arizona portion of the game.  With that being the halfway point we're looking at a 50+ hour game which is more than most games today will give you for the pricetag.  There were no corners cut or shortcuts taken and it's very evident in the late beta.  The game is highly polished and the bugs are (almost) gone!  The expectations are very high for release (Sept 19th?) and I fully believe InXile won't disappoint.  Synopsis:  You are a freshly recruited Desert Ranger in the post-nuclear wastes of Arizona, USA.  Welcomed and rushed straight off to investigate a prominent ranger's death and complete his critical mission, the game wastes no time showing you the harsh and dangerous environment that is the Wasteland.  Through use of skills, combat, dialogue, and cunning, you will forge a unique path through the wasteland and write your own story as a member of the Desert Rangers.  Of course there's mutated plants and animals, killer robots, raiders, cannibals, thugs, and radiation clouds to keep you company along the way.  The Game:  Unlike most games that ease you in with kiddy missions and tutorials, this game slaps you in the face.  ADAPT OR DIE is the theme for the first few run-ins with the bad men and creatures of the wastes.  If you're unlucky enough not to recruit a special friend before setting out, you'll be lucky to survive to the first real location without a ridiculous number of reloads.  On my first playthrough I was losing team members in the first 10 minutes.  Then I realized the coolest thing about this game:  You have to actually THINK.  About Everything.  The combat is highly tactical, and the choices have real consequences.  There's actually no way to do everything in one playthrough.  With each location you visit you'll make decisions that affect the rest of your game.  And the consequences don't show up until later, making your choices semi-permanent (you REALLY don't want to reload and replay the last 1.5 HOURS to fix that dialogue choice).  This is one of the most immersive top down TBC RPG games I've ever played.  It is very much a spiritual ancestor of the Fallout series, but the playability is very much with the times.  You can also have a party of up to 7 members, which is much more than other games have allowed, but furthermore in my playthrough of just the Arizona area, I encountered 6 recruitable NPCs and I know for a fact I missed at least 1 due to a choice I made.  So there's probably upwards of 12-15 characters you can add to your party throughout the game, which is a  TON!  And there's so many ways to do everything!  Locked door?  Pick it, bust it down, or find the key.  Broken robot? Fix it mechanically or hack the cpu.  There's a real sense of reality applying in this world.  If it makes sense, you can probably do it.  I must commend the developers for that specifically, as it's frankly an amazing thing to see in a game.  Also, in many situations you can avoid combat alltogether, or you can choose a side and manipulate the outcome, so there's just as much variation to the game strategy as there is to the skill use.  It feels very complete in the way of forging your own path.  Combat:  The combat in this game is a bit more complicated than your typical tactical turn based game.  Aside from the usual Action Points system for movement/weapon use, you also have to deal with weapon jams, your NPCs going rogue and doing whatever they want for their turn, and rampant friendly fire if you don't watch your angles.  The only way to avoid this (and you can't ever avoid it entirely) is to invest survival points into your weapons and leadership skills to minimize the chance of jams/rogue turns.  Some may find this a frustrating addition to combat, but I find it adds a great depth and believability to it.  To compare the combat to something, I'd say it's similar to XCOM but with more of a Fallout RPG focus, so it's not nearly as hard once you get the hang of it.  Overall this game is what Post-Apocalyptic gamers have been waiting for since Fallout 2.  If you enjoy turn based games and love the genre, it's bound to become one of your favorite titles for any number of reasons.  The story is huge, the choices are real, the combat is deadly.  Do you have what it takes to be a Desert Ranger?

content:
ry 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								OK...now this is the game. This is the successor to the grand father of cRPGs, the spiritual father of FALLOUT...This is Wasteland 2!The game is still in beta (or early access, what ever you want to call it). It is also still suffering from optimization issues, bugs, and clunky game design.HOWEVER, these things do not hinder the game. In its state, is is solid, and plays very well. It feels like a true port-apocalyptic game, and it can definitely stand up to FALLOUT of STALKER. The story telling is wonderful, combat works and feels great, the atmosphere is just perfect, there is a bit of humor and secrets, many new and unfamiliar enemies, andTONS of customization. You can tactically set up your team and develop them as they level up, or you can build your own character from the ground up. It is just overall a well done project.It is still being developed, and new updates will be coming out for it. The UI will be fixed, it will be optimized, much more will be added...and in the end, this wonderful, promising stone will be polished to be one of the greatest cRPGs done.I know, the price tag is a little steep. But, if you are willing to buy it, and if you are willing to put up with a (currently) incomplete game, and if you are going to commit yourself to giving back to the devs, then it will be a worthwhile purchase. Additionally, this is a great game if you loved FALLOUT (esp. the first 2 and tactics) and Wasteland. Should you buy it? It depends, you might not want to, and you are certainly not being forced to. But if you do, know you are contributing to a constantly developing and promising sequel to a beloved game.

number of helpful: 28 of 57 people (49%) found this review helpful
content:
er 30, 2014
												I backed this one on Kickstarter, mainly because there was a goal set to fund aLinux version and there was only a few games for Linux then. The idea soundedgood – reviving an old classic, something like Fallout, multiple skills andways to solve quests, etc.After over two years of waiting it came. Playing it was tricky at first, due toa 'fog of war bug' on my integrated Intel GPU. It seems the problem was knownfrom early beta but all the developers could say was 'Intel GPUs are notsupported'. Oh… and I thought the game was supposed to be about story,playability and reviving classic. Nothing that should require a dedicatedgaming hardware. Current laptop should be enough. And is enough when theworkaround for the bug is known. But creators would not acknowledge that – buya gaming computer or don't bother us.OK, so with the workaround for the GPU bug the game was fun to play. There weresome game bugs, sometime ruining some quests, but nothing making the gameunplayable. I have played 60 hours… and got bored. 'Dozens of skills' reallymeans 'many different ways to open containers' all the same containers all thetime. It is a game of opening chests and safes. And digging holes.Yes, there is also the combat and combat skills. You need good hand gun orsniper skills not to kill your own people by mistake… But there are also highexplosives, which you need not skill to use at all. Always 100% hit chance,always 100% deterministic effects. How can it be? If not the price andavailability explosives would be the most effecting and safest method of fight.Then come the patches. Some bugs were fixed, often for parts I have alreadyplayed and do not wish to come back. Some features were implemented. And youknow what? Linux is not an equal platform now. Steam achievements wereintroduced two patches ago and they are 'Windows only'. Steam achievements!I could understand, that some advanced graphics or sound effects could betricky to do in Linux, or that handling some exotic controller could beimpossible. But the achievements?!It is not that Wasteland 2 is a bad game or that my contribution was waste ofmoney, but I am a bit disappointed and the game is not worth the 'user reviews'rating it has now.BTW I got bored by Fallout 2 too, so if you really love this type of games you could probably ignore my opinion.

content:
6, 2014
Early Access Review
								As a fan of the original Wasteland, I had very high hopes for this game. Overall, I enjoyed the tone, the story, the interface -- and don't have the same criticisms that many others have had.Unfortunately, I found navigating around the world much more cumbersome that I would have expected. I spent a long time wandering around levels looking for the right building, a doorway within a map or the tiny green highlight that showed the way to the next location. So, basically I found myself spinning around and mousing around in order to find the locations I was looking for.In one of the early locations, I found myself having to make many time consuming trips across half of a beaten map to return to the city -- no way to fast-travel straight to it. While I appreciate the return to some of the old school magic, some of the hand holding that newer games do does allow the players to focus on the more important aspects of the gaming experience.

Most frustrating is the "it's not linear play, but if you don't follow the line you're in for bugs, major bugs" dissapearing NPCs, arbitrary choices closed off and a jumbled mess inbetween, I tried hard to love this game, played a few dozens hours and yet am defeated by it's schlock.
