number of helpful: 11 of 23 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
er 4, 2014
												I funded this game at Kickstarter. I have mixed feelings about the result, as much as I try to like it:+ Size of game: Large world, much to explore, long play time. Lots of different, quite large (larger than in Fo1) cities/places. Often they have some politics with each other but usually most quests are done right at the location you are, and some quests are generic get-and-return or talk-to-and-return quests.-  Random encounters: Only fights and traders. Fights, if in the same area, take place on the same single map, same enemies. Traders can sometimes be found, nothing special. Better to skip everything if possible.o Only limited freedom. No real sandbox. No real open world. The game is mostly seen to be linear because you are always locked out of new places unless you progress in the story, a story which is very linear unless you take the "bad path" leading to an early-on bad ending. Along the storyline you just do whatever the Ranger HQ tells you to do, at least when it comes to the main quests. You got more freedom to do whatever you want when it comes to how you solve disputes and such, which is nice in turn.+ NPCs: A diverse selection of followers can be selected from to join your team throughout your journeys. Practically no interaction possible with them or between them. They do however often make comments, and rarely cause an event.-- Bugs: The game is definitely playable, but after Patch 4 there are still a lot of major bugs. Especially in the California half of the game. This game was released too early and clearly had obvious issues left at release, and the developers must have been aware of its state. Releasing a game as "finished" when it in reality is riddled with bugs, that's a BIG no-no for me!++ Bug-Fixing and Support: The feedback on bug report is fast and they still improve the game a LOT.o Story: While the story is in its essence very interesting, the dialogs are often not. The writing could be improved upon a lot. Aso Vargas is annoying.- Gameplay I: Quite weak attributes and skills system. It seems they did not think this design through well enough. Some skills were also dropped pretty late in development (sneaking). Negatives: Skills are not tied to attributes at all (brute force skill 10 works as well with strength 1  as it does with any other stringth. charisma and intelligence dont affect speech or dialogue options and dont affect the 3 speech skills (smartass,kissass,kickass) in any way, etc.)  Some skills should probably have been combined into one. Over all they tried to reinvent the wheel with their system and the wheel turned out to be cubic and clunky rather than more useful and efficient. Also: each player characters needs a lot of skill points to be spent on a weapon type to hit well wit hit but then a grenade or rocket launcher has 100% accuracy on any character by default. There are also two skills written as "???" without description in the character window, and that still after 4 patches.-- You want to open a box or safe or pick up some poo? Well, bad luck for you: Boxes, safes, doors,  poop; everything explodes in your face when touched. And the real bummer: disarming bombs, safecracking and lockpicking is extremely time-consuming even if skilled at maximum possible levels. Try a whole mine field... Medic and surgery also takes forever. It often feels like wasting my time waiting for bars to fill up when playing. It felt like this took a large part of my playtime. Even unlocking a door with a key (!!) takes about 5 seconds. Pure nuisance. At some point I started to just triggers bombs, mines and traps and eat the damage instead of defusing them because even if skilled to the max, it still takes too long to defuse everything in the game. What is also very time consuming is the movement inside locations. If entering rooms, all characters will be teleported, so you can't even split up your team leaving one character at an area's exit to shortcut running back all the way.o Gameplay II: The fights are not overly tactical. Formations are not supported. You often have to manually position each character 1 by 1 without being able to utilise the actual grid used in fights, meaning the characters will be moved unpredictably a short distance when a fight starts. Taking cover is practically useless, yjust shooting the enemy is often better than wasting action points running around taking cover. Fights are overall fun though. Just don't expect a Jagged Alliance here. ++ Gameplay III: Lots of weapons and weapon types available in this game and weaponsmithing is fun.o Dialogs: while you get different options in dialogs, most are just serving you some general info, repeating almost the same batches of text. When it comes down to actual choice, I often felt a bit limited despite having skilled all 3 speech skills to the necessary levels to have all options present. The skills are pretty useless because you only get to use each of them maybe 5 times in the entire game, and often they do not even lead to better results but to WORSE results which really sucks after having invested valuable points...++ Lots of quests and lots of things to do in this world. Often you have choices to solve quests differently, but ...-  ...the quests do however still converge to an unwanted ending in a lot of cases no matter how you approach it. Sometimes places and people cannot be saved against all logic.-- Graphics: The art direction feels uninspired / heartless and forgettable. Generally too many saturated vivid yellow/green/brown colours, subpar shading (where is the specular lighting?), terrible AA (some bad version of FXAA was chosen whyever), sometimes random blobs of colours. It overall looks very "meh" to me, they could have done a lot better. The low-poly modeling is generally fine for third person, but unfortunately they made mistake of letting the character portraits (optionally) be zoomed-in screenshots of the character. These captures look quite awful and you would normally not even see your character that close-up so why enforce making this flaw apparent?- Character portraits:  For your own characters, instead of the 3D snapshots, 2D portraits can be chosen. But the selection is small and some can be encountered in the game again on NPCs. However, you can add custom portraits to the game if you want. A lot of NPCs in the game unfortunately share the exact same portraits. Often the portraits are contrary to the 3D model. The character portraits repeat even on important characters creating great confusion in anyone who would try for recognise them by looking at the portrait. The descriptions given in the text can often conflict the 3D model's looks which also is contrary to the 2D portrait. Three impressions which do not go along with each other. This killed the immersion for me at times.- Many quests have to be solved in an unintuitive and sometimes unsatisfactory way (your actions may have an effect contrary to your goal), some relevant spots inside areas are weirdly hidden (Alexey in Highpool) which took me a lot of time to find in order to solve quests. Also I often encountered situations that weren't solvable (with the outcome I wanted) with logic and speech skills (Railroad Nomads conflict). Some quests were also bugged, but this was solved now. Personally I preferred the quest-solving in Planescape or Fallout. It seemed more straight-forward there, meaning that my actions lead to the results that I wanted to achieve.All in all I feel like this game didn't get as much love from the developers as it should have and also was released prematurely with unfinished design aspects all over the place. Some issues i mentioned might be resolved in future patches but most won't because they would require redesigning big parts of the entire game. Overall it was okay fun to play, but the buggy release make me give thumbs down.

												The graphics are incredibly bland, by which I mean that they were made by people that just don't have any sense of style whatsoever. There are games old like gameing itself like Fallout tactics or Baldurs gate that have more personality like Wasteland 2.The music and the sound design are as bland as the graphics are. Not really worth this line of virtual text.Another chapter are the dialogs or should I rather say monologs with intersections. You can't really select any answers. Well you can but only very very rarely. Mostly, the "dialogs" are all about utterly boring "Tell me about this one thing", "Tell me about 2nd thing"..."Tell me about that 20th thing. Really the dialogs even though nicely writen are total ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.But of all else what I found the most boring is the combat system. Today when you got really interesting combat situations with elemental interactions like in Divinity: Original sin. But hell! Even old games like Baldurs gate got interesting AOF weapons and buffs and summons and what not. In W2 you got guns. Then you get slightly better guns. Snipers are guns with higher effective range but still guns. And then you got sticks. And thats about all of it. Oh yeah and you get to cover and everything happens in something I would call very bland arenas. Thats all I was able to see of the combat before I died of boredom.Remember me.

content:
17, 2016
												1. Live action actor playing your commander in a cutscene has a beard.2. In-game portrait of your commander has a beard.3. Examining your commander reads: "A stiff, bearded older man... walks with a cane... wears a pearl-handed revolver..."Well... his actual in-game model is a 30 years old clean-shaven generic male dude with a generic DesertEagle-sized handgun and it seems that he misplaced his cane somewhere. Bummer.This pretty much sums up the whole game, because everything it offers to the player works exactly like that: roleplaying, combat, economy model, loot system, all of it. It's not an awful game per se, more so in it's Director's Cut version, but if it's the apotheosis of mr. Fargo's publisher-free talent, then it's a very good retirement milestone. It could pass as a solid 15$ mobile platform game, maybe even 30$ in it's DirCut state, but it is too weak and barebone, if not primitive, for a 60$ PC CRPG title.

content:
er 14, 2014
												An excellent return to the formula of the original isometric CRPGs of the past, Wasteland 2 is a worthy successor to its fargone original. Mostly. There are a few moments of derp-dome come again with characters that simply don't fit in the game, but overall it has a good story and excellent gameplay. Bugs do occur, but the developers have released fixes promptly enough to satisfy my needs. Overall, I enjoyed the playthrough and the challenge of its "Supereme Jerk" difficulty.  While there are issues with the balance of the game (namely, assault rifle weapons are god-like, while pistols are mostly useless) and the game does use a simplistic toughening/weakening of the enemies and player respectively for its 'difficulty' scaling, it was certainly a well executed, if not perfect, recall to the early years of RPGs.

content:
er 12, 2014
												I really wanted to like this game. I liked games like Fallout 1/2 and Fallout Tactics.  So the squad-based turn-based RPG is a category I like.  I also wanted to like this game to support indie designers, so against my better judgement I purchased the game shortly after release and at full price.  However, the flaws in this game are vary glaring and difficult to ignore.1) If you haven't played Wasteland 1, this game is hard to follow.  It is more like a continuation of the story than a sequel set in the same world. Many of the clues dropped require some knowledge of the events in Wasteland 1.2) The gameplay mechanics are just a mess.  The armor system is borked to the point of being pointless.  While the initiative system is interesting, there is no prevision for a character to delay his turn.  The effect of which is to create a log jam if a slower character is blocking a door.  Fortunately most of the combat is in wide open area -- probably for this very reason.3)  Looting is similarly botched where crappy useless loot is stored in containers that require a number of difficult checks to open.  The difficult of skill checks is uneven through out the game as well.I do like the three dimensional maps and the ability to rotate them (however they definitely do not rotate smoothly). The attitude and feel of the game seem to be done well.  The character models and animations however do not match the environment very well.  The in game character appearance does not change based upon the armor that is equipped. Clothing choices seem to be poorly matched to gender (I guess cross-dressing is a thing in the wasteland).Overall, I doubt many people will get past part one in the game much less get into part 2 (Las Angels) where the writing and encounters start to fall apart.This game will probably have to be saved by mods, which there does seem to be a few on the horizon to fix the mechanics.  However, I don't see the skill system being reworked with mods, which has a few issues as well -- mainly too many skills.  There are 29 skills in the game and at least 6 of them could simply be removed/combined with existing skills.Overall, Fallout Tactics was a better game.  If you are really liking this type of game, wait for a steam sale.

content:
er 14, 2013
Early Access Review
								after 5 hours played during my first livestream of the game I am absolutely hooked. It captures the perfect feeling of the original wasteland mixed with what the wasteland dev's ended up creating as Fallout 1 and Fallout 2; - along with elements added from XCom (tile) the AP points are used in a mixture of Fallout and more modern style; The ability to import photos of people you know as characters is a huge "Well; I better not let THEM die" - and I adore that it does not hold your hand.. at all. Things have been implemented to make it easier to understand for the newcomer; but if you are in a situation and your party does not have the abilities despite multiple methods; you are F'd. - It's hardcore. Its Wasteland. It's Fallout. It's... wasteland 2.I've waited for this for ages; It feels like how I've waited for Fallout 3 back when it was a rumor, then in development by various companies prior to actually being "fallout 3" with a teaser 3-4 years before FO3's release.... Wasteland 2... is an A+ title by inExile - Who are currently also working on the sequel to PLANESCAPE TORMENT (how can we lose with these guys? -They promised on everything they said they would thus far - "One Size Does Not Fit All: Don't feel like finding the key for a door? Why not try a Rocket Launcher! Basically the same thing... right? Enhanced Classic RPG Game Play: Classic RPG game play ideas updated with modern design philosophies. Decision Making... with Consequences: With both short and long term reactivity to the players choices, every decision matters in the outcome of the story. Hugh & Customizable: Dozens of hours of game. Hundreds of characters. Thousands of variations on your Rangers' appearance. Over 150 weapons. Dozens of skills. Even the UI can be customized."- All true and very exciting for the old schooler to the new schooler.A+

content:
ber 23, 2014
												I'm playing on Normal difficulty and have about 6 hours in. The game starts out really promising, but then throws a bunch of missions at you at one time. When you get to the second big mission of the game, the enemies are extremely powerful and your band of mercenaries will not stand a chance. GOOD Things: The tactical combat is nice. There are a variety of weapons and it is critical to manage your squad's inventory.Resource Scarcity makes gameplay feel exciting and changes how you approach conflict. The world seems interesting and you won't feel bored reading through all the text. BAD Things: This game is difficult. This comes from someone who loves Dark Souls. Whereas another game could be difficult and fair, this one does not seem fair in the least. Oh, your squad member can shoot once per turn? Awesome. Here is a pack of enemies that can empty their magazines into you. Or, here are some people carrying machetes who can cross the whole of the wasteland and smack you in the face in the same turn you may get a chance to unjam your weapon.Seriously, this is infuriating. Let me shoot this pistol with a 3 percent chance to jam. 3 percent is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. You can set your watch to that thing jamming. No kidding, the game is incredibly unfair. I am a huge fan of the old school fallout games as well. I've played Ghosts and Goblins on the NES. I've seen unfair games, and this is such. WHO will enjoy this?Sadists. Masochists. People who love playing CIV on unfair difficulties. People who like pulling triggers and having their guns jam while criminals beat you in the face with spiked 2 by fours.

number of helpful: 7 of 15 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
r 16, 2014
												I'm mainly writing this for my friends because I recommended this game to them before I spent enough time with it. I had really high expectations for this game but I really can't recommend it.  I wanted to love this game, I mean really LOVE it like I loved Fallout 2 or Jagged Alliance 2 or Morrowind. And I tried so hard to overlook the flaws I saw because damn it, I was waiting for this game over 20 years and I wasn't going to let some nittpicky BS stop me. But unfortunately all the problems I kept encountering just kept building up on each other until I pretty much gave up. Some of these problems are as follows: The combat is shallow and lacks any sort of tactical feel despite being turn based; You rarely have a need to move your characters and most battles can be won by standing still and spaming attack or maybe toss a grenade. You can crouch or use a headshot but there's no real advantage that I notice to even bother with these moves.  The missions all seem half finished; apparently it's "hand holding" to ask for any sort of clue as to what you need to do or even why you need to do it. And all of the quests have multiple ways to "complete" them but if you're looking for multiple ways to complete them in a manner that the devs wanted you to in order to "win" the game then you'll need to rely on online guides because those solutions require an extremely linear path to be followed. And by "win" the game I mean by having the optimal completion where everyone you encounter was happy with what you did. Those endings are there but as I said they're not very easy to figure out. "Conversations" with NPC's are nothing more than triggering the next bit of dialog by clicking on the keyword; there's no branching at all and you're really not interacting with NPC's in any meaningful way.  Character creation is also an oddity since it breaks the norm in most RPG's by having skills act completely independant of  attributes; ie charisma has no effect on your characters conversation skills or barter. And lastly there are some really bad bugs that have caused me to lose a lot of game play time; there's 3 quick save slots for a reason and you should be sure to use them.There's a lot to like here but I'm not going to sit here with a "pros and cons" list because I figure a lot of people are like me: if I'm thinking about buying a game I'm pretty much sold on it already and what I need to know is the bad stuff. Now none of the stuff I said above is so much that it's caused me to hate the game but it is enough to make me wish I had held off and waited for more reviews instead of buying it day one. $14.99-$19.99 is probably a good price point for this game but $40 is too much for what you get.

												Having never played Fallout 1 or 2 (and indeed spent only 7 hours on this game), I haven't seen much nuclear wasteland from a turn based isometric perspective. Hence, for me this game evokes memories of Baldur's Gate. The first one, not the higher praised sequel. And like going back to BG1 after playing the sequel, this game feels like a throwback. The writing and voice acting is good, but the combat is lackluster and picking the right skills is hit-and-miss unless you watch a Let's Play on Youtube first. It's recommended you atleast skim through a few video's before playing the game.Also like BG1, the first ten hours didn't win me over and I gave up. The game probably gets good later on, but even during the free weekend, I wasn't invested enough to keep going.Verdict: Wait for a sale.

But unfortunately all the problems I kept encountering just kept building up on each other until I pretty much gave up. Some of these problems are as follows: The combat is shallow and lacks any sort of tactical feel despite being turn based; You rarely have a need to move your characters and most battles can be won by standing still and spaming attack or maybe toss a grenade. You can crouch or use a headshot but there's no real advantage that I notice to even bother with these moves.  The missions all seem half finished; apparently it's "hand holding" to ask for any sort of clue as to what you need to do or even why you need to do it. And all of the quests have multiple ways to "complete" them but if you're looking for multiple ways to complete them in a manner that the devs wanted you to in order to "win" the game then you'll need to rely on online guides because those solutions require an extremely linear path to be followed. And by "win" the game I mean by having the optimal completion where everyone you encounter was happy with what you did. Those endings are there but as I said they're not very easy to figure out. "Conversations" with NPC's are nothing more than triggering the next bit of dialog by clicking on the keyword; there's no branching at all and you're really not interacting with NPC's in any meaningful way.  Character creation is also an oddity since it breaks the norm in most RPG's by having skills act completely independant of  attributes; ie charisma has no effect on your characters conversation skills or barter. And lastly there are some really bad bugs that have caused me to lose a lot of game play time; there's 3 quick save slots for a reason and you should be sure to use them.There's a lot to like here but I'm not going to sit here with a "pros and cons" list because I figure a lot of people are like me: if I'm thinking about buying a game I'm pretty much sold on it already and what I need to know is the bad stuff. Now none of the stuff I said above is so much that it's caused me to hate the game but it is enough to make me wish I had held off and waited for more reviews instead of buying it day one. $14.99-$19.99 is probably a good price point for this game but $40 is too much for what you get.

content:
ber 28, 2014
												Bryan Fargo presents: Bryan Fargo's Wasteland 2 eschews almost every major game design improvement of the last thirty years for the cause of nostalgia. Combat is simplistic and enemy difficulty scales purely by turning them into bullet sponges, and any 'set piece' fights can be negated by having one party member trigger combat and then run back, drawing snipers from towers and cover to chase them down on foot. Attributes are completely disconnected from skills simply because that's how it was done 20 years ago; as a result, two of your *seven* attributes are dumpstats and may as well not exist (Luck and Charisma), and since Coordination is a meaningless concept when divorced from fine manipulation skills, it may as well have been folded into Speed. The modified ASSI system would be in fact, far less so than the current CLASSIC set-up.However, if you do want to choose Charisma on a character, do not level any social skills with them whatsoever! Charisma's only real benefit is a set boost to all XP gained that scales with how high the stat is, and all dialogue skills grant experience to the entire party when used. Active skills such as the two redundant Lockpicking skills, Demolitions, Mechanical Repair and Computer Science, et al, only grant experience to the user. As a result, your Charismatic character should be highly Intelligent in order to gather as many active skills to benefit from the experience stat. As a result, none of your other three characters really need high Int; 4 or 6 should suffice. Your ideal party should be a beautiful Adonic IT guy who can't tie his own shoes and can calculate pi to the first 200 decimals without paper, and three semi-♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ punch monkeys who kill or sweet-talk everything between them and victory.The game is riddled with minor bugs, which would be expected of a newly released game, except every higher-tier Kickstarter backer got the questionable reward of becoming QA-tester for a day the majority of the development process. Unless you got a copy of the game for participating in the Kickstarters of other Interplay alumni, I guess. Currently, keeping any allied non-party NPC alive is terrifyingly difficult as they're often equipped with pistols, and since you can't control them, gleefully run into the firing arcs of any Ranger they can see to maximize their self-harm. But they will duel you to the death if you accidentally clip them, which results in the player having to utilize amazingly unorthodox tactics. Prepare to think outside the box!I've played through the original Wasteland multiple times, as well as Fountain of Dreams, Wasteland's toilet baby. It's not that I hate this game, or even dislike it; in fact, it's exactly what I expected when I put $60+ into the Kickstarter. I've privately bemoaned streamlining game mechanics in favor of overall experience, and it's almost cathartic to have the inevitable conclusion of that flawed ideal thrown in my face. I'm not a casual, but there have been a lot of general QOL improvements to RPG and strategy gameplay mechanics that an entire development team had to put horse blinders on to avoid.

content:
ber 28, 2014
												I backed this game because I am a huge fan of Fallout 1, but after a few hours I can't be bothered to play it. Everything seems unfinished and generally rough around the edges. The engine is garbage and the graphics are ugly even at maximum setting. And I'm not talking low-definition ugly - the whole look of the game is just a big mess. It's all pasted together and no details seem to stand out. The UI is abhorrent with a ton of wasted space, which is not acceptable in 2014.  Navigating around the place is a pain because there aren't any proper map markers like in Baldur's Gate, for example. In fact, various caves and other area transitions are so poorly marked that they are hard to click. The camera is beyond terrible and adds to the unfinished feel of the game. On one map there was a tall tower that got in the way of the camera while I was in combat and I spend an ungodly amount of time trying to see around it. This is simply not acceptable in modern games. And don't get me started about combat, such utter rubbish! The guns feel like little slingshots and at times it seems more tactically sound to just come at the enemy bare handed. The combat is so boring and broken I don't even have the space to get into it. This is just one of those games that you want so much to like but the more you play it the more everything bothers you until you just decide enough is enough, close it and then uninstall it. I really don't know what the developers were doing but no one is going to convince me that this pile of garbage is the result of over 3 million US dollars and countless unexplained delays by the developer. My department just finished coordinating a 1.5 million international research project and if we pulled things like inXile we would in all probability be sued into utter oblivion.

content:
3, 2015
												Short review- the more you play this, the less you'll like it. It is long, very repetitive, and boring. I don't just want my money back, I want my time back.I'm a big fan of Fallout 1 & 2 and similar games. When I first started playing Wasteland 2, I enjoyed it. It had a similar feel. Unfortunately, as the game progressed, it just aggravated me. I found myself spending all my time performing useless actions rather than actually playing a game. There are crates/boxes strewn about everywhere, and nearly every single one is locked/trapped, so you spend a lot of time using skills to open them (which takes several seconds each attempt), having to reload multiple times because the difficulty of each lock/trap seems to be random. They pretty much never have anything useful, so you've just wasted your time. Also, you have to run across the same areas you've already cleared, just to exit the map. Then run BACK across just to turn in a minor quest.The areas are sprawling, but VERY repetitive. There's relatively little NPC interaction, and most of those are the same, too. I don't know how many times I've gone to a town where they complain about a disease, had to find the local doctor who magically can cure it, but he needs you to go get a specific item to save the day. It creates the illusion of a sandbox as you explore the open world, but most places won't appear on the map until you hit that point in the storyline, no matter how many times you walk over it.Even the fights got boring quickly. Weapon variety seemed decent at first, but ultimately felt pointless. And the "friendly fire" is ridiculous. I don't mind friendly fire, but it seems almost guaranteed to hit your friend if he's between you and the opponent, even if it doesn't make sense (like if the friend is in a crouched position right in front of the firer, who is standing, and you're firing at someone at a higher elevation).I got to a point where I thought the game was almost over, and I was excited. Then I discovered I was only about halfway through and got depressed. I considered quitting the game right then, but hoped it would get better in the second half. I should've stopped playing.
